HEADLINE: Independent Plants a Factor In the Latest Energy Crisis 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
N.R.G. Energy Inc. was not even a stand-alone company a year ago, but it has big plans for the next few years: building enough power-generation plants to supply the equivalent of 35 million homes. 
 With power supplies tight across much of the United States and Wall Street opening its pocketbook to energy concerns, companies like N.R.G., based in Minneapolis, are reshaping the power-generation industry. 
 Nearly every new power plant in the United States is being built not by an old-fashioned state-regulated utility, but by largely unregulated operations like N.R.G. The independent companies now account for more than 20 percent of domestic electricity generation, a number that is rising quickly as demand for power continues to grow.
The industry's growing market power is starkly evident in the California power crisis, where Gov. Gray Davis is trying to press the independent generators to keep their electricity flowing -- but at cheaper prices -- and to forestall bankruptcy filings by the state's two largest utilities. Those utilities, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric, are struggling to pay for electricity they have already bought from the generators, and Mr. Davis said last week that four of the power producers had threatened to force the utilities into bankruptcy. 
California's four-year-old deregulation law has allowed the power producers to grab a larger share of generation capacity than in most states. Indeed, the utilities were under orders to sell their power plants, although California regulators recently reversed course. But the trend is the same across the nation, as electricity supplies are increasingly controlled by companies that do not operate under the oversight of state regulators. 
These companies build power plants only where it is most profitable -- and not necessarily where they are most needed. And unlike the old days of regulation, state governments cannot mandate the development of excess generating capacity for independent producers, or the use of a varied mix of energy sources, instead relying on the marketplace to anticipate power needs and fuel supplies. 
"Market forces were supposed to discipline the market better than what regulators could do," said Ken Rose, a senior economist at the National Regulatory Research Institute at Ohio State University. "But if market forces are weak, or somebody has market power, there's a tremendous ability of suppliers to control the price, or at least influence it, and not a lot of recourse for the state, because power plants are now out of their jurisdiction."
Instead, he said, it falls to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to fix a broken market -- the commission has engaged in a running battle with California officials who feel it has not done enough to resolve the energy crisis.
Independent generators and other backers of deregulation -- President Bush among them -- say that market forces, allowed to operate freely, will ensure an adequate supply of power. Along with many analysts, they attribute California's problems mostly to a badly designed deregulation law -- unique to the nation's biggest state -- that left the utilities victims of a marketplace that invited price spikes and volatility.
The pro-deregulation forces say, too, that none of the many investigations into suspected market manipulation during the crisis have conclusively fingered the generators, for all of Governor Davis's castigating them as "profiteers."
But even if the mess in California is not repeated elsewhere, concerns remain that shifting so much generation into the hands of unregulated companies could expose other parts of the country to significant market disruptions. While about half the states have passed retail deregulation laws -- many of which will not become effective for several years -- there is an active wholesale market for electricity across the nation, and unregulated power generators have broken ground for new plants in many states.
Before the federal government began speeding up the deregulation of power production in the 1990's, planning for new plants was overseen by state public utility commissioners, who conducted hearings with testimony from industry and consumer groups. State regulators emphasized the need for excess generation capacity, guaranteeing utilities a predictable rate of profit, and they guided utilities to buy or generate power from varied fuels. Consequently, while coal is the largest source of generating fuel, natural gas, nuclear and hydro power together account for nearly as much.
In the new world of deregulation, generators are free to build whatever types of plant they want, and more than 90 percent of the plants that are currently planned will run on natural gas. Gas-fired plants are relatively inexpensive to build, cleaner burning than coal-fired operations, and -- at least until the run-up in natural gas prices began last year -- cheaper to operate. 
But consumer groups and some big industrial power users worry that the generators are placing too many eggs in a volatile basket. Annual natural gas use by electric power generators could triple over the next 20 years, to more than 11 trillion cubic feet, according to the Department of Energy. That would consume about 60 percent of the current annual gas production in the United States -- output that also is used for industrial processes and home heating and cooking.
Even if there is enough natural gas, some in the industry question whether the nation will have the pipeline and storage capacity to get it where it needs to go. Tight supplies of natural gas have played a big role in California's problems -- a factor magnified after a pipeline explosion last August curtailed the flow of gas for months. Gas prices in California recently soared as high as $60 per million British thermal units -- six times the price elsewhere -- partly because of transportation constraints.
"The bigger issue is the infrastructure, the ability to transfer and store gas," said Craig Mataczynski, president of N.R.G.'s North American operations. 
The company, which was partly spun off last year from Xcel Energy Inc., plans to add about 35,000 megawatts of generating capacity to its current 15,000 megawatts in the next five years, mostly in the United States. But in contrast to competitors, about one-third of the N.R.G. plants will be coal fired, with the others able to switch between natural gas and oil, Mr. Mataczynski said. 
While the California crisis has created a reaction of sorts against the generators -- companies like Dynegy and Reliant Energy, both of Houston, and Duke Energy of Charlotte, N.C. -- it is unlikely to greatly curtail their expansion. President Bush, whose Texas financial backers include companies profiting from the situation in California, has made it plain he is unlikely to impose caps on the price of wholesale power or other restraints that generators oppose. Yesterday, Mr. Bush's top economic advisers said that the federal government should let California solve its own power problem.
Instead, Mr. Bush has proposed several initiatives to spur the electric power industry: opening protected land in the West to drilling for natural gas, investing in cleaner-burning coal-fired plants, and easing regulatory burdens on pipeline and power plant operators. 
At the state level, there are signs of retreat from deregulation. Of the two dozen states that still work on the old model of monopoly utilities with regulated rates and guaranteed profits, at least four have indicated they may rethink any moves toward open energy markets. 
But at the wholesale level, deregulation is flourishing. Industry officials estimate that close to 3 billion megawatt-hours of electricity -- 1 megawatt-hour is enough to power 1,000 average homes for an hour -- changed hands on the wholesale power market last year, with giant traders, including Enron, taking a tiny piece of each transaction. Yesterday, Enron, based in Houston, reported that operating profits in its wholesale energy business tripled in the fourth quarter, to $777 million.
Independent generators, meanwhile, are grabbing a fast-growing share of the power market. During the first nine months of last year, nonutility producers generated 20.3 percent of the electricity consumed in the United States, compared with 10.6 percent in 1997, according to the Department of Energy. And that percentage will keep growing, as utilities continue to sell power plants to unregulated companies and independent power producers build more and more plants.
Under old-fashioned state regulation, utilities were given financial incentives -- or otherwise were forced -- to maintain surplus capacity, just in case it was needed. But deregulation has greatly reduced that tendency, leaving most power producers with smaller reserves, said Philip K. Verleger Jr., a California energy economist.
This is part of the trend to break up vertically integrated industries and operate with leaner inventories, Mr. Verleger said. "Electric utilities used to be required to hold 15 percent reserve capacity, but this inventory has been wiped out," he said. "No one has the responsibility to hold extra capacity." It is when peaks in demand sap scarce supply that prices soar in deregulated power markets.
Rattled by the mess in California, consumer advocates have other concerns, such as how the nation's electric transmission grid will be maintained and improved once the federal government completes turning control of the grid over to independent regional authorities. They also worry about whether the marketplace will move quickly enough to avert shortages, or whether other states will, like California, be caught short.
"The concern we have is whether, while we wait for those market forces to work, consumers either suffer through periods of high prices or shortages of electricity," said Janee Briesemeister, a utility analyst for Consumers Union in Austin, Tex. 
Regulated utilities, she said, "had a responsibility to ensure that there was enough power to meet the demand."
"But when you throw that open to the market," she added, "the market doesn't respond to predictions about how much power is needed. It responds to concerns about how much they can earn."
Power generators say they are responding vigorously to the nation's power needs -- and not just in California, where 9 plants are under construction and 22 more are in the regulatory pipeline. 
Nationwide, nonutility generators have announced plans for more than 250,000 megawatts of new capacity, though estimates in the industry are that in the next decade closer to half that amount will be built -- still a huge addition to today's total of more than 700,000 megawatts.
But executives at these companies warn that efforts to cap wholesale electricity prices or otherwise restrain them will curtail construction, hurting consumers in the long run. Such talk, Mr. Mataczynski of N.R.G. said, "certainly prevents positive solutions from being proposed."

HEADLINE: No Charges After Inquiry Of Pataki Ally 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Manhattan district attorney yesterday closed a long-running investigation into whether Charles A. Gargano, the state's top economic development official, had done favors for political contributors and said that he would file no charges against Mr. Gargano.
 District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau had never formally announced the inquiry of Mr. Gargano, who oversaw billions of dollars in economic development deals as chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. But its existence was widely known and hung like a dark cloud over Mr. Gargano for the last two years. 
 Although Mr. Gargano was never charged with anything, the investigation appeared to cost him a top post in George W. Bush's presidential campaign, just as he was packing the photographs on the walls of his office on Third Avenue in preparation for that job.
The inquiry began with an examination of spending by one part of Mr. Gargano's agency, and later broadened to focus on Mr. Gargano's role in nearly every aspect of its work.
Mr. Gargano, a former construction industry executive who had risen to prominence in Republican circles because of his prowess as a fund-raiser, had consistently maintained that the investigation would not turn up any wrongdoing.
Yesterday, the district attorney's office released a terse statement saying, "No criminal charges will be filed in connection with the two-year investigation."
Prosecutors would not elaborate on their decision to end the inquiry.
"Chairman Gargano is gratified by District Attorney Morgenthau's decision," said Maura Gallucci, his spokeswoman. "He has always been confident that there was no basis for any action to be taken."
With the investigation now behind him, Mr. Gargano seems poised to return to the prominence he once enjoyed as a close aide to Mr. Pataki and a leading Republican fund-raiser. It was Mr. Gargano who led the effort to raise more than $14 million to finance Governor Pataki's victory over Mario M. Cuomo.
"Charlie Gargano has been the premier economic development director in America, helping Governor Pataki create more private sector jobs than at any time in the history of this state," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Mr. Pataki. "No one's better at it."
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Gargano were together yesterday in Niagara Falls, where they announced a plan to bring the Times Square development model to that city's beleaguered downtown.
The district's attorney's investigation of Mr. Gargano began in 1999 as an inquiry into whether agency officials misspent funds from annual receptions to honor Italian-Americans. It initially revolved around Paolo Palumbo, an old friend of Mr. Gargano's, whom he had appointed to be deputy commissioner for international business. A former baker and professor of Italian literature at Fordham University, Mr. Palumbo arranged the Italian affairs and sometimes wrote Mr. Gargano's speeches.
Mr. Palumbo subsequently resigned from his $91,877-a-year state job in July, 1999, and agreed to plead guilty to a bribery charge. At the same time, Mr. Palumbo was also working with investigators.
Mr. Gargano told friends at the time that he felt that his old friend had betrayed his trust.
But within months, the inquiry had grown into a wide-ranging exploration of Mr. Gargano's role in a variety of economic development projects in Westchester, his involvement in the sale of state land to Republican contributors and the construction of his new home in the Hamptons. Investigators interviewed a dozen current and former staff members of the state agency and deluged the Empire State Development Corporation with subpoenas demanding cartons of documents, memos and e-mail messages.
While Mr. Gargano never went to work for the Bush campaign, he has remained head of the state development agency during the inquiry, and in recent months, he has resumed his high-profile role in state affairs.

PERSON: FELIX G. ROHATYN 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Ex-Ambassador Samples the Simple Life

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
FELIX G. ROHATYN professes not to miss any of the accouterments of an ambassador, not the palatial residence in Paris, not the servants and staff, and most of all, not the security detail. 
 "We went to the movies very little in Paris because of our security and because we always went to the head of the line," Mr. Rohatyn said. Now, he and his wife, Elizabeth, are back to waiting in line for movies and enjoying a simpler life -- simple for a wealthy financier who just spent four years as United States ambassador to France. 
 Mr. Rohatyn never was too comfortable with the trappings of power he had in Paris, he said, sitting in a modest office in his Fifth Avenue apartment. "I'm not sure it's a great idea to live like a colonial governor when you're representing the United States."
He and his wife share their apartment with a pair of Labrador retrievers, Noodles and Nobu, the latter named for one of their favorite restaurants in Manhattan. A plastic scoop near the elevator door reminds visitors that even the rich and famous have to clean up after their pets. (Of course, the apartment does overlook Central Park.)
"Coming back here and coming back to a lifestyle that is more basic is, in a way, kind of a liberating thing," he said, appearing casual in faded blue jeans and a pullover sweater. "I'm beginning to try to see what kind of a life I want to lead."
As an ambassador, he said, "there was a complete loss of privacy and a loss, although I battled it every day, of the control of my calendar."
For the first time in decades, Mr. Rohatyn, 72, is representing only himself. He does not intend to return to Wall Street by rejoining the Lazard investment bank, whose New York operations he managed before President Clinton chose him for an ambassadorship.
Instead, he is considering forming a small firm with a few associates to advise corporations on finance and strategy. He plans to serve as a director of the Comcast Corporation and a few other companies, and to work on some pet projects, including setting up a company to develop cancer-fighting drugs. In between, he will write for the Council on Foreign Relations and The New York Review of Books and will try to get his life story down on paper. 
He says writing his memoirs "is a difficult thing to do." Friends have advised him to start each day by filling three or four pages. He is obviously daunted by the challenge of recounting all he has done and seen in 40 years as an adviser to corporate executives, and as chairman of New York's Municipal Assistance Corporation during the city's financial crisis in the 1970's.
Mr. Rohatyn said his original entry into the world of finance was serendipitous. In 1949, after studying physics at Middlebury College in Vermont, he needed a summer job. He landed one at Lazard, where his duties included adding up the value of rich, elderly ladies' accounts. After serving in the Army during the Korean War, he returned to Lazard and stayed for four decades.
"I entered this business because I wasn't good enough to be a physicist," he recalled.
To write a "good book about what I have seen in my life" is one of his few unfulfilled ambitions, he said. 
MR. ROHATYN is secretive about the rest of his plans. He would not say which other corporate boards he planned to join, nor would he divulge the identity of the scientists involved in the drug-development venture.
He is happy to talk about his hope that he will have time to assist Teaching Matters, a nonprofit organization his wife founded to train New York public school teachers. The Rohatyns' charitable foundation provides funding for Teaching Matters. 
Mr. Rohatyn is less sanguine about what he sees as a troubling trend on Wall Street, the triumph of analysts who are willing to broadcast overly positive views on companies' stocks in hopes of landing financing business for their firms. From a distance, he said, he was appalled by the frenzied rush to market with the stocks of unprofitable dot-com companies.
After seeing that bubble inflate and burst, he said, "I kind of thought that maybe it was time for me to step aside. I have no interest at this stage of my life of looking for clients or chasing after business."
He did not rule out the possibility that he might serve as a sort of freelance adviser to corporate leaders. "I do believe there will always be a need for independent advice by serious people," he said. 
So when he met with President Clinton recently, he offered some: Run for mayor of New York. What better role for Mr. Clinton, he said, than chief executive of "the capital of the world."
Mr. Rohatyn said that Mr. Clinton laughed off the suggestion, saying it was too soon for him to think about his next move. But Mr. Rohatyn was not joking. Cities are on the rise, he said, gaining power and influence as hubs of global commerce. 
"If you take the position that New York is a global community, then what you need is somebody who is a global leader. It seems to be that Bill Clinton is a perfectly obvious choice," he said.
But, the consummate New Yorker was asked, would New Yorkers ever accept Bill Clinton of Hope, Ark., as one of their own? Oh, sure, Mr. Rohatyn said. "I think that, at heart, Bill Clinton is a New Yorker."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Felix G. Rohatyn says writing a memoir is one of his ambitions. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; 
SIGN OF GERMAN SLOWDOWN

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Germany's Ifo business index fell for the seventh consecutive month in December, an indication that the economy, the biggest in Europe, was set to continue losing steam as concern remains about the global impact of the slowdown in the United States. 
The monthly index of business confidence from Ifo, Germany's biggest economic research institute, fell to 96.5 from 97.0 in November, broadly in line with the consensus forecast. Ifo said the data showed the slowdown in Germany was now more broadly based and would continue for some time. The index reached its lowest level since a reading of 96.0 in October 1999, after steadily slipping from a nine-year high of 102.0 in May.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Profit Warning From Dell Starts Week on Down Note

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday after Dell Computer warned that its profit would be hurt by a global economic slowdown, beginning a heavy week for corporate earnings on a dour note.
 Strength in the stocks of retailers and biotechnology companies helped cushion the broader market's slide. 
 "This is the blockbuster week, where the vast majority of earnings will come out, so people are pausing and are willing to take some profits" from the recent rally, said Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Company. 
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 12.47 points, or 0.5 percent, to 2,757.91. It was weighed down by weakness in computer and software companies after Dell blamed a slower economy and sluggish computer demand for its poor earnings outlook.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 9.35 points, at 10,578.24, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.36 point, to 1,342.90.
The Dow was hampered by American Express, which fell $3.63, to $45. Although it posted a 12 percent jump in earnings, it warned that earnings growth this year would be at the low end of its current target because of weak financial markets and a slowing economy.
Dell, whose shares fell as low as $23.63, finished off just 13 cents, at $25.50. But it did nudge its rivals lower on worries that the softening global economy would also harm their profits.
I.B.M. lost $2.69, to $108.56, and Hewlett-Packard skidded $1.25, to $34.50. Compaq Computer dropped 68 cents, to $19.82; Gateway declined $2.24, to $21.45, and Apple Computer fell 25 cents, to $19.25.
"There's a little bit of caution, and it's warranted," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal Lyon & Ross. "We now have to sit back and say, 'is this a one-quarter phenomenon or are we going to get more earnings warnings at the end of the first quarter?' "
But despite the pall cast by Dell, the market has largely withstood bad news, as it did after recent warnings from other bellwether companies.
"We are beyond the stage where such announcements are going to shake it to its feet like they did a few months ago," said Donald Selkin, chief market strategist at Joseph Gunnar & Company, a New York-based brokerage firm and money management company.

Treasuries Move Lower
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as investors bet that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates aggressively enough to spur the economy.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 16/32, to a price of 103 30/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.22 percent from 5.16 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 27/32, to 109 9/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.60 percent from 5.55 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: New Leadership in the Philippines 

 BODY:
President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines, ethically discredited and politically abandoned, spared his country needless turmoil over the weekend by yielding his office to Vice President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. He should drop any plans to challenge the constitutionality of that transfer.
 Mrs. Arroyo's ascension gives Manila a fresh chance to address longstanding problems of political corruption and disappointing economic growth. This former American colony, once one of Southeast Asia's richest nations, is now one of its poorest. Twice in the past 15 years its people have courageously taken to the streets to turn out failed leaders. They deserve better governance and a better life. 
 Like Corazon Aquino, who succeeded Ferdinand Marcos in 1986, Mrs. Arroyo was carried to office by a wave of demonstrations and military defections from the ruling camp. Mr. Marcos was a venal dictator. Mr. Estrada's failings were limited to cronyism and incompetence. 
Mrs. Arroyo comes to the job well prepared. The daughter of a former Philippine president, she studied economics in the United States. She served in Mrs. Aquino's administration, won election as a senator and then, in 1998, was elected vice president. 
She must make clear that business interests will no longer be able to buy political influence and government contracts through campaign contributions to top legislators. Contracts should be submitted to open bidding. Independent judges should be named and insulated from political pressures. It would set a healthy example if prosecutors were allowed to follow through on the plans they announced yesterday to pursue criminal corruption charges against Mr. Estrada. 
With wise leadership, the Philippines, a country of more than 80 million people with a favorable geographic location, charter membership in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and historic ties to the United States, could again become an economic leader in Southeast Asia. It could also become a positive example to its less democratic neighbors, like Vietnam and Myanmar. That is the formidable challenge awaiting Mrs. Arroyo.

HEADLINE: THE NEW ADMINISTRATION: THE JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; 
Ashcroft Leaned Right, Then Center

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 19 

 BODY:
Early in Missouri's 1984 Republican primary for governor, the front-runner, Gene McNary, coined a nickname for his rival, State Attorney General John Ashcroft, the straight-laced, strongly conservative, Yale-educated son of a Pentecostal preacher. "I was the warrior," Mr. McNary recently recalled, "and he was the poet."
 But then the poet started throwing punches. In commercials, mailings and speeches, Mr. Ashcroft attacked Mr. McNary for having supported a costly school desegregation plan for St. Louis. The attack, which analysts say badly hurt Mr. McNary among rural white voters, helped Mr. Ashcroft score an easy primary victory, his first step to becoming Missouri's 50th governor. 
 Mr. Ashcroft's sharp-edged -- critics say polarizing -- campaign was a departure for voters more accustomed to the genteel style of the state's senior Republican, then-Senator John C. Danforth. But if Mr. Ashcroft's campaign seemed to veer right, his policies in office frequently did not. To the surprise of many, he often governed from the political center he had professed to disdain. 
Three times, he endorsed Democratic-backed tax increases for roads and schools. He signed legislation increasing penalties for crimes motivated by bigotry and raised spending on legal services for the poor. And his legislative agendas relied heavily on bipartisan ideas, from economic development to higher pay for teachers to tougher penalties for criminals.
In part, Mr. Ashcroft's moves to the center were the result of working with a Democratic-controlled Legislature throughout his two terms. But in part, they also reflected his governing style, which people in both parties described as cautious, pragmatic and acutely sensitive to public opinion.
"He's one of the most clever politicians I ever met," said Chris Kelly, a state judge and former Democratic state senator. "He knew the pulse of the electorate. And he didn't become public about positions unless he thought he could win. He was not a risk taker."
With contentious confirmation hearings over President Bush's nomination of Mr. Ashcroft to be attorney general expected to conclude this week, many people are looking to his tenure in Missouri for clues about how he would run the Justice Department. Many Democrats say the record suggests that Mr. Ashcroft would not enforce federal laws he opposes, like one intended to protect abortion clinics from violence.
Indeed, Mr. Ashcroft was a die-hard believer in limited government who frequently vetoed bills he considered overly broad or expensive. A fundamentalist Christian, he advocated outlawing most abortions, banned alcohol from the Governor's Mansion and declined to dance at his own inaugural balls. And he formed close alliances with Christian conservatives, anti-abortion groups and the National Rifle Association.
But many Missouri politicians, including Democrats, say that despite his strong beliefs, Mr. Ashcroft played by the book, even when he disliked the rules. As attorney general, for example, he ruled that religious literature could not be distributed at public schools and that federal money could not be used for teaching parochial school students, though he supported both policies.
And when term limits ended his tenure as governor in 1992, the most common criticism against Mr. Ashcroft was not that he had been a firebrand conservative who tried to dismantle state government, but a careful administrator more adept at blocking Democratic initiatives than twisting arms to advance his own.
"There were people to the right of me who thought he had missed an opportunity to do big things," said Woody Cozad, a Kansas City lawyer who is an ally of Mr. Ashcroft and a former chairman of the state Republican Party. "They thought he was too cautious."
Missouri political analysts say Mr. Ashcroft's politics are best understood by looking at his roots in Springfield, a city of unpretentious bungalows, farm supply stores and factories in the Ozark foothills of southwest Missouri, the state's Bible Belt and most-Republican region.
The city was the national headquarters of the Assemblies of God church, and Mr. Ashcroft's father was president of the church's liberal arts school, Evangel College.
Mr. Ashcroft lost a 1972 campaign for Congress and a 1974 race for state auditor. But he went on to win five statewide races: two for attorney general, two for governor and one for United States Senate. In his re-election campaign for governor in 1988, his winning percentage was, at 64 percent, the highest for a Missouri governor since the Civil War.
But he narrowly lost his 2000 Senate campaign to Gov. Mel Carnahan, who had died a few weeks before the election. Mr. Carnahan's widow, Jean, was appointed to the seat.
At the heart of those winning races were three factors, political analysts say: Mr. Ashcroft's hard-driven but folksy campaign style, his ability to win support from socially conservative Democrats and his powerful appeal to rural white voters.
A self-trained pianist and gospel singer who wrote and recorded scores of songs, Mr. Ashcroft spent many weekends singing at churches across the state, building a following of fundamentalist ministers and their congregations. 
Missouri voters also seemed to like the tight-fisted way he managed the state's finances. He became well-known for repairing his own cars to save money, and voters seemed to expect him to bring the same ethic to state government, where he cut programs to help create rainy-day funds and budget surpluses.
But Mr. Ashcroft also relied on big turnouts and deep support from the overwhelmingly white rural and suburban areas of the state, particularly in southwest Missouri. Democrats assert that Mr. Ashcroft's staunch opposition to court-ordered school desegregation plans was part of an effort to appeal to those voters.
In the late 1970's and early 1980's, federal judges had held the state liable for segregated schools in St. Louis and Kansas City, and they ordered it to help pay for busing, school construction and other improvements, which cost the state tens of millions of dollars a year.
As attorney general, Mr. Ashcroft led the state's legal efforts to overturn those rulings. And as governor, he continued to denounce them in harsh terms, accusing the judge in the Kansas City case of trying "to command unlimited resources from taxpayers throughout Missouri."
Mr. Ashcroft's supporters say he did not oppose integration, just the court-ordered plans to achieve it, which he believed unfairly siphoned money from other parts of the state. "He had a duty to defend the state of Missouri, and all of the state of Missouri," said Chip Robertson, who was a top aide to Mr. Ashcroft in the attorney general's office.
But Democrats, and some Republicans, contend that Mr. Ashcroft's unyielding stand prevented him from negotiating a settlement that might have ended the case, saving state money. And while few people accused him of being racist, many said they thought his strenuous opposition to desegregation inflamed anti-black and anti-urban attitudes among white voters, who make up about 90 percent of Missouri's electorate.
"Ashcroft wasn't going to get many votes out of St. Louis and Kansas City," said David Leuthold, a professor emeritus of political science at the University of Missouri. "So he could go to all the other areas of the state and say, I've been fighting for you. You're getting ripped off by the courts."
Many polls showed that Missouri voters tended to agree with Mr. Ashcroft on school desegregation. And his strong opposition to gun control and abortion, and equally strong support for fiscal restraint and limited government, were also well within the mainstream of Missouri politics, political analysts say. 
"When you run for office in Missouri, babies, guns and taxes are the issues," said Richard Hardy, a political scientist at the University of Missouri who has been active in Republican Party politics. "I think he reflected the majority of Missourians when he advanced those causes."
Despite his popularity with voters, Mr. Ashcroft was not well liked in the Legislature. Democrats accustomed to the more gregarious personality of Mr. Ashcroft's predecessor, Christopher S. Bond, were put off by what they considered Mr. Ashcroft's more reserved -- some said sanctimonious -- personality.
"When he came into a room for negotiations, you could have given him a lectern," said Attorney General Jay Nixon, a Democrat who served in the State Senate during Mr. Ashcroft's tenure. "There wasn't much interaction."
Moderate Republicans said they found Mr. Ashcroft respectful of their views even when they disagreed on issues like abortion. But some of them also raised a concern voiced by Democrats: would Mr. Ashcroft, with the support of a Republican president and Congressional leadership, pursue a more aggressively conservative agenda in the Justice Department?
"When he says he'll uphold Roe v. Wade, I believe him," said State Senator Betty Sims, a Republican from St. Louis who supports abortion rights. "But he's not playing alone, and that's what frightens me."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 23 about John Ashcroft's public career in Missouri referred incorrectly to his religious denomination. It is the Assemblies of God -- a Pentecostal church, not fundamentalist.
The article also misstated Mr. Ashcroft's position on a federal law to combat violence against abortion clinics. He has said he is in favor of it, not against it. 
The article misstated the title of Chris Kelly, a former state legislator who praised Mr. Ashcroft's political abilities. He was a state representative, not a state senator.

HEADLINE: Ousted Manila Leader Says He Yielded Just Temporarily 

BYLINE:  By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: MANILA, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Joseph Estrada, forced from the Philippine presidency last week, indicated today that he had yielded power only as a temporary measure and appeared to be creating a basis for legal challenge to his ouster. 
 Congressional leaders have expressed concern that Mr. Estrada, whom prosecutors accused of corruption, may be preparing to file a last-ditch legal action seeking to reverse his removal. The Supreme Court declared him unfit for office, and Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, who had been vice president, was sworn in as his replacement on Saturday. 
 Mr. Estrada, who never officially resigned, fled the Presidential Palace after most of his cabinet and military leaders denounced him and tens of thousands of protesters threatened to come after him. When he left office, he issued a statement saying that while he was stepping aside, he had "strong and serious doubts about the legality and constitutionality" of Mrs. Arroyo's installation as president.
Today, a letter from Mr. Estrada dated Saturday was delivered to the Senate president, Aquilino Pimentel. In the letter, Mr. Estrada contends that he was only temporarily incapacitated and turned over power to Mrs. Arroyo to serve in an acting capacity. A similar letter was sent to several members of the House of Representatives.
"This letter appears to be the basis for a constitutional challenge," Mr. Pimentel said in an interview. "We could very well be headed for a major constitutional crisis if Mr. Estrada decides to contest his removal."
In a television interview on Sunday, Mr. Estrada's son, Joseph, said his father had "not resigned the presidency," and he strongly intimated that Manila had not seen the last of Mr. Estrada, a former movie star who was very popular with the poor and working class. For now, Mr. Estrada remains secluded in his private mansion on the outskirts of the capital, and it is unclear whether he will seek to return to power. 
But he has raised serious questions about the legitimacy of the new presidency just as Mrs. Arroyo is assembling a cabinet, formulating policy initiatives, and moving into the Presidential Palace, where she lived when her father was president in the early 1960's. 
Many foreign governments and organizations, including the United States and the United Nations, have expressed support for Mrs. Arroyo, a 53-year-old economist, who has vowed to crack down on corruption, strengthen the country's sagging economy and reduce poverty. Financial markets rose sharply today in reaction to Mr. Estrada's removal. 
Aides to Mrs. Arroyo dismissed the prospect that Mr. Estrada would initiate a legal challenge or that such an effort would succeed. They said the Supreme Court chief justice, Hilario Davide, administered the oath of office to Mrs. Arroyo after the 12-member court unanimously declared the presidency vacant. They said they had done so because Mr. Estrada was not able to carry out his duties after he lost the support of his top officials and the military. 
In an effort to head off any constitutional challenge, the Supreme Court approved a resolution today upholding its decision to install Mrs. Arroyo. But the court said its resolution was "without prejudice to any justifiable case that may be filed by a proper party." 
Some legal scholars and legislators said the Supreme Court had erred in installing Mrs. Arroyo as president because succession under the Philippine Constitution requires a sitting president to submit his or her resignation in writing to both Houses of Congress, a step that Mr. Estrada did not take. 
Mrs. Arroyo, a bitter political enemy of Mr. Estrada, acknowledged today that she had come to power under unusual circumstances. 
"The path that brought me here today has not been an easy one, and I did not take that path alone," she said at a flag-raising ceremony. "I came here riding on a wave created by millions of people making their voices heard above the dark confusion of crisis and confrontation."
A high-ranking Western diplomat based in Manila said that Mr. Estrada had raised legitimate questions about succession and that in hindsight, "it could be argued that constitutional principles were disregarded in the name of people power." But the diplomat expressed doubt that the events of last week would be reversed on legal appeal. 
Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's elder statesman, said in an interview with The Associated Press that the change of power in Manila did not enhance democracy because it was done outside the Constitution. "I would have preferred that Estrada could be removed in a constitutional way in the Senate," said Mr. Lee, the 77-year-old founder of the modern city-state of Singapore, a democracy which nonetheless stifled dissent. "So I don't think it was a plus for the democratic system." 
Some political experts speculated that Mr. Estrada was declaring that he remained head of state to keep his presidential immunity from prosecution.
Prosecutors have begun a new criminal inquiry into charges that Mr. Estrada pocketed millions of dollars in excise taxes and bribes from gambling syndicates while in office. The charges were similar to those brought against him in a Senate impeachment trial that collapsed last week, leading to the protests and defections that culminated in his downfall.

HEADLINE: Bush Administration Warns Iraq on Weapons Programs 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
The Bush administration warned Iraq today to honor its agreements to destroy its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs, but the White House said it was too soon to say what steps the new administration would take to ensure Baghdad's compliance. 
 Responding to a report today that Iraq had rebuilt a series of factories long suspected of producing chemical and biological weapons, the new White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said, "The president expects Saddam Hussein to live up to the agreements that he's made with the United Nations, especially regarding the elimination of weapons of mass destruction." 
 But when asked how and when the administration would help resume international inspections of suspected weapons sites and factories, Mr. Fleischer said, "I'm not prepared to address that today, but we will." 
A decade after Mr. Bush's father led a coalition that ousted Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait, Iraq remains one of the most daunting foreign policy problems that former President Bill Clinton has left his successor. 
Mr. Bush and his national security advisers -- including Gen. Colin L. Powell, now secretary of state, and Vice President Dick Cheney, who both confronted Iraq as top defense officials 10 years ago -- have talked tough about containing President Hussein.
But as they enter office, it is not clear whether they have any better options than Mr. Clinton had. International support for tough enforcement of sanctions has waned, while Mr. Hussein has managed to ease his diplomatic isolation, making it difficult to re-energize sanctions, as General Powell has suggested.
If Mr. Bush pursues a more aggressive strategy, including military force, the new administration is likely to find few allies, despite evidence that Iraq has resumed covert work on dangerous weapons. 
As a condition of ending the 1991 Persian Gulf war, Iraq agreed to destroy its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs, as well as the production of long-range missiles to deliver to such weapons. 
But since the middle of 1998, Iraq has barred any meaningful inspections by teams of United Nations experts, who since the end of the gulf war had ferreted out and destroyed large quantities of weapons and uncovered secret programs to create biological and chemical weapons. 
"The challenge is larger than a lot of people suspect," said Representative Porter Goss, a Florida Republican who heads the House Intelligence Committee. "To say we've lost our eyes and ears in Iraq is true." 
Clearly, constraining Mr. Hussein's weapons programs is at the core of the new administration's policy. "His only tool, the only thing he can scare us with are those weapons of mass destruction, and we have to hold him to account," General Powell said last week. 
Mr. Bush and his top advisers have vowed to reinvigorate the economic sanctions against Iraq, convince skeptical allies of their value, and somehow spare Iraqi children from bearing the brunt of their effect. 
"The most important thing is to maintain the core sanctions, the key sanctions that do make it more difficult and prevent Iraq from rebuilding its weapons programs, particularly its weapons of mass destruction," Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said today. 
But even some of Mr. Bush's own advisers question this approach. "Re-energizing sanctions is a mistake," said Richard Perle, a foreign policy adviser to Mr. Bush during the campaign. "Ten years later, they're an obvious failure." 
The new administration also supports Iraqi opposition whose goal is to topple Mr. Hussein.
The Clinton administration provided only tepid support to the Iraqi opposition. Although President Clinton signed a law in 1998 authorizing $98 million in military aid and equipment, the administration provided very little in the end and explicitly refused to provide any weapons.
Under pressure, the Pentagon began providing some direct military training to Iraqi dissidents and opposition leaders in the fall of 1999. Since then, the Pentagon has given courses to 90 members of the Iraqi National Congress -- including 27 at a public affairs seminar in London last summer and 43 who went to a one-week course on war crimes in November at the Defense Institute of International Studies in Newport, R.I. Training continues, but it does not involve combat-related skills.
Senior military commanders opposed giving much military aid to the Iraqi groups, warning that they were too weak and fractious to pose a serious threat to Mr. Hussein's rule. 
The Bush administration would be committed to the opposition's cause, aides say. "What we have in mind is making it clear to Saddam and the world that we're in favor of seeing this regime change," Mr. Perle said. "We'll support freedom fighters who are prepared to engage in a long-term struggle." 
The Bush administration has not ruled out bombing suspected weapons sites as a last resort. "If, in fact, Saddam Hussein were taking steps to try to rebuild nuclear capability or weapons of mass destruction, we'd have to give very serious consideration to military action," Mr. Cheney said in a debate on Oct. 5. 
As they departed, Clinton administration officials defended their policies. Walter B. Slocombe, who stepped down last week as Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, said of Mr. Hussein, "I don't want to claim he hasn't made progress, but he's still in the box."

HEADLINE: THE NEW ADMINISTRATION: THE EDUCATION ISSUE; 
Education Plan By Bush Shows New Consensus

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
As his first major policy proposal, President Bush plans to present an education package today whose theme, "leave no child behind," echoes the decade-old motto of the Children's Defense Fund.
 That a Republican president and one of the nation's premier liberal groups share a slogan reflects the recent narrowing of the education debate to focus almost exclusively on the plight of poor, minority children in inner-city schools. 
 From social promotion to summer school, standards and accountability to universal preschool and after-school programs -- even in the contentious struggle over school choice -- the young faces being used to sell virtually every education reform proposal these days tend to be black and brown.
For Mr. Bush, the poverty-focused education program represents his best hope for bipartisan backing, and could even win him support from a campaign adversary, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. Page A14. 
The new emphasis is a stark change from the 1980's, when educators and policy makers fretted over the fate of even America's best schools in international competition, and it is in striking contrast to other domestic policy issues, like health care, in which middle class concerns drive the debate. 
With corporate leaders dissatisfied about the quality of the labor pool helping to steer the discussion, talk from years past about experimental curriculums and individual portfolios has been overshadowed by a bottom-line approach stressing basic skills, tests and accountability -- all aimed at the neediest students in impoverished urban districts.
"The whole discussion is an equity discussion," said Diane Ravitch, the education historian. "The tenor of the discussion is: Do charter schools help poor kids? Do vouchers help poor kids? Is state testing good or bad for poor kids? How can we design a system that increases equity?"
On education, it seems, the political spectrum is collapsing into near consensus, with the goal of helping a constituency long represented by liberals using methods -- competition, accountability and a focus on fundamentals -- that are conservative at their core. Disputes remain over whether to expand taxpayer-financed vouchers for private-school tuition and over the power of teachers' unions, but broad swaths of common ground exist in between. 
Mr. Bush plans to unveil this morning a package that includes early literacy programs, annual assessment comparing progress among racial groups and an escape hatch that would make federal money portable for families in failing schools.
Counterproposals by Democrats and Republicans also aim to close the achievement gap between poor and middle-class students through accountability measures like standardized tests, school report cards and pay incentives.
The shift to focus on the poor has its roots in the decade-old push for high-stakes testing in schools nationwide, as Americans for the first time expect all students to master a college preparatory curriculum. With the new tests have come reams of data about individual school performance, and the disquieting discovery that the achievement gap between white and minority pupils, while narrowed from several decades ago, has begun to widen again.
"There is the 'all' word -- that's a brand-new word in this whole discussion," said Marshall S. Smith, a Stanford education professor who was deputy secretary in the Clinton education department. "That word 'all' applies a lot more to poor and minority kids, and limited English proficiency kids."
While many liberals who have been advocating for the poor for decades welcome the new voices to the conversation, others are skeptical about their sincerity. Some question whether highlighting the failures of urban schools is just laying the groundwork for disbanding the public school system; others worry that the focus on education ignores the more intractable underlying problems of poverty, discrimination and family dysfunction. Complaints abound, too, that parents and teachers of the poor are rarely consulted.
"Most policy makers don't have either any interest in or clarity about what it is they'd really do with urban schools," said Michael D. Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, which represents the nation's 60 largest urban districts. "Sometimes the conversation will start around the obvious needs, in this case poor kids in urban and rural communities, and that becomes the rationale for freeing up money that is then spent on somebody else."
Emeral A. Crosby, a Detroit high school principal for 30 years, was more cynical, suggesting a profit motive for those running charter schools, designing tests or putting computers in impoverished schools.
"Right now there's a lot of money in saying you're going to help the poor," he said. "Salesmen are good at this. They're going to tell me how this is going to benefit me, whatever it is that they're selling, but really what they want to do is sell me something, whether I need it or not, to improve their quality of life."
To be sure, the education debate has always emphasized the disadvantaged, particularly at the federal level. From the desegregation of schools in the 1950's to the Great Society programs of the 1960's, the bulk of federal attention and money has focused on the needy.
But for decades, conservatives talked of dismantling such federal programs, not proffering different ways to help the same population. More recently, the debate was shaped by the 1983 report, "A Nation at Risk," which consciously emphasized excellence over equity and criticized schools with a broad brush rather than singling out those serving the poor.
"We have, in effect, been committing an act of unthinking, unilateral educational disarmament," the report warned. "We must dedicate ourselves to the reform of our educational system for the benefit of all -- old and young alike, affluent and poor, majority and minority."
Similarly, the standards movement that inaugurated this era of bipartisanship on education a decade ago was originally seen as something for everybody -- all students pushed to higher levels. But as new tests have taken hold, attention has fallen on those who are failing, and there is a growing middle-class backlash against schools' stripping their curriculums and resembling test-prep factories.
Now, suburban priorities like art and music, special education and high school design often get pushed aside in the national debate by the inner-city plagues of illiteracy and high dropout rates. Even universal problems like the impending teacher shortage are typically couched in concerns for the poor, where they are most acute.
"The poor children have advocates all over the place; the upper class places their children in private schools," said Shelley Joy Tellez, the mother of a ninth grader in Mesa, Ariz., who runs an anti-testing Web site, www.stopaimsnow.org. "The middle-class kids, I think they get lost in the wash."
On most issues, politicians cater to white, middle-class, suburban concerns because that is where the votes are. But with education, many such residents tell pollsters they are satisfied with their own schools, yet worried about the inner city, so it makes political sense to frame the debate that way. In addition, poor children inspire more sympathy than other subjects of ambitious social programs, like welfare mothers, drug addicts, the unemployed, or veterans of the criminal justice system.
"Some care as a matter of compassion; increasingly, they care as a matter of competitiveness," said Hugh Price, president of the National Urban League. "A lousy education is costing the business community billions of dollars."
Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, agreed. "We can't afford to have a large segment of the population left behind," she said. That Ms. Feldman is echoing the slogan of President Bush, whose candidacy she fought fiercely, is symbolic of the broad agreement on major education issues from all corners of the political landscape, as Republicans seize an issue long dominated by Democrats.
This weekend, a Democratic donor sponsored a dinner for the new Secretary of Education, Roderick R. Paige, and there were no clear aisles as people from both sides mingled around the vodka fountain. "We may have come on different ships," Mr. Paige said, quoting former Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas, "but we are in the same boat now."
Look at Christopher T. Cross and Jack Jennings. For years, they dueled on Capitol Hill, staff directors of the House education committee for opposing parties; today, Mr. Cross is chairman of the board of Mr. Jennings's Center on Education Policy in Washington. 
The Wall Street Journal's editorial page courts Howard Fuller, a former black power radical. Chester E. Finn Jr., a Reagan administration alumnus, and Amy T. Wilkins, a former labor organizer who now works with a Washington group devoted to underserved pupils, often share the same side of the table. 
"The us against them in education politics today is outsiders across the political spectrum versus people with a direct interest in the status quo," Mr. Finn said. 
Earlier this month, at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, a Who's Who of education's right-wing met for two days, and virtually every conversation, Ms. Ravitch said, turned on the question of "how can we benefit the poor?"
Referring to that liberal bastion on the other coast, she added, "I think the same discussion would be held at the Harvard school of education."

HEADLINE: THE NEW ADMINISTRATION: THE PRESIDENT; 
BUSH ACTS TO HALT OVERSEAS SPENDING TIED TO ABORTION

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI and MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
President Bush moved today to deny federal aid to overseas groups that provide abortion counseling or otherwise help women obtain abortions, using his first full day of work in the Oval Office to reinstate restrictions that had been in place under the previous Bush and Reagan administrations.
 Mr. Bush's action reversed the Clinton policy on aid for international family planning groups, which Bill Clinton had instituted in his first days in the White House. 
 And it came on the 28th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision that first established a constitutional right to abortion, a day that brought busloads of opponents of legal abortion here for a protest around the Washington Monument. Page A16. 
"It is my conviction that taxpayer funds should not be used to pay for abortions or advocate or actively promote abortion either here or abroad," Mr. Bush wrote in an executive memorandum to the Agency for International Development, which administers and monitors family planning aid to overseas groups.
In a statement released along with the memorandum this evening, the White House made clear that Mr. Bush was not proposing any reduction in the $425 million in aid allocated for overseas family planning for this fiscal year, but was simply placing restraints on how it was used.
The change in abortion policy quickly diverted attention from the new administration's theme of the week, education, which had been chosen in part for its promise of creating the kind of bipartisan coalitions Mr. Bush may need to push legislation through a Congress narrowly divided along party lines.
And by wading into an especially divisive social issue, Mr. Bush seemed to be stepping on his other efforts today to reach out to Democrats and strike a harmonious tone.
Administration aides were, in fact, putting the finishing touches on a package of education proposals that they are expected to send to Congress on Tuesday, when Mr. Bush is also scheduled to meet at the White House with groups of Democratic lawmakers to discuss education.
The abortion debate also drew attention away from the introduction in the Senate of legislation for the sort of huge tax cut that Mr. Bush promised in the presidential campaign.
Advocates of legal abortion immediately questioned whether, with the abortion memorandum, Mr. Bush was showing himself to be much more conservative than he had in his campaign and whether it was part of a broader assault on abortion rights.
"He had a moderate demeanor throughout the campaign," said Kate Michelman, the president of the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League. But today's action -- along with the selection of John Ashcroft, a committed foe of abortion, as attorney general -- suggested that Mr. Bush "intends to use his powers to restrict a woman's right to choose," she added.
But Mr. Bush's press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said Mr. Bush was simply following through on a position and philosophy that he enunciated clearly in the campaign and that was in line with the thinking of a majority of Americans.
"I think there's, frankly, widespread bipartisan support that there should not be taxpayer money used to promote abortion," Mr. Fleischer said at his first briefing as the White House press secretary.
The day featured many other firsts, as well as a noticeable degree of chaos, as the people working in the new administration moved into their White House offices, struggled with their White House computers and digested their new obligations. Their morning began in the East Room with a swearing-in ceremony, at which Mr. Bush emphasized the high ethical standards he expected his staff to adhere to.
"We are all accountable to the law and to the American people," Mr. Bush told them. That televised statement, along with subsequent televised comments in which Mr. Bush said that "the country is pleased that it's time to move on," carried hints of reproach for Mr. Clinton's conduct in his presidency.
Mr. Bush held a series of meetings at the White House intended to build support for his legislative agenda. He had lunch there with Republican Congressional leaders, including Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois. 
Later, he sat down in the White House with former Democratic lawmakers and other party elders. Mr. Bush used his brief public remarks at that meeting to insist, as he had in his inaugural remarks and in preinaugural speeches, that he was less interested in party affiliation than in progress on crucial issues.
"This administration is going to seek the good in everybody and find that ability to come together for the good of the country as well," Mr. Bush said at the meeting. It was attended by Richard Moe, a former chief of staff to Vice President Walter Mondale; Robert Strauss, a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee; Jody Powell, a former press secretary to President Jimmy Carter; William H. Gray III, a former congressman from Pennsylvania who is now president of the United Negro College Fund; and former Senators John Glenn of Ohio and Paul Simon of Illinois.
"My feeling is, the president is going to reach out," Mr. Simon said as he left the White House late this afternoon. "Strangely, the 50-50 situation in the Senate may lead to greater cooperation between the parties."
But there were reminders today, as Senate Democrats spelled out their own priorities, of some of the fault lines and tensions that Mr. Bush will confront.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said Democrats believed strongly that "any tax cut must be affordable and fiscally responsible." For many Congressional Democrats, that means a far less sweeping reduction than proposed in the Bush plan, which essentially arrived on Capitol Hill today in the form of legislation introduced in the Senate. It called for a tax cut of roughly $1.6 trillion over 10 years.
There were also hints that Mr. Bush, the former Texas governor, was on legislative terrain less familiar and hospitable than what he was accustomed to.
After the lunch with Republican leaders, one, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, said, "We basically talked about how the Congress actually works -- not that we were teaching him, but talking to him about what we've been able to do over the last six years."
"What we've been able to do is different from what he's used to in Texas," Mr. DeLay added.
In a day with a flurry of unrelated developments, the White House also announced that Mr. Bush's first foreign trip would not be to Canada, the customary destination for many new presidents, but to Mexico.
Aides said that he would meet with the Mexican president, Vicente Fox, at Mr. Fox's ranch in San Cristobal, and that Mr. Bush might well be able to fit in a visit to his own ranch, in Crawford, Tex., then.
But all other business was eclipsed by the abortion memorandum, and Mr. Fleischer endured question after question about its timing so soon into the administration. Mr. Bush did not have to render a decision on the federal aid until Feb. 15. "This is something that he ran on, and so I don't think it's anything that's unexpected," Mr. Fleischer said.
But Mr. Bush seldom dwelled on abortion in his campaign, and even today, he seemed intent on striking a balance. He did not address the protesters here but instead passed along a statement, which a Republican congressman read aloud.
"The promises of our Declaration of Independence are not just for the strong, the independent or the healthy," the statement from Mr. Bush said. "They are for everyone -- including unborn children."
The memorandum Mr. Bush signed today reinstated a 1984 ban, issued by President Ronald Reagan and then maintained by Mr. Bush's father, on providing money for use by overseas groups that promote abortion. Mr. Clinton essentially suspended that ban, although the delivery of the money was halted late last year until Feb. 15, thus allowing a new president to decide what to do.
The $425 million affected by Mr. Bush's decision goes to an array of groups, like Planned Parenthood International and the Centre for Development and Population Activities, in addition to foreign governments. While many private groups would lose financing, the governments would not be bound by the edict.
Administration officials and abortion rights advocates said they could not immediately determine how the aid was divided between private groups and foreign governments, nor how many groups involved in abortion services would face a cutoff.

HEADLINE: THE NEW ADMINISTRATION: THE TAX PLAN; 
Bush's Proposal to Cut Taxes Is Swiftly Introduced in Senate

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
Congress began considering President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax-cut proposal today, with a renegade Democrat joining a Republican in introducing the bill in the Senate and Democratic leaders saying they would insist that the package be scaled back.
 With a Republican in the White House, an economy that may or may not be faltering and a growing federal budget surplus, Republicans in Congress said that they were confident of passing a substantial tax cut this year and that it might even be bigger than the plan outlined by Mr. Bush during his presidential campaign. 
 Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a Republican, teamed with Senator Zell Miller of Georgia, a Democrat, to put Mr. Bush's plan into the legislative pipeline, with both senators predicting that it would attract considerable bipartisan support. 
Mr. Bush's plan would reduce all federal income tax rates, raise the child credit, give a break to married couples and repeal the federal tax on large estates. Most of its provisions would be phased in over the next five to eight years, though the new administration is considering accelerating the schedule to help give the economy an immediate lift.
Members of Congress are considering adding provisions like an expansion of individual retirement accounts and 401(k) retirement programs.
In the form proposed by Mr. Bush during the campaign, the plan would reduce taxes by $1.3 trillion over nine years, starting next year. Congress normally estimates tax cuts over 10 years, in this case starting next year and extending through 2011; by that yardstick, the Bush tax plan would be worth about $1.6 trillion.
Mr. Gramm acknowledged that the Bush plan as he introduced it was sure to be revised in coming weeks and months, both by Congress and by the new administration. 
But Mr. Gramm said he had consulted with the president, Vice President Dick Cheney and the new Treasury Secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, before deciding to introduce the bill now. And he was clearly delighted at having a Democrat to co-sponsor it, especially after years in which Republican efforts to cut taxes were thwarted by Bill Clinton.
"What we wanted to do, on a bipartisan basis, is to start the debate today," Mr. Gramm said. 
Mr. Gramm said that Republicans now expected the federal budget surplus for the next decade to be roughly $5.6 trillion, of which about $2.9 trillion would come from outside the Social Security program. The two parties have agreed not to use the part of the surplus generated by Social Security for tax cuts or new spending.
Mr. Miller, whose support could be critical to Republicans as they seek to steer the tax cut through a Senate split 50-50 between the two parties, was unapologetic for breaking with his party over Mr. Bush's plan.
"Right now, our taxes have never been higher," Mr. Miller said. "Right now, our surplus has never been greater. To me it's just plain common sense that you deal with the first by using the second." 
Mr. Bush discussed tax cuts today in his meeting at the White House with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate's Republican leader. Afterward, Mr. Hastert said he and Mr. Lott would work to complete something very close to Mr. Bush's plan as fast as possible. 
"We're going to work with the president to get it through both the House and the Senate the best we can and try to keep to the president's principles and parameters," Mr. Hastert said. 
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said the president would "fight for the package that he ran on."
No longer able to rely on a veto from the White House to back them up, Democrats in Congress said they would continue to press for a considerably smaller tax cut, with benefits primarily directed to low- and middle-income households.
"We are willing to negotiate," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader in the Senate. "At the same time, we are committed to two fundamental principles. First, the bulk of the tax relief must go to middle-class working families, because they are the people who need tax relief most. Second, any tax cut must be affordable and fiscally responsible."
Mr. Daschle said Democrats had introduced their own package, including tax breaks for some married couples with two incomes, a cut in the estate tax and tax breaks for specific purposes like college tuition and the cost of long-term care for disabled and elderly family members.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Independent Generators Reshaping Power Industry
With power supplies tight across much of the nation and Wall Street opening its pocketbook to energy concerns, independent companies are reshaping the power-generation industry.
 Nearly every new power plant in the United States is being built not by a state-regulated utility but by largely unregulated independent companies, which now account for more than 20 percent of domestic electricity generation, a number that is rising quickly. Page A1. 

President Bush's economic officials gathered for the new administration's first crisis meeting and decided that the government should let California solve its own power problem. C4.

Rich Pardon Surprises Prosecutors
The pardon of Marc Rich, the commodities trader who has been a fugitive for almost two decades, came as an unwelcome surprise to federal prosecutors when President Clinton granted it as one of his final acts. A16.

Ex-Nabisco Chief to Head Gillette
James M. Kilts, who turned around Nabisco in his three years there, was hired as the chairman and chief executive of Gillette, which has struggled with a weak euro and heavy competition. Mr. Kilts, who is 52, said he would reserve judgment on what ails Gillette but promised to improve sales, as he had done at Nabisco and Kraft. C8.

Justices to Review Telecom Cases
The Supreme Court decided to review cases that could have profound implications for how much consumers will pay for local telephone and high-speed Internet services. C2.

Stocks Decline on Warning by Dell
Stocks fell after Dell Computer warned that its profits would be hurt by a global economic slowdown. The Nasdaq composite index fell 12.47 points, or 0.5 percent, to 2,757.91. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 9.35 points, to 10,578.24, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.36 point, to 1,342.90. C8.

Japanese Official Steps Down
Casting a further cloud over the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, Fukushiro Nukaga, Japan's head of economic and fiscal policy, resigned because of a bribery scandal. (An earlier article about pressure on Mr. Nukaga to step down appears in World Business, which went to press before his resignation.) C2.

Tax Cut Plan Goes to Congress
Congress began considering President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax cut proposal, with Democratic leaders saying they would insist that the package be scaled back. A15.

American Express Profit Rises 12%
American Express said that its fourth-quarter profit rose 12 percent, in line with Wall Street expectations, as it gained new cardholders but said earnings growth in 2001 would be at the low end of its current target. The company, known for its signature green charge cards and traveler's checks, earned $677 million in the quarter, or 50 cents a share, compared with $606 million, or 44 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Shares of American Express fell $3.63, to $45. C13.

F.T.C. Drops DoubleClick Inquiry
The Federal Trade Commission dropped its inquiry into whether DoubleClick, the Internet's biggest advertising agency, violated consumer privacy by tracking Web-surfing habits. C5.

Auction House Names New Chief
John Block, who resigned last fall as vice chairman of Sotheby's North America, was named chief executive of the auction house Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg. C7.

Leading Indicators Decline 0.6%
The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.6 percent in December, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Conference Board said. But a technical adjustment in the index deepened the drop. Without that change, the leading indicators would have fallen 0.3 percent. C13.
