HEADLINE: Administration Leaves Power Crisis in California's Hands 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 

 BODY:
President Bush's top economic officials gathered today to deal with the threat of electricity blackouts and utility bankruptcies in California. But they decided that the federal government should let California solve its own power problem.
 The signal from the administration in its first working day in office contrasted with the more activist stance by the Clinton administration, which convened the parties involved in California's power crisis to try to hammer out a compromise that would ensure sufficient supplies of power at reasonable prices. That effort did not produce a solution before President Clinton left office on Saturday. 
 California's electricity reserves have fallen into crisis levels for seven days. The state avoided rolling blackouts today, but power officials warned that they were still at a Stage 3 electrical emergency and that at any time they might have no choice but to shut off power to homes, offices and factories in parts of the state.
The administration faces a deadline of Tuesday to decide whether to continue two emergency orders that require out-of-state companies to continue selling surplus electricity and natural gas to California. State utility companies and electricity officials are pressing Mr. Bush to extend the orders, which expire at midnight that day, arguing that the state's power shortage will become more precarious without federal help.
The California Independent System Operator, the agency that oversees the state's electrical supply, wrote a letter to Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham urging an extension of the order, which mandates that electricity producers in nearby states sell their surplus to California. The letter called the order "critical to efforts to secure the energy supplies needed."
A California state electricity official said today that the order had helped California buy hundreds of megawatt hours of electricity on the wholesale market -- enough to tip the balance between sufficient supply and blackouts on several days.
Administration officials left open the possibility that Mr. Abraham would extend the temporary orders, which were put into place by the Clinton administration. But they said they were not prepared to announce a decision on the matter today.
State legislators in Sacramento wrestled with proposals that would overhaul the 1996 deregulation law that led to the problem. One proposal would make it possible for the state to secure long-term power supplies at lower prices than those that prevail in the wholesale power market today.
Legislators also debated ways of easing the debt burden of the state's two main utilities, which say they face imminent bankruptcy because they cannot recover the high cost of buying power by selling to consumers at fixed prices.
President Bush has rejected the possibility of using federal emergency powers to cap prices or mobilize energy supplies to alleviate California's shortage, arguing that such measures would ultimately do more harm than good. Instead, he has emphasized long-term efforts to increase energy supplies, like promoting more oil and natural gas drilling in areas that are now under environmental protection.
"The real solution long term is to enact President Bush's comprehensive energy policy," the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said today. "He plans on making it a priority and we'll work with Congress to get it enacted."
Mr. Fleischer said that several cabinet officers, including Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and Mr. Abraham, met to discuss the California situation this afternoon. He said they explored "options and ideas" for helping the state, but added that the administration preferred to see California work its own way out of the morass.
"The president continues to believe that the issue is mostly a California matter, dealing with the legislation that is before the state," Mr. Fleischer said.
In a sign that the new administration will continue to push for energy deregulation despite the California disaster, Mr. Bush today promoted Curt Hebert, a strong deregulation advocate, to lead the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the agency that oversees the interstate sale of power.
Mr. Hebert is a Mississippi native and an ally of Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader. He has said that he favors liberalizing the buying and selling of power in ways seen as beneficial to the nation's largest energy producers, who are eager to break the monopolies utility companies traditionally enjoyed to sell power in heavily regulated states.
Mr. Hebert, the only Republican on the commission, opposed a request by Gov. Gray Davis of California to use the commission's power to place a limit on the wholesale price of power last month. He replaces a Democrat, William Massey, who favored price caps.
"These are challenging times for the commission as the bulk-power markets more fully embrace the tenets of the free enterprise system," Mr. Hebert, 38, said in a statement. "I believe this system is part of the solution rather than part of the problem for the malfunctioning markets on the West Coast."
On the legislative front, California's representatives in Congress tried to force the federal government to play a more active role.
Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, introduced legislation that would impose a price cap on electricity throughout the West. Representative Bob Filner, also a Democrat, pushed a similar measure.
The state's other senator, Dianne Feinstein, another Democrat, offered a slightly more complicated bill that would give the energy secretary the power to choose between blanket regional price limits or to negotiate with individual producers to set rates of return for their sales to California.
None of the measures were expected to gain momentum in the Republican-controlled Congress or to win the support of the administration.
Work continued in Sacramento to find a solution. One proposal announced today was a plan that would relieve the state's two main utilities of their debt, estimated at $11.5 billion, in exchange for state ownership of their hydroelectric generating operations. The measure would help end the credit problem for utilities, which has made power producers wary of selling to them.

HEADLINE: Job Aides Open Doors For Those Who Can't 

BYLINE:  By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU

 BODY:
Richard Bergeron, president of a computer consulting company, has Lou Gehrig's disease. He uses a number of devices that help him do his job, like a motion detector on his computer that lets him type by raising his eyebrows. But for all the special gear, he would be unable to work were it not for his assistant, Wendy Brown. She is often his arms and legs, and sometimes his voice.
 Ms. Brown accompanies Mr. Bergeron, who is completely paralyzed and barely able to speak, to business meetings where she might translate his muffled words to peers or give presentations on his behalf. She also takes care of his mail, telephone calls, faxes and follow-ups with clients. She even helps feed and dress him. 
 "Because of her dedication and compassion, I've been able to not only stay out of a nursing home, but also actually enjoy a very high quality of life," Mr. Bergeron said in an e-mail message from his Malvern, Pa., office.
Mr. Bergeron is one of a growing number of severely disabled people who are turning to personal assistants to help them keep up with the daily grind or even carve out successful careers, advocates for disabled people say. Despite the employment opportunities that have opened up as a result of technological advances and the legal protections contained in the 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act, such human intervention is crucial to bringing more disabled people into the work force, they say.
Only 32 percent of disabled people 18 to 64 have a full or part-time job, compared with 81 percent of the rest of workers, according to a recent Harris poll. And more than two-thirds of the disabled unemployed would prefer to be working, the survey found.
"There are a lot of people we hear from who want to work but can't without that kind of human assistance -- either ongoing or just temporarily until they can learn how to do it themselves," said Ellen Daly, a spokeswoman with the Office of Disability Employment Policy, a federal agency.
Employers in industries where there are labor shortages are looking for ways to tap into the huge pool of unemployed disabled people, according to Chris Bell, a partner for the employment law firm of Jackson Lewis in Minneapolis. For most employers, the decision hinges on cost: Will the expense of employing an assistant, who can cost from $7 to $20 an hour, outweigh the benefits?
The answer is increasingly yes. Mr. Bell, who is blind, says his firm is happy to supply him a full-time secretary to help with tasks like reading client faxes out loud. Most other partners have to share secretaries.
For disabled people with sought-after skills, a small investment can go a long way. Take Richard Salem, a corporate lawyer in Tampa, Fla., who has been blind since 17. One of his biggest challenges is picking up nonverbal cues during meetings that could make or break a case. So his main assistant, Jeanne Crepeau, often attends client meetings with him and tips him off about body language. "I can whisper in his ear if someone is squirming in their seat or appears to have something to say," she said.
Mr. Salem said, "I rely on my assistants to do my job."
Employers are not required to provide assistants to perform such personal tasks as helping disabled employees take their coats off, getting them a sandwich or helping them go to the bathroom. But sometimes they do anyway.
Heidi Van Arnem, president of i.Can.com, a Web site for disabled people, has been paralyzed from the neck down since she was shot at the age of 16. She hired Pam Morenzetti as her personal assistant and later promoted her to handle customer service. She still relies on her, though, to switch her legs around to help with circulation and to give her a sip of water every hour or two.
"We have a great deal of trust for each other," Ms. Arnem said.
Such care can be expensive, but state agencies and nonprofit groups can pick up some or all of the tab. Quest, a nonprofit in Orlando, Fla., pays the salaries of three developmentally disabled workers who dismantle old wire and other metal materials for the Orlando Utilities Commission, and of their supervisor, Pablo Santiago. It makes good business sense, said Mark Ausley, site manager for the materials handling center. "They probably recover $150,000 in good materials each year," he said.
Vocational agencies in all 50 states provide money for so-called job coaches, who work with newly hired disabled people for anywhere from a week to several months to train them in their new jobs. Wendy Strobel, a job coach with the Virginia Commonwealth University's Rehabilitation Research and Training Center in Richmond, worked with one quadriplegic woman, whom the center had placed at a small- business development center doing telephone customer service.
"She had good communications skills but initially had a difficult time with the etiquette required," Ms. Strobel said. "For example, if someone called in and asked for the date of an event, she'd get nervous and freeze up on the phone. We set up a system where she could put the call on hold and I would then come on." After three months, the woman gained the confidence to do the job herself, Ms. Strobel said.
The Americans With Disabilities Act requires companies to provide interpreters for the deaf and readers for the blind. Beyond that, employers have to assess whether providing personal help is needed to ensure that disabled workers can perform the essential job functions.
The McClean, Va., office of Booz Allen & Hamilton, the management consulting firm, pays an interpreter $35 to $55 an hour depending on skill level, for four hours every Monday so a deaf employee can participate fully in weekly staff meetings, said Meg O'Connell, an associate in the firm's disability consulting division.
While the worker is able to read lips well one on one, interaction with groups can be challenging. "The meetings are important for the development of a team mentality here," Ms. O'Connell said. "We don't want any worker to feel like an outsider."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pablo Santiago, left, supervises Dennis Smith, one of three disabled workers who work for Quest, a nonprofit group in Orlando, Fla. (Gregg Matthews for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE; 
Man of Grand Ideas Welcomes the World To His Party in Rio

BYLINE:  By NEIL STRAUSS

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
Last week, during a day off from the third installment of the Rock in Rio festival he created, Roberto Medina sat in his luxurious house in the Barra da Tijuca neighborhood here. A Salvador Dali sketch hung on the wall across from him, a gift from Freddy Mercury of Queen, who, after headlining the first Rock in Rio festival in 1985, was impressed enough to ask Dali to create something for Mr. Medina, a Brazilian impresario. 
 To his left was a sunken living room with an overhead skylight that could be opened by remote control. A maintenance man tended to a pool outside, a maid prepared drinks in the kitchen, and a sound system quietly piped the music of Alanis Morissette throughout the house. Like his home, Mr. Medina, gray-haired, neatly attired and meticulously groomed, projected an image of tranquillity and satisfaction. 
 The scene was the antithesis of his festival, seven days of diverse music stretching past 3 a.m. on 2.7 million square feet of trash-strewn earth packed with 150,000 to 250,000 music fans a night. 
An advertising man by trade, Mr. Medina naturally lapses into sales pitches full of big numbers and grand ideas. The way he looks at it, Rock in Rio III, which ended on Sunday, pumped $180 million to $300 million into the local economy, generated $40 million in media coverage (local papers like O Globo dedicated as many as 13 pages of articles to the festival a day), donated 5 percent of its multimillion-dollar take to an education program, and is in the process of expanding the subscription base of its main sponsor, America Online (which paid some $17 million for the privilege), to 250,000 in Brazil from 70,000.
"Companies need to take responsibility for society and stop thinking that the governments alone can solve the social deficit, because the governments aren't," he said. "This is the task for the citizen and for private enterprise, and that's what this festival is trying to do. Corporations could sell more Coke at a higher price if they adhere to the philosophy that there's no better publicity than for them to engage in something that's serious and furthers progress."
Convinced that entertainment can be a more powerful tool of persuasion or change than advertising or politics, Mr. Medina plans to expand his franchise of socially conscious festivals into North America, the rest of Latin America and even Africa in the coming years.
The theme of Rock in Rio III was "a better world." Many who were hired to work at the event even had to write essays on their applications describing their vision of that better world. But for those in the audience, "a better world" was just another marketing slogan, swallowed in the sea of logos displayed all over the grounds on behalf of the festival's 15 sponsors. Unlike, say, the Beastie Boys's Tibetan Freedom Concerts, where speakers lecture the audience between acts, Rock in Rio III made little attempt to enlighten ticket buyers beyond sponsoring a small tent for speeches, discussions and presentations. 
"I said to Roberto Medina, 'Do you know the world outside your stain-glassed house?' " said Jose Junior, who leads Banda Afro Reggae, a collective of socially minded batucada, capoeira, funk and hip-hop performers who played at the festival. "Then I told him about the violence and poverty of the favelas," or slums. "The next day, his girlfriend came up and said, 'Who's Junior?' Then she told me that the night after Medina and I talked, he couldn't sleep."
Over all, this was simply an opportunity to see some of Brazil's most established acts share a stage (reputed to be the largest ever built for such a festival) with pop stars from around the world, many of whom had never performed in Brazil before. (The Who and Pearl Jam were the only bands Mr. Medina said he wanted to book but could not.)
The crowning moment of Rock in Rio III was the return of Axl Rose and the large-stage debut of his new-model, high-pressure Guns 'n' Roses, which adeptly tore through songs old and new in a show that was, more or less, seven years in the making. The other jaw-dropper was Neil Young's Brazilian debut, which followed a standard-issue Sheryl Crow performance and an oddly short set by the Dave Matthews Band. 
The audience watched in relative silence for the first few minutes of Mr. Young's performance. The crowd was unaccustomed to his huddled electric jams with his band, to the sight of a man whose power emanates from his back as he plays, and to the dictum that, no matter how long its recorded equivalent may be, a song isn't over onstage until Mr. Young says it's over. But by the end of "Hey Hey, My My (Into the Black)," the audience began to cheer with every solo and clap along to songs that were never meant to be clapped along to. 
In a performance loaded with live favorites like "Rockin' in the Free World" and "Cinnamon Girl," "Like a Hurricane" stole the show when Mr. Young broke a guitar string and, instead of bravely finishing the song with a handicap like most performers, turned disaster to advantage. After a frenzy of inspired feedback and improvisation, he let the guitar hang parallel to his leg and, as he sang, slapped the fretboard with the end of the broken string, creating a moody, ambient version of the song.
For both popular and little-known musicians, a debut show in a new country can be crucial: a strong performance that leaves audience members rushing to record stores and raving to their friends can open a whole new continent for future tours, which is one reason two of the most enthusiastically received concerts at Rock in Rio III were by veterans of South American tours, Iron Maiden and the Red Hot Chili Peppers. 
At this festival, Queens of the Stone Age, a rock band almost unknown in Brazil, became stars overnight, but not just because of the show. When Nick Oliveri, the bassist, appeared onstage nude, a judge who was watching ordered the police to arrest him. A festival lawyer on the site was able to explain that Mr. Oliveri, having heard so much about Bacchanalian Brazilian carnival, thought nudity was acceptable in the country. He was released on the spot, only to see his photograph alongside that of Britney Spears on the front page of local papers the following day.
By contrast, Ms. Spears didn't seem to be winning new fans during her first Brazilian performance on the teen-pop night of the festival. 
It wasn't so much her overly slick presentation and long breaks for costume changes, or her over-rehearsed stage patter and camera-ready smiles. It wasn't even the clear evidence of lip-synching. (When she touched the microphone of her headset during a song, it didn't make a sound; but when she touched it as she was preparing to talk to the audience, it crackled loudly.) It was the overall coldness and detachment of a show in which Ms. Spears was unable or unwilling to create the illusion that is at the heart of almost every pop concert: that this is a special show for a special audience. 
Where rock acts like Guns 'n' Roses sought favor from the crowd by bringing out a samba school during their encore, Ms. Spears made little effort (which was probably better than Aaron Carter's committing the faux pas of thanking the Portuguese-speaking audience in Spanish at the end of his set). When films of American flags were shown onstage as Ms. Spears and her dancers cavorted in white outfits modeled on United States Navy uniforms, the audience hissed and then began chanting, "Brazil." (By contrast, when Mr. Young improvised on "The Star-Spangled Banner" in the coda to "Rockin' in the Free World," the crowd applauded.)
Asked what she thought of Ms. Spears's performance, Priscilla Alves de Franca, 17, put a finger to the tip of her nose and pushed her nose upward. "Stuck up," she said, as her friends nodded assent. 
It certainly didn't help much when, technicians working on the show said, Ms. Spears's headset microphone was accidentally left on during a costume change and her cuss-filled tantrum was heard by those watching the live broadcast. (The excerpt is already on Napster for those interested in hearing Ms. Spears's unscripted concert monologues.)
Though 'N Sync (whose late show kept fans awake until after 3 a.m.) delivered a much warmer, more relaxed, Brazilian flag-waving set, the pinnacle of the evening was Sandy and Junior, a squeaky-clean Brazilian teenage brother-and-sister team. Tears streamed from the eyes of 8- to 15-year-old fans as they passionately sung along with every word.
Often the pair would have to deliver only the first syllable of a couplet before the children in the crowd, who have grown up with Sandy and Junior, would fill in the rest. It was also interesting to watch the dynamic between the siblings, because, unless he grows up to become a heartthrob on the order of Ricky Martin, Junior, whose talents and charisma were far eclipsed by his sister's, seems like a VH-1 "Behind the Music" debacle in the making.
Many of the highlights of the festival's final weekend occurred on the smaller Brazilian and roots-music stages. As Ms. Spears and 'N Sync demonstrated America's latest pop export, the Brazilian band Funk N Lata was looking to performers from the more creative American past, namely James Brown, and combining the music with an 11-man bateria. 
Dancers in the wings pumped up their muscles with hundreds of push-ups before emerging on stage in a high-energy show best described as guarana funk. Also notable on the smaller stages, Tom Ze closed his strong set by using a welding torch as an instrument and light show; and the blind Malian couple Amadou and Mariam had the crowd singing along in French to their sweet, upbeat, Cuban-influenced brand of African blues .
Mr. Medina said he expected to stage Rock in Rio IV at the same site in 2003.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS, KATHLEEN CARROLL, KAREN W. ARENSON, MICHAEL POLLAK and MERRI ROSENBERG

 BODY:
The Chancellor at Play
 Who was that man belly-flopping through the new snow on the 116th Street hill in Riverside Park on Sunday? None other than HAROLD O. LEVY, the city schools chancellor, turning the heads of passers-by. Mr. Levy was out romping with his two children. As they steered their plastic sled, Mr. Levy hitched a ride, gripping the back of the sled with one hand and his white baseball cap with the other as he hurtled down the hill on his stomach. 

Studying Governance
New York University's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service is opening the Center for Excellence in New York City Governance. The school's dean, DR. JO IVEY BOUFFORD, a former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said the center's mandate was to "strengthen public policy and public service." ARTHUR FRIED, a longtime city official who was most recently general counsel of the Social Security Administration, was named executive director. The center will hold its first event, on the city's election machinery, on Jan. 30.

Columbia Courses Online
Columbia University is unveiling the first courses in its online continuing education program: information technology and American business writing courses for nonnative English speakers. The courses were developed in partnership with Cognitive Arts, an educational software company headed by ROGER SCHANK. Columbia and Cognitive Arts are working on adding liberal arts courses like psychology and economics. DAVID H. COHEN, vice president for arts and sciences at Columbia, said other courses would be developed more slowly than had been expected before the plunge in Internet stocks. The online courses can be reached at www.as.columbia.edu.

A New Charter School
CDCH Charter School, a new school for mainstream and learning-disabled children, opened this month with more than 20 children age 5 to 11 on the grounds of the East Hampton Indoor Tennis Club in Wainscott. Its founder, DAWN ZIMMERMAN, is raising $3 million for a permanent school at the Town Industrial Park in Wainscott, and plans to add a grade a year up to 12th grade.
The charter school arose from the Child Development Center of the Hamptons, a three-year-old preschool founded by Ms. Zimmerman that serves mainstream and disabled children. 

Support for Writing
Barnard College's writing fellows program, which trains talented undergraduates to coach their classmates in producing more polished prose, recently got a boost from two alumnae.
ANNA QUINDLEN, a former reporter, editor and Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist at The New York Times who now writes novels and a Newsweek column, has donated $100,000. And CHERYL SHAFFER GREENE, a managing partner at Deutsch, an advertising agency, gave $50,000. "I owe Barnard a debt I can never repay, but I am bound and determined to try," Ms. Quindlen said. 
 ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS, KATHLEEN CARROLL, KAREN W. ARENSON, MICHAEL POLLAK and MERRI ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
EMC Results Beat Wall Street Expectations in Fourth Quarter

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The economy may be slowing, but businesses are not cutting back spending on data storage, according to the EMC Corporation, which reported fourth-quarter revenue and profit yesterday that slightly exceeded Wall Street's expectations. 
 EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., said revenue for the last quarter of 2000 jumped 40 percent, to $2.62 billion, from $1.88 billion a year earlier. 
 The quarter completed a year in which the rate of revenue growth accelerated as the year progressed, resulting in a 32 percent gain for the entire year to $8.87 billion. EMC told analysts that it remained confident of hitting its previously announced goal of $12 billion in revenue this year along with Wall Street's current earnings projections. 
Michael C. Ruettgers, the chairman of EMC, said the quarter had reinforced EMC's view that information was being created so rapidly in the networked economy and was so essential to competitiveness that demand for intelligent data storage systems was bound to remain strong. 
EMC reported that earnings jumped to $563 million in the last quarter of 2000, up 49 percent from $377 million in 1999, excluding a charge against 1999 earnings related to acquisitions. Earnings per share rose 47 percent, to 25 cents a share, from 17 cents a share a year earlier, excluding a charge of 8 cents a share in 1999 related to the acquisitions. 
International storage revenue grew 67 percent in the quarter, led by a 134 percent increase in the Asia/Pacific region. 
EMC also expanded its market-leading position during the quarter. The company's shares, which rose faster than any other stock on the New York Stock Exchange during the 1990's, rose $3.03 yesterday to $79.56. They are up about 20 percent this year, although still well below last September's peak of $104.94.
"EMC and storage are clearly islands in the storm," said Thomas Kraemer, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Mr. Kraemer said storage companies, and particularly EMC, were adding so much software to their systems that they were becoming the intelligent hub of corporate computer systems. As a result, spending on storage systems is taking a larger piece of the information technology pie and hurting the prospects of companies that rely heavily on computer sales, he said.
In EMC's case, the increasing role of software in its sales mix helped lift gross margins to 59.2 percent in the fourth quarter, up from 55.1 percent a year ago. William J. Teuber, the chief financial officer, said EMC expected revenue from storage systems to grow in the mid-30's percent range this year. Revenue from services like helping customers put together storage networks is projected to grow at almost 50 percent and software revenue to grow at more than 50 percent.
But EMC suggested that profit margins might decline slightly because it planned to keep up its practice of cutting prices to expand markets and increase its market share.

HEADLINE: Penney Closing Raises Fear For White Plains Economy 

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
J. C. Penney plans to close its department store at the Galleria mall here, raising fears among city officials about the business district's economic outlook just as the city is trying to encourage a downtown revival.
 J. C. Penney, which has 1,100 stores in the United States, said it would shut some 50 of its stores in the next six months after reporting operating losses in three of the last four quarters. 
 The White Plains closing, scheduled for April 28, would mean the loss of 235 jobs, said a Penney spokesman, Tim Lyons. A store in Ithaca, N.Y., is also scheduled to close. 
The management of the 20-year-old Galleria, at 100 Main Street, which functions as a more affordable alternative to the newer Westchester Mall here, said it was already reaching out to potential successors and expressed optimism at the prospect of leasing the 217,000-square-foot space Penney is leaving.
Winnette B. Peltz, the mall's general manager, pointed out that H&M, a Swedish apparel store, was set to open a 23,000-square-foot outpost at the mall in the spring.
But for officials in White Plains, Westchester's county seat, the Penney news represented a serious setback. Two blocks from the Galleria is a boarded-up former Macy's that has been empty for five years, sapping the energy from the heart of the downtown.
The city is still reeling from the recent withdrawal of a proposal by Tishman-Speyer, a real estate developer, to build a 21-screen Loews movie theater and shopping center at that site, a project that was to be the linchpin of its revitalization efforts.
"I was just so taken aback," said Mayor Joseph M. Delfino, who learned of the decision on Monday in a letter Penney sent to City Hall after it quietly notified sales clerks at the store on Friday.
"What's troublesome to me is that I never received a phone call from them as chief executive officer of the city of White Plains to advise me that they were going to consider closing the store," he said.
Today, Mayor Delfino called the company's headquarters in Plano, Tex., to try to persuade officials that positive things were happening in White Plains and that they should reconsider. But he was unable to reach any officials connected with the decision.
In the last three years, the office vacancy rate in White Plains has dropped to 14 percent from 34 percent, and the city recently approved 1,000 units of market-rate housing to be built within four blocks of the Galleria, he said. 
Mayor Delfino and others seemed particularly surprised because they were under the impression that the Penney store had strong sales. But Mr. Lyons said the stores chosen for closing were "unprofitable or were marginally profitable," though he declined to discuss the specific considerations here.
Today customers expressed dismay at the demise of a moderate-price store they frequented for clothes and housewares and worried what it might portend for the mall. 
"I'm very disappointed," said Clayton Byrne of Chappaqua, a lawyer here who visits Penney's to look for clothes for her grown sons. "Their prices are very good. I think it will hurt the mall terribly -- it's one of the anchor stores."
Some real estate brokers familiar with the county's retail landscape speculated that the Galleria might entice a chain like Target Stores, which was to be part of the Tishman-Speyer complex at the former Macy's site.

HEADLINE: With Private Help, A New Public School; 
Niagara Falls Turns to Honeywell

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. 

 BODY:
There is something phoenixlike about it, the glassy modernist building that lights up electric blue at night over this depressed city of incessantly gray snowy streets, vacant storefronts and abandoned chemical plants.
 Visible from almost anywhere in the city, it is the new Niagara Falls High School. Visitors come to see its Broadway-caliber theater, the sunlight shooting through the glass walls of the library like water over the falls, the students plugging their free laptop computers into hundreds of stations in classrooms, labs, even the cafeteria. 
 But mostly, they come to hear how it was done: in an unusual public-private partnership, Honeywell Inc. raised money on Wall Street and put up the $83 million school for the city to lease, allowing the city to avoid any increase in taxes or debt. And with exemptions from state laws, Honeywell was able to build the school for less than it would have cost the school district. 
For years, school construction has been one of the most contentious issues in the politics of education. Saying that the country's school buildings were "nothing less than a national embarrassment," the Clinton administration pushed for federal aid to build new schools, only to be blocked by Republicans who were skeptical of the idea that gleaming classrooms are necessary to a good education or who said the federal government should leave building to local communities.
But locally, school districts have not been able to get support for building, either. Nationwide, just 25 percent of the population has children of school age. Even in well-off suburban communities where pride in the schools runs high, empty nesters and those without children have repeatedly shot down bond issues to build new schools.
Niagara Falls offers a compromise, a conservative approach to a liberal issue. For school officials who have come to visit here, it offers a vision of the future.
Privatization has come to almost everything else in education, with school districts contracting out everything from custodial services to college guidance and even the operation of entire schools. Many school officials say it only makes sense that they should look to the private sector for their buildings as well. As Carmen A. Granto, the superintendent of schools here, says: "Our core business is teaching. We ought to stick to that core."
In New York City, a private group called the Schoolhouse Foundation has raised $200 million from private bond issues to build schools on a financial model resembling the one used here. Other cities in New York, including Buffalo, Ithaca and Corning, are also considering similar plans as they look to build new schools. 
David Erik Chase, the head of the Hillier Group, the country's third-largest architecture firm and the one that designed the Niagara Falls school, says he is talking to schools in Texas, Virginia and Washington, D.C., about such projects. "We feel we're on the forefront of a real crest of opportunity," he said.
The strategy is not without critics, or perils. Some fear that developers, eager for cheap land or good public relations, will offer to build schools but skimp on quality. With the school day already woven with commercial messages -- billboards on buses, soda machines in hallways -- others worry that all this will lead to Coca-Cola High Schools across the country. 
"There are significant questions that need to be asked," said Paul Abramson, president of Intelligence for Education, a consulting company in Westchester, and editorial director of School Planning and Managing magazine. "We need to measure in terms of quality and not just cost."
Private money becomes particularly tempting as demand rises and public support falls.
Most of the country's schools were built either for the last baby boom, in the 1950's and 1960's or earlier, and a third of those have not been renovated since 1980. Those baby boomers produced a baby boomlet that has sent public school enrollments to their highest level ever, with the increase expected to continue for the next five years. The General Accounting Office in 1999 estimated the cost of renovating the nation's schools at $112 billion; some people call that figure conservative, and it does not include upgrading classrooms for Internet access, which would cost about $100 billion more.
Five years ago, Niagara Falls had two aging high schools. In the older one, plastic bags collected rainwater in the hallways. The roof was lined with asbestos and leaked into the gym, giving Niagara Falls what the superintendent called the dubious distinction of having "the only high school in New York State to cancel basketball games because of rain."
A city that needs a new school normally goes to the voters for permission to issue a 30-year bond to pay for it. Cities can issue a 10-year bond without a vote, but Niagara Falls was too broke, as the superintendent bluntly said, to afford the interest payments.
The school board knew it would not get support from the community. Residents could not afford higher taxes; average per capita income is $10,500, and 63 percent of students, Mr. Granto said, are on public assistance. The industrial tax base the city once had has declined as chemical and other companies moved away.
When Don J. King, the president of the school board, first joined the board 23 years ago, there were 50,000 industry jobs, and Niagara Falls had the highest concentration of chemical plants in the nation. Now, he said, there are 6,000. "Realistically, the only way we could do this was to privatize it," Mr. King said.
Mr. Granto, whose coffee table reading in his small neat office includes a book titled "The $163 Lightbulb: How Albany Mandates Drive Up Your Local Taxes," approached the building division of Honeywell, which is based in Minneapolis. The company had provided boilers and other equipment to the district on a performance-based contract; the company promised the district that if it bought the new, more efficient boilers, it would be able to pay for them with the money it saved in energy costs.
Mr. Granto wondered why the district could not lease an entire school provided by Honeywell.
Honeywell agreed to build the new school and lease it back to the district. The company would not pay for the school, however. It issued certificates of participation, which are similar to government bonds, and sold them on the private market through J. P. Morgan, using connections no school district would have.
The district had to seek exemptions from the Legislature on several state laws: it was allowed to build the school without choosing the lowest bidder, it was allowed to issue the certificates, and perhaps most important, the district did not have to build according to the Wicks Law, which requires at least four contractors for any public works project. To win labor leaders' support for that exemption, Honeywell used only union labor.
The state reimburses districts for new school buildings depending on their relative wealth. In the case of Niagara Falls, the reimbursement rate was 83 percent of the cost. (The city raised the other 17 percent from sales of the two old school buildings.) The 83 percent goes directly to the certificate holders through lease payments for 30 years, so the certificate holders' investment, with a 6.5 percent interest rate on a tax-exempt bond, is secure. After 30 years, the building reverts to the city.
For Honeywell, the benefit was a chance to showcase its technology, and to earn a developer's fee of $5 million.
The private financing was crucial, officials say, but so were the exemptions from traditional building rules. "They were able to get a lot more into their building because of the Wicks Law exemption," said Charles A. Szuberla, coordinator of facilities for the State Education Department. The school district estimates that it saved $15 million by using one contractor.
The building hardly looks as if it was built with bargain material. The architect tried to infuse the school with the spirit of the nearby falls, with the blue of the outside stone suggesting the water and the staircases that jut out at inverted angles suggesting the flow of the rapids.
There are four wings -- math and science, the arts, health and sports, and business education -- surrounding a glass dome that houses the library and technology center. Classrooms have small side rooms to which teachers can take students for conferences or extra help. The ceilings in the art studios soar two stories, allowing students to create large projects.
There are computer ports in every classroom and along the bar that curves around the cafeteria. In the old schools, there was so little space for athletics that players would spread out to elementary schools and other sites to practice. In the new Niagara Falls High School, there are two gyms, including one with a running track. The bright primary colors of the school -- a different one for each of the four floors -- are modeled on the work of the Dutch artist Piet Mondrian, with terrazzo floors instead of the usual vinyl providing the bursts of color. 
"Remember," Mr. King said several times during a tour, "this is Niagara Falls."
The school doubles as a community center now.
New laptops were leased for all 2,400 students, another benefit of the savings. Black computer bags have become a status symbol -- something even the suburban kids do not have. "You feel privileged. For once, we're the cool ones," said Jessica Sullivan, 15, a sophomore. "Kids like coming to school now. They have something to look forward to."
To those who say that sparkling schools will not make a difference in what students learn, Mr. Granto said he fully expected achievement to rise. The students agreed.
"It took all the excuses out of school," said Rachel Rafferty, 16, a junior. "Before, you could complain that everything's out of shape, it's broken. Now everything works. If you don't succeed, it's because you aren't doing something, it's not because of resources."

HEADLINE: Whitman Seeks to Boost Fiscal Legacy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
Gov. Christie Whitman unveiled a $23.2 billion spending plan today that incorporates two major proposals of her soon-to-be successor, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco: a doubling of the property tax rebate checks for New Jersey homeowners and a new prescription drug benefit for the middle-income elderly.
 In her last budget address to the Legislature, Mrs. Whitman, who is expected to leave office by the end of the month if she is confirmed as administrator of the federal Environmental Protection Agency, offered a host of her own modest initiatives, among them a tax credit to promote inner-city redevelopment and a $1-an-hour raise for workers who care for the disabled. 
 With an eye to her legacy, Mrs. Whitman sought to shore up her reputation as a fiscal steward by playing down the state's soaring debt burden and setting aside a record $1 billion cash reserve. She also set aside $25 million for measures to help end racial profiling by state and local police officers, another sore point for her administration. 
But the measures most likely to be enacted by the Legislature are Mr. DiFrancesco's, not Mrs. Whitman's -- a fact she acknowledged by including two of his top priorities: a doubling of the New Jersey Saver property-tax rebate, to an average of $480 per homeowner, and his Senior Gold proposal to cover the costs of prescription drugs for middle-class elderly and disabled people. The state already covers prescription drug costs for the poor.
Mr. DiFrancesco welcomed those items and called Mrs. Whitman's spending plan "a good framework to begin the budget process." But he said he was disappointed by the omission of a third item on his agenda as a leading Republican candidate in this year's election for a full term as governor: an increase in the maximum Homestead Rebate check for elderly and disabled residents, to $750 from $500.
As acting governor once Mrs. Whitman resigns, Mr. DiFrancesco will be free to discard her proposals and add his own. And he has already outlined more than $200 million that he wants to spend for other items including water quality improvements and aid to hospitals. Today, Mr. DiFrancesco said he could not yet name a proposal of Mrs. Whitman's that he would delete -- he was careful to say he had learned of many of them today for the first time -- though he reiterated that he was not wedded to her call for setting aside $1 billion as a reserve in the new budget.
In an interview, Mr. DiFrancesco said that once he was sworn in as acting governor, he planned to deliver a major address to the Legislature, perhaps on Feb. 5, outlining his own legislative and budgetary priorities.
The economic forecast that underlies state revenue projections is unlikely to change between now and then, however. And Treasury officials warned today about slowing growth in the New Jersey economy.
A strong sell-off in the stock market last year caused a 66 percent increase in capital gains by New Jersey investors, an "all-time high," said Treasurer Roland Machold. As a result, he said, overall state income tax revenues are expected to increase by $1.1 billion in the current fiscal year, ending June 30. But income taxes are expected to rise by only $606 million in the following fiscal year, Mr. Machold said.
Still, Mr. Machold said fears of a recession were unfounded. And in any case, he said, the state will be well prepared: the new budget assumes that a $1.3 billion surplus will remain at the end of the current fiscal year, and that revenues will rise by another $1.4 billion in the next. And it calls for a $1 billion cash reserve as a safety net.
In her speech to lawmakers today, Governor Whitman took pains to defend herself against what is likely to be the most lasting criticism of her record as a fiscal manager: the soaring debt burden of the state government. Since she took office, the state debt has more than doubled, rising from $7.2 billion in 1994 to $17.4 billion this fiscal year. By June 2002, officials said today, the debt will reach $18.8 billion, and required annual debt payments will reach $1.7 billion.
"Yes, we have increased our debt," Mrs. Whitman said. But then she rattled off the reasons for new borrowings: "saving land, building schools, fixing bridges, dredging our ports and building prisons." She said that each major borrowing had been approved by bipartisan votes of the Legislature or in ballot referendums, and that the state's credit rating had been repeatedly upgraded.
"You've heard the critics, but those who know best say that we're in sound financial health," Mrs. Whitman said.
Addressing racial profiling, the governor called for $25 million to recruit more minority and female state troopers, upgrade computers used to track the performance of the state police and install video cameras in municipal police cars across the state.
"New Jersey is not the only state where racial profiling exists, but it will be the first state where it ends," she said.
Her other budget proposals included some that were previously announced, like $200 million for a variety of programs to promote New Jersey's high-tech industries. She proposed modest spending increases for farmland preservation, water quality and watershed management programs, and crime prevention programs in the cities.
But Mrs. Whitman, who is all but certain to be the nation's new top environmental official, also unveiled a new "smart-growth" initiative: $10 million in tax credits to promote development projects in cities rather than in the sprawling suburbs. Officials said that builders are frequently deterred from choosing inner-city sites because the costs for upgrading sewer or water pipes or other infrastructure elements mean lower profits. Tax credits up to $1 million apiece for such investments will help steer more projects to the cities, they said.
Mr. DiFrancesco called the tax credit "a neat idea," but did not commit to retaining it in the budget.
The governor also set aside $3 million to help Salem and Sussex Counties replace punch cards with modern voting machines before the November election.
Democrats were not charitable to the departing governor or her successor, however.
State Senator Richard J. Codey, the minority leader, said that the state debt was closing in on $20 billion because of what he called Mrs. Whitman's "excessive" borrowing. "That's a lot of legacy," he said.
He recalled that Democrats had spoken out against Mrs. Whitman's penchant for borrowing as early as 1995. "Little did we know it would take six more years and another $14 billion in borrowing before she'd get out of town," Mr. Codey said.
And Senator Wayne R. Bryant, Democrat of Camden, alluded to Mr. DiFrancesco's candidacy in warning against a "frenzy of election-year spending."
Indeed, the governor's speech ended on a note reminiscent of a campaign endorsement as Mrs. Whitman praised Mr. DiFrancesco. She also cited Jack Collins, the Assembly speaker.
"Should I earn Senate confirmation, I will not only leave a balanced budget that builds on our accomplishments but also leave the governorship in the able hands of a proven leader, Don DiFrancesco," Mrs. Whitman said. "Thank you, Don. Thank you, Jack. Thank you, citizens of New Jersey."

HIGHLIGHTS
Tax Rebates, High-Tech and Caretakers

MAJOR SPENDING PROGRAMS

$300 million to double the property tax rebate for homeowners to about $480 on average. About 1.7 million people will receive checks in September. Proposed by Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco.

$200 million to promote and develop New Jersey's high-tech industries.

$56.4 million for a $1-an-hour raise for caretakers for the disabled, raising annual salaries to an average of $20,000 from $18,000.

$50 million to expand prescription drug coverage to middle-income elderly and disabled people. Proposed by Mr. DiFrancesco.

$29 million for teacher preparation, recruitment bonuses and mentoring for new teachers.

$25 million to recruit minority and female state troopers and install video cameras in municipal police cars.

NEW TAX CUTS

Smart-growth infrastructure: Tax credit for investments in infrastructure in selected cities. Up to $1 million per investor. Total of $10 million budgeted.

Small business: Tax credit for equipment that helps small businesses hire people with disabilities. Match of a federal tax credit, up to $5,125 per business. Total of $500,000 budgeted.

Small business: Elimination of the corporation business tax for first-year businesses with less than $100,000 in income and less than $10 million in assets. Total of $1 million budgeted.

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
Fearful of a Recession? Stop Hugging Trees, Start Collecting Bills

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

 BODY:
As the economy slows, some economists are openly uttering the R word for the first time in years. Though a recession is far from a certainty, Americans might do well to check out what happened to their profession during and after the last one for clues about what might lie ahead. 
 In that recession of 1990-91, jobs that were closely tied to economic expansion were hard hit. For example, almost every corner of the construction industry, from hardhats to civil engineers who oversee their work to interior designers, registered double-digit declines. So, too, did occupations that were already being transformed by new technologies, like word processing. 
 The fastest expanding job sector was computer technology. That was not unexpected, according to Mark Zandi, chief economist of Economy.com. "Companies use recessions as an opportunity to raise productivity by bringing in technology," he said. "In the last recession, pink collar workers -- people in call centers and back offices who are most vulnerable to having their jobs automated -- fared poorly. The same thing could happen in any potential downturn," Mr. Zandi said.
 Others who did well were workers who specialize in controlling costs and collecting bad debts, as well as entertainers and athletes who helped take people's minds off their troubles. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

MANHATTAN: MORE SMOKING CURBS -- Moving to strengthen rules against smoking, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone is to introduce legislation today to ban smoking in the bar areas of restaurants. The city's six-year-old smoking law allows smoking in bars that are six feet away from dining areas, while Mr. Vallone's proposal would confine it to separate designated rooms, or to limited outdoor seating. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

GREENVALE: JOCKEY'S WIFE KILLED -- The Nassau County police are investigating the hit-and-run death of Marjorie Cordero, the wife of the jockey Angel Cordero, left. Mrs. Cordero, 41, was hit by a speeding car as she crossed the southbound lanes of Glen Cove Road, near the Greenvale railroad station, about 9:45 p.m. Monday, said Detective Sergeant William Cocks. He said the front end of the black Ford that hit her would have been damaged.There were no witnesses. Al Baker (NYT)

ALBANY: NEW SCHOOL PLAN URGED -- The Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the group that won a landmark court decision ordering the state to revise its education financing system to provide more money to New York City schools, called yesterday for an expert panel of educators and economists to determine what a "sound, basic education" should cost across the state. Gov. George E. Pataki plans to appeal the decision, which scrapped the state's complex school aid formula, and the appeal could take more than a year. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

RIVERHEAD: COUNTY OFFICIAL SENTENCED -- The former chief mechanic of the Suffolk County Sheriff's Department, who pleaded guilty to corruption, was sentenced to a year in jail yesterday. The former mechanic, Robert Davis, 52, of Calverton, was sentenced after he admitted that he stole cash and surplus military equipment and submitted false vouchers for auto parts and services that were never performed. Mr. Davis also pleaded guilty to 18 counts of official misconduct. Tina Kelley (NYT)

BROOKLYN: TEACHER ACCUSED OF ABUSE -- A high school teacher was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually abused a 15-year-old girl repeatedly over a period of time, the police said. The teacher, Randall Lieberman, 34, of 75th Street in Bensonhurst, was charged with third-degree sexual abuse, a misdemeanor involving sexual contact with an underage person, the police said. Mr. Lieberman teaches at Lafayette High School in Gravesend, though the abuse did not occur inside a school, said Officer Guy Braun, a police spokesman. Andy Newman (NYT)

LIBERTY: SUIT OVER POSSIBLE CARCINOGEN -- About 100 residents of Liberty, in Sullivan County, have filed a lawsuit against the village and two gas stations owned by Exxon Mobil that they say were responsible for contaminating the village's water supply with a possible carcinogen. The substance is methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., a gasoline additive that is a possible cause of cancer. Maria Newman (NYT)

CONNECTICUT

WATERBURY: CITY EXTENDS DEADLINE -- Nine days before a deadline that would have allowed the state to take over Waterbury's troubled finances, the Board of Aldermen announced Monday night that it would extend the deadline by one month. The extension will give state legislators time to consider the city's request to pay off its $50 million deficit over 10 years rather than the 2 years required by state law. The city finance director, Richard Russo, presented a plan that includes borrowing $86 million this spring and raising $212 million through grants, tax increases and cost-cutting over the next three years. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

HARTFORD: TRIBAL ACTION CRITICIZED -- Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has asked the Bush administration to overturn a decision, made on President Clinton's last day in office, granting the Nipmucs preliminary federal recognition as a tribe. Mr. Blumenthal said the Bureau of Indian Affairs's decision is "the latest event in a series of actions that calls into question the B.I.A.'s credibility and fairness." Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

NEW JERSEY

CAMDEN: DISGRACED MAYOR SENDS LETTER -- In a letter from prison meant for publication, former Mayor Milton Milan criticized Camden's Hispanics for not standing up for him during his recent trial. "I just want you to know that I do not hate the people who testified against me falsely," he wrote to a friend, Angel Cordero, a convicted drug dealer, from federal prison in Cumberland County. "I pray for them. I also pray for the people who kept silent when they should have spoken." The letter was printed yesterday in The Camden Courier-Post. Mr. Milan was convicted of bribery and money laundering. Iver Peterson (NYT)

EAST ORANGE: OFFICER WOUNDS MAN -- An off-duty police officer shot and wounded a man who the authorities said tried to rob him at a gas station Monday night. The man, Rahjn Kalin, also known as Jeffrey Morton, was in stable condition yesterday at University Hospital in Newark, shot in the stomach and left leg, a hospital spokesman said. The officer, William Rowe, had just bought gas at a station on Central Avenue when Mr. Kalin approached him with a 10-inch knife, the police said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

HEADLINE: Shopping Perks Up, Defying Worries of aSlowing Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
After the slowest holiday shopping season in a decade, Americans seem to have cautiously reopened their wallets in the early weeks of 2001, spending more than either executives or analysts had predicted.
 General Motors said last week that its January sales were unexpectedly strong, and DaimlerChrysler has canceled plans to shut two plants temporarily this month, citing consumer demand. After falling rapidly in December, mortgage applications for home purchases have bounced back and are again near their record high, the Mortgage Bankers Association said. Spending in restaurants and for compact discs and videos has grown more this month than it did in December, based on Visa USA's tracking of credit card sales. 
 Almost all of the nation's major retailers -- including J. C. Penney, Kmart, Sears, Roebuck and Target -- have sold more goods in the last three weeks than they had planned. Over all, sales at major chain stores are likely to rise almost 4 percent this month compared with January 2000, according to the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, which publishes a weekly retail index. In December, sales at existing stories grew just 0.7 percent. 
Despite the signs of improvement, there is little doubt that spending has slowed since the middle of last year. January sales, of course, are now exceeding goals that were sharply lowered in the final months of 2000, as energy costs rose, most stocks fell and the economy soured.
But the raft of mildly encouraging consumer data suggests the economy has not entered a free fall. The numbers also add weight to the argument -- still being made by a majority of economists -- that the United States is more likely than not to avoid a recession this year. Corporate profits may decline and investment spending flatten out, but a tight labor market and falling interest rates should keep consumers flush enough to extend the decade-long expansion, these economists say.
"The economy has clearly softened," said J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., president of the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank, in a speech last week. "For all the current media and public focus on the economy's softening, though, it is not at all clear at this point that the economy as a whole is slowing really precipitously."
Analysts caution, however, that the January data covers a short period of time during the least busy shopping month of the year. The pickup could reflect the weather as much as anything else, as a series of storms in December kept people at home and caused them to delay some purchases, analysts said. 
Even if consumer spending -- responsible for about two-thirds of the economy -- continues to recover from its late 2000 malaise, risks of a recession remain. Corporate inventories have been building lately, suggesting that companies may need to slow their production and lay off workers in the coming months. Many companies are slowing their investments in equipment and computers, after years of heavy spending. And the world's oil cartel, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, announced a cut in production last week in an effort to raise prices.
But most Americans remain optimistic about the economy, even if they are no longer as giddy as they were in 1999 and 2000. In mid-January, 67 percent of people surveyed by the Gallup Poll described economic conditions as excellent or good, down from 74 percent in August, but still higher than at any point between 1992 and 1998.
More people think the economy is getting worse than see it as improving, but 63 percent of Americans expect to be better off a year from now than they are today, according to the poll. 
"I think that we are on a decline," said Julie DeMent, a 23-year-old student and part-time waitress, who was walking through a shopping district near Rice University in Houston last weekend. But, she said, "I don't think we're actually headed for a recession." 
Ms. DeMent has recently tried to save money on energy costs by sharing a ride to the community college where she is studying electrical engineering and by using her air-conditioner and heater less often. She also said she had cut back on holiday spending but was optimistic because she would eventually have a degree in engineering.
Economists said the Federal Reserve's surprise cut in interest rates on Jan. 3, the stock market rally that followed, the still-low unemployment rate and even the end of the uncertainty over the presidential election could all be making people less worried than a few weeks ago. 
Since the start of the year, the Nasdaq composite index has gained 24 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average have both risen modestly. At the same time, the most recent employment report from the government showed hourly wages accelerating in the second half of 2000, as unemployment hovered around 4 percent.
"People are still employed; they're still making pretty good money," said Frank A. Ursomarso, the president of Union Park Automotive, which owns seven car dealerships in Wilmington, Del. And, Mr. Ursomarso said, lower interest rates had made his cars less expensive in recent weeks. He can charge less because his own interest payments on unsold cars have fallen slightly, and customers' finance payments are now smaller than they were.
During the first two weeks of 2001, Union Park sold 121 vehicles, up from 105 during the corresponding period of last year. In November and December, by contrast, fewer people were walking into Union Park's showrooms to look at Hondas, Fords and BMW's, and sales dropped 4 percent -- or by 21 vehicles -- compared with the previous year. 
The widespread discounts being offered by the Big Three carmakers are also keeping sales from falling further than they did at the end of last year, said Ben Hollingsworth, the chairman of Group 1 Automotive, which owns 55 dealerships in the South and in Massachusetts. Many buyers can choose among making no down payment, delaying monthly payments or getting a rebate of $1,000 to $3,000, he said
In fact, "sale" signs have popped up in stores of almost all kinds, as merchants have scrambled to unload goods that they had expected to sell during the holidays. The discounts are helping to convince shoppers to make purchases but are unlikely to bring much good news for retailers.
"They may not make any money, but they're going to report big sales levels," said C. Britt Beemer, the chairman of America's Research Group, a consulting and polling firm in Charleston, S.C. This January, for example, only about one out of every two consumers who buys a discounted item is also buying a product that is not on sale, Mr. Beemer said. Last year, the ratio was one in three.
At the Target Corporation, which also owns Mervyn's and Marshall Field's, sales in stores that have been open for at least a year are up 3 percent to 4 percent this month, according to Goldman, Sachs. Target had been expecting a gain of about 2 percent.
Still, Susan Kahn, a company spokeswoman, said, "I wouldn't call January some outstanding month."
If the increases in sales are mainly a reflection of the discounts, consumer spending could start to disappoint retailers as soon as Presidents' Day weekend, the next major shopping period, analysts said.
"It's certainly hard to believe that people abandoned their prior gloom and went charging out to the shops," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. 
Skeptics also point to the unusual nature of both December 1999 and December 2000 to explain some of the recent data. In 1999, some Americans stocked up on batteries and other items to help them survive any disruptions that they feared might come from Year 2000 computer problems. Others bought jewelry or new clothing to celebrate the turning of the calendar. 
Last month, storms hit the Midwest, the South and the Northeast, delaying some shopping trips. As a result, the 1999 data may have overstated consumers' enthusiasm, while this month's numbers exaggerate the comeback.
"It may have turned a little better," Michael P. Niemira, a vice president at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi who tracks retail sales, "but it remains to be seen if it's anything to write home about."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 26, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a pickup in consumer spending reversed last year's and this year's statistics on the effectiveness of discounts in drawing customers to full-price merchandise. About one of every two consumers who buys a discounted item this January is also buying a product that is not on sale; last year the ratio was one in three.

She also said she had cut back on holiday spending but was optimistic because she would eventually have a degree in engineering.
Economists said the Federal Reserve's surprise cut in interest rates on Jan. 3, the stock market rally that followed, the still-low unemployment rate and even the end of the uncertainty over the presidential election could all be making people less worried than a few weeks ago. 
Since the start of the year, the Nasdaq composite index has gained 24 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average have both risen modestly. At the same time, the most recent employment report from the government showed hourly wages accelerating in the second half of 2000, as unemployment hovered around 4 percent.
"People are still employed; they're still making pretty good money," said Frank A. Ursomarso, the president of Union Park Automotive, which owns seven car dealerships in Wilmington, Del. And, Mr. Ursomarso said, lower interest rates had made his cars less expensive in recent weeks. He can charge less because his own interest payments on unsold cars have fallen slightly, and customers' finance payments are now smaller than they were.
During the first two weeks of 2001, Union Park sold 121 vehicles, up from 105 during the corresponding period of last year. In November and December, by contrast, fewer people were walking into Union Park's showrooms to look at Hondas, Fords and BMW's, and sales dropped 4 percent -- or by 21 vehicles -- compared with the previous year. 
The widespread discounts being offered by the Big Three carmakers are also keeping sales from falling further than they did at the end of last year, said Ben Hollingsworth, the chairman of Group 1 Automotive, which owns 55 dealerships in the South and in Massachusetts. Many buyers can choose among making no down payment, delaying monthly payments or getting a rebate of $1,000 to $3,000, he said
In fact, "sale" signs have popped up in stores of almost all kinds, as merchants have scrambled to unload goods that they had expected to sell during the holidays. The discounts are helping to convince shoppers to make purchases but are unlikely to bring much good news for retailers.
"They may not make any money, but they're going to report big sales levels," said C. Britt Beemer, the chairman of America's Research Group, a consulting and polling firm in Charleston, S.C. This January, for example, only about one out of every two consumers who buys a discounted item is also buying a product that is not on sale, Mr. Beemer said. Last year, the ratio was one in three.
At the Target Corporation, which also owns Mervyn's and Marshall Field's, sales in stores that have been open for at least a year are up 3 percent to 4 percent this month, according to Goldman, Sachs. Target had been expecting a gain of about 2 percent.
Still, Susan Kahn, a company spokeswoman, said, "I wouldn't call January some outstanding month."
If the increases in sales are mainly a reflection of the discounts, consumer spending could start to disappoint retailers as soon as Presidents' Day weekend, the next major shopping period, analysts said.
"It's certainly hard to believe that people abandoned their prior gloom and went charging out to the shops," said Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. 
Skeptics also point to the unusual nature of both December 1999 and December 2000 to explain some of the recent data. In 1999, some Americans stocked up on batteries and other items to help them survive any disruptions that they feared might come from Year 2000 computer problems. Others bought jewelry or new clothing to celebrate the turning of the calendar. 
Last month, storms hit the Midwest, the South and the Northeast, delaying some shopping trips. As a result, the 1999 data may have overstated consumers' enthusiasm, while this month's numbers exaggerate the comeback.
"It may have turned a little better," Michael P. Niemira, a vice president at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi who tracks retail sales, "but it remains to be seen if it's anything to write home about."

 BODY:
Microsoft Agrees to Settle Suit Over Java Language
Putting one legal hurdle behind it, Microsoft has agreed to pay $20 million to Sun Microsystems to settle a four-year-old lawsuit over Microsoft's use of the Java programming language, the companies said.
 Under the agreement, the companies ended the licensing contract at the center of the dispute, which gave Microsoft the right to incorporate Java, the most popular language for programs that run on the Web, into Windows. Microsoft will still be allowed to use Java in its products, with some restrictions. Page C4. 

Bush Extends Orders on Power President Bush agreed to extend for two weeks federal orders that require power producers to sell surplus electricity and natural gas to California. But his administration warned the state, strapped for energy, that it will have to resolve the crisis on its own after that. A1.

Profit Rises 11% at Merrill Lynch
Merrill Lynch reported that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, surpassing expectations. For the quarter, Merrill earned $877 million, or 93 cents a share, up from $793 million, or 91 cents a share. Analysts had expected Merrill to earn 88 cents a share. Shares of Merrill rose $4.88, to $80. C2.

Stocks rose as investors shrugged off a poor outlook from Texas Instruments. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 82.48 points, or 3 percent, to 2,840.39. Merck and Johnson & Johnson posted robust fourth-quarter results, indicating that sales of prescription drugs remain strong even as the economy cools. Dennis Eck, chief executive of Coles Myer, the largest retail company in Australia, said he did not want to wake up at 70 not having accomplished enough. "The only thing we all want is to have what we've done matter," he said. After growing up on an Indian reservation, Mr. Eck said, he spent his career "going from a series of places that had problems to the next place that had a problem." The Boss. C6.

HEADLINE: U.S. Diplomats Are Safe After Yemeni Hijacking Fails 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: SANA, Yemen, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
An armed man who said he wanted to show support for Saddam Hussein hijacked a Yemeni plane carrying the American ambassador and 90 other people today and diverted it to neighboring Djibouti, where the crew overpowered him.
 The man was apparently unaware that the Yemen Airways flight that he commandeered was carrying the United States ambassador to Yemen, Barbara Bodine, and four of her aides. 
 The hijacking started less than 10 minutes into the flight and before the seat belt light was switched off. The hijacker moved from the economy to the first class section of the plane, where the American diplomats and two senior Yemeni officials sat. 
The man, wearing a dark gray jacket, placed a small handbag on an empty chair close to the cockpit. When a flight attendant tried to stop him, he pushed her aside.
"I am hijacking this plane," he shouted before storming into the cockpit. "Nobody touches this bag. It is full of explosives."
"I am a follower of Saddam Hussein and I want to fly to Baghdad," the hijacker added in Arabic.
The pilot, Amer Anis, began giving the co-pilot and flight engineer instructions in English when he realized that the hijacker did not understand what was being said.
The pilot told his crew in English that as soon as they landed at Djibouti airport, they should open the emergency doors and evacuate the passengers. When the plane landed, a Reuters correspondent who was on the flight from Yemen's capital, Sana, to the southern city of Taiz, heard the captain order the crew, "Start with the ambassador and her team, quickly, quickly."
Passengers moved to the rear of the Boeing 727 and jumped, one by one, out of the plane onto emergency chutes.
Mr. Anis said later that the hijacker, a Yemeni in his 40's, started screaming when he saw the empty plane, waving a miniature pistol that looked like a long pen.
"He started shouting and threatening me, 'You will be the first to die,' " Mr. Anis said.
One crew member fired foam from a fire extinguisher into the hijacker's face in an attempt to blind him. Another tried to wrestle him down.
"The hijacker fired one bullet, slightly injuring a flight engineer in his left arm," Mr. Anis added.
An airport official said two shots were fired, but all passengers and crew were safe, and the hijacker was arrested. 
Ms. Bodine and her team appeared calm throughout the ordeal. They declined to make any comment on the hijacking.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara Bodine, American ambassador to Yemen, was on the hijacked jet. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Mayor to Propose Record Sum To Expand Cultural Centers 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
A 10-year city construction plan Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to propose tomorrow would provide a record $1.2 billion for projects by city museums, libraries and other cultural institutions, as well as a chance for the mayor to extend his influence far beyond the end of his tenure.
 The mayor's proposal is to be detailed in his final budget package, which is due to be released tomorrow. His top aides, speaking yesterday on the condition of anonymity, said the budget also included about $1.5 billion worth of new tax cuts over the next four years. 
 The mayor's aides provided few details yesterday on where the money for the construction would come from or which taxes would be cut. 
Yesterday's disclosures were more of an opportunity for Mr. Giuliani's aides to show off their commitment to Lincoln Center, the Guggenheim, the Museum of Modern Art, the New York Public Library and other institutions, while also pumping up the city's economy.
"So many people come here specifically to see our museums, to see our centers for art, whatever form that it takes," one aide to Mr. Giuliani said. "This is in part to bolster that industry, because it is such a major component" of the city.
The city has previously committed to much of the proposed spending for cultural institutions, like the $65 million for the Museum of Modern Art's expansion project and about $25 million apiece for renovations and expansion efforts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
But several of the other initiatives are showing up in city budget documents for the first time. These include $240 million to rebuild and expand Lincoln Center; $68 million for a new Guggenheim museum in Lower Manhattan; $19.2 million to expand the New York Public Library's Mid-Manhattan branch; $10 million to help the Brooklyn Academy of Music create a cultural district in Fort Greene; and $13 million to renovate the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.
The last 10-year capital plan, issued two years ago, allocated $487 million for cultural groups and libraries, city officials said, meaning this new plan represents more than a doubling of that commitment. The city's cultural organizations were pleased but not surprised by the plans, each of which the mayor has previously discussed.
"Thank God for the city's generosity," said Beverly Sills, chairwoman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. "Thank God for Mayor Giuliani."
Mr. Giuliani's aides would not say yesterday if he intends, as he has done in past years, to propose cuts in contributions to the annual operating budgets of city libraries and museums. "Stay tuned for the budget," one aide said. But a City Council official said yesterday that the Council expected the mayor to again propose such cuts. Each year, the Council has either restored the money or persuaded the mayor to do so. 
Mr. Giuliani's aides yesterday also provided no specifics on how the mayor proposes to cut $1.5 billion worth of city taxes over the next four years, saying only that these reductions would be in addition to the $2.5 billion worth of tax cuts already adopted by the city or state since the Giuliani administration began.
The City Council today intends to make its own tax-cut offering, voting to modify the current 2001 fiscal year budget by reducing a tax on rent that many businesses pay, officials said. Under that proposal, businesses that pay less than $150,000 a year in base rent would no longer have to pay the commercial rent tax, and those paying between $150,000 and $190,000 would pay a smaller levy.
Collectively, this would save city businesses about $16 million a year, although because it would go into effect halfway through the current fiscal year, it would cost the city an estimated $8 million. Over all, the commercial rent tax brings in about $340 million a year, so many businesses that have large or expensive offices will still pay the tax.
And Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles let it be known yesterday that Mr. Giuliani intends to press the City Council to allocate $12 million for grants that would help low-income parents send their children to private or parochial schools. Previous attempts by the mayor to set up a similar program have not survived challenges by the City Council, whose members have said it would take away needed dollars from public schools. The measure is no more likely to pass this year, they said yesterday.
