HEADLINE: BUSH ADDS 2 WEEKS TO ORDERS ENSURING CALIFORNIA POWER 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
President Bush agreed today to extend for two weeks federal orders that require power producers to sell surplus electricity and natural gas to California. But his administration warned the state that it would have to resolve the crisis on its own after that.
 The extension ensures that neighboring states, which fought any renewal of the federal order out of concern for their own electricity needs, will continue to use extra generating capacity to supplement California's now chronically depleted supply. The action, in response to pleas from California politicians and power officials, also marked a softening of Mr. Bush's approach to the energy crisis after he repeatedly ruled out intervention. 
 But under the ruling, California would have to line up sufficient electricity supply on voluntary, commercial terms after Feb. 7, when the Bush administration said the federal assistance would end. 
The Clinton administration, which first exercised emergency powers in December to compel sales of electricity and gas to California's heavily indebted utilities, renewed the ruling six times and put no limit on extensions.
"This is designed to give the governor, the Legislature and the power producers time to take action," Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said this afternoon in announcing the extension. "I strongly urge them to take that action immediately."
The decision provided a brief respite for California. State officials estimate that the federal mandate helps the state procure hundreds of megawatts of electricity from neighbors, enough to light hundreds of thousands of homes each day and, at times, to tip the balance between normal service and forced blackouts.
Removal of that cushion in two weeks will add to the already intense pressure on state officials to work out both short- and long-term solutions to the power shortage. Without the federal orders, the neighboring states are likely to provide less power.
Bush administration officials said they extended federal help reluctantly. They said it was intended to give Gov. Gray Davis more time to arrange long-term purchase contracts with out-of-state energy producers.
That could potentially end the supply crunch in California, but would require the state to take the politically poisonous step of raising the cap on electricity costs and making consumers pay tens of billions of dollars more in coming years for pricier power.
"There's no question they will have to face facts and deal with this themselves," a senior Bush administration official said in describing the decision. "But there's also an awareness that they need a little more time."
Governor Davis and California's Congressional delegation put heavy pressure on the Bush administration to extend the orders in recent days. Though their pitch had less political weight than it did during the Clinton administration -- the governor, two senators, and the majority of both chambers of the State Legislature are Democratic -- people involved in the lobbying effort said they sought to persuade Bush administration officials that the power crisis could cripple the giant California economy and send ripples around the nation.
Mr. Bush, who administration officials said today made the decision on the extension himself, also came under pressure from representatives of surrounding states not to extend the orders. Many of California's neighbors have said that they are depleting water tables during the abnormally dry winter, thus jeopardizing their own hydroelectric supplies to keep California out of the dark.
"The president assured me that we will not be harmed by this any more after two weeks," said Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, who had urged Mr. Bush not to extend the order and spoke to the president about the decision today.
"But the president is walking a tightrope here between the terrible problem in California and the other states that are getting dragged into it," Mr. Smith said.
Some California politicians are skeptical that the supply shortage can be alleviated within two weeks.
The state's two main utilities, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric, say they have accumulated nearly $12 billion in debt because of the state's partial liberalization of the electricity market in 1996. The law requires them to supply the state's consumers at fixed prices but to buy electricity wholesale at market prices, which have soared to many times the retail price as supplies shriveled with the state's rapid economic growth in recent years.
But local politicians have fought to prevent higher costs from being passed on to consumers. They argue that numerous out-of-state energy producers and marketing companies have taken advantage of the state's shortages by increasing prices. State officials say they are reluctant to sign long-term purchase contracts at relatively high prices that ensure windfall profits for producers.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who has pushed for more federal help, said the two-week extension of the orders was welcome, but he expressed doubt that the matter could be resolved so quickly.
"People are still very divided about the solution, and I don't think it's going to happen in two weeks," Mr. Matsui said. "I would have hoped that the White House would keep its options open."
California was under threat of more power shutoffs today, the eighth straight day of the highest level of electricity alert. But state officials said they believed they had rounded up enough electricity to squeak through the day without new blackouts, in part by buying hydroelectric power from Canada.
They may not be so lucky in coming days. The state for much of the year has saved power by denying service, on occasion, to utility customers who volunteered for favorable rates in exchange for having their power shut in emergencies. But the utilities are fast approaching the limit at which they can deny service to those customers. They could then be forced to hit more ordinary retail customers with rolling blackouts.
As part of a possible longer-term solution, the state's Department of Water Resources today began accepting much-anticipated bids from power generators for multiyear contracts.
The generators have until midday Wednesday to submit their bids, although analysts are not optimistic that generators will meet the maximum price of $55 a megawatt-hour that Governor Davis has demanded. Instead, they say the bids are likely to be higher, in the $75-to-$80 range.
The federal gas order primarily helps Pacific Gas and Electric, a unit of the PG&E Corporation. The company says its supplies of natural gas are dangerously low and has said that without extension of the federal order, it may be forced to begin halting gas service to "noncore" industrial users. Some gas suppliers had stopped selling to Californiabecause of the utility's huge debt and the possibility that it would declare bankruptcy.
The electricity order does not directly affect major independent power producers and marketers like Duke, Dynergy and Enron. Those companies have continued to sell electricity to California during the crisis.
But it does require municipal and cooperative power plants in nearby states to use any extra capacity they have -- many do not routinely run dams or other electrical plants at peak capacity in the winter months -- and transfer power to California. The problem, those neighbors say, is that the order requires them to drain dam reservoirs, used to generate power in the spring and summer.
"Our snowpack is just 50 percent of what it normally is, and we are being told to drain our reservoirs and ship power off to another state," said Dirk Kempthorne, governor of Idaho. "That's not a smart energy policy as far as I'm concerned."
Mr. Kempthorne, a Republican, added that he understood Mr. Bush's predicament in the short term and supported the president's promises to enact a longer-term energy policy.
Despite the extension of the order today, the Bush administration has stressed that it does not plan to continue day-to-day oversight of California's problems. It said it would focus instead on pushing legislation through Congress to allow energy companies to drill for oil and natural gas on land and water that are currently under environmental protection.
The Bush administration has also sent strong signals that it intends to push ahead with free-market liberalization of electricity markets, arguing that California's troubles illustrate the hazards of halfway deregulation.

HEADLINE: THE NEW ADMINISTRATION: THE PLAN; 
Bush Pushes Ambitious Education Plan

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 

 BODY:
President Bush proposed a significant increase today in the federal role in public education, detailing an ambitious plan that includes requirements that states test all students in the third through eighth grades and report on their progress to the public, states and the federal government.
 The proposal, making good on a campaign pledge to focus on education in his first legislative initiative, would also provide parents of children in failing public schools federal money to help pay tuition for private or religious schools. 
 Mr. Bush detailed his plans in a presentation in the East Room of the White House alongside his new education secretary, Roderick R. Paige, who until a few weeks ago was superintendent of the Houston schools. 
Mr. Bush's aides declined to put a price tag on his proposals today, saying they differed slightly from his campaign proposals, but they would clearly cost tens of billions of dollars. 
At the heart of the plan, Mr. Bush said, lies a single concept: more accountability for schools that receive federal money, but considerable flexibility in how those schools meet the stricter standards. 
Mr. Bush also signaled a recognition that he may need to compromise on the most contentious element of his plan: giving vouchers to parents that will allow them to remove their children from schools that "persistently fail to perform."
"Parents and children who have only bad options must eventually get good options if we're to succeed all across the country," Mr. Bush said. "There are differences of opinions about what those options should be," he said, adding that he would "take my opinion to the Hill and let folks debate it." Excerpts, Page A14. 
Critics of Mr. Bush's plan, including teachers' unions, say vouchers -- a word Mr. Bush carefully avoided today -- would siphon money away from public schools that need the cash the most. 
Vouchers are missing from an otherwise similar education proposal introduced today by Congressional Democrats, led by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut. 
Moderate Republicans, in their own plan, have also stricken vouchers, an indication that Mr. Bush may be forced to negotiate if he wants to get the main elements of his program through a Congress so closely divided between the parties. 
Mr. Bush frequently talks about how proud he is of the improvement in the Texas education system in his tenure as governor, though many of the changes there were put into motion before he took office. Crucial elements of today's proposals were drawn from his experience in Texas.
But the Bush plan also demonstrated how much the Republican Party's position has changed to conform to Mr. Bush's initiative. In 1994, one of his party's rallying cries was the elimination of the Department of Education. Under Mr. Bush's plan, it would become significantly more powerful, overseeing the yearly assessments of how schools and states have progressed. 
"There are parts of this we can't abide," said Amy Wilkins, a policy analyst at the Education Trust, a nonpartisan group that focuses particularly on improving the education of disadvantaged students. "But you have to say that the core of his proposal -- accountability -- is much needed, and a big change." 
"It's a serious proposal," Ms. Wilkins said, "and there is a lot to work with."
Mr. Bush's plan includes the following main points:
*States would be allowed to "select and design assessments of their choosing" for all students in grades three through eight, using federal money to develop the tests. But the plan must be used consistently to allow year-to-year assessments of progress and to clearly show the progress of various groups of students. Each school must publicly report results "by race, gender, English language proficiency, disability and socioeconomic status."
*If a school has not made adequate progress for two years, the local school district "must implement corrective action" and allow students to choose another public school. If there is no progress after the next year, "disadvantaged students within the school" may use federal aid "to transfer to a higher performing public or private school" or receive outside tutoring.
*In addition to conforming to state standards for reading and math, the states would also be required to set "challenging content standards in history and science." States would have access to money from a Reading First program, and other funds could be used in preschool and Head Start programs.
*States or districts could negotiate a "charter option" with the Department of Education, which would free them from some federal requirements in return for their agreeing to specific goals for increasing student performance over five years. There would be economic sanctions for failing to meet those terms. 
In a separate proposal, the details of which have not yet been released, the Bush administration wants to expand education savings accounts so that parents can contribute up to $5,000 a year and use the money for any education-related expense in kindergarten through 12th grade. Currently the annual contribution per student is limited to $500, and the program is intended chiefly for college savings. The new proposals would effectively give wealthier parents a tax-free option for helping finance a private-school education.
Today's proposals came on the second working day of the new administration, one full of diversions for Mr. Bush. He spoke by telephone this morning with Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, whom he plans to visit next month. He also spoke with the British prime minister, Tony Blair, a close friend and political partner of former President Bill Clinton. 
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said Mr. Bush and Mr. Blair agreed to arrange a meeting soon, though it was unclear where it would be. Tonight, Japanese officials said that Mr. Bush had a five-minute talk with Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori and that they had agreed to set up a meeting soon.
The Senate today confirmed two more of Mr. Bush's cabinet nominees: Melquiades R. Martinez as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Anthony J. Principi as secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Mitchell Daniels was confirmed to direct the White House Office of Management and Budget, a powerful noncabinet post.
On Wednesday the Senate is likely to confirm Tommy G. Thompson, the governor of Wisconsin, as secretary of health and human services. But Mr. Thompson has asked that his swearing-in be delayed until he can give his last state-of-the-state address, in Madison on Jan. 31.
In a 28-page proposal that Mr. Bush's aides said was intended as a guide to legislative language -- but not a bill -- the president contended that federal education dollars were scattered to the winds, $120 billion a year "spread across 39 federal agencies." Curiously, his plan does not call for consolidating many of those programs, though some would be refined, refocused or redirected.
Mr. Bush defended his voucher program today, saying that "in order for an accountability system to work, there has to be consequences, and I believe one of the most important consequences will be, after a period of time, giving the schools time to adjust and districts time to try different things, if they're failing, that parents ought to be given different options. If children are trapped in schools that will not teach and will not change, there has to be a different consequence."
On Capitol Hill, Republicans said they were thrilled with Mr. Bush's education proposal, saying they hoped to draft and pass a bill in the next few months. Mr. Bush said he wanted final passage in time for the next school year.
Many Democrats also gave the proposal high marks, saying they were particularly pleased that it zeroed in on the poorest, most troubled schools and revised Mr. Bush's original campaign proposal to offer them additional help. He also promised money for school safety and drug prevention during and after school.
"It has received very positive remarks in a bipartisan way," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader. "He promised education would be his No. 1 commitment."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the ranking Democrat on the Education Committee, said he was encouraged by Mr. Bush's ideas, though he was opposed to using taxpayer money for private school tuition. 
A few Republicans signaled that they would push for vouchers but were open to other suggestions, like permitting students to switch public schools. Mr. Bush has incorporated that idea as an option in his plan. 
Senator Larry E. Craig, a conservative Idaho Republican, said, "There is some flexibility there." And Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican who is on the education task force, added, "I don't think we're going to walk away if we don't get everything on that issue."
Mr. Bush's plan closely resembles the bill introduced today by Mr. Lieberman and Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, which has generated strong support from moderate Democrats and is looked upon favorably by some Republicans. Under the centrist Democrat plan, which serves to reauthorize spending for primary and secondary education, the government would send $35 billion more than is being sent now to local school districts over five years. 
It would also hold schools accountable by requiring that certain grade levels be assessed every year. Schools that do not improve could lose their administrative financing. But education experts note that under current law, failing schools can lose financing -- and none ever have.
"The states set the bar so low that the threat is an empty one," noted Ms. Wilkins of the Education Trust. "And the problem with the Bush plan is that it does not define what constitutes an improvement."
Mr. Lieberman's plan does not permit parents to use federal money for private school tuition. It also steers more money to poor schools than does Mr. Bush's proposal.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Power and Profits

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
"Let them eat cake!" cried the new president's friend, a key campaign supporter who was also a prominent advocate of bakery deregulation, not to mention the owner of a chain of cake shops.
 O.K., not exactly. Kenneth Lay, chairman of Enron, was a prime mover in George W. Bush's presidential campaign; he has also been an influential voice in favor of electricity deregulation, and Enron is profiting handsomely from the electricity it sells in California. But what he actually said was that California's power consumers "need to see the price signals that is, pay much more and start modifying behavior to reduce demand until we get new supplies." He also rejected the plea of California officials for a federally imposed cap on wholesale electricity prices, arguing that this would merely "start spreading the shortage around." And his friend the president has echoed his views. 
 Full disclosure: Before this newspaper's conflict-of-interest rules required me to resign, I served on an Enron advisory board that turns out to have been a hatchery for future Bush administration officials. (What was I doing there? Beats me.) I can't say that I got to know Mr. Lay well, but I presume that he is an honorable man. He was, I assume, sincere in those remarks -- which one can't say about everything one has heard from former members of that board -- and he also, one must admit, has a point. But in a deeper sense he is missing the point.
It's true that the California power system lacks adequate conservation incentives. The regulated prices paid by homes and businesses do not rise or fall with the wholesale price. So even in a situation of severe shortage, with wholesale electricity selling for many times its normal price, individuals have no incentive to cut back; that is why there are blackouts.
Why didn't California deregulate the whole shebang? For a very good reason: The distribution of power, its actual delivery to your house, is still a "natural monopoly" -- you can't have multiple power lines running down each street. It would have been bad economics and worse politics to give the utilities that distribute electricity free rein to exercise their monopoly power. Someone should have warned that the system needed nonetheless to give consumers an incentive to conserve during power shortages; but the enthusiasts for deregulation led state officials to believe that power would be so abundant that such technical details wouldn't matter. 
Clearly, it's a priority for California to revise that pricing system. But even so, there is a very good case for a wholesale price cap; far from "spreading the shortage," such a cap would probably increase short-term supplies, and provide some much-needed financial relief.
The most pressing problem, after all, is not the blackouts but the imminent bankruptcy of the utilities; their financial distress also indirectly contributes to the blackouts, because of the difficulty they have in paying suppliers. And the wild wholesale market also, arguably, leads to another source of reduced supply: power-generating companies have a clear incentive to produce less than they can, because doing so drives up the prices they get on what they do produce. A temporary price cap would both take off some of the financial pressure and reduce the incentives to "game the system."
And there's a deeper principle involved, too.
Nobody to the right of Ralph Nader denies that prices have to be allowed to serve a role as "signals" of shortage or abundance, that the profit motive is what makes our economy run. But even now the public rightfully draws a line, fuzzy but real, between profits and profiteering. Natural gas prices that rise in a cold winter are acceptable; $10 a gallon for bottled water after a hurricane is not. 
And one can sympathize with the many people in California who feel that what is happening to them falls on the wrong side of that line -- that the Houston-based companies that helped sell naive officials on the glories of a deregulated market are now saying: "Sorry, it hasn't worked out the way we promised, but tough luck -- you'll pay the cost for our mistake, and we'll profit. And don't even think about alternatives -- our friend the president won't let you try them." It's not entirely fair -- but it's not entirely unfair, either.
Houston, you have a problem.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Flaws in Annual Testing

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein

 BODY:
THE big idea in President Bush's education plan, sent to Congress yesterday, is to hold schools with poor children accountable, using an annual test. Pupils at schools with two years of inadequate test-score gains can transfer to another public school. After a third year of little progress, they can use public money at private schools.
 It seems reasonable to have tests identify schools that don't improve. But the president may put too much faith in scores that are less accurate than he thinks. 
 Under President Bush's proposal, commonplace measurement error could cause states to identify as "failing" some schools that don't deserve the label.
This column previously described the pitfalls of using one test to evaluate a student. Because any day's score might differ from a student's average, or true, score if the test were taken many times, one test should not decide promotion. Judging a student by one test is like judging a baseball player by one day's batting average.
It may seem that these problems don't apply schoolwide because when some students have good days, others have bad ones. If these average out, accountability using a test should work.
But even a school average can wobble around its true value, so sanctions based on annual score changes run a risk of unfairness.
Thomas J. Kane, an economist at the Hoover Institution in Palo Alto, Calif., and Douglas O. Staiger, an economics professor at Dartmouth College, have studied the accuracy of North Carolina's tests. When schools there have above-average score gains, teachers get bonuses.
But Dr. Kane says even tiny sampling errors can keep scores from reflecting true performance. Consider how teachers think of their classes as "good" or "bad" in any year. A less-able teacher could produce greater score gains in a class with better pupils than a more-able teacher could produce with worse students -- even if the classes are demographically identical.
Dr. Kane says that in typical North Carolina elementary schools, nearly one-third of the variance in school reading gains is a result of this "luck of the draw," that is, whether this year's seemingly identical students are easier to teach than last year's.
This affects small schools more, Dr. Kane says, because a few extreme scores can more easily distort an average. Thus, small schools with big gains may seem more effective. But small schools also more often post tiny gains or even losses. A small school's results may have more to do with sampling error than school quality.
Also, even at large schools, a rainy day or other random events may change children's dispositions. This can affect a school's rank: nearly another third of the variance in score gains is linked to the fact that a school's average can vary from one day to another.
North Carolina solved one problem while creating another. Like the Bush plan, the state's program judges schools by annual gains, not absolute scores, to avoid rewarding schools that test well only because they have privileged students. But sampling and random events affect both earlier and later scores, compounding the inaccuracy.
David Rogosa, a professor of education statistics at Stanford University, is analyzing error rates in California, where teachers at schools with rising scores will soon receive bonuses as high as $25,000 each.
Professor Rogosa estimated that if awards were based on school averages alone, over one-fourth of schools with no gains would still qualify.
But California avoids this problem by insisting that schools succeed for low-income students and each minority group, as well as schoolwide. This reduces the chances of undeserved awards, because simultaneous false gains in each group are unlikely.
But the reverse is also true. Schools deserving rewards will be more likely to lose them because if any group fails as a result of random events or sampling error, the school will be disqualified. Diverse schools will fail more often; they have more subgroups where false declines can occur.
President Bush wants to hold schools accountable for gains schoolwide as well as for disadvantaged students. So if either the school or the disadvantaged group posts a false decline, the school could be wrongly labeled failing. But the president's requirement that sanctions follow two successive years of failure is a partial safeguard against measurement error.
The administration's proposal is intended to spur achievement. Schools showing adequate progress will be encouraged to continue their practices; failing schools should change their ways.
But if the wrong schools are sanctioned, what message do we send? Will unfairly sanctioned schools drop methods that work? Will ineffective schools get rewards and continue poor teaching?
Surely we can find better ways to measure schools than relying on an annual test.

PERSON: Tamera Stanton Luzzatto 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Heading a Very Prominent Senator's Office

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN a basement dungeon in the Dirksen Senate Office Building, Hillary Rodham Clinton's temporary headquarters, Tamera Stanton Luzzatto, her chief of staff, ignores the clutter of packing boxes, the jumble of desks, the incessantly ringing telephones and the general mayhem that comes with the transition to a new government. 
 This is all familiar to Ms. Luzzatto, 43, a Capitol Hill insider, who has the perfect resume to build a staff, manage an office and shepherd a legislative agenda for a freshman senator. But Mrs. Clinton is not an average freshman, joining the Senate with expectations -- and baggage -- unmatched since Edward M. Kennedy in 1962. 
 "At least it isn't the same old same old," Ms. Luzzatto said. "This is a true next challenge." 
Ms. Luzzatto came on board just days after Mrs. Clinton's election, to get the office up and running, on the recommendation of John D. Podesta, chief of staff for the senator's husband, the ex-president. The two women hit it off and the temporary job became permanent, providing Mrs. Clinton with a top aide who is intimate with her signature issues, children and health care, and her latest cause, economic development for upstate New York.
Ms. Luzzatto, the daughter of a Presbyterian minister, mastered those areas in nearly 15 years with Senator John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia. Rising from legislative assistant to chief of staff from 1985 to 1999, Ms. Luzzatto was his primary adviser on the National Commission on Children, the Pepper Commission on Health Care and ongoing efforts to bring prosperity to the depressed hollows of the state. 
Ms. Luzzatto's route to Capitol Hill is similar to that of many Democratic baby boomers, who have crossed paths along the way and still constitute an ad hoc family, a la "The Big Chill." Fresh from Harvard University in 1979, she worked for Action, a defunct organization that was, in the Carter administration, the umbrella for the Peace Corps, Vista and a handful of related projects. 
"There was no better way to start working in government and public service," Ms. Luzzatto said. "It was a small agency, with not many layers and a clear mission." It was there that she met Mr. Podesta, as well as other party stalwarts like Betty Currie, President Clinton's secretary -- and also her future husband, Francis A. Luzzatto, a Jewish refugee from Mussolini's Italy, who died of heart disease in 1999 at the age of 64. 
Only at an agency like Action would a 22-year-old be given the opportunity Ms. Luzzatto had: to run a pilot energy conservation program, in Fitchburg, Mass., a struggling mill town, which was later replicated across the country, including Elmira, N.Y. It was her introduction to America (and to cheap motels) and grounding for the work she would later do for Senator Rockefeller and now for Senator Clinton, who intends to repay her upstate supporters by making her first bill an economic development package. 
FROM Action, Ms. Luzzatto gravitated toward privately financed energy and environmental projects, a post in the losing Mondale campaign in 1984, and finally the Senate, where she found a job with Mr. Rockefeller, who had spent his youth in the Peace Corps. But for a leave of absence to work on the Dukakis campaign in 1988, where she was reunited with many of her Action pals, that is where she remained until the summer of 2000. 
Ms. Luzzatto's husband had been dead for nearly a year and she decided "to get off whatever ride I was on and finish grieving." She traveled, "did all the crummy things you have to do after your husband dies," and "reconnected with New York," where she was raised. 
She knows both the suburbs and city, since her father served as assistant minister at the North Avenue Presbyterian Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., during her childhood and at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan during her adolescence. There, the family lived in a church-owned apartment and Ms. Luzzatto and her siblings were scholarship students at prep schools, she and her sister at Brearley and her brother at Collegiate. 
Working for the junior senator from her home state, Ms. Luzzatto said, is part of the appeal of the job, which came just as she was polishing her resume. Then there is the scale of the endeavor, since New York State has 18.2 million people compared with West Virginia's 1.8 million.
And there is the celebrity of her new boss. But Ms. Luzzatto says that what impresses her about Mrs. Clinton is that "she knows star power isn't currency in the bank of the Senate." She describes the former first lady as a "workhorse, not a show horse," with an "instinct for organization" and a talent, like Mr. Rockefeller's, for combining visionary ideas with the humdrum legislative work that makes them happen. 
To succeed, Mrs. Clinton must reach across party lines, and that, too, is something Ms. Luzzatto knows about, in the most personal way. Three years before her husband's death, he had open-heart surgery. One hundred and twenty of Ms. Luzzatto's Senate and staff colleagues, Republicans and Democrats, donated 56 pints of blood.
"I've experienced the good side of Washington," she said, "the heart and soul that are here, on both sides of the aisle."

HEADLINE: 2 Drug Companies Post Solid Quarterly Results 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN

 BODY:
Merck and Johnson & Johnson posted robust fourth-quarter results yesterday, indicating that sales of prescription drugs remain strong even as the economy cools.
 Merck, the nation's second-largest drug company behind Pfizer, reported a 12 percent increase in profits on rising sales of drugs like Vioxx, a pain reliever; Zocor, a cholesterol treatment; and Singulair, an asthma controller. 
 Merck reported net income of $1.76 billion, or 75 cents a share, compared with $1.57 billion, or 66 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Although the results were in line with Wall Street expectations, shares of Merck slumped $2.75, or 3.3 percent, to $79.56. 
Sergio Traversa, a pharmaceutical industry analyst at ING Barings, said Merck's stock price fell because Wall Street had been hoping that the company would post better-than-expected results, as it did in the second and third quarters.
"We got spoiled," Mr. Traversa said. "Merck is human again. It is not supernatural."
Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit, excluding special charges, rose 16 percent, to $924 million, or 65 cents a share, compared with $796 million, or 56 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 64 cents a share.
Including special charges, Johnson & Johnson's net income was $891 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with $754 million, or 53 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Shares of Johnson & Johnson fell $1.63, to $92.69.
Pfizer is expected to announce its results today. Analysts expect that most of the big drug companies will announce double-digit earnings gains for both the fourth quarter and the year.
Mr. Traversa said that he expected the large pharmaceutical companies to report average profit growth of 15 percent to 16 percent for 2000. That should continue into 2001 and 2002, he said. Unlike the sales of many other products, prescription drug sales do not generally slow with a downturn in the economy, Mr. Traversa said. "People still buy drugs," he said.
At Merck, executives have decided to pour more money into marketing its newer drugs like Vioxx and Singulair as older drugs lose their patent protection. When a patent expires, generic drug companies can make their own, less expensive version of a brand name drug, and sales of the brand name drug often fall quickly.
For instance, sales of the Merck drug, Vasotec, a blood pressure treatment that lost its patent protection last year, fell 44 percent, to $330 million, in the fourth quarter.
Merck said last month that it planned to hire 1,500 sales representatives, increasing its sales force in the United States to more than 6,500.
Over all, Merck's spending on marketing and administration increased 12 percent last year while the amount spent on research and finding new drugs increased 5 percent.
Johnson & Johnson, which sells prescription drugs, medical devices and consumer products, benefited most in the fourth quarter from higher sales of Procrit, an anemia drug. 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 25, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about fourth-quarter results for Merck misstated the increases in its spending last year. Spending on marketing and administrative costs rose 19 percent; 12 percent was the quarterly increase over last year. Spending on research and development grew 13 percent; 5 percent was also the gain for the quarter.

HEADLINE: Footlights 

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
 NEWS

Musical Rarity
The quintessential Romantic composer Robert Schumann has been dead since 1856, yet one of his symphonies has never been heard in New York. So goes the billing for the Riverside Symphony concert at 8 p.m. Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, where George Rothman will lead the orchestra in the Symphony in G minor, Schumann's first orchestral composition after a hand injury that compelled him to abandon his career as a piano soloist. The music will be a version fashioned by the music scholar Marc Andrae, who combined Schumann's first and second editions of the two-movement work.

Art as Politics
Napoleon, renowned for military conquest, heroism and political genius, understood the power of art. He employed artists to further his political agenda through images and symbolism, and he fostered French decorative arts to build national prestige and enhance the economy. Starting on Sunday and continuing through April 29, his achievements will be celebrated in "Napoleon and His Age" at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. Assembled from public and private collections, the exhibition includes paintings by David, Baron Gerard, Girodet and Baron Gros as well as sculpture by Antonio Canova and furniture, porcelain, jewelry, objets d'art, uniforms, court dress, swords and guns.

Flowering Art
Although Edouard Manet (1832-1883) was known for the pioneering realism of his figure paintings, his predilection for depicting his immediate surroundings led him inevitably to the still life. Of this French master's 430 known oils, 80 were still lifes. Beginning on Sunday, the Walters Art Museum in Baltimore will house what is described as the first major survey devoted to Manet's still lifes. Given its world premiere at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris last fall and drawn from museums and private collections, "Manet: The Still Life Paintings," on view through April 22, features 55 works.

Past and Present
Part oratorio, part opera, part music-theater, "Udu" blends autobiography, history, fact and fiction in a depiction of present-day slavery in Africa. This work, produced and commissioned by 651 Arts and created by the poet Sekou Sundiata and the composer Craig Harris, will have its New York premiere at 8 p.m. tomorrow and will be repeated on Saturday at the BAM Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

HEADLINE: If Protesters Can't Take to the Streets, They Can Go to the Mountain 

BYLINE:  By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
EVERY year at about this time, world leaders gather at a Swiss resort for the World Economic Forum, an event that usually produces images of prime ministers giving speeches and, at times, protesters railing against them.
 As this year's forum opens today, those who tune into the event may come away with another image: that of laser-beamed messages -- of no more than 160 characters, each character about 15 yards high -- scrolling up the snow-covered mountainside overlooking the resort, Davos. 
 The messages are part of Hello Mr. President, an Internet art project that is designed to collect the electronic musings of anyone, anywhere in the world, and project them out of the window of a nearby apartment and onto Bolgen Mountain. 
People may send in their messages over the Internet, by visiting www.hellomrpresident.com. Or they can send them using the short-messaging system on their cell phones.
Johannes Gees, a Swiss artist, is leading the $50,000 project, which is being sponsored by SwissInfo.org, an online portal for multilingual news. 
"It's like demonstrating in remote mode," Mr. Gees said. 
This is his second foray into Internet art. His first was an ever-growing quilt of images stitched together from photographs and computer graphics that people have posted on www.communimage.com.
With the Davos project, Mr. Gees said he was hoping to have some fun with technology and art while trying to open a less antagonistic channel of communication between protesters and world leaders.
Protests are expected in the wake of the upheaval last year during the World Trade Organization's meeting in Seattle. Last week, the State Department issued a notice discouraging Americans from visiting Davos until the world meeting has concluded.
It is not, Mr. Gees said, that he imagines that the problems of the world will be solved with this unusual communication medium. 
"Definitely not," he said. "I'm not naive."
But he added that he can imagine the project's conjuring a dialogue something like this: A worker in Mexico might hear about the project and decide to send a message from a local Internet cafe. About 10 seconds later, the words could be beamed onto the mountain's base. A corporate executive or Mexican official might see that message from the balcony of a nearby hotel and send a response using a cell phone. 
For those who want to watch the laser show, a photograph of the mountainside will be updated continuously on the Web site until the forum ends on Jan. 29. 
Messages must be sent in English, French, German, Italian or Spanish, Mr. Gees said, and will be reproduced in the language sent. 
The team, he said, will try to post a wide range of political viewpoints but will exclude those that contain racist or profane language. 
The messages will be shown from 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. in Switzerland (or midafternoon in the United States). 
Mr. Gees has also decided to accept messages only during those hours. That is the best way, he said, to ensure that the statements that come over the Internet are interesting and meaningful. 
"I want people to think about what they are going to say," he said, "and not just sit at their computer and send something and then forget about it."

HEADLINE: Is Cindy Crawford A Bad Neighbor? 

BYLINE:  By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
THE model Cindy Crawford and the nightclub entrepreneur Rande Gerber spend most of their time in Los Angeles. But they keep a co-op apartment in Manhattan at 33 East 70th Street, where they now find themselves squaring off with their neighbors. Last week, when the couple arrived in New York to open Mr. Gerber's new nightspot, the Underbar on Union Square, they said they were surprised to find themselves defendants in a lawsuit filed Jan. 10 by Marina and John French, their downstairs neighbors. The suit asserted that the Frenches' lives had been disrupted since 1998 by "intolerable noises" from upstairs, in particular "the intimate sounds of daily life." 
 No, not those intimate sounds. (And the Frenches should be grateful that when Ms. Crawford gave birth at home 18 months ago, she chose her other home.) The lawsuit lists the offending sounds as telephones ringing, toilets flushing, doors opening and closing and footsteps overhead. "It's Rande's high heels," Ms. Crawford joked. 
 Mr. Gerber said, "Cindy said I'd better take down the disco ball."
They are, however, taking the matter seriously. "They're not wearing their shoes now," Mr. French said on Monday. But he can still hear them thumping around. "This morning someone dropped some coins on the floor and it sounded like hammers on the floor," he said.
Like teenagers who cannot bear the sound of their parents chewing, New Yorkers, stacked one on top of another, have noise issues that no amount of nirvana at Integral Yoga will overcome. They raise their eyes to heaven as the neighbors' 4-year-old dumps out a crate of Legos; they accept that on Superbowl Sunday, they will hear groans and cheers from apartments on all sides.
But New Yorkers do not want to hear any noise at all after 10 p.m., the magic time when the standard lease and co-op bylaws assure "peaceful enjoyment" of an apartment.
Lawyers, builders and owners believe that noise complaints are increasing, and they blame the economy. Money brings changes, including that new home theater next door, the one with the subwoofer. And people have been redecorating, pulling up the wall-to-wall, putting down marble, leaving floors bare. (Most leases and co-op rules require that 75 percent of floors be covered, to control noise.) 
When apartment dwellers replace plaster ceilings with wallboard, decibel levels rise fast. Chuck Walsh of Apartments Unlimited, which owns three rental buildings in the East Village and manages others, says that ceilings made with wooden laths and two layers of plaster deaden sound, while two layers of 5/8-inch-thick wallboard create "a drum overhead."
And then there's the climb in apartment prices, which has inspired a lot of quiet, older couples to cash in. Enter young families. By contrast they sound "like football practice going on above you," said Stuart Saft, head of the real estate department of the law firm Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman and Herz, which represents the co-op board at Ms. Crawford's building. 
Mr. French said that the previous upstairs tenants had not been a quiet old couple. On the contrary, he said, they "had an active family life," and children who visited frequently.
Indeed, Mr. French believes Ms. Crawford's contractor removed sound-deadening material between her floor and the concrete slab above his ceiling. Bernard Wincig, the lawyer for Ms. Crawford and Mr. Gerber, said, "We'll explore a mutually amicable solution -- if there's a problem we'll correct it."
"I spent a year trying to get through to Cindy," Mr. French said, sounding like a suitor. "I wrote her letters, I tried to make contact and talk to her as soon as it became apparent that there would be a problem." Mr. French, who is a lawyer and the former president of the co-op board, sued the board as well, seeking damages for nuisance, loss of value, court costs and an injunction to force "defendants Crawford and Gerber" to fix things up there.
Mr. Saft counters that the board believes Ms. Crawford and Mr. Gerber have done everything they can. "We requested as soon as the complaints came in to have the apartment inspected to be sure the floors were covered," he said. Mr. Wincig said that in the apartment, "the surface is covered 90 percent with carpeting or rugs." 
Mr. Saft noted that noise is in the mind of the listener. After one couple in another East Side building complained about being awakened every day at 6:30 by a thud coming from directly above their bedroom, it turned out to be nothing more than a 10-year-old jumping out of bed. "The little girl has a right to get out of bed," he said.
It may not always seem that way to a neighbor. Last September, in Los Angeles, a man allegedly lost control when his neighbor's alarm clock went off at 5:45 a.m. and started shooting a rifle through the wall. (No one was hit.)
Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said that noise complaints often come down to this: "You're always going to have people who are somewhat more sensitive to noise living underneath people who are somewhat less sensitive to their neighbor's concerns," he said. "Everyone hears noises in their apartments -- so to what extent are you sensitive to them?"
For those who can't help being sensitive, noise complaints in New York are forwarded from 911 to a "quality of life" phone line. Landlord-Tenant Court stands ready to resolve disputes, but mediation may be a better recourse than any court. Mediation in New York is handled by the State Court Alternative Dispute Resolution organization. 
"Instead of having the parties argue positions and rights, and a judge decide a win-lose situation and who violated an ordinance, in mediation the idea is really to get them to their practical concerns," said Daniel M. Weitz, coordinator for the program. "It's usually about peace and quiet. We ask people to prioritize, and the parties come up with solutions." 
The best solutions (as always) come with communication. Mr. Walsh, of Apartments Unlimited, represented one elderly landlord who started receiving complaints from a tenant after he renovated her building. Mr. Walsh checked to make sure the couple next door had installed carpets and moved speakers away from the walls. 
Only then did the young woman confess that it was the sound of her neighbors making love all night that was driving her crazy.
The landlord "was so mortified, he had the contractor go over there and ripped down the walls and put up sound board," Mr. Walsh said. "It cost him a fortune." In landlord parlance, such tenants are called "the honeymooners."
Now, Mr. and Mrs. French, that's the real intimate sound of daily life.

GRAPHIC: Photos: NO NOISE IS GOOD NOISE -- John and Marina French, below; Rande Gerber and Cindy Crawford, inset, with their son, Presley. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times; inset, Alex Berliner/Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Nannies Get Tough, Parents Tremble 

BYLINE:  By KIMBERLY STEVENS 

 BODY:
THERE'S a power struggle under way in many households between parents and nannies, and the nannies seem to be gaining the upper hand.
 You've heard about parents who install videocams so they can spy on the baby sitter? Well, nannies are beginning to return the scrutiny. Just check out the chat rooms proliferating on the Internet, where nannies exchange juicy anecdotes about dysfunctional parents and their spoiled offspring. "What good am I to these kids when I'm angry and frustrated?" one nanny recently asked her peers. 
 Other nannies don't get mad -- they get even, posting the names of "bad" employers in hopes of scaring away other candidates. 
Not long ago, nannies landed in the spotlight only when women with high-level political appointments were caught hiring them off the books. The notion of nannies venting online -- never mind demanding compensation packages that include stock options, Broadway tickets and up to three weeks of paid vacation, plus travel expenses -- was inconceivable.
That changed when the economy expanded, encouraging more households to opt for private care over group care.
The number of nannies in the United States has gone up 25 percent in five years, to more than a million, according to estimates by the International Nanny Association, a 16-year-old group. But there's still a nanny gap.
The result is fierce competition among moms who want on-call care -- and are willing to pay top dollar -- and a demanding new work force. "The nanny has become a much more powerful figure in the household and in the neighborhood, especially a beloved, respected nanny," said Clifford Greenhouse, director of nanny placement at the Pavillion Agency in New York.
Lyn Peterson, who lives in Scarsdale, N.Y., offers her nanny everything from private Internet access to all-expenses-paid ski trips with the family to Vail. "You're so vulnerable, you just do whatever they want," Ms. Peterson said.
A Manhattan mother, asking not to be named, said, "All the mothers I know are intimidated by their nannies," adding that you don't want her to be unhappy and possibly take it out on your child.
"It's a very subtle thing," she said, comparing the managerial skills that are required of her as a magazine editor to those required for an employer at home. "You don't question where she's taking the child during the daytime because you don't want her to think you're infringing on her independence. You don't ask her to work overtime if she doesn't want to."
This woman wound up paying her nanny for two weeks of leave after only four months on the job. "We gave in," she said. "We didn't want to lose her."
In New York, parents say, the demand for good nannies is so pitched that nanny cartels can effectively shut out unknown nannies and families that fail to abide by the rules. This can mean handing over not only control of the children -- their social lives, wardrobes, eating habits and doctors' appointments -- but other managerial responsibilities.
"It used to be a nanny was just another working member of a household," said Carmine De La Gala, who has worked for upper income households in New York since 1993. But now, she said, nannies often help supervise housekeepers and repair people.
Today's nannies even delegate rudimentary household chores to others -- including parents. Carol Fitzgerald and her husband, Jeffrey, parents of 4-year-old twins on the Upper West Side, gave up asking the nanny to do more than pick up toys.
Helping nannies to build a united front are dozens of Web sites and support groups, including the National Association of Nannies (www .nannyassociation.com).
"We'd be provincial if we didn't think our nanny was online," Ms. Peterson said. "I assume my nanny is in the nanny chat rooms."
The Internet is not that different from a conventional playground, said Heather Heflin, who works for a family in Chappaqua, N.Y., and moderates www.unitednannies.com. "It's a place to find common ground and to blow off steam. Difficult employers are discussed on the board, especially with the regulars, because they really get to know each other."
Real-life playgrounds still provide a way to network, too.
"It's really like the nanny den," said Francie Hermelin, who takes her 13-month-old to a playground in TriBeCa. "It's really intimidating." She added, "If you get on their bad side, I don't know how you'd find another nanny in this town."
One mother in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, Danielle Claro, said the nannies in her neighborhood ganged up on a parent recently because she had fired a series of nannies. "That woman was simply written off," Ms. Claro said, and was forced to seek a new nanny in another part of town.
As Mr. Greenhouse, the placement director, said, "No matter how big you think New York is, when it comes to nannies and baby sitters, it becomes a very small place."
When one longtime nanny, Diane Sleeper, took a job on the Upper West Side recently she was struck by how entrenched the nanny network had become. "The nannies are often more exclusive than the mothers," she said, alluding to stares from the playground cliques. 
Ever since the days of the Irish nanny, young women have relied on one another for job leads and social support. Today, many nannies are from Latin America, the Caribbean islands and Asia, and their networks break down accordingly.
Settling in the more affordable boroughs outside Manhattan, they often commute long distances to work. Some make reverse commutes during the day, taking their charges to playgrounds in Queens or the Bronx so they can meet with other nannies they know. 
Susan Carlton, a co-author of "The Nanny Book: The Smart Parent's Guide to Hiring, Firing and Every Sticky Situation in Between" (St. Martin's Griffin, 1999), says play dates are often arranged because two nannies are friends.
Yet parents hesitate to question their nannies' day-to-day activities. "We don't want our nanny to think we have a bias against certain neighborhoods or the company a nanny may keep," Ms. Carlton said.
In New York, bias has elements of class consciousness. Teresa Coles, a British nanny who has worked for New York families for 18 years, said she appreciates the flexibility of her current employers in TriBeCa. "There are plenty of families down here that don't want their arty kid traveling uptown to socialize in what they perceive as a more sterile, conservative environment," she said. 
Other parents try to work around their nannies' needs. After Jean Koerner and her husband, Greg, hired a Tibetan nanny about a year ago, they were startled one day when they were asked to attend a birthday party for a child whose parents they had never met.
They decided to encourage other families in their Greenwich Village neighborhood to hire friends and relatives of the nanny. That way, Ms. Koerner said, "You don't have to worry about the nanny traveling across town for play dates."
Though nannies typically work long hours -- 12-hour days are not unusual -- many are making the time to attend meetings of groups like the International Nanny Association, which has 530 members in the United States. 
Nannies also get together socially. Thirty gathered recently at the Redeye Grill, in Midtown, to unwind and talk shop over drinks and dinner.
One thing many agree on: salaries and benefits have never been better. "Eighteen months ago, the average nanny's salary was between $9 and $12 a hour," said Stephanie Breedlove, who helps run an accounting firm based in Austin, Tex., that specializes in household payroll issues. "Now, it's between $11 and $15."
In a scramble to attract and keep nannies, Ms. Breedlove said, many parents over the last five years have started providing health insurance, paid sick leave and vacation, none of which is required by law. Some offer to pay tuition so that their nannies can improve their language and teaching skills.
In Silicon Valley, recruitment "carrots" have included stock options, said Denise Collins, the owner of Aunt Ann's, a placement agency in San Francisco. But, she said, "the dot-com bomb," coupled with many nannies preferring to be paid up front, may put an end to the stock option come-on.
Many families still shower their nannies with old-fashioned gifts. One New York couple, asking not to be named, said they felt compelled to give their nanny orchestra tickets to "The Lion King" after she mentioned that "everyone else in the neighborhood had gone to see the show."
The Fitzgeralds give their nanny round-trip airplane tickets home to England at least once a year, plus paid vacations and annual bonuses -- and even an occasional bottle of wine after a hard day of work.
Over the four years they have known each other, the two women have become close, Ms. Fitzgerald said. Nevertheless, she added: "I was intimidated. My husband kept having to remind me that she worked for us."

HEADLINE: Swank Plans In Skid Row Los Angeles 

BYLINE:  By FRANCES ANDERTON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
IN "The Million Dollar Hotel," a movie opening next week, the director Wim Wenders focuses on a flophouse, the Frontier Hotel, in downtown Los Angeles. The movie, in fact, was shot in the dilapidated hotel, whose rooftop sign trumpets its impressive cost in the 1920's: "The Million Dollar Hotel." There on screen are its still-tatty rooms ($14 a night), its heavy brick facade, the cracked sidewalks outside and, nearby, the other sad, fallen buildings in Los Angeles's impoverished, abandoned core.
 Another man, Tom Gilmore, 48, has a different view of Downtown. He is now in escrow to buy the hotel that stars in the movie. Mr. Gilmore is adding the Frontier to the six buildings, one garage and one parking lot he already owns on the same block as part of a plan to turn this defunct commercial district near Skid Row into a thriving residential area. "Everything we do starts out being something really seedy," he said. 
 Mr. Gilmore, a former New Yorker, is the loudest, most ebullient true believer in the unconventional wisdom that Los Angeles has a soul -- its beautiful but down-at-the-heels historic Downtown, which the middle class has forgotten for years except as a movie location. He is banking that Angelenos will trade beach, hills or suburban flatlands for a loft there. 
Mr. Gilmore and his partners at Gilmore Associates will spend, by his estimate, $170 million -- with help from equity partners, and city, state and federal agencies -- on Downtown, including former financial buildings in the historic core, near Pershing Square (redesigned in 1994 by Ricardo Legoretta) and only blocks from Arata Isozaki's Museum of Contemporary Art. Mr. Gilmore has grandly christened his buildings between Fourth and Fifth Streets "the Old Bank District." The name, he says, is a handy marketing ploy to counter the perception problem connected with Downtown, an area as undesirable as the Lower East Side of Manhattan was 10 years ago. 
Fourth and Main has itself served as a generic corner of "Manhattan" being showered by meteors in the opening scenes of the movie "Armageddon." In fact, the historic core of Downtown could stand in for Any City, U.S.A., circa 1932.
Many here believe that if anyone has a chance to turn Downtown around, it is Mr. Gilmore. One of his properties, the San Fernando Building, has been open for three months, and its 70 apartments are almost all rented, from $800 a month for a studio to $2,400 a month for a two-bedroom loft. The sprawling turn-of-the-century Hellman Building opens on Saturday with more than half of its apartments rented. Conversions on the Rowan, the Continental, the Frontier, the El Dorado and the Farmers and Merchants Bank buildings are in the works.
A convergence of factors have made Downtown ripe for habitation: a tight housing market; a new city ordinance allowing office buildings to be turned into apartments; a bumper crop of historic buildings available at rock bottom prices because of a recession in the early 1990's. Ed Rosenthal, a longtime real estate broker who has seen past Downtown projects fail miserably, said: "The entire environment is now geared to reclaiming these inner cities, which it wasn't before. Circumstances are such that Gilmore fits the lock."
Downtown Los Angeles has already sprouted a number of cultural institutions, often presented as the answer to reviving inner cities. The Staples Center, a sports arena, that opened in 1999, is several blocks southwest of Gilmore's development. The Walt Disney Concert Hall, designed by Frank Gehry, is scheduled to open in 2003, in the Bunker Hill area. Also, Rafael Moneo's Our Lady of Angels Catholic Cathedral is being built near the concert hall. The Southern California Institute of Architecture has relocated from Marina del Rey to a railroad freight building in the artists' district in east Downtown. And new stops on the subway have opened Downtown. 
Andre Balazs is opening another hip Standard Hotel in Bunker Hill, and several art galleries have moved into Chinatown on the other side of the Hollywood Freeway. Downtown is heating up.
Stoking the fire is Mr. Gilmore. He is "the P. T. Barnum of developers," said a competing developer, Dan Rosenfeld, affectionately. The Los Angeles Times has heralded him as "a Downtown proselytizer, a sort of combination Robert Moses and Aimee Semple McPherson."
"Downtown is so much better for what he's done," said Councilwoman Rita Walters, whose district includes Mr. Gilmore's area. "He's come in with fresh eyes and looked at possibilities others had given up on."
A painter-turned-gardener-turned-architectural-designer and now developer, Mr. Gilmore was born in Manhattan and grew up on Long Island. He moved to Los Angeles in the early 90's; three years ago he bought the San Fernando Building. "I thought, 'This is a city I can have an impact on,' " he said.
But many people are doubtful Los Angeles needs a thriving Downtown. "I'm not convinced there needs to be one," said Matthew Miller, of Cresa Partners, a company that advises companies on leasing office space. "And the trend is for less centralization rather than more." That said, he added, "Downtown is not dead or dying." 
However, it is a place with a very irregular heartbeat. In the early 1900's, the business and entertainment center of Los Angeles was between Third and Seventh Streets on Broadway and Spring. But Downtown today is a strange and atmospheric four-square-mile area. In it is a hodgepodge of disparate neighborhoods, including Little Tokyo and Skid Row, "bumping together like icebergs," said Jack Kyser, a local economist. 
To the north are city, state and federal buildings. Broadway, which slices from north to south, is now a thriving Hispanic shopping street. To the east of the Old Bank District is the 12-square-block Skid Row area, where several thousand men and women fill missions and single-room-occupancy hotels. There are vibrant produce, jewelry, toy and garment districts. Downtown is alive by day but dead at night.
Mr. Gilmore is not the first to try to put new housing Downtown. Last year, a developer, Geoffrey Palmer, built an Italianate-themed block of corporate apartments near the financial district in Bunker Hill and surprised naysayers by filling it. (Other high-end apartments were built near the Museum of Contemporary Art in the 1980's.)
Nor is Mr. Gilmore the first developer to convert historic buildings Downtown. In the late 80's and early 90's, Ira Yellin blazed the trail by creating 120 apartments in the Homer Laughlin and Million Dollar Theater Building on Broadway. 
But Carol Schatz, president of Downtown's Central City Association, an advocacy organization for businesses and property owners, credits Mr. Gilmore with being the first "to take a crop of contiguous buildings" and try to create a neighborhood. His renovated San Fernando, a 1907 eight-story Renaissance Revival-style pile with a new coat of paint, is currently a lone beacon of upward mobility in a zone of empty, rundown buildings and welfare hotels.
People moving into the San Fernando are attracted to its semi-industrial, open-plan spaces with sandblasted concrete floors, large tiled bathrooms and fully-equipped kitchens. Paul Warner, an artist, shares a $1,400 935-square-foot loft there with his wife, Marie. New York "is the place that everyone wants to live but no one can afford," he said.
"For one-third of the cost, I get a place I like with a great view and great location," he added.
If all goes as planned, Mr. Gilmore, who also has interests in the Hollywood and Vine area, miles west in Hollywood, foresees mixed-income apartments renting for $500 to $6,000 a month joining the San Fernando in the Old Bank District. Also in the works is the El Dorado Hotel -- a project in development with Cedd Moses and Mark Smith, the owners of several trendy bars and restaurants in Los Angeles -- and roof gardens, coffee bars and shops. 
A few blocks north is St. Vibiana's Cathedral, a 19th-century Spanish baroque building damaged in the 1994 earthquake. Mr. Gilmore owns it and plans to turn it into Vibiana Place, a performing arts center and housing complex. He also owns the Palace Theater on Broadway, an ornate 2,200-seat house built for vaudeville in 1911. The Palace, one of 12 historic movie or vaudeville theaters on Broadway, will become the Gilmore Associates new offices next month and later a performing arts center.
"Our challenge is to buy enough real estate and transform enough so it becomes a town unto itself," Mr. Gilmore said.
Of course it has a way to go before it's a town. Mr. Warner says he drives 15 minutes to West Hollywood for groceries. "One advantage is that we are near all the freeways," he said. The Acapulco Gold coffee bar will open in the San Fernando Building next month, but restaurants and bars are few and far between. 
Mr. Gilmore and his third wife, Trish Keefer, who manages properties for another real estate company, plan to occupy a loft on weekdays in the Continental when it is completed this spring. On weekends, however, they plan to return to their Spanish Revival house in the Hollywood Hills. Asked if he would trade that for full-time living downtown, he said that if he were younger, yes. "But at 48 years, with a wife and cats, I'd live in the country," Mr. Gilmore said. He added that he enjoys tending his garden as much as his developments. "I like peace more than I like action," he said.
Such action, to his critics, represents the specter of gentrification. "In order for his plan to work, he's got to push the Skid Row people away from the neighborhood," said Alice Callaghan, a local Episcopal priest who works with the homeless. 
Bud Hayes, chief executive of the S.R.O. Housing Corporation in the Skid Row area, argues that Mr. Gilmore's project is a boon to the neighborhood and will bring amenities, like grocery stores, to the area.
Complaint No. 2: Mr. Gilmore's rentals are overpriced. Spacious lofts in the nearby Spring Towers building owned by Izek Shomof rent for 75 cents to $1 a square foot a month. Lofts in Mr. Gilmore's San Fernando Building rent for around $1.50 a square foot. The difference, he says, helps pay for things like better security.
Complaint No. 3. "The Gilmore Effect." Other developers complain that by drawing so much attention to Downtown, he has contributed to a rise in prices. The Alexandria Hotel, a flophouse on Spring and Fifth, may be the next candidate for developers, with its grand ballroom with a Tiffany stained-glass ceiling. But what will it cost? When Mr. Gilmore began buying in 1997, he paid $10 a square foot; today, prices are $30 to $50 a square foot. 
But Downtown, if it is to succeed, needs thousands, not hundreds, of lofts. And other developers need Mr. Gilmore to succeed, especially if a recession threatens the embryonic project. "He's the brightest object in the downtown sky right now," Paul Solomon, a young developer, said. "And the momentum of the area would be affected to the negative if he were not to succeed."
Mr. Gilmore says he's not worried about failure. "L.A.'s been a movie set for long enough," he said. "Now it's time for it to become a real city."

HEADLINE: World Needs to Add 500 Million Jobs in 10 Years, Report Says 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
With one-third of the world's work force unemployed or underemployed, at least 500 million new jobs will be needed over the next 10 years to accommodate new arrivals in the job market and help reduce global unemployment by half, an international labor group says in a new report.
 The International Labor Office, the headquarters of the International Labor Organization, a United Nations affiliate, issued the report on Tuesday, saying sweeping advances in information technology and communications offer the most promising solution for creating work. 
 Still, its World Employment Report 2001 warned that "the global employment situation remains deeply flawed," because inequalities in access to technology and education are leaving many developing countries behind the industrialized world. 
"Growth cannot in itself be expected to ensure that the needed 500 million jobs are of sufficient quality to bring all the world's workers closer to the enjoyment of decent work," the report said. "To achieve this requires much greater attention to core labor market issues, including investments in human capital, overcoming discrimination and making employment a central goal of economic policy."
To cross the so-called digital divide of the computer age, the report said, governments of developing countries will have to consider policies that would make the new technologies available to their people and equip them with the necessary education and skills. 
"A passive policy stance that leaves to markets alone the direction of change will reinforce divides," the report said.
Duncan Campbell, an economist in the organization's employment strategy department and the senior editor of the report, said: "There are clear positive potentials from these technologies. There are clear opportunities for good. But there are also concerns and worries." 
"No country has succeeded economically without well-educated people," Mr. Campbell added, speaking by telephone from the agency headquarters in Geneva. "We really view education as being the key source of the divide."
The report estimated that fully one-third of the three billion potential workers in the world were "unemployed, underemployed in terms of seeking more work or earn less than is needed to keep their families out of poverty," a subsistence wage level reckoned at $1 a day.
Of those, 160 million are visibly jobless, which, the report said, was 20 million more than at the peak of the Asian financial crisis in 1998, because Asia's population kept growing during the economic downturn.
It further estimated that at least 460 million new young job seekers, two-thirds of them Asian, would join the global work force by 2010. 
But the AIDS pandemic that is sweeping sub-Saharan Africa is widely expected to reduce the number of job seekers there, with losses disproportionately high among professional and other skilled workers.
Although more workers in the United States and other industrialized countries are finding jobs, the report said, unemployment has risen in Latin America and the Caribbean, and it remains high in Central and Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In China, the problem has apparently become more visible.
The new technologies, the report added, have the potential to improve women's opportunities. It said women held 27 percent of professional jobs in India's thriving software industry.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue-Chip Earnings Reports Put Some Investors on Edge

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors refrained from making any big commitments in the stock market yesterday, leaving stocks little changed as they tried to discern a trend in earnings and the economy.
 Blue chips fluctuated amid a series of bleak profit reports and forecasts. Technology stocks fared better, but they struggled to stay in positive territory. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average finished slightly lower, down 2.84 points, to 10,646.97. The Nasdaq composite index rose 18.76 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,859.15, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended up 3.90 points, or 0.3 percent, at 1,364.30. 
With blue chips including DuPont and McDonald's issuing downbeat reports, investors were taking few chances. No big-name technology companies reported earnings yesterday.
Analysts say it is hard to predict how coming earnings announcements will affect the market each day. Wall Street's overall mood seems optimistic, but there is some uncertainty about whether bad earnings news has been factored completely into the cheaper prices of many stocks.
"The general tone is positive even though the market is weighing things," said Dan Ascani, president and research director at Global Market Strategists in Gainesville, Ga. "Generally speaking, the market is digesting well."
Investors are most concerned about the future. Shares of many companies that meet or beat fourth-quarter earnings expectations have slipped when those concerns also warned that first-quarter results will be disappointing.
That was the case yesterday with DuPont, which surpassed profit forecasts by a penny a share but said challenging business conditions will pinch earnings into the first half of this year. DuPont shares fell 19 cents, to $41.88.
McDonald's, after warning that the first quarter will be difficult, tumbled $2.06, to $30.81. McDonald's also missed fourth-quarter earnings forecasts by a penny.
Investors are still trading with some caution, but they seem to be growing more confident that profits and the economy will improve, partly because of lower interest rates. The market is hoping that the Federal Reserve will reduce rates for the second time in a month when it meets next week.
"An edge of optimism has come into the market," said A. C. Moore, chief investment strategist at Dunvegan Associates in Santa Barbara, Calif. "There's the thought that the economy may have a soft landing as a consequence of the Fed's action."
There is evidence of increasing optimism in the market's recent preference for technology stocks over so-called defensive issues, like drug stocks, that tend to perform better in bearish markets.
The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb fell $1.38, to $64.88, despite beating earnings forecasts by a penny. Analysts say the drug sector has become overpriced as investors sought safer bets during last year's high-technology tumble.
 --------------------

Treasury Bonds Fall
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell for the fourth consecutive day as investors said the Federal Reserve might not cut interest rates as much as they had previously thought. 
"The market is shifting expectations from a half-point to a quarter-point" rate cut as investors bet the economy will recover by the second half of the year, said Mitch Stapley, who is adding investment-grade corporate debt to the $3.5 billion he manages at the Kent Funds in Grand Rapids, Mich.
Bond traders expect the Fed to cut rates by at least a quarter of a percentage point at its meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 5/32, to a price of 103 11/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.30 percent from 5.28 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 108 13/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.66 percent from 5.65 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Board Ends Method of Accounting for Mergers 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Financial Accounting Standards Board voted yesterday to eliminate the pooling method of accounting for mergers, a move that was widely expected.
 The accounting board, in a unanimous vote, reaffirmed an earlier decision that had drawn strong opposition from businesses and had led some members of Congress to propose legislation to overturn the decision. 
 But opposition had softened since the board voted to change the other method of accounting for mergers, called purchase accounting, to make it less onerous. 
Companies have tried to avoid using purchase accounting because it often required them to add intangible assets, known as good will, to their balance sheets and then write those assets off over 20 years or more, reducing reported earnings.
But the board decided to allow a company to not write off good will until the company concluded that the value of the asset had been impaired. The move will allow companies to report higher earnings.
The board's chairman, Edmund L. Jenkins, said the change was needed because the purchase method "reflects the underlying economics of business combinations by requiring that the current values of the assets and liabilities exchanged be reported to investors."
"Without the information that the purchase method provides," Mr. Jenkins added, "investors are left in the dark as to the real cost of one company buying another and, as a result, are unable to track future returns on the investment."
When companies used pooling, they combined the balance sheets of the two companies that were merging. As a result, the asset values shown did not reflect the value of the stock that had been exchanged to buy the company being acquired. In purchase accounting, the value of the assets on the balance sheet of the merged company reflect the price that was paid for the acquired company.
The board also announced that two new members had been named to the seven-member board, to serve five-year terms beginning on July 1. They are John K. Wulff, the chief financial officer of Union Carbide, and Katherine Schipper, an accounting professor at Duke University.
They succeed two retiring members, Gaylen N. Larson, a former financial executive with Household International, and Gerhard G. Mueller, a former professor at the University of Washington.
