HEADLINE: REDESIGNING NATURE: Hard Lessons Learned; 
Biotechnology Food: From the Lab to a Debacle

BYLINE:  By Kurt Eichenwald; The following article is based on reporting by Kurt Eichenwald, Gina Kolata and Melody Petersen and was written by Mr. Eichenwald.

 BODY:
In late 1986, four executives of the Monsanto Company, the leader in agricultural biotechnology, paid a visit to Vice President George Bush at the White House to make an unusual pitch.
 Although the Reagan administration had been championing deregulation across multiple industries, Monsanto had a different idea: the company wanted its new technology, genetically modified food, to be governed by rules issued in Washington -- and wanted the White House to champion the idea. 
 "There were no products at the time," Leonard Guarraia, a former Monsanto executive who attended the Bush meeting, recalled in a recent interview. "But we bugged him for regulation. We told him that we have to be regulated." 
Government guidelines, the executives reasoned, would reassure a public that was growing skittish about the safety of this radical new science. Without such controls, they feared, consumers might become so wary they could doom the multibillion-dollar gamble that the industry was taking in its efforts to redesign plants using genes from other organisms -- including other species.
In the weeks and months that followed, the White House complied, working behind the scenes to help Monsanto -- long a political power with deep connections in Washington -- get the regulations that it wanted. 
It was an outcome that would be repeated, again and again, through three administrations. What Monsanto wished for from Washington, Monsanto -- and, by extension, the biotechnology industry -- got. If the company's strategy demanded regulations, rules favored by the industry were adopted. And when the company abruptly decided that it needed to throw off the regulations and speed its foods to market, the White House quickly ushered through an unusually generous policy of self-policing. 
Even longtime Washington hands said that the control this nascent industry exerted over its own regulatory destiny -- through the Environmental Protection Agency, the Agriculture Department and ultimately the Food and Drug Administration -- was astonishing.
"In this area, the U.S. government agencies have done exactly what big agribusiness has asked them to do and told them to do," said Dr. Henry Miller, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution, who was responsible for biotechnology issues at the Food and Drug Administration from 1979 to 1994.
The outcome, at least according to some fans of the technology? "Food biotech is dead," Dr. Miller said. "The potential now is an infinitesimal fraction of what most observers had hoped it would be."
While the verdict is surely premature, the industry is in crisis. Genetically modified ingredients may be in more than half of America's grocery products. But worldwide protest has been galvanized. The European markets have banned the products and some American food producers are backing away. A recent discovery that certain taco shells manufactured by Kraft contained Starlink, a modified corn classified as unfit for human consumption, prompted a sweeping recall and did grave harm to the idea that self-regulation was sufficient. The mighty Monsanto has merged with a pharmaceutical company.
How could an industry so successful in controlling its own regulations end up in such disarray?
The answer -- pieced together from confidential industry records, court documents and government filings, as well as interviews with current and former officials of industry, government and organizations opposing the use of bioengineering in food -- provides a stunning example of how management, with a few miscalculations, can steer an industry headlong into disaster.
For many years, senior executives at Monsanto, the industry's undisputed leader, believed that they faced enormous obstacles from environmental and consumer groups opposed to the new technology. Rather than fight them, the original Monsanto strategy was to bring in opponents as consultants, hoping their participation would ease the foods' passage from the laboratory to the shopping cart.
"We thought it was at least a decade-long job, to take our efforts and present them to environmental groups and the general public, and gradually win support for this," said Earle Harbison Jr., the president and chief operating officer at Monsanto during the late 1980's.
But come the early 1990's, the strategy changed. A new management team took over at Monsanto, one confident that worries about the new technology had been thoroughly disproved by science. The go-slow approach was shelved in favor of a strategy to erase regulatory barriers and shove past the naysayers. The switch invigorated the opponents of biotechnology and ultimately dismayed the industry's allies -- the farmers, agricultural universities and food companies.
"Somewhere along the line, Monsanto specifically and the industry in general lost the recipe of how we presented our story," said Will Carpenter, the head of the company's biotechnology strategy group until 1991. "When you put together arrogance and incompetence, you've got an unbeatable combination. You can get blown up in any direction. And they were."

Biology Debate
New Microbes Bring New Fears
In the summer of 1970, Janet E. Mertz was working at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, picking up tips on animal viruses from Dr. Robert Pollack, a professor at the private research center on Long Island and a master in the field. One day she began to explain to Dr. Pollack the experiment she was planning when she returned to her graduate studies in the fall at Stanford University with her adviser, Dr. Paul Berg. They were preparing to take genes from a monkey virus and put them into a commonly used strain of bacteria, E. coli, as part of an effort to figure out the purposes of different parts of a gene.
Dr. Pollack was horrified. The virus she planned to use contained genes that could cause cancer in rodents, he reminded her. Strains of E. coli live in human intestines. What if the viral genes created a cancer-causing microbe that could be spread from person to person -- the way unmodified E. coli can. Dr. Pollack wanted Ms. Mertz's project halted immediately. .
"I said to Janet, 'There's a human experiment I don't want to be part of,' " Dr. Pollack said in a recent interview.
The resulting transcontinental shouting match between Dr. Pollack and Dr. Berg set off a debate among biologists around the world as they contemplated questions that seemed lifted from science fiction. Were genetically modified bacteria superbugs? Would they be more powerful than naturally occurring bacteria? Would scientists who wanted to study them have to move their research to the sort of secure labs used to study diseases like the black plague? 
"The notion of being able to move genes between species was an alarming thought," said Alexander Capron, a professor of law and medicine at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. "People talked about there being species barriers -- you're reorganizing nature in some way." 
As researchers joined in the debate, they came to the conclusion that strict controls were needed on such experiments until scientists understood the implications. In 1975, the elite of the field gathered at the Asilomar conference center in Pacific Grove, Calif. There, they recommended that all molecular biologists refrain from doing certain research and abide by stringent regulations for other experiments. To monitor themselves, they set up a committee at the National Institutes of Health to review and approve all research projects.
It took just a few years -- and hundreds of experiments -- before the most urgent questions had their answers. Over and over again, scientists created bacteria with all manner of added or deleted genes and then mixed them with naturally occurring bacteria.
But rather than creating superbugs, the scientists found themselves struggling to keep the engineered bacteria from dying as the more robust naturally occurring bacteria crowded them out.
It turned out that adding almost any gene to bacteria cells only weakened them. They needed coddling in the laboratory to survive. And the E. coli that Ms. Mertz had wanted to use were among the feeblest of all.
By the mid-1980's, the Institutes of Health lifted its restrictions. Even scientists like Dr. Pollack, who sounded the initial alarm, were satisfied that the experiments were safe.
"The answer came out very clearly," he said. "Putting new genes into bacteria did not have the unintended consequence of making the bacteria dangerous."
That decision echoed through industry like the sound of a starter's pistol. First out of the gate were the pharmaceutical companies, with a rapid series of experiments on how the new science could be used in medicines. Hundreds of drugs went into development, including human insulin for diabetes, Activase for the treatment of heart attacks, Epogen for renal disease and the hepatitis B vaccine.
"It's been huge," said Dr. David Golde, physician in chief at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. "It has changed human health."
The success that modifying living organisms would bring the pharmaceutical industry quickly attracted attention from some of the nation's largest agricultural companies, eager to extend their staid businesses into an arena that Wall Street had endowed with such glamour.

Reaching Out
Monsanto Takes A Soft Approach
In June 1986, Mr. Harbison took control of Monsanto's push into biotechnology, a project snared in mystery and infighting. A 19-year veteran of Monsanto who had recently become its president and chief operating officer, he formed a committee to lead the charge.
"There is little more important than this task in our corporation at this time," Mr. Harbison wrote to the 13 executives selected for the assignment.
"We recognized early on," Mr. Harbison said in a recent interview, "that while developing lifesaving drugs might be greeted with fanfare, monkeying around with plants and food would be greeted with skepticism." And so Mr. Harbison drafted a plan to reach out to affected groups -- from environmentalists to farmers -- to win their support.
That same month, the company's lobbying effort for regulation began to show its first signs of success. The Environmental Protection Agency, the Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration were given authority over different aspects of the business, from field testing of new ideas to the review of new foods.
In an administration committed to deregulation, the heads of some agencies had been opposed to new rules. At an early meeting, William Ruckelshaus, then the head of the E.P.A., expressed skepticism that his agency should play any role in regulating field testing, according to people who attended. That was overcome only when Monsanto executives raised the specter of Congressional hearings about the use of biotechnology to create crops that contain their own pesticides, these people said.
By fall, Monsanto's strategy committee was developing a plan for introducing biotechnology to the public. A copy of a working draft, dated Oct. 13, 1986, listed what the committee considered the major challenges: organized opposition among environmental groups, political opportunism by elected officials and lack of knowledge among reporters about biotechnology.
It also highlighted more complex issues, including ethical questions about "tinkering with the human gene pool" and the lack of economic incentives to transfer the technology to the third world, where it would probably do the most good.
To solve political problems, the document suggested engaging elected officials and regulators around the world, "creating support for biotechnology at the highest U.S. policy levels," and working to gain endorsements for the technology in the presidential platforms of both the Republican and Democratic Parties in the 1988 election.
To deal with opponents, the document said, "Active outreach will encourage public interest, consumer and environmental groups to develop supportive positions on biotechnology, and serve as regular advisers to Monsanto."
Former Monsanto executives said that while they felt confident of the new food's overall safety, they also recognized that bioengineering raised concerns about possible allergens, unknown toxins or environmental effects. Beyond that, there was a reasonable philosophical anxiety about human manipulation of nature.
"If this business was going to work, one of the things we had to do was engage in a dialogue with all of the stakeholders, including the consumer groups and the more rational environmental organizations," said Mr. Carpenter, who headed the biotechnology strategy group. "It wasn't Nobel Prize thinking."

A Blunder
Decision on Milk Causes a Furor
Even as Monsanto was assembling its outreach strategy, other documents show that it was making strides toward what former executives now acknowledge was a major strategic blunder. The company was preparing to introduce to farmers the first product from its biotechnology program: a growth hormone produced in genetically altered bacteria. Some on the strategy committee pushed for marketing a porcine hormone that would produce leaner and bigger hogs. 
But, simply because the product was further along in development, the company decided to go forward with a bovine growth hormone, which improves milk production in cows -- despite vociferous objections of executives who feared that tinkering with a product consumed by children would ignite a national outcry. 
"It was not a wise choice to go out with that product first," Mr. Harbison acknowledged. "It was a mistake."
Scientists who watched the events remain stunned by Monsanto's decisions. 
"I don't think they really thought through the whole darn thing," Dr. Virginia Walbot, a professor of biological sciences at Stanford University, said of Monsanto's decision to market products that benefited farmers rather than general consumers. "The way Thomas Edison demonstrated how great electricity was was by providing lights for the first nighttime baseball game. People were in awe. What if he had decided to demonstrate the electric chair instead? And what if his second product had been the electric cattle prod? Would we have electricity today?"
The decision touched off a furor. Jeremy Rifkin, director of the Foundation on Economic Trends, an opponent of biotechnology, joined with family-farm groups worried about price declines and other organizations in a national campaign to keep the Monsanto hormone out of the marketplace. Some supermarket chains shunned the idea; several dairy states moved to ban it. The first step toward the shopping cart brought only bad news.
One year later, in 1987, the E.P.A. agreed to allow another company, Advanced Genetic Sciences, to test bioengineered bacteria meant to make plants resistant to frost. But under the agency's guidelines, it had to declare the so-called ice-minus bacteria a new pesticide -- classifying frost as the pest.
On April 28 and May 28, strawberry and potato plants were sprayed in two California cities. Photographs of scientists in regulation protective gear -- spacesuits with respirators -- were broadcast around the world, generating widespread alarm.
"It was surreal," said Dr. Steven Lindow, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, who helped develop the bacteria.
For the executives at Monsanto, these troubling experiences reinforced their commitment to the strategy of inclusion and persuasion.
The most complex challenge came in Europe, where there was deep distrust of the new foods, particularly among politically powerful farmers. Faced with such resistance, Mr. Harbison said Monsanto began subtly shifting its attention from the lucrative European market to Asia and Africa. The hope was that the economic realities of a global agricultural marketplace would eventually push Europe toward a more conciliatory attitude.
But by the early 1990's, company executives said, everything would change. Mr. Harbison retired. Soon, Monsanto's strategy for biotechnology was being overseen by Robert Shapiro, the former head of Monsanto's Nutrasweet unit, who in 1990 had been named head of the agricultural division.
In no time, former executives said, the strategy inside the company began to change. Mr. Shapiro demonstrated a devout sense of mission about his new responsibilities, these executives said. He repeatedly expressed his belief that Monsanto could help change the world by championing bioengineered agriculture, while simultaneously turning in stellar financial results.
Eager to get going, he shelved the go-slow strategy of consultation and review. Monsanto would now use its influence in Washington to push through a new approach. 
Mr. Carpenter, the former head of the company's biotechnology strategy group, recalled going to a meeting with Mr. Shapiro, and cautioning that it seemed risky to tamper with a strategic approach that had worked well for the company in the past. But, he said, Mr. Shapiro dismissed his concerns.
"Shapiro ignored the stakeholders and almost insulted them and proceeded to spend all of his political coin trying to deal directly with the government on a political basis rather than an open basis," Mr. Carpenter said. 
Mr. Shapiro, now the nonexecutive chairman of the Pharmacia Corporation, which Monsanto merged with last year, declined to comment. But in an essay published earlier this year by Washington University in St. Louis, he acknowledged that Monsanto had suffered from some of the very faults cited now by critics. 'We've learned that there is often a very fine line between scientific confidence on the one hand and corporate arrogance on the other," he wrote. "It was natural for us to see this as a scientific issue. We didn't listen very well to people who insisted that there were relevant ethical, religious, cultural, social and economic issues as well."

Turning Point
Objections By Scientists
On May 26, 1992, the vice president, Dan Quayle, proclaimed the Bush administration's new policy on bioengineered food. 
"The reforms we announce today will speed up and simplify the process of bringing better agricultural products, developed through biotech, to consumers, food processors and farmers," Mr. Quayle told a crowd of executives and reporters in the Indian Treaty Room of the Old Executive Office Building. "We will ensure that biotech products will receive the same oversight as other products, instead of being hampered by unnecessary regulation."
With dozens of new grocery products waiting in the wings, the new policy strictly limited the regulatory reach of the F.D.A, which had oversight responsibility for foods headed to market.
The announcement -- a salvo in the Bush administration's "regulatory relief" program -- was in lock step with the new position of industry that science had proved safety concerns to be baseless. 
"We will not compromise safety one bit," Mr. Quayle told his audience.
In the F.D.A.'s nearby offices, not everyone was so sure. 
Among them was Dr. Louis J. Pribyl, one of 17 government scientists working on a policy for genetically engineered food. Dr. Pribyl knew from studies that toxins could be unintentionally created when new genes were introduced into a plant's cells. But under the new edict, the government was dismissing that risk and any other possible risk as no different from those of conventionally derived food. That meant biotechnology companies would not need government approval to sell the foods they were developing.
"This is the industry's pet idea, namely that there are no unintended effects that will raise the F.D.A.'s level of concern," Dr. Pribyl wrote in a fiery memo to the F.D.A. scientist overseeing the policy's development. "But time and time again, there is no data to back up their contention."
Dr. Pribyl, a microbiologist, was not alone at the agency. Dr. Gerald Guest, director of the center of veterinary medicine, wrote that he and other scientists at the center had concluded there was "ample scientific justification" to require tests and a government review of each genetically engineered food before it was sold.
Three toxicologists wrote, "The possibility of unexpected, accidental changes in genetically engineered plants justifies a limited traditional toxicological study." 
The scientists were displaying precisely the concerns that Monsanto executives from the 1980's had anticipated -- and indeed had considered reasonable. But now, rather than trying to address those concerns, Monsanto, the industry and official Washington were dismissing them as the insignificant worries of the uninformed. Under the final F.D.A. policy that the White House helped usher in, the new foods would be tested only if companies did it. Labeling was ruled out as potentially misleading to the consumer, since it might suggest that there was reason for concern.
"Monsanto forgot who their client was," said Thomas N. Urban, retired chairman and chief executive of Pioneer Hi-Bred International, a seed company. "If they had realized their client was the final consumer they should have embraced labeling. They should have said, 'We're for it.' They should have said, 'We insist that food be labeled.' They should have said, 'I'm the consumer's friend here.' There was some risk. But the risk was a hell of a lot less."
Even some who presumably benefited directly from the new policy remain surprised that it was adopted. "How could you argue against labeling?" said Roger Salquist, the former chief executive of Calgene, whose Flavr Savr tomato, engineered for slower spoilage, was the first fruit of biotechnology to reach the grocery store. "The public trust has not been nurtured," he added.
In fact, the F.D.A. policy was just what the small band of activists opposed to biotechnology needed to rally powerful global support to their cause.
"That was the turning point," said Jeremy Rifkin, the author and activist who in 1992 had already spent more than a decade trying to stop biotechnology experiments. Immediately after Vice President Quayle announced the F.D.A.'s new policy, Mr. Rifkin began calling for a global moratorium on biotechnology as part of an effort that he and others named the "pure food campaign."
He quickly began spreading the word to small activist groups around the world that the United States had decided to let the biotechnology industry put the foods on store shelves without tests or labels. Mr. Rifkin said that he got support from dozens of small farming, consumer and animal rights groups in more than 30 countries. In Europe, these small groups helped turn the public against genetically altered foods, tearing up farm fields and holding protests before television cameras.
If the F.D.A. had required tests and labels, Mr. Rifkin said, "it would have been more difficult for us to mobilize the opposition."
Today, the handful of nonprofit groups that joined Mr. Rifkin's in lobbying the F.D.A. for stronger regulation in 1992 have multiplied to 54. Those groups, including the Sierra Club, Friends of the Earth, the Natural Resources Defense Council, Public Citizen and the Humane Society of the United States, signed a petition this spring demanding that the government take genetically engineered foods off the market until they are tested and labeled.
"There is absolutely no question that the voluntary nature of the policy was unacceptable to many," said Andrew Kimbrell, one of the early activists to oppose biotechnology and now the executive director of the Center for Food Safety, which filed the petition.
The F.D.A. policy has also helped organizations like Mr. Kimbrell's raise money. In late 1998 groups opposed to biotechnology approached the hundreds of foundations that give regularly to environmental causes and told them about the government's decision to let the companies regulate themselves. Since then, the foundations have given the groups several million dollars out of concern over the policy, said Christina Desser, a lawyer in San Francisco involved in the fund-raising effort.
There was also an about-face in the approach to dealing with overseas markets. As the Clinton administration came to Washington, Monsanto maintained its close ties to policy makers -- particularly to trade negotiators. For example, Mr. Shapiro was friends with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade negotiator who would eventually be named a Monsanto director. 
Confrontation in trade negotiations became the order of the day. Senior administration officials publicly disparaged the concerns of European consumers as the products of conservative minds unfamiliar with the science.
"You can't put a gun to their head," Mr. Harbison said of the toughened trade strategy with Europe. "It just won't sell."
And it didn't. Protests erupted in Europe, and genetically modified foods became the rallying point of a vast political opposition. Exports of the foods slowed to a stop. With a vocal and powerful opposition growing in both Europe and America, the perceived promise of biotechnology foods began to slip away.
By the end of the decade, the magnitude of Monsanto's error in abandoning its slow, velvet-glove strategy of the 1980's was apparent. Mr. Shapiro himself acknowledged as much. In the fall of 1999, he appeared at a conference sponsored by Greenpeace, the environmental group and major biotechnology critic.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Belgian Software Maker Said to Have Pact for Rescue Loan

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER with RIVA D. ATLAS 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 

 BODY:
Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V., the struggling maker of voice-recognition software, has reached a preliminary agreement on $60 million in rescue financing from a New York firm, according to an executive who has been briefed on the plan.
 Lernout & Hauspie, based in Ieper, Belgium, will go before a bankruptcy judge in Camden, N.J., on Thursday to get permission to release funds that will allow the lender, Ableco Finance L.L.C., to conduct due diligence for the rescue package, according to the executive. Ableco Finance specializes in making secured loans to troubled or bankrupt companies. Ableco is an affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management, a New York-based hedge fund. 
 Ableco has committed itself to lend at least $20 million, which will go to repay a bridge loan from GE Capital made to Lernout & Hauspie late last year. An additional $40 million, which would finance the company's operations, was contingent upon Ableco's review of Lernout's operations, according to the executive. The review must be completed by Feb. 7, the executive said. Lernout & Hauspie declined to comment on the court hearing and on the finance package. A person close to the company, however, said that Abelco's terms were "a lot better than those offered by GE Capital."
A spokesman for GE Capital confirmed that it had provided a loan facility of as much as $20 million, but declined to say how much of it had been tapped by Lernout & Hauspie.
Ableco's terms include an interest rate of 11.5 percent on the financing. The loan is in first position in the line of creditors waiting to be repaid by the ailing company.
Lernout & Hauspie filed for bankruptcy in Belgium and the United States last fall. It is also under investigation on both sides of the Atlantic after revelations of a $100 million cash shortfall in the company's South Korean unit and questionable accounting practices companywide. A new chief executive -- the third in six months -- was appointed last week. The new chief, Philippe Bodson, was chosen as much for his financial contacts in the United States as for his track record as a manager, analysts in Brussels said.
Ableco makes around $950 million of loans a year, with the average financing $20 million to $60 million, according to an executive close to negotiations.
Because of its affiliation with Cerberus, which specializes in investing in distressed securities, Ableco is often willing to invest in deals that larger, traditional secured lenders, like GE Capital, might turn down, the executive said.

HEADLINE: G.M. and Ford Set To Close 7 Plants 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
General Motors and Ford said today that they would idle a combined seven North American assembly plants in hopes of winnowing bloated inventories.
 G.M. said it would temporarily close five plants for the week. 
Those sites and their products are: Oklahoma City, Chevrolet Malibu; Oshawa, Ontario, Buick Century and Buick Regal; Orion Township, Mich., Buick LeSabre, Oldsmobile Aurora and Pontiac Bonneville; Lordstown, Ohio, Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunfire; and Hamtramck, Mich., Cadillac Seville, LeSabre and Cadillac DeVille. 
 All of tho shutdowns, which G.M. said would affect about 14,400 workers, were previously announced, except for the Hamtramck plant.
Ford said the two van plants it would idle were in Avon Lake, Ohio, where the Mercury Villager and Nissan Quest are made, and in Lorain, Ohio, where the Ford Econoline is produced.
Those plants employ 4,150 hourly workers, a Ford spokesman, Ed Miller, said.

HEADLINE: California's Lawmakers Submit an Energy Relief Proposal 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Encouraged by signs that the state could persuade generating companies to sell power to California at sharply reduced prices, Gov. Gray Davis and legislative leaders have drafted a comprehensive financial package for resolving the simmering energy crisis.
 Robert M. Hertzberg, the speaker of the State Assembly, submitted a roughly 35-page package of measures today to restore the state's ailing utilities to financial health and make the state government the major buyer and seller of electricity. 
 While some consumer advocates condemned the package as a bailout for the battered utilities, Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, the bill represented the first practical step by the state's political leaders for providing a long-term solution to the crisis. 
The bill would provide a way for the utilities to repay close to $12 billion in debt they incurred in recent months because of soaring wholesale prices for energy, allow the state to sell bonds to finance its own long-term purchases of energy for consumers and possibly grant the state stock warrants in the utilities, so if the prices of their shares rise in response to the plan, taxpayers would benefit.
In addition, Governor Davis, who has been slow to throw his weight behind any specific plans of this breadth, is preparing a package of proposals to increase conservation across the state and hasten the construction of new power plants, his aides said.
"Let's be clear about the stakes," Mr. Hertzberg said. "The California dream of a better life is in danger if we do not immediately move to return stability to our power supply."
The utilities have expressed reservations about some aspects of the plan; in particular, they have not embraced the idea of granting the state stock warrants. But utility officials said that over all, the proposals looked good and they were encouraged that their flirtation with bankruptcy could end if the package is passed.
"Reality is setting in," said Bob Foster, a senior vice president at Southern California Edison and the utility's leader at the negotiations in Sacramento. "Everybody's perception of the reality is getting narrower and more focused. Everybody is faced with difficult choices, but they're closer to making them."
He added: "I think people are getting comfortable with the major elements of the plan. Any reasonable proposal that could solve this problem and bring us closer to becoming a viable economic entity we'd look at."
Although some Republicans in the Democratic-dominated Legislature have said they did not agree with some details, they have also said they would support the package if some changes were made.
"This is the first time it's been drafted and then discussed in a public forum," said Bill Campbell, the Republican leader in the Assembly, "and that is what has to happen now to move it forward." 
A critical piece of the puzzle was an auction the state held on Wednesday. It had sought offers for long-term power supply contracts, and said it received packages from 39 bidders. Governor Davis had said he was seeking top bids of about $55 a megawatt hour. Late Wednesday the state said that the weighted average price was $69 a megawatt hour, and the governor called that close enough to begin negotiations, a fact that heartened most of those involved.
Today, state officials would say no more about the precise contents of those offers, saying they did not want to harm the negotiations that would commence soon. Larry Makovich, the senior director for electricity generation research at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, called the bids "a stopgap measure" that would not affect the core problem of short supplies of power.
Among the provisions in the bill, and other measures being considered, are these: 
*A 90-day emergency increase in power rates approved last month, which lifted residential charges about 9 percent, would be extended, probably for several years.
*About six-tenths of a cent to 1.2 cents out of every utility bill would be put in a special fund dedicated to helping the two utilities pay off the $12 billion or so in losses they have suffered in recent months because of soaring wholesale energy prices. 
*The state would sell revenue bonds totaling many billions of dollars to purchase power in long-term contracts and, as needed, on a day to day basis, to make up for the amounts the utilities cannot supply.
*The state would reduce the cost at which the utilities must purchase power produced by companies with cogenerating facilities or that have wind or other renewable power generation.
*In return for providing this support and relief to the utilities, the state would receive some financial benefit, perhaps stock warrants. If the shares of the utilities rebounded because of this stabilization plan, the value of the warrants would rise. 
These warrants could then be sold, and the proceeds be used to pay off the revenue bonds.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Peaks and Plateaus of a Volatile Year Surveyed

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Now that the books are closed on the gyrating Manhattan real estate market of 2000, surveys by two leading brokerage firms give a clearer picture of what happened.
 They indicate that prices dropped significantly as the Nasdaq stock index began its plunge, then rebounded substantially in the third quarter before slipping again slightly by year's end. 
 Although the steep price increases of recent years eased a bit for all Manhattan apartment sales, prices for co-ops -- traditionally less expensive than condominiums -- continued to rise through the year, even as condominium prices moderated somewhat in the third and fourth quarters.
And brokers say that prices have generally held steady during the first weeks of the new year. 
The overall average price for co-ops and condominiums sold during the fourth quarter of 2000 was $787,708, according to the Douglas Elliman Market Report. That was essentially unchanged from the $789,225 average in the third quarter, but was 38 percent higher than at the end of 1999, when the average was $569,005.
In fact, the year-end average was only 7.8 percent below the record average price of $854,704 set in the second quarter -- just before the Nasdaq began a 34 percent drop, from 5,048 on March 10 to 3,321 on April 14.
"The volatility in recent years really came to a head in the second quarter when we saw that record of $854,704," said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, the appraisal company that prepares the Elliman report. "Now I see some continuity, and I think that bodes well for the long term because double-digit appreciation isn't sustainable indefinitely."
But Manhattan real estate has been a good investment. The average price of an apartment at the end of 2000 was essentially double the average $395,035 recorded a decade ago. Even after being adjusted for inflation, the average price tag in the fourth quarter of 1990 was 29.6 percent less than it was at the same point in 2000. (The Elliman report examined 8,799 sales during the year, from Wall Street to West 116th Street and East 96th Street.)
Similar patterns were evident in the report compiled for the Corcoran Group by the Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson appraisal company. According to the Corcoran Report, the average price at the end of 2000 was $754,000, up 23 percent from $614,000 at the end of 1999. (The report covered 10,332 transactions from Wall Street to 116th Street.)
During the first quarter of 2000 alone, said Barbara Corcoran, the firm's founder, the average jumped 22 percent from the end of 1999, to $750,000. Then, Ms. Corcoran said, it slipped by 4 percent to $723,000. There was a 5 percent rise to $759,000 in the third quarter, followed by a 1 percent slip to $754,000 by year's end.
"It seems that at the same moment, everyone in New York decided they caught a cold," said Ms. Corcoran, who easily admits to a broker's ever-ready optimism. "Nobody really has a cold, but everybody's agreeing that they caught something.
"Asking prices are softer, sellers are more willing to deal, and bidding over the asking price, except for the choicest properties, seems a thing of the past."
The two studies found that co-op and condominium prices followed somewhat different paths.
The Elliman survey looked at 5,193 co-op sales and 3,606 condominium sales. As had long been the pattern, condominiums, which are generally newer, tended to be higher priced than co-ops.
Average co-op prices, the Elliman report said, rose to $710,947 in the fourth quarter of 2000 from $508,210 at the end of 1999 -- with most of the gain coming in the first six months. 
Condominium prices rose to $952,164 at the end of 2000 from an average $695,815 at the end of 1999. They jumped 50 percent during the first six months of the year, dropped 8.5 percent in the third quarter and were virtually unchanged, at minus 0.3 percent, in the fourth quarter.
The Corcoran Report indicated that the average price for studio apartments was $193,000 at the end of 2000 (up 21 percent from the end of 1999); $371,000 for one-bedrooms (a 32 percent jump); $843,000 for two-bedrooms (a 27 percent increase); and $1,689,000 for three-bedrooms (up 13 percent).
Mr. Miller was cautiously optimistic about the new year. Despite volatility in the stock markets, the average difference between list price and sales price remained below 2 percent for all of 2000, ending at 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter. "If they are close like that, it means there is still some upward pressure, albeit modest," Mr. Miller said.
"Couple that with actions taken by the Federal Reserve in lowering interest rates," he said, "and we may see more of the same over the next few months."

While average co-op prices in Manhattan increased somewhat in the last half of 2000, condominium resale prices eased. Sales are from Wall Street to East 96th and West 116th Streets. Figures are plotted quarterly.

HEADLINE: Las Vegas Bet on Growth But Doesn't Love Payoff 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 19 

 BODY:
Ten floors above the bail bondsmen, the sunburned homeless and the wedding ministers-for-hire that dominate downtown, Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas looks out at the gleaming carpet of urban expansion covering the Mojave Desert as far as the eye can see and utters a civic blasphemy.
 "Look at all those gated communities, those big beautiful houses where people don't know their neighbors and never talk to anyone," Mr. Goodman says. "It's nothing but -- I'm not supposed to say this -- sprawl!" 
 The mayor, who boasts of being a longtime lawyer for the mob and sprinkles his comments with wise-guy threats like "I oughtta throw them out this window," has become a most unlikely New Urbanist: He presides over the heart of a metropolis growing by 6,000 people a month while preaching the virtues of limitation. 
The 2000 census shows that the Las Vegas metropolitan area remains the fastest-growing region in the country, adding about 70,000 people a year to a population of 1.4 million. But troubles abound for this city that was but a gleam in Bugsy Siegel's eye 55 years ago, from bad air to choked traffic to diminishing water supplies to a squalid downtown ignored by the big-money casinos that are just beyond the city limits on the Las Vegas Strip.
"Las Vegas has become Orange County with casinos," said D. Taylor, an official with the Culinary Workers' Union, referring to the sprawling county southeast of Los Angeles. Mr. Taylor's union represents a majority of the bartenders, busmen, cooks and maids who keep the casino factories running for 35 million visitors a year. 
Mayor Goodman has big plans. He wants the core of his city to have "some culture," as he calls it, and a monorail, restaurants, apartments, grocery stores, bookstores, boutiques, a stadium, a high tech center, a museum, an art school -- in other words, the vital mix of ingredients that make up a healthy downtown. He wants all of this to happen soon -- or else.
"I represented the mob -- I don't fool around," Mr. Goodman said. "What Oscar wants, Oscar gets."
What Oscar Goodman wants is for Sin City to be a real city. But it is one thing to transform a mile-long strip of sand into fantasy replicas of Venice, Paris, New York and ancient Egypt, as the casino conglomerates have done just a few miles from downtown. There, giant television screens flash words that could pass for the civic mantra of Las Vegas: "Defeat Reality."
But it is another thing to get people to move downtown, to give up their cars, 3,000 square feet of stucco-encased home and a half acre of Mojave dirt for a high rise with a view of the "Defeat Reality" signs.
For if Las Vegas is the Detroit of the New Century, as some demographers have called it, the city appears to be following the pattern of the Detroit of the Old Century -- with the most striking growth happening in largely white, new suburban communities planted a good distance from the neighborhoods that once made up the vital center of the city. 
The fastest-growing city in the nation is not Las Vegas proper, which accounts for only a third of the people in the metropolitan area of Clark County, but Henderson, 10 miles to the southeast. Henderson has grown to 200,000 residents from 69,000 people 10 years ago and is expected to have a population of 560,000, or "full build out," in developer argot, within a generation. 
Henderson -- "A Place to Call Home," as its official motto says -- is a clutter of bulldozers and timber frames, sienna-colored cement walls, burlap-wrapped palm trees in midtransplant, and real estate flags flying above streets without names at the end of an unfinished highway. Some of the gasoline stations have Tuscan-style water fountains in the front, and there are so many new gated communities under construction that developers have run out of evocative Spanish and Italian names and started to recycle California names, like Napa and Sonoma. 
And California is the source of many of Henderson's new residents, who are fleeing high real estate prices, taxes and traffic for the new frontier in the middle of the Mojave, state population figures show. Many nouveau Hendersonians are baby boomers retiring early.
"We're in the midst of migration from the old Sun Belt to the new Sun Belt," said Bill Frey, a demographer from the University of Michigan and the Milken Institute in Santa Monica, Calif. "California, for example, is never going to be the draw that it used to be for a majority of new people, because it is simply not affordable."
The recent census showed that Nevada, with a 66 percent population growth rate over the last decade, and Arizona, with a 40 percent rate, were the nation's two fastest-growing states. These states, characterized by gangly, growth-spurt towns like Henderson, or Gilbert, Ariz., near Phoenix, which has grown to 112,000 people from 29,000 in 1990, are drawing what Mr. Frey calls "the yuppie elderly" -- people retiring early and looking for active entertainment. 
Arizona and Nevada are also attracting young, largely immigrant families, who find easy jobs in the booming service and construction economy and can afford to buy homes at the suburban fringe, where three-bedroom-two-bath houses sell for as low as $120,000.
"We moved to Las Vegas because here we can buy a house and get health insurance," said Andy Dunngrudeeswat, an immigrant from Thailand, who lived out of the back of a car wash in Los Angeles before moving to Las Vegas. Here, Mr. Dunngrudeeswat and his wife have been able to save enough money to buy a new house. He makes $13.63 an hour as a fry cook at Paris, the theme hotel on the Strip with its own Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe. 
The question some people in Las Vegas are asking is how long until this region resembles the places from which people are fleeing. Yes, the median price for a new home is inexpensive compared with prices in neighboring California -- $158,000, or practically one-fourth the cost of a new house in the four counties of Silicon Valley. 
But the prices of houses here are rising quickly -- up 11 percent last year -- far exceeding the median rise in household income. Bad air and clogged traffic are major concerns, so much so that the Environmental Protection Agency has said Las Vegas could lose some federal money if it does not take steps to clean its air. 
The smog is in large measure a result of auto traffic and dust from construction of new houses, federal officials say -- a hint that the Vegas boom may be creating the foundation of its own decline.
"We have perhaps 10 years left until we have to stop growing horizontally and have to grow vertically," said Mayor Goodman, whose office is officially nonpartisan. 
Another concern is that half of all jobs in Las Vegas are generally low-wage service-economy jobs -- the highest percentage of such jobs of any major American city. Nevada leads the nation in new job growth, but this region is starved for high-paying technology jobs. The best way to bring in technology talent, the mayor says, is to build the center of Las Vegas into a multidimensional urban area.
Whether retiring early or just entering the work force from a foreign country, the newcomers of metropolitan Las Vegas are not settling in the places where Mayor Goodman would like them to. While more than 20,000 houses were built in this area last year, there is still virtually no housing downtown, a hodgepodge of government buildings, parking lots and small offices. 
The older neighborhoods close to the city -- somewhat of an oxymoron, given that Las Vegas was basically a train depot with barely 8,000 souls in 1940 -- are run down, with few services. 
As the demographic tide flushes through Las Vegas to its newest suburbs, people like Dora Fribush, late of Baltimore, would seem to be just the kind of people the mayor is looking to attract. She and her husband, a stockbroker who works out of his house, looked at living in downtown Las Vegas but were lured to Henderson, to a $4.3 billion planned community called Lake Las Vegas Resort.
"When I told my friends we were moving to Las Vegas, they said, 'What are you going to do -- be a showgirl?" said Ms. Fribush, 52.
She looked at parts of Florida but thought the areas were too narrowly focused around older retirees, and California, which was too congested for her taste.
"I love the light here," Ms. Fribush said. "I love the space. But I do have some concerns about it being overdeveloped."
She has marveled at how quickly people, and places, have reinvented themselves in the desert.
Reinvention, another civic byword, is what Mayor Goodman would like for Las Vegas. A native of Philadelphia who moved to Las Vegas in 1964, Mr. Goodman has represented clients from Anthony Spilotro to Meyer Lansky. Since taking office 18 months ago, he has made "reurbanization," his No. 1 goal, using decidedly non-tough-guy lines like "we need places where the public can exchange social dialogue."
He has helped lure a company to build some low-income housing in the central city, smoothed the way for the first new downtown office building in 20 years -- a modest six-story structure -- and persuaded the Federal Bureau of Investigation to keep its regional headquarters here, instead of moving to Henderson. 
The last effort brought a letter from the F.B.I. to the mayor, noting that he had once said he would rather have his daughter date a member of the mob than an F.B.I. agent, and wondering if he still felt that way.
"I'm reconsidering," Mr. Goodman said.
But his biggest coup, the mayor said, was to acquire 61 vacant acres, once owned by the Union Pacific Railroad. On this land, he vows, Las Vegas will rebuild itself.
"My 61 acres downtown -- this is the greatest land swap since they took New York from the Indians for $24," Mr. Goodman said.
Though no specific plans have been announced, Mr. Goodman said he was encouraging any combination of apartments, offices, stores, cultural centers and a stadium to take root on the empty 61 acres.
But a city with 125,000 hotel rooms and only seven miles of bike paths could have trouble creating a vibrant new urban core when most of the civic energy, and certainly the money, is just beyond the city limits. On the Strip, the casinos are building a $600 million, three-mile extension to an existing one-mile monorail, the largest privately financed mass transit system in the nation.
The monorail will not extend the logical next few miles to downtown, meaning it serves only the millions of gamblers and gawkers who float though this town. 
Of late, Mr. Goodman has been critical of the major casino owners, saying they have not done their share to invest in the city beyond the Strip. He has even threatened to annex the Strip. 
"I'd like to see them extend the monorail to my 61 acres," he said. "These casinos -- they don't have to keep people hostage. They ought to let them out for a little air a few hours a day, and then they can let them go back to losing money."
If Las Vegas does not act to channel the additional half-million people expected to move here in the next decade into some semblance of dense, vibrant city, the mayor said, then it is only inviting the kinds of urban ills that have plagued older cities. But then again, he is not so sure what to make of the metropolis growing fat in the Mojave.
"Las Vegas is either the most unreal place in the world or the most real place," Mr. Goodman said. "I've lived here 37 years, and I've yet to figure out which it is."

HEADLINE: World Briefing 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:
 EUROPE

BRITAIN: ASYLUM SEEKERS SET RECORD
Britain recorded its highest annual number of asylum seekers in 2000, more than 76,000, up 5,000 from the year before. The rise occurred even as the Labor government, accused by the opposition Conservatives of turning Britain into a "soft touch" for bogus applicants, tightened entry measures and speeded up processing. The Home Office said a backlog of applications had been reduced from 100,000 to 66,000. Warren Hoge (NYT)

FRANCE: STRIKE HITS CITIES
Tens of thousands of French workers and retirees paralyzed transportation services in several major cities, protesting plans to change the way their pension funds are run. In a rare gesture of solidarity, France's combative public-sector trade unions joined private-sector employees in taking to the streets. The protesters are angry at the country's largest employers' group, which wants to increase the amount employees pay into their retirement funds. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

GERMANY: NAZI PAYOUT DELAYED
Nazi victim groups and German officials said they feared further delays in compensation payments to surviving Nazi-era slave laborers after a New York court deferred a ruling over outstanding litigation against German banks. Under the terms of the compensation deal, all outstanding suits against German companies over their Nazi past must be dismissed before payments from a $4.8 billion fund can begin. Victor Homola (NYT)

ITALY: A PAT IS NOT A CRIME
Italy's highest appeals court upheld a verdict that a pat on the bottom does not amount to sexual harassment. A man was sentenced to 18 months and a $4,000 fine, but the conviction was overturned. The woman charged he also threatened to block her career if she denounced him. The court ruled that a pat that is "isolated and impulsive" should not be considered a crime. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

VENEZUELA: PLANE CRASH KILLS TOURISTS
An airplane carrying American and European tourists crashed in southern Venezuela, killing all 24 people on board, officials said. The DC-3, operated by a regional airline, Rutaca, crashed near a hotel shortly after taking off from Ciudad Bolivar, officials said. The cause was not immediately known. The passengers included six Americans. Two children on the ground and their mother were injured. (AP)

CANADA: CHRETIEN TO VISIT BUSH
Prime Minister Jean Chretien is to visit Washington Feb. 5, becoming the first foreign leader to meet President Bush. The meeting is important to Canadians, who see the former Texas governor as oriented toward Mexico. Breaking with a loose tradition of making a first presidential visit to Canada, Mr. Bush is to make his first foreign trip to Mexico, meeting with President Vicente Fox on Feb. 16. James Brooke (NYT)

ECUADOR: PIPELINE SABOTAGED
An explosion in Ecuador's main crude oil pipeline near Santo Domingo de los Colorados, 83 miles west of Quito, caused about 10,000 barrels of oil to spill into local waterways, the state-run Petroecuador said. Jim Wyss (NYT)

ASIA

MYANMAR: ACTIVISTS FREED
Twenty activists of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's pro-democracy league were released from jail, a member of the group said, hours after one of the party's top leaders, Tin Oo, was freed after four months' detention. The releases were another sign of improved relations between the rulers and the league. (AP)

SRI LANKA: NO TO CEASE-FIRE
Prime Minister Ratnasiri Wickremanayake said on state radio that the government would not reciprocate a cease-fire declared by separatist Tamil rebels until the rebels entered peace talks. He also appealed to young men to join the armed forces so the military can press its offensive against the rebels. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

EAST TIMOR: MURDER SENTENCE
An international court sentenced Joao Fernandes, a pro-Indonesia militia member, to 12 years in prison for murdering an independence activist during the destruction of East Timor that followed the territory's vote to secede from Indonesia in 1999. It was the first successful prosecution for the rampage in which the United Nations said hundreds of people were killed and thousands left homeless by marauding militia gangs and the Indonesian military. Calvin Sims (NYT)

PHILIPPINES: DEFENSE AIDE QUITS
Defense Secretary Orlando Mercado abruptly resigned, delivering a jolt to President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's five-day-old government, which is already unsettled by economic anxieties and rumors of coup plots. Mr. Mercado said he did not agree with a decision to appoint a retired general whom he had investigated in the past for discrepancies in pension funds to be national security adviser. The resignation appears to underscore divisions in the new government. (Reuters)

MIDDLE EAST

JORDAN: A RETRIAL
A Jordanian-American sentenced to death in absentia in September for plotting to bomb tourist sites in Jordan will be retried next month on the same charges, his lawyer said, adding that he expected the trial to take place "in February at the latest." Raed Hijazi was arrested in Syria and extradited to Jordan late last year. (Agence France-Presse)

AFRICA

CONGO: INAUGURATION RESCHEDULED
The inauguration of Joseph Kabila as the country's new president was postponed a second time, the government said, citing logistical problems. The ceremony is now scheduled to take place today. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

HEADLINE: Economic Groups Call for New Power Supplies 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
Some of New York City's most powerful economic interest groups, including the Building and Construction Trades Council and the Real Estate Board, said yesterday that they feared that the city would face an energy crisis as early as this summer, and urged that new electricity supplies be installed as quickly as possible.
 A report by the groups released at a news conference in Manhattan offered no new solutions to the combined problems of rising electricity demand and unregulated energy prices, which were first felt in New York City last summer, when many residents and businesses saw energy bills increase as much as 40 percent in one month. 
 But electricity experts and environmental groups said the report would probably heighten both the anxiety in the region and the pressure on politicians to take action because of the large economic influence of the sponsoring organizations and the urgency of their words. 
The groups' core message was that the signature elements of economic life in New York -- Wall Street, the vast transit systems and the high-rise buildings that dominate the city's landscape and culture -- all hang by an invisible thread: ample electricity at a reasonable price.
"The decisions of businesses to expand or relocate to the city -- and thus the health of the city's economy -- will largely be determined by the sufficient supply and price of electricity," the report said.
Consolidated Edison, which delivers electricity to New York City and its northern suburbs, said this month that while it would probably have enough power to run the system this summer, assuming normal weather conditions, it might fall as much as 300 megawatts short in the amount of electricity that must be generated within the city's borders.
This does not necessarily mean that New York will not have enough electricity to run its lights, computers and air-conditioners, the company said, but that there might not be enough extra electricity to maintain reliability under the most extreme conditions.
Some citizen groups and environmentalists who are resisting the pressure to build new power plants in New York say that the projections of a shortfall have since been whittled by incremental growth in capacity at the city's plants and that the situation might not be as dire as yesterday's report suggests. They add that the business and construction groups counted only part of the economic costs of the electricity equation in reaching their conclusions.
"Power plants are pollution sources," said E. Gail Suchman, a senior environmental counsel at New York Lawyers for the Public Interest and a technical adviser to Communities United for Responsible Energy, a citywide coalition. "They affect people's health and waterfront development and open-space development -- there's an economic cost associated with those things, too. What we have here is a hysterical environment where everybody is playing on people's fears," she said.
The groups, which also included the New York Building Congress, the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce and the Association for a Better New York, also advocated conservation measures and proposals that would make it easier for companies to generate their own electricity.
But those measures, the group said, will not be enough, especially in the future, partly because some of the city's power plants are getting old and will have to be replaced.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
AMC SAYS IT WILL CLOSE UP TO 20% OF ITS MOVIE SCREENS

BYLINE:  Reuters

 BODY:
 AMC Entertainment, a leading operator of movie theaters, said yesterday that it would close as many as 548, or 20 percent, of its 2,774 screens. 
AMC, based in Kansas City, Mo., became the second theater operator this week to scale back operations. The company said that it had identified 307 poorly performing screens for disposal, and was considering closing 241 others. It said it had already shut 184 screens in the nine months ending Dec. 28. On Monday, Loews Cineplex Entertainment, the No. 2 theater operator, said it would close 675, or 23 percent, of its 2,967 screens.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
PHELPS DODGE SAYS ENERGY COSTS MAY FORCE LAYOFFS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the world's No. 2 copper producer, warned yesterday that it might reduce production and lay off as many as 2,350 employees at mines in New Mexico and Arizona because high energy costs in California had spilled over into nearby states. 
High electricity, diesel and natural gas prices had a significant effect on mines in Chino and Tyrone, N.M.; and Sierrita, Ariz., Phelps Dodge said. Those mines accounted for a quarter of the company's copper output last year. Its fourth-quarter energy costs rose 65 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
BRUNSWICK TO CLOSE 4 PLANTS AND LAY OFF 650 WORKERS

BYLINE:  Reuters

 BODY:
 The Brunswick Corporation, the world's largest maker of pleasure boats, said yesterday that it would close four plants and warned that its 2001 earnings would be lower than expected. The company, based in Lake Forest, Ill., said it would eliminate 650 jobs, or 7 percent of the workers in its boat group, when the plants closed at the end of March. The announcement came as the company posted a 4 percent increase in its fourth-quarter profit. Brunswick, also the largest maker of marine engines, said it expected its first-quarter profit to fall short of analysts' estimates. Its shares fell 50 cents, to $18.81.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
STANDARD REGISTER TO LAY OFF 28% OF ITS WORK FORCE

BYLINE:  AP

 BODY:
 Standard Register, a business forms printing company, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 2,400 workers, or 28 percent of its work force of 8,700, as part of a reorganization that calls for more investment in potential high-growth areas. 
Tara Henriksen, spokeswoman for the company, based in Dayton, Ohio, said layoffs would be across the board and would probably be phased in over a year. The locations have not been determined. Standard Register, which has operations in 31 states, makes business forms and provides document-management services to health care, financial and general business markets.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Increases Tolls And Train Fare 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to raise tolls at bridges and tunnels for the first time in a decade, and to increase fares on PATH commuter trains. But after sharp criticism at public hearings last week, the agency decided against even steeper increases proposed in November.
 The fare on PATH trains will rise to $1.50 from $1. The cash tolls at bridges and tunnels connecting New Jersey and New York City will rise to $6 at all times for automobile drivers, up from $4. E-ZPass users will pay $5 at peak hours and $4 at other times. 
 The new fares, adopted after intense discussions between Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey over the last two days, go into effect March 25. 
The new prices reflect the board's determination to keep tolls lower for E-ZPass users, and to give them even greater discounts at nonrush hours. 
The so-called congestion-pricing schemes are meant not only to encourage drivers to get the time-saving E-ZPass transponders but also to offer drivers lower tolls for traveling in less congested times.
Under the modified plan, approved by a vote of 10 to 1 with one member not present, the board decreased its proposed new PATH fare to $1.50 from $2 for a one-way trip. It is now $1. The PATH trains are used by 116,000 riders a day.
The new $6 cash toll for cars is a dollar lower than the cost originally proposed at the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington and the Staten Island bridges to New Jersey, which are used by 123 million vehicles a year. 
But E-ZPass holders will pay only $5 at peak hours, between 6 and 9 a.m. and 4 and 7 p.m., and $4 at nonpeak hours. The original plan provided off-peak discounts to E-ZPass users that ranged from $3 to $6, depending on the bridge or tunnel used and the time of travel. 
The current 50-cents-a-trip toll for carpools of three or more occupants who purchase up to 30 trips in advance will increase to $1.
For trucks, the modified plan charges the same $6 one-way toll per axle for cash payers at all times, as well as for E-ZPass-equipped trucks at peak hours. But truckers with E-ZPass can cross for $5 per axle at off-peak hours, and pay as little as $3.50 between midnight and 6 a.m.
PATH fares have not been raised since 1987, and tolls on the bridges and tunnels have not risen since 1991.
Governor Whitman endorsed the modified plan in a statement saying that it did not "place an unfair burden" on New Jerseyans, who make up 62 percent of the users of the bridge and tunnel crossings and 55 percent of PATH users.
Brad Race, the secretary to Governor Pataki and a member of the port agency board who favored the modified plan, said that while "nobody is ever happy to raise tolls," Mr. Pataki supported the plan and believed that it "minimized" the impact on commuters.
But there were some critics.
The Hudson County executive, Robert Janiszewski, said in a statement that he thought authority members "would listen to the concerns of commuters and see the faults within their proposal," but was disappointed.
Matthew L. Wright, president of Apgar Brothers, a trucking company in Bound Brook, N.J., and a board member of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, said the new toll schedule would result in "a huge increase" in costs for many trucking companies. 
Mr. Apgar noted that the previous rate of $4 per axle, which applied to all times of day or night, whether paid in cash or E-ZPass, meant a cost of $20 per crossing for a five-axle truck. At the new rate, the same truck will pay $30 in cash at all times or E-ZPass during peak hours. 
Many truckers will be unable to take advantage of off-peak pricing, and even fewer will have the overnight option, Mr. Wright said, because of constraints in the marketplace and local regulations that restrict delivery hours.
The Staten Island borough president, Guy V. Molinari, said he was pleased with the port agency's decision to preserve a discount for drivers who regularly use the Staten Island crossings. That discounted toll, which is now $2, will rise to $2.50.
The agency had initially proposed eliminating the discount, which has existed since 1991. It applies to 22,000 commuters a day. 
One of the key questions that remained for many, including the Port Authority's executive director, Robert Boyle, was whether the congestion-pricing plan, the largest in the country, will alter driver habits and encourage E-ZPass enrollments with with a differential of only $2 between the cash toll and the off-peak E-ZPass price.
The increases were intended to finance an ambitious series of construction projects over the next five years, projects totaling $14 billion -- as much as the agency has spent on construction in its 80-year history. 
The plan would re-establish the agency as a master builder in the region, expanding ports, rebuilding airports and upgrading mass transit.
Critics of the agency, including the Giuliani administration, condemned what they said was a continuing imbalance in what is spent in New York, which has 70 percent of the region's population, and in New Jersey, which has 30 percent. They were particularly critical of what John Dyson, the mayor's chief economic adviser, called the agency's "continuing trend" to spend more on Newark International Airport than on either of New York's airports, La Guardia and Kennedy. Port Authority officials deny that charge.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 27, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about fare and toll increases approved by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey gave a misspelled surname in some copies for the Hudson County executive who criticized the decision. He is Robert C. Janiszewski, not Janisewski.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
LAND AVAILABLE

BYLINE:  By Tara Bahrampour

 BODY:
 New York City has announced that it will accept proposals for the development of city-owned property at 16 locations for industrial, retail and residential use. 
The largest sites are a 107,000-square-foot plot in the Bathgate Industrial Park in the Bronx and two lots totaling 306,000 square feet in the College Point Corporate Park in Queens. Other sites include industrial properties and city-owned parking lots in Brooklyn and Queens. The city's Economic Development Corporation selects plans for city-owned land based on the offering price, an assessment of a project's economic viability, its impact on the surrounding community and the developer's experience. Proposals are due by March 29. Tara Bahrampour

HEADLINE: Argentina Off to Fast Start This Year 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
After years of desultory results, the Buenos Aires stock market has begun the year by soaring 26 percent, easily beating every other stock exchange in the world.
 The impressive spike has led some investors to say that Argentina might be poised to return to the days of the early 1990's when, with the government carrying out a sweeping privatization and deregulation program, the country was the darling of investors seeking emerging markets. 
 Other analysts caution that the rise in the main market indicator, the Merval index, could be just another speculative bubble -- there have been several here in the last decade -- that will burst unless the Argentine economy begins to grow quickly after shrinking for two years.
The total value of Argentine stocks has risen this year to $205 billion from $167 billion. The Merval index fell 5.69 points today, to 527.69. 
Prospects for stocks began to improve late last month after the International Monetary Fund and private banks approved a $39.7 billion financial package that eased fears that Argentina might default on its debts, release the peso from its peg to the American dollar, and spiral down a path of devaluation, rising inflation and corporate bankruptcy. 
Argentine stocks received another big lift when, in the United States, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point on Jan. 3. Lower interest rates up north usually translate into lower interest payments for Argentine government bonds. Every half-point drop in the United States, analysts say, means $350 million in annual savings for the Argentine government.
In a sign of renewed investor confidence in Argentina, the government sold $350 million in three-month treasury bills on Tuesday at a nominal annual interest of 6.75 percent -- the lowest rate in well over a year.
The stock market is also surging because of the stronger euro, since 25 percent of Argentina's commercial trade is with Europe. The euro's climb has produced what is effectively a 15 percent devaluation of the Argentine peso relative to Europe over the last two months. Meanwhile, a recent strengthening of the Brazilian economy and currency, and rising wheat, corn and soy prices promise to improve Argentina's exports this year, local economists say.
"The key issue for Argentina is growth, but the basis for growth is there," said Jorge Mariscal, chief investment strategist for Latin America at Goldman, Sachs. "The consumer has very little debt, companies are not very leveraged and banks are very liquid. You could see spending and lending pick up rapidly."
But so far, evidence of growth is spotty for an economy -- South America's second-largest -- that shrank 3.2 percent in 1999 in the wake of the Asian and Russian currency crises. Last year, it shrank again, by a fraction of a percent. 
"What is lacking fundamentally is real recovery in growth," said James Upton, Latin America equity strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "We forecast G.D.P. will grow only 1.5 percent this year. What that means is that at some point equity traders, who by nature are opportunistic, may very well take money off the table in Argentina and put it to work in Brazil."
Consumer and investor sentiment has been depressed in Argentina in the last six months, after a period of renewed hope and stock market gains at this time last year. President Fernando de la Rua took office just over a year ago, promising to bolster growth, but his tax-raising and budget-cutting policies had the opposite effect.
"Growth cannot come from one day to another," the economy minister, Jose Luis Machinea, acknowledged this week. "It will come when people have confidence they are not about to lose their job."
Unemployment remains stubbornly high at about 15 percent. But government officials predict that a decline in interest rates will translate into 2.5 percent growth this year, followed by sustained rates of 4 percent to 5 percent in coming years. 
But uncertainties remain, analysts say. One is the strength of the United States economy, since a recession would be likely to have a strong ripple effect across Latin America.
Another is the steadiness of the de la Rua government, a coalition whose weakness was highlighted by the resignation of Vice President Carlos Alvarez in October in a dispute over the handling of a Senate bribery scandal.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Market Rebound"As 2001 began, investors seized on a run of good economic news and bid up Argentine stocks. Chart shows Merval Index since Dec. 2000.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Bosnia, Sort Of

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: ZVORNIK, Bosnia 

 BODY:
What is the best way to sum up the situation in Bosnia today, five years after NATO came to its rescue? Very simple: Bosnia today is sort of a country -- it's sort of united, sort of divided, sort of peaceful, sort of corrupt, sort of coming back, sort of not coming back -- a place where NATO armies feel sort of good about what they've done to stabilize the country, but where NATO diplomats feel sort of bad that Bosnia's Serbs, Muslims and Croats still have not come together enough for the state to function on its own. 
 It's sort of like that. 
 This ambiguous reality is a perfect mirror of the ambivalent attitudes the NATO allies brought to the task of rescuing this country. That is, the allies were not so callous as to let Bosnia be formally partitioned between Serbia and Croatia. They cared enough eventually to move in 60,000 NATO troops to stop the fighting. But they did not care enough about the place to actually take over the government, throw out all the rotten nationalist politicians and rebuild Bosnia from the ground up so that by now it would be more than sort of a country. As such, change here is going to be painfully slow, and both NATO and America are going to have to be here for a long time. 
Lt. Col. Bruce Hain of the U.S. Army, who commands a U.S.-NATO unit near the border with Serbia, let me join him on a patrol through the largely Bosnian Serb town of Zvornik, where you can see exactly what has and has not changed here.
You see that a makeshift marketplace in the town center sits where one of Zvornik's three mosques once stood, before it was razed by the Serbs. But if you look up in the hills you see that thousands of Zvornik's Muslims have returned, with international aid and protection, and rebuilt their homes. But around the corner you also see apartments that used to belong to Zvornik Muslims but are now occupied by Serbian refugees from Sarajevo, who will have to be forcibly evicted if more Muslim refugees want to come home. Colonel Hain says that will not be easy. 
You see the Drina River flowing by full of garbage because Zvornik has no waste system, but you see that the road into town has been neatly plowed of snow, because NATO pays local Serbs to clear it, a symbol of how dependent the locals are on NATO. Unemployment here is 50 percent. You see that you can walk across the Drina bridge right into Yugoslavia and no one will stop you, because only 3 of Bosnia's 432 border crossings are manned, which is why this country has become the key portal for smuggling drugs and people into Europe, particularly Iranians and Chinese. Stopping that is not part of NATO's mission. Maybe it's the grim weather, but you see no one with a smile, not even kids.
Actually, the happiest people here are the 4,900 U.S. troops serving with NATO. "It's a great opportunity for someone like myself to lead people," explains Colonel Hain. "Everyone here feels that they're doing something important." This is not spin. You hear this from all U.S. troops: We're keeping the peace and getting experience in everything that an army does -- patrols, intelligence, transport, operations -- except killing people. It beats marching around a flagpole in Germany. It is no accident that the highest rate of re-enlistment in the U.S. Army today comes from troops in Bosnia and Kosovo.
That's no reason to stay here forever, but it is a reason not to rush away. The Bush team wants to turn Bosnia peacekeeping over to the Europeans. But without some U.S. troops on the ground, the Europeans won't stay here for long either. It's the U.S. troops who intimidate the bad guys in Bosnia, and it's U.S. leadership that makes NATO work. Period. 
Civil wars end in one of three ways, and Bosnia will be no different. Either they end like Lebanon, with a soft partition, a lot of mixing, but under an iron fist (Syria); or they end like Cyprus, with a hard partition and no mixing; or they end like the U.S. Civil War, with one side crushing the other and imposing its order. NATO will not allow a hard partition, but it has no desire to conquer and run the country properly itself. So Bosnia is going to have a soft partition, with a weak government and with, ideally, more mixing of people every year. But it will need NATO's iron fist in the background for years to achieve even that, and NATO will need America's help. If we're lucky, in 10 years Bosnia will be like Bulgaria. That's the future. Get used to it. Things could be worse. Sort of.
