HEADLINE: Chiquita Sues Europeans, Citing Banana-Quota Losses 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
In the latest move in an escalating trade dispute, Chiquita Brands International sued the executive body of the European Union yesterday for $525 million in damages related to banana quotas that the company contends have pushed it to the brink of bankruptcy. 
 Chiquita, based in Cincinnati, which until now had relied on the United States government to fight for its market share in Europe, filed the lawsuit with the Court of First Instance of the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg. In the suit, Chiquita contended that unfair European trade barriers had cost it half its market in Europe and directly contributed to the financial difficulties that forced the company to suspend payment on its debts last week and begin a financial restructuring. 
 The $525 million the company is seeking from the commission represents "only a fraction of the damages" Chiquita has suffered because of the trade restrictions, said Robert W. Olson, a senior vice president and general counsel. 
Mr. Olson said that $525 million corresponded to lost profit and other harm that Chiquita has incurred only since Jan. 1, 1999, the date on which the most recent banana import system was put in place by the European Commission, the European Union's day-to-day executive. 
Chiquita contends that even though the 15 nations of the European Union have agreed to comply with World Trade Organization rulings that the restrictions are unfair, the new system, like the one it replaced, is illegal. In April 1999, the W.T.O. ruled that the new restrictions did not comply with international trade laws. 
Chiquita also warned the European Commission that it would seek further damages later this year if another new method of distributing import licenses on a first-come-first-served basis is enforced in April. Chiquita and United States trade officials have called that system unfair. 
In Brussels, Pascal Lamy, the European Union trade commissioner, declined to comment on the suit because it is before the Court of Justice. But the commission has rejected Chiquita's contention that the import system is the cause of its financial woes. Anthony Gooch, a spokesman, said, "If you try to compare the respective situations of Chiquita and the other banana companies that have to operate under similar conditions, it suggests that Chiquita's difficulties probably lie elsewhere."
The banana trade war has been going on since European nations in 1993 started favoring bananas imported from their former colonies in the Caribbean and Africa. The Europeans contended that without such help, small-scale banana growers would suffer. 
Chiquita had invested heavily to break into the European market a decade ago. After the trade barriers were erected, it turned to Washington for assistance. The company's chairman and chief executive, Carl H. Lindner, has made big contributions to both political parties. 
Chiquita's bananas are grown in Latin America, and are not United States products. But the Clinton administration took up the company's cause anyway and brought several complaints to the W.T.O. on Chiquita's behalf. They were decided in Chiquita's favor, but the Europeans delayed amending the import rules. 
The United States then imposed $191 million in punitive sanctions on a range of European goods including Italian pecorino cheese and British shortbread. Mr. Lamy has said that the European Union will challenge the American sanctions if they are not lifted when the new banana import rules take effect in April.
Craig Pouncey, a lawyer with the Brussels office of Herbert Smith, the firm representing Chiquita, said the European Commission has also been sued by five European companies involved in the banana trade that have been hurt by the quotas. He said trade-related suits are brought against the European Commission "very frequently." 
Mr. Gooch, the commission spokesman, said four European producers of goods that have been put on the United States sanctions list have sued the commission for damages indirectly caused by the banana rules. "Our position on these cases has been clear," Mr. Gooch said. "We do not believe they have any grounds for bringing these cases before the Court of Justice." 
Steven G. Warshaw, president and chief operating officer of Chiquita, said he did not expect the suit against the European Commission to be decided before the company completes the financial restructuring of its $862 million debt with corporate bondholders later this year. "This legal proceeding will extend beyond that," Mr. Warshaw said. "This is a subject we'll have to discuss with our bondholders."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Ad Bowl 2001 Will Be a Rout

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Warren G. Harding was never president during a Super Bowl. But his campaign promise of a "return to normalcy" could describe Super Sunday for Madison Avenue as the dot-com mania of 2000 gives way to a far more traditional advertiser lineup. 
Last year, as digital fever was cresting, 17 advertisers during the game were dot-coms, compared with 3 during the game in 1999; including Britannica
.com, Computer.com, Epidemic.com, Lifeminders.com, OurBeginning.com and Pets.com. Their frenzy to get a sales pitch before the biggest single viewing audience of the year even led some to pay $3 million for 30 seconds of commercial time, $800,000 more than the average price.
 01-26-01 
 That cyberstampede sent several mainstay Super Bowl advertisers like MasterCard to the sidelines to avoid the high cost, not to mention the hyperbolic atmosphere of so many newcomers all clamoring for attention at once.
Now, with dot-com hysteria as deflated as a football sat upon by Tony Siragusa of the Baltimore Ravens, the roster of Internet marketers has been pared to three, all Super Bowl veterans: the E*Trade Group, Hotjobs.com and the Monster.com division of TMP Worldwide.
As a result, most of the 30 marketers paying CBS an estimated average of $2.3 million for each 30-second time slot during Super Bowl XXXV on Sunday come from established categories like apparel, automobiles, films, financial services, packaged goods and soft drinks.
In 2001, "there are no 'flaky' clients," said Joseph Abruzzese, president for network sales at CBS, owned by Viacom, in New York. "They're all bona fide, real marketer clients." Among the blue-chip, not-com names: Anheuser-Busch, FedEx, the M&M/Mars division of Mars, the Frito-Lay and Pepsi-Cola units of PepsiCo, Visa, Volkswagen of America -- and MasterCard, back after its I year away.
"This is going to be a return to what the Super Bowl was," said Larry Flanagan, chief marketing officer at MasterCard International in Purchase, N.Y. "All the major advertisers back in place."
The result could be a less frenetic Ad Bowl than last year, when the agencies working for the dot-coms -- almost all fledglings desperate to be noticed amid a sea of competitors -- produced myriad commercials that grated and annoyed with bizarre plots or self-consciously madcap antics. For instance, spots for Computer.com and Lifeminders.com both assumed coy, faux-naif poses by pretending to be cheap home movies, while OurBeginning.com centered its commercial on a cat fight among angry brides.
"If you looked at a lot of the dot-com ads, they were wacky, but they didn't tie back to their brands," said Dawn Hudson, senior vice president for strategy and marketing at the Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo in Purchase.
"I wouldn't want to say that dot-coms were better than traditional or traditional were better than dot-coms," she added, "but we would like people to keep looking forward to the ads as well as the game."
That is an understatement, as Ms. Hudson is buying three minutes' worth of commercial time during the game for her flagship brand. The spots, by the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, will feature a new theme, "Joy of Pepsi," replacing the more generic "Joy of cola."
Last year, the ad lineup included "a lot of first-timers throwing money around," said Bob Lachky, vice president for brand management at Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis. "The vast majority of them weren't very memorable."
"Now, you've got a lot of major advertisers coming back, people with more experience on branding," he added. "It is a more challenging year for us, very competitive."
Anheuser-Busch will run commercials in every quarter for Budweiser and Bud Light beers as well as a spot about under-age drinking featuring the boy band 'N Sync. The spots are from two other Omnicom units, the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide and Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco.
As if to underscore the drastic difference between Super Bowl XXXIV and XXXV, 4Sure.com, a direct marketer in Trumbull, Conn., announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the assets of Computer.com, which closed in November. The subject line of an e-mail message delivering a news release about the deal read: "4Sure.com acquires last year's big Super Bowl ad spender."
Yet even though the dot-com presence has diminished so markedly, the Internet is now a more intrinsic part of the game plans of all advertisers, whether their technology is high or low.
For example, Anheuser-Busch had promotions on two of its own Web sites, BudBowl.com and Budweiser.com, and on a CBS site, SportsLine.com. MasterCard will be the sponsor of "the biggest online travel program we've ever done," Mr. Flanagan said, "live on our Web site on Super Bowl Sunday." And Pepsi-Cola joined Yahoo in sponsoring an online poll at pepsi.yahoo.com in which computer users can vote for their favorite Pepsi Super Bowl spots.
"You'll see more interaction," Ms. Hudson said. "It's a wave of the future."
"The number of rooms with both television and computers on at the same time is surprisingly high," she added. "That enables us to have a one-to-one dialogue with somebody while doing something broad-based on TV."
Nonadvertisers are seeking to ride the coattails of the companies willing to spend the most money ever for commercial time to reach what is likely to be the largest audience by far for any TV show this year. Among those conducting ad polls during and after the game or putting up game spots on their sites are Ecreativesearch.com, Eisner Communications, Greenfield Online, NTN Communications and USA Today, the latter for a special, "Super Bowl's Greatest Commercials," to be shown by CBS tomorrow night.
"We wanted to have an interactive component to have the fans involved," said Bob Horowitz, senior vice president for programming at the Trans World International unit of the International Management Group in New York, which is producing the show with the National Football League.
Given the dot-com disappearing act, how do the few actually advertising in the game feel?
"The Super Bowl has become a crucial component of our strategy," said Jeff Taylor, chief executive at Monster.com in Maynard, Mass., the job search Web site that is running Super Bowl spots for the third consecutive year. "We made the decision to come back the day after last year's."
"People watch the advertising like a show, so it's the only time the whole year your ads are content," he added. "And January marks a huge surge in job hunting; last Tuesday we set a record with 38,100 resumes posted on our site. The Super Bowl kicks in another additional surge; we doubled our traffic the day after the Super Bowl last year."
Monster.com will run two commercials from its new agency, Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising.
Hotjobs.com in New York, which competes against Monster, is also back for the third consecutive year, this time with a commercial by Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York. Richard Johnson, chief executive at Hotjobs, said that traffic to www.hotjobs.com, its Web site, soared 450 percent after the 2000 Super Bowl, and resume submissions climbed 750 percent.
The largest dot-com advertiser, E*Trade, is back again not only with commercials during the game but also as the sponsor of the halftime show.
"It's a very different marketing environment this year," said Michael Sievert, chief marketing officer at E*Trade in Menlo Park, Calif. "It's an investment that works best for leading brands, brands that have something to say."
What E*Trade has to say, according to Mr. Sievert, is to describe "how we've evolved from a trading company to a fully integrated financial services company." That is why the company's commercials, by Goodby, Silverstein, will promote its banking and retirement planning services as well as its stock trading service.
Another sign of how the Super Bowl ad landscape has returned to normalcy is the lessening of the frantic demand for commercial time compared with last year, when the dot-coms bid up prices.
The softening economy has even led to widespread speculation in trade publications that CBS had trouble maintaining the $2.3 million average price for each 30 seconds of commercial time in selling the 30 minutes of spots that will appear during the three-hour game.
"There was such a huge hole from the dot-coms, everyone said, 'They'll never fill it; I'll buy at the last minute,' " Mr. Abruzzese said. "But we saw this coming months ago, and we had a good strategy to sell it for what it was worth."
"We beat our estimates, and that's all that really matters," he added.
CBS will take in $155 million from selling time before, during and after the game, Mr. Abruzzese said. The previous record, $130 million, was set by the network broadcasting the game last year, the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company.
Add the $50 million in ad revenue coming in on Sunday at the local stations CBS owns around the country, and the payday exceeds $200 million.
Is that enough to satisfy Mel Karmazin, the president and chief operating officer at Viacom, who is renowned for his close scrutiny of ad revenue?
"I am very happy; I am extremely happy," Mr. Abruzzese said, adding with a laugh, "Mel is probably, too, but he would never say that."

HEADLINE: At Qualcomm, Earnings Beat Forecast by 1 cents 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Qualcomm, the developer of wireless communications technology, posted first-quarter earnings today that beat Wall Street estimates. And it said it agreed with profit forecasts for the year.
 The company, which is based in San Diego, reported earnings of $231.6 million, or 29 cents a share, versus $209.6 million, or 27 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
 The results topped Wall Street's forecast of 28 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Qualcomm reported revenue of $684 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, down 10 percent from the period a year ago. Including one-time items, the company posted a net loss of $228.7 million, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter, in contrast to a net profit of $177 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Reported revenue fell to $684 million from $1.1 billion.
Qualcomm shares fell 31 cents, to $73.94, in Nasdaq trading before the announcement. The stock jumped 3 percent, to $76.31 a share, in after-hours trading on Instinet.
Qualcomm's chairman and chief executive, Irwin M. Jacobs, said demand was strong and still growing for the company's code division multiple access (CDMA) technology, Qualcomm's proprietary wireless technology that competes with two other global standards.
"Our technology licensing and semiconductor businesses are benefiting from strong demand for CDMA technology and products," Mr. Jacobs said in a statement.
Qualcomm said it was comfortable with current analyst estimates for second-quarter earnings of 29 cents a share, as well as full-year 2001 estimates of $1.27 a share.
In the first quarter, Qualcomm's satellite business was hit by economic and capital market conditions, as well as a recent decision by the satellite telephone company Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd. to suspend payments on its debt as it looked at restructuring options.
On Jan. 16, Globalstar said it had indefinitely suspended payments on all its debt, meaning it did not make a principal and interest payment of about $22 million to Qualcomm the day before.
Qualcomm recorded $595 million in charges relating to reserves against certain Globalstar-related assets.

HEADLINE: IN POLICY CHANGE, GREENSPAN BACKS A BROAD TAX CUT 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave his blessing today to a substantial tax cut, but warned that it should not be so big that it would plunge the government back into deficit if the federal budget surplus fails to materialize as projected.
 In a clear shift from his previous position that reducing the national debt should be the focus of fiscal policy, Mr. Greenspan said improvements in the economy's long-term potential and the swelling surplus projections had "reshaped the choices and opportunities before us" to permit a combination of debt reduction and tax cuts. 
 Mr. Greenspan also provided his first public assessment of the state of the economy since the Fed cut interest rates at the beginning of the month to help keep the precipitous slowdown from becoming a recession. 
He said the economy had all but stopped growing, leading some analysts to conclude that the central bank is likely to cut rates by another half a percentage point at its meeting next Tuesday and Wednesday.
"As far as we can judge, we have had a very dramatic slowing down, and indeed we are probably very close to zero at this particular moment," Mr. Greenspan said. 
As his stature has grown in Washington and around the world, Mr. Greenspan has increasingly exerted influence on issues outside of the central bank's responsibility for setting interest rates. His statement on taxes, in testimony to the Senate Budget Committee, was reminiscent of his support in early 1993 of President Bill Clinton's first big economic initiative -- his proposal to bring what was then a huge federal budget deficit under control.
Just as his hedged backing of Mr. Clinton's plan provided invaluable political cover to Democrats then as they voted to raise taxes, his guarded endorsement of a tax cut today gave new impetus to the effort by Republicans to push through the biggest tax reduction since the Reagan administration.
His comments were especially pleasing to the White House, which has made President Bush's proposal for a $1.6 trillion tax cut over the next decade the centerpiece of its economic agenda.
Speaking to reporters at the White House this evening, Mr. Bush said Mr. Greenspan's statements were "measured and just right," and that the Fed chairman recognized "that we need good monetary policy and sound fiscal policy to make sure the economy grows."
Democrats cited Mr. Greenspan's focus on fiscal discipline as justification to keep any tax cut much smaller than what Mr. Bush has been seeking. But Democrats were clearly disheartened that Mr. Greenspan, who until now had provided them with one of their most effective arguments against sweeping tax cuts, had changed his tune.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said he had always viewed Mr. Greenspan as the anchor of efforts for fiscal responsibility.
"I believe that you were right then, and I am somewhat stunned by the fact that the anchor seems to be wavering today," Mr. Byrd said. 
As he always does, Mr. Greenspan, who is less than a year into his fourth four-year term as head of the central bank, told members of both parties at least some of what they wanted to hear. He said he was a supporter of across-the-board reductions in income tax rates, the provision at the heart of Mr. Bush's plan.
But Mr. Greenspan passed up an opportunity to endorse Mr. Bush's proposal specifically. And while he did not say how big a tax reduction would be appropriate, he suggested that he was sympathetic to the concern expressed by many Democrats that a stampede to cut taxes could come back to haunt the nation if the surplus falls short of expectations.
Surplus projections are little more than educated guesswork, he said, and Congress should view them with some skepticism, at least until economists have a better understanding of why the economy has been generating far more tax revenue than expected in recent years. Analysts have been grappling in particular with how much of the surge in tax revenue came from the run-up in stock prices in the late 1990's and what would happen if the market remained flat or fell in coming years.
"With today's euphoria surrounding the surpluses, it is not difficult to imagine the hard-earned fiscal restraint developed in recent years rapidly dissipating," Mr. Greenspan said. "We need to resist those policies that could readily resurrect the deficits of the past and the fiscal imbalances that followed in their wake."
Mr. Greenspan also undercut one of Mr. Bush's main arguments for cutting taxes now, that doing so would help counteract the current economic slowdown. Fiscal policy, he said, moves too slowly to deal effectively with the ups and downs of the business cycle, especially in a period in which the economy seems to be adjusting to changing circumstances with exceptional speed.
He said a tax cut could "do noticeable good" in the unlikely event of a long-lasting economic downturn. 
But he suggested that any tax reduction be tied to continued progress in reducing the debt on the schedule currently contemplated by both parties. If the surplus rolls in as anticipated, the entire $3.4 trillion in national debt held by the public could be paid off by the end of this decade or shortly thereafter.
Any plan for using the surplus "could include provisions that, in some way, would limit surplus-reducing actions if specified targets for the budget surplus and federal debt were not satisfied," he said.
"Only if the probability was very low that prospective tax cuts or new outlay initiatives would send the on-budget accounts into deficit would unconditional initiatives appear prudent."
Republicans have not seriously considered any plan under which tax cuts would be linked to progress in debt reduction, and it is unclear whether Mr. Greenspan's suggestion had any chance of being adopted.
Democrats said the roughly $3 trillion in surpluses expected over the next decade outside the Social Security system would not be enough to cover a tax cut of the scale envisioned by Mr. Bush. They said that once other needs are accounted for, like increased military spending and adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare, Mr. Bush's plan would send the government into deficit.
But Republicans said the surplus provided more than enough room for a tax cut and other needs. Jill Kozeny, a spokeswoman for Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Republican from Iowa who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Mr. Greenspan's testimony had convinced Mr. Grassley that a tax cut the size of Mr. Bush's "is doable and that it's important to do it."
Mr. Grassley had previously suggested that it would be difficult to get a tax cut of more than about $1 trillion through the Senate, which is divided 50-50 between Republicans and Democrats. Mr. Greenspan denied that he had flip-flopped on his support for tax cuts. He said that until now, it was not at all clear that the government had a real chance at eliminating the debt held by the public within a decade.
But improvements in the most basic measure of economic potential -- productivity, or output per hour -- have substantially brightened the economy's long-term prospects, even at a time when the economy is enduring a short-term downturn, he said.
As a result, he said, there is a greater likelihood that the government will run surpluses for years to come -- and that the government will soon confront the welcome but tricky question of what to do with surplus revenue when the debt is zero.
Lacking anything else to do with the money, Mr. Greenspan said, the government might eventually end up buying stocks and corporate bonds on Wall Street, involving Washington heavily in private enterprise.
To avoid that outcome, he said, the government should act now to put fiscal policy on a "glide path" that pays off the debt and leaves little or nothing in the way of additional surpluses once the debt reaches zero.
The trade-off between debt reduction and other uses of the surplus "appears no longer an issue," Mr. Greenspan said.
Budget policy should strive to make the surplus outside of the Social Security system "economically inconsequential when the debt is effectively paid off," and it is "far better, in my judgment, that the surpluses be lowered by tax reductions than by spending increases," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Greenspan did not address the current state of the economy in his prepared testimony, but answered questions about it from members of both parties.
Growth in the fourth quarter of last year "was a very small positive," he said. The most notable aspect of the slowdown, he said, is that businesses are responding to the deterioration in the outlook by reducing their inventories of unsold goods and supplies before ordering any more.
Whether the economy sinks into recession, he added, will be largely dependent on how consumer confidence holds up.
He said there was also some risk to the national economy if the power crisis in California were not resolved. And he noted that higher energy costs in general had acted as a brake on growth.
"We're in a period where we are observing the beginnings of what is probably a major inventory correction," he said. "The critical issue we need to address is whether that degree of contraction is enough to breach the fabric of consumer confidence. At the moment, it has not. Indeed, we do not yet see the actual immediate implications of what recessions look like, but we won't know how this all works out for a while."
Mr. Greenspan said that investments in technology allowed companies to respond to fluctuations in demand for their products, and to their need for supplies and raw materials, more quickly and with greater accuracy than ever before. As a result, he said, the inventory adjustment may take place much more rapidly than in past cycles.
Investors have been debating for the last several weeks whether the Fed would cut interest rates by another half a percentage point next week, or hold the rate cut to a quarter of a percentage point. The Fed cut its benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks to 6 percent from 6.5 percent on Jan. 3.
Analysts said Mr. Greenspan's testimony suggested that the Fed was more likely to cut rates by half a point next week. They said the chances for a half-point cut were bolstered by the government's report today that employment costs increased in the last three months of 2000 at a slower-than-expected pace.

HEADLINE: Once a Critic, Giuliani Turns Benefactor, With $1.2 Billion for Arts Projects 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

 BODY:
With classic Giuliani-esque swagger, the mayor who launched an infamous assault on the Brooklyn Museum of Art asserted last month that he had done more to support the city's great cultural institutions than any other City Hall occupant of the last half century. Yesterday, Rudolph W. Giuliani provided hard numbers to turn that claim into fact -- and change the image of a mayor known more for his desire to build baseball stadiums than opera houses.
 In a financial plan presented to a packed crowd in the City Hall Public Hearing Chamber, Mr. Giuliani proposed that the city spend a record $1.2 billion over the next 10 years on expanding or rebuilding Lincoln Center, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guggenheim Museum, the Museum of Modern Art, the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the New York Public Library, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the New York Aquarium, among other institutions. Cultural leaders, who had been generally aware of the mayor's proposals, were nonetheless taken aback by the extent of the riches. 
 No other mayor, they said, had ever given them so much. Mr. Giuliani, once a scourge in the city's salons for trying to shut down the Brooklyn Museum over an exhibit he termed "sick stuff," was now a hero.
"This is what happens to all good mayors," said Gordon J. Davis, the president of Lincoln Center, which is to receive $240 million from the city over the next decade. "All good mayors learn how the arts are so intertwined in the identity of New York City. Even if they don't appreciate the art, they come to appreciate the power of those institutions -- the power of ideas, the power of the art they're creating, the economic power, the political power."
What caused the change in Mr. Giuliani, who also happens to be an ardent opera fan? And why now, when the term-limited mayor has only 11 months left in office?
First, many of the city's cultural leaders said, the mayor is hurriedly trying to erect an attainable physical legacy after two terms largely free of splashy new edifices. "This is a mayor who until now has not shown a tremendous interest in building monuments," said Randall Bourscheidt, the president of the Alliance for the Arts, an advocacy group. "And I think that approaching the end of his term, and no doubt because of some of the other reflections that have been prompted by his health, he is probably thinking in the long-term. And nothing is more long-term than building a museum or a library or a botanical garden. These are the things that survive all the changes that this city is known for."
Second, the leaders said, the mayor has seized on a prosperity-fueled renaissance in cultural building that has not occurred in the city since the last quarter of the 19th century. "You couldn't have invented this, even if he had wanted to," Mr. Bourscheidt said. "The timing is perfect because of the long period of prosperity, but also because of a period of great civic optimism." Yesterday, for example, Mr. Giuliani pointed out that the city's $240 million for Lincoln Center is to be used to help attract private donations to what is estimated to be a $1.5 billion redevelopment project.
Third, the mayor has said himself that he has come to see spending on cultural institutions as an investment in one of the city's booming businesses in a post-industrial New York -- a view he expressed as far back as 1993, before there was much city money for him to spend. 
"If we looked at it that way, and if the mayor talked to the people of the city that way, it would be much easier to invest in cultural institutions and not create the feeling that you're being a dilettante," Mr. Giuliani said at the end of last year. "What I observed happening in the city for 30 years, as a resident and a citizen, is that whenever there were difficulties in the budget, mayors would pull money out of the cultural institutions on the theory of 'How can you spend money on music, how can you spend money on dance, how can you spend money on painting, how can you spend money on these things when people are starving?' And the reality is that by spending money on all those things, many fewer people starve. Because that's the way you develop an economy in a capitalist country," he had said.
Fourth, the cultural leaders said, Mr. Giuliani was engaging in the pleasant task of spending hundreds of millions of dollars in the budgets of future mayors, who will bear the expenses when he office next year. Although nothing legally binds a future mayor to spending money committed in the city's 10-year capital budget, cutting such funds would be politically costly.
Finally, cultural leaders pointed out that members of the City Council, who have approved or in some cases increased the mayor's proposed spending on cultural projects, were as much heroes as Mr. Giuliani. City Council members also pointed out yesterday that the mayor had once again cut the operating budgets of the cultural institutions, an annual budget negotiating tactic that Mr. Giuliani uses to keep overall city spending in line.
It also helps, budget analysts independent of City Hall said, to keep the mayor's spending on culture in perspective. The record $1.2 billion represents less than 2 per cent of the city's 10-year capital budget, which is made up largely of spending on schools, bridges, road, highways and sanitation.
Put another way, the eye-popping $240 million over 10 years for one of the city's cultural jewels, Lincoln Center, still does not match the $302 million proposed over the same time period to replace the Willis Avenue Bridge.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 Greenspan Lends Support To a Substantial Tax Cut
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his blessing to a substantial tax cut but warned that it should not be so big that it would plunge the government back into deficit if the federal budget surplus fails to materialize as projected.
 Mr. Greenspan, in testimony before the Senate Budget Committee, also provided his first public assessment of the state of the economy since the Fed reduced interest rates on Jan. 3, saying the economy has all but stopped growing. That led some analysts to conclude that the central bank is likely to cut rates by another half a percentage point at its meeting next week. Page A1. 

Neighbors Point Finger at California
Public officials in Western states have ominous political problems like soaring electricity rates and deregulation plans in turmoil. But those leaders, at least for now, have a convenient one-word explanation for the debacles and a place to point the blame: California. A1.

Some of New York City's most powerful economic interest groups said that they feared the city could face an energy crisis as early as this summer and urged that new electricity supplies be installed as quickly as possible. B2.

Chiquita Sues European Agency
In the latest move in an escalating trade dispute, Chiquita Brands International sued the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union, for $525 million in damages related to banana quotas that the company contends have pushed it to the brink of bankruptcy. Chiquita, led by Carl H. Lindner, contends that unfair trade barriers have cost it half its market in Europe and directly contributed to the financial difficulties that forced the company to suspend payment on its debts last week and begin a restructuring. C5.

Dow Edges Up, but Nasdaq Falls
The stock market reacted cautiously to remarks made by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 82.55 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,729.52. But the rally was confined to blue-chip stocks, as technology issues declined. The Nasdaq composite index fell 104.87 points, or 3.7 percent, to 2,754.28. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.79 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,357.51. C5.

Scientists Map Genome of Rice
Two companies are expected to announce that they have determined the sequence of the genome of rice, the first commercially important crop to have its genetic code unraveled. C5.

Double-Digit Gains for Drug Makers
American Home Products posted a fourth-quarter loss after a charge that was higher than expected for diet pill litigation. Two rivals, Eli Lilly and Schering-Plough, said profits rose as they sold more drugs that are meant to have fewer side effects. American Home's income rose 17 percent before the charge. Eli Lilly's profit rose 14 percent, and Schering-Plough's gained 13 percent. Shares of American Home climbed $2.89, to $57.64, while Eli Lilly advanced 31 cents, to $83.06, and Schering-Plough rose $1.69, to $53.63. C5.

Bidder Chosen for Japanese Bank
After an intense round of bidding, Japanese financial regulators have chosen the Lone Star Group, a private equity fund group based in Texas, to take over the bankrupt Tokyo Sowa Bank, because its bid for the bank would require the least amount of public money to clear away bad loans. World Business, Section W.

Qualcomm Profit Beats Forecast
Qualcomm posted a 10.5 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, beating Wall Street expectations, and said it agreed with profit forecasts for the full year. C2.

HEADLINE: Choosing Hunter College President Puts CUNY Trustees in Tug-of-War 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
The selection of the next president of Hunter College on Manhattan's East Side is the subject of a fierce power struggle, with Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani lobbying trustees of the City University of New York to choose Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, and the university's chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, jockeying for a proven manager of a large complex organization. 
 Ms. Raab, who was issues director for Mr. Giuliani's 1989 mayoral campaign, is pressing hard for the position, and aides to Mr. Giuliani and Governor Pataki have talked to many of the trustees about supporting her, according to trustees who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 Randy M. Mastro, a former deputy mayor under Mr. Giuliani who is one of the trustees who supports Ms. Raab, said she would bring special skills to the job.
"Jennifer Raab is obviously a person of extraordinary ability, leadership and accomplishment," he said, noting that he had worked closely with her. 
He predicted that with her wide contacts in the city, she would have "an immediate positive impact on fund-raising and attracting private sector energy and talent."
Dr. Goldstein however, is said to want someone with more managerial, academic and fund-raising experience for Hunter, which has 20,000 students and is CUNY's most populous college. He has told trustees that he favors Jo Ann M. Gora, the provost of Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Va., a Vassar graduate with a doctorate in sociology from Rutgers. He said he felt that she had demonstrated the capacity to manage a large, complex organization, to raise money and to understand the culture and problems of higher education.
Located on East 68th Street and Park Avenue, Hunter is highly visible and is one of CUNY's most popular campuses. Former Hunter presidents include Donna E. Shalala, who served as Bill Clinton's secretary of health and human services, and Paul LeClerc, the president of the New York Public Library. 
Some of the trustees who back the chancellor's candidate say that their efforts to improve the university and its image will be set back by a presidential appointment that they say is politically motivated. They added that such an appointment could impede their ability to attract strong candidates for the presidencies of two of its other flagship campuses, City College and Queens College.
But other trustees, who support Ms. Raab's candidacy, say that CUNY will look best if it chooses the strongest person, and that it is appropriate for the governor and the mayor to express their perspectives both on policy issues and personnel decisions. 
Most of the trustees on both sides would only talk on the condition that they not be quoted directly. Herman Badillo, the chairman of the board of trustees, Dr. Goldstein and Ms. Raab all declined requests to be interviewed about the selection process.
Yesterday, Hunter students and faculty leaders sent a joint letter to the trustees, calling on them "to ignore external forces that can intrude on the collaborative and unambiguous results of the presidential search."
The letter was signed by Hunter's student government leaders, the chairwoman of the Hunter College Senate, the president of the Faculty Delegate Assembly and the three Hunter professors who sat on the trustees' search committee.
The mayor appoints 5 of the 17 trustees and the governor 10. (The remaining board seats are held by a student who votes on appointments and a faculty member who does not.) 
Mr. Giuliani's office did not respond two requests for comment Wednesday and yesterday. Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the governor, would only say, "The governor has every confidence that the trustees have conducted a proper and thorough search that will produce the best qualified candidate."
Ms. Raab was one of four finalists that the board's search committee forwarded to Dr. Goldstein, but she had less support than the two leading candidates, one of whom was Dr. Gora.
Ms. Raab, who holds degrees from Cornell University, Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs and Harvard's law school, has served since 1994 as chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, an agency with 60 employees, a $3 million budget and wide reach throughout the city. 
During a meeting with Hunter College students, faculty and staff in December, she noted that she had graduated from Hunter College High School and believed strongly in public service and in public education. She added that her training as a lawyer helped her be a strong advocate and pointed to others, like Ellen V. Futter, the former president of Barnard, who had become college presidents without having risen up through academe.
CUNY officials said yesterday that Dr. Goldstein had been impressed with Ms. Raab and confirmed a report by the cable news channel station NY1 that he had offered her a job as president of a new economic development agency for CUNY.

HEADLINE: New Spending And Tax Cuts In '02 Budget 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, in his final budget plan, offered city residents a crowd-pleasing smorgasbord yesterday, with funds for new museums, low-cost housing and an extended school week and a sprinkling of new tax cuts on top.
 But the budget plan, while acknowledging that the city economy is cooling, leaves many of the bills for these offerings for his successor to handle. 
 A $39.32 billion plan for the coming fiscal year contains few surprises since the mayor outlined most of the new initiatives in his speech on the state of the city earlier this month. There is $103 million in new money to offer weekend science and English-language classes, as well as an expanded summer school program and mini-libraries in 21,000 classrooms, among other school initiatives.
And there is an extra $110 million for police programs intended to improve officer morale, track down suspects with outstanding warrants and combat the city's drug trade, among new crime-fighting efforts. 
A $405 million package of tax cuts the mayor is offering for 2002, climbing to $1.02 billion by 2004, has been proposed before but failed to win approval from the State Legislature. The package includes the elimination of a $2-a-night tax on hotel rooms, the creation of a city tax credit for the working poor, a series of reductions in levies paid by city businesses and the elimination of the city sales tax on clothing and shoes.
Mr. Giuliani, who used the opportunity during his hourlong budget presentation yesterday at City Hall to once again review the highlights of his seven years in office, said the city could afford to supplement spending in targeted areas while cutting taxes because of the years of able management by his administration and the City Council.
"The city has room to make choices," Mr. Giuliani said. "We have done the difficult job and continue to do it, more modestly now, of reducing the size of our spending, or trying to keep it under control." He used a laser pointer to run through dozens of budget charts, some of which had so many numbers that the mayor joked that the city officials and reporters packed into the old Board of Estimate chamber in City Hall would need the eyesight of Air Force pilots to read them.
His plan drew mixed reviews from the candidates vying to replace him, as well as the budget watchdogs who paged through the four volumes of spending data for the next four years and construction plans for the next decade.
"It is a major step in the right direction," said the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Democratic candidate for mayor. "It also has some pretty deep potholes in it."
The part of the 2002 city budget paid for by local taxpayers, according to the mayor's calculation, would drop by two-tenths of 1 percent. But once adjustments are made to reflect the city's prepayment of some of next year's debt with this year's expected $2.26 billion surplus, there would actually be inflation-adjusted growth of half of 1 percent, according to the city's Independent Budget Office.
The single biggest piece of the overall budget, as always, would go to the school system, a total of $12.19 billion, once pension and debt costs are included. That is less than 1 percent more than in the current year, but still a record. 
The mayor balances the budget for fiscal 2002, which begins July 1, with a Wall Street profit forecast that, despite hints of an economic slowdown and a sluggish stock market, is slightly more optimistic than it was at this time last year. 
And Mr. Giuliani's plan to spend $51.9 billion on new schools, rebuilt bridges, new museums and hundreds of other projects over the next decade would mean that 18.75 cents of each city tax dollar collected by 2004 would have to go to repay debt, up from 12 cents in 1990. 
The 10-year capital plan includes $13.4 billion for schools, translating into 13 new schools in the 2002 fiscal year, or 20,000 new classroom seats. The plan for the first time also includes $68 million for the new Guggenheim museum in Lower Manhattan and an extra $200 million a year for low-cost housing.
Mr. Vallone said he welcomed the tax cut plan since many of the specific items were reductions he first proposed. But the mayor's plan projects deficits in the next four years that cumulatively are a third larger than he predicted a year ago, totaling $7.18 billion. 
"Yes, taxes are too high in New York," said the public advocate, Mark Green, another Democratic candidate for mayor. "But with hard economic times looming, the city needs a more modest and targeted tax cut plan that doesn't leave the next mayor with a large deficit."
Mr. Vallone and other Council members also chided the mayor for once again including proposed spending cuts in city agencies -- from libraries, to parks, to museums and health and welfare programs -- that the Council has convinced him to restore in past years.
"It is just a waste of good time, essential time that we could spend on other things," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, of the detailed program cuts, which totaled $700 million. "These are good programs. It should not happen."
The mayor and his budget director, Adam L. Barsky, dismissed suggestions that the budget would leave the city in a financial bind for the next mayor. In fact, the mayor said, "It makes the fiscal condition of the city a lot more stable today than it has been since, I guess, before the fiscal crisis" of the 1970's.
Mr. Giuliani's revenue projections, while somewhat less conservative than last year's, are still extremely sober, City Council officials said, estimating, for example, that Wall Street would earn $7.2 billion in profits in the 2002 calendar year, compared with the estimated $19.5 billion in 2000. A year ago, the mayor estimated 2002 Wall Street profits at $5.3 billion.
The mayor attributed much of the projected future deficits to the state government, which in 1999 eliminated a commuter tax paid by suburbanites who work in the city and last year sweetened pension benefits for retired city employees. Those and other changes by the state will cost the city $853 million in 2002. And, the mayor added, the tax cuts can always be scaled back in the future if there are problems.
One of the biggest unknowns is the cost of settling contracts with the unions representing about 200,000 city employees. The mayor has about $800 million in the budget to provide about a 2.5 percent raise for most city workers, although he wants this money to be given out on the basis of merit.
But if the raises reach 5 percent -- about the level granted in the last year of the expired contracts -- the city would have to find $728 million more in 2002, according to the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit budget group. Furthermore, the four-year spending plan does not include money for raises in the final two years.
"We do want to settle," Mr. Giuliani said. "We do want to give them a pay raise. We are anxious to do that. But we can't do it at an irresponsible level."

HEADLINE: California Gets Scant Sympathy From Neighbors 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
Soaring electricity rates. Record-low reservoir levels at some big dams, which could imperil migrating salmon this spring. Deregulation plans in turmoil. A crash conservation program being urged on consumers and businesses. A dispute over whether to resume a long-abandoned nuclear power project.
 For public officials in California's neighboring states and elsewhere in the West, these sound like ominous political problems. And they certainly are, except that those leaders, at least for now, have a convenient one-word explanation for the debacles and a place to blame: California. 
 "California made their mess and we're paying for it," said Ken Rust, the chief financial manager for Portland, Ore. Utah's governor, Michael O. Leavitt, blamed California's "disastrous deregulation scheme" for an 11 percent increase in electricity rates that a major utility is proposing in his state. 
"Consumers in other Western states are left to pick up the tab," Governor Leavitt said. An editorial cartoon in The Salt Lake Tribune shows California plugging into an electrical outlet in snowy Utah to run a hot tub to the south.
Criticism of California, long popular in the West, has reached a crescendo in recent days as that state's electricity woes continue to mount, forcing rolling blackouts and threatening its largest utilities with bankruptcy. Far from expressing much sympathy, many people outside of California say that state has brought a huge problem on itself and, increasingly, on the entire region.
There is truth in this finger-pointing, but it hardly tells the whole story. While California is desperately seeking electricity during a season in which it normally exports electricity to the Pacific Northwest and the Rocky Mountain states, there are plenty of other reasons for the rising rates here.
Natural-gas prices are soaring throughout the nation, and reservoir levels for the mammoth hydroelectric projects in the Northwest are low mainly because the region's rainfall in the past few months has been among the least in decades.
John Savage, Oregon's energy director, acknowledged this factor in testimony before the State Legislature's House Committee on Smart Growth and Commerce on Wednesday when he said, "Our hope is for 75-degree weather and rain of biblical proportions for the rest of the winter." 
And even as California gets blamed for failing to build any major power plants in a decade as its population grew by four million and itseconomy boomed, many other Western states do not have a much better record of increasing generation of electricity in the face of burgeoning populations.
"First and foremost, there is a shortage of megawatts," said Lawrence J. Makovich, senior director of power research for Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., referring to problems throughout the Western states. "There simply isn't enough generating capacity attached to the grid to meet the demand. The second problem is that when shortages hit, prices go through the roof."
Montana, the nation's fourth-largest energy-producing state on a per-capita basis, is one Western state that no longer has huge surpluses. Until recently, it exported 40 percent of the energy it produced. But over the last decade, the state population has grown nearly 13 percent, and state lawmakers are considering loosening environmental regulations to make it easier and faster to build new power plants.
Still, people in other states say California is failing to hold up its end of a long-running bargain, even as its governor, Gray Davis, blamed "out-of-state profiteers" for driving up the price of electricity and pushing the state to the brink of crisis. Neighboring states are angry about California's demands for power.
"It was a very complementary system," said Jacques P. Lawarree, an economics professor at the University of Washington and an expert on deregulation. "California sends power in the winter, when it's most needed here, and in the summer we send back power. It's always been a very good thing.
"Now that they have a problem and cannot do their part, we in the Northwest are suffering for that," Mr. Lawarree said, "and there are some who wish we could cut off California entirely from the grid. But it's also clear that we've benefited for many, many years."
Indeed, like it or not, there is recognition that the Western states will remain tied together on the power grid that sends huge amounts of electricity across the region, and that more cooperation, not less, is needed between California and other states. The Western Governors' Association, a nonpartisan group, is scheduled to meet in Portland next week with federal regulators and the new energy secretary, Spencer Abraham.
"It's very important that this doesn't deteriorate into a Northwest versus California thing," Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon said before a meeting with Gov. Gary Locke of Washington and Governor Davis of California in Sacramento earlier this month. (All three are Democrats.)
"We're all in this together," added Governor Kitzhaber who, with Governor Locke, has urged home owners, businesses and state agencies to find ways to cut electricity consumption by at least 10 percent. "We cannot afford to let California go down the tubes."
Still, as Mr. Rust, the director of Portland's bureau of financial management, put it, the federal mandates compelling the Northwest's generators to send power to California have aggravated the often "tenuous relationship" between his state and its much larger neighbor to the south.
As federal reservoirs have been drawn down to generate more power during this emergency, Mr. Rust said, the odds are being driven up that more young salmon will die this spring because river flows will not be adequate to get them downstream. The region, under the Endangered Species Act and a plethora of lawsuits, has spent billions of dollars on plans to save the fish.
"This is a huge issue in the Northwest, and it seems like it's barely getting factored into the discussion right now," Mr. Rust said in a telephone interview. "The concern is that with this requirement to send power to California, all the concerns about protecting the stream flow, the salmon habitat, all the money that's been spent to protect those fish, it all could get thrown out the window in an instant." 
Officials at the Bonneville Power Administration, the federal agency that sells power from a network of two dozen dams in the Northwest, said that low reservoirs are, indeed, danger signs, but are the result of the weather more than of the demands that the California crisis has placed on the system. The fate of the fish this spring will depend a great deal on the amount of rain and snow in the coming months and on the rate at which the winter snowpack melts into the region rivers.
But senators from Washington and Oregon have pleaded with federal regulators to stop an order requiring Bonneville electricity to go to California, so far to no avail. President Bush recently extended that order until early February but said it would not be continued after then.
"Frankly, I think my state is being set up -- and I include Washington State -- to be an energy farm for California," Senator Gordon H. Smith, an Oregon Republican, complained last week. He said he had received calls from several business executives in his state who said electricity rates for their companies had gone up between 30 percent and 40 percent, and they blamed California's demands. 
Meanwhile, while no other Western state is as far along with deregulation as California is, the recent woes seem to be putting the brakes on any movement toward deregulating. Several Oregon officials, including Mayor Vera Katz of Portland, have called for postponing a limited deregulation plan in that state. 
And earlier this week, Gov. Kenny Guinn of Nevada, said in his State of the State speech that he would delay a plan there that had been set to begin this fall.
"I cannot and will not support deregulation until I am assured that power supplies are secure," Governor Guinn, a Republican, said.
The recent problems have even sparked a debate here in Washington State that for much of the last decade would have been unthinkable: whether to finish a nuclear power plant, which was abandoned three-quarters finished in 1994, at the giant Hanford reservation. The organization building it, the Washington Public Power Supply System, known by its initials, W.P.P.S.S., and widely called Whoops, had a spectacular financial collapse and defaulted on more than $2 billion in bonds.
Officials at a successor utility consortium, Energy Northwest, said recently that the plant could be completed and generate electricity at competitive rates, given the recent spike in the market. But the idea outraged environmentalists and some utility executives, and prompted another official at the the consortium to say that it was about as likely to fill in the Grand Canyon as to resurrect the nuclear plant.

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on
Page 8.

Now Playing

"ANTITRUST," starring Tim Robbins, Ryan Phillippe, Rachael Leigh Cook and Claire Forlani. Directed by Peter Howitt (PG-13, 120 minutes). Overplotted and overdirected, this thriller about high-tech corporate skulduggery is clever and likable enough to make you feel a bit sorry about the lousy timing of its release. Mr. Phillippe plays an earnest young geek seduced away from his friends' Internet start-up by a Bill Gates-like cyberguru (Mr. Robbins). Like most Hollywood movies about corporate villainy, "Antitrust," waving the banner of the open-source movement, feels a bit phony. But Mr. Howitt and the production designer, Catherine Hardwicke, do a nice job of capturing the ambience and idioms of the New Economy workplace (A. O. Scott).

* "BEFORE NIGHT FALLS," starring Javier Bardem. Directed by Julian Schnabel (R, 125 minutes). Mr. Schnabel's romanticized portrait of the exiled gay Cuban poet and novelist Reinaldo Arenas, who died of AIDS, imagines pre-Castro Cuba as a pagan paradise of endless erotic promise ruined by the puritanical Communists, whom Arenas initially embraced then turned against. Mr. Bardem's arresting performance paints Arenas as an emotionally volatile daredevil. But this biography, which incorporates swaths of Arenas's writing, is sketchy, and the star's thick Spanish accent is daunting. It's still quite indelible (Stephen Holden).

* "CAST AWAY," starring Tom Hanks and Helen Hunt. Directed by Robert Zemeckis (PG-13, 143 minutes). The core of this contemporary Robinson Crusoe story is an unforgettably gripping survival drama. Mr. Hanks is a Federal Express employee shipwrecked on a desert island after a plane crash. Physical survival depends on things like rubbing two sticks together to start a fire and cracking open coconuts. For companionship, he paints a face on a volleyball and names it Wilson. As in all his films, Mr. Hanks makes his character compelling by infusing him with a childlike openness. But the interrupted love story that frames the survival sequences is sappy and formulaic (Holden).

* "CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON," starring Chow Yun Fat, Michelle Yeoh and Zhang Ziyi. Directed by Ang Lee (PG-13, 120 minutes). Mr. Lee puts his particular stamp on the Hong Kong action film, and it results in "Sense and Sensibility" with a body count. Mr. Lee and the writer James Schamus are careful to invoke all the conventions of the genre, affectionately exposing them to parodic excess: there's so much high-flying swordplay that the movie seems to have repealed the laws of gravity. Mr. Lee also gives the proceedings a soulfulness not endemic to the genre. Mr. Chow comes across as the Cary Grant of the blade. But Zhang Ziyi is the real focal point of the film, and she claims it for herself (Elvis Mitchell).

"DOUBLE TAKE," starring Orlando Jones and Eddie Griffin. Directed by George Gallo (PG-13, 88 minutes). A shell game of a movie that will do anything to hustle a chuckle out of an audience. Mr. Jones is a smooth-talking investment banker named Daryl who finds himself implicated in a multimillion-dollar swindle while mysterious killers dog his tracks. The motormouth Mr. Griffin is a small-time con man who agrees to take on Daryl's identity as a life-saving gesture. "Double Take" has a criminal lack of attention: it ruthlessly sacrifices its own logic on a regular basis for a cheap laugh (Mitchell).

"THE GIFT," starring Cate Blanchett and Keanu Reeves. Directed by Sam Raimi (R, 112 minutes). Mr. Raimi's moody exercise in small-town supernaturalism may belong, with "The Sixth Sense," to a special subgenre: the emotional thriller. Ms. Blanchett plays a young widow gifted with second sight who becomes embroiled in a murder investigation. The plot is adequate, but Ms. Blanchett plays her character with such feeling and intelligence that you forgive the film its logical and narrative lapses. The supporting cast -- especially Mr. Reeves as a backwoods brute and J. K. Simmons as a skeptical sheriff -- is also, for the most part, superb (Scott).

* "THE HOUSE OF MIRTH," starring Gillian Anderson. Directed by Terence Davies (PG, 140 minutes). One of Edith Wharton's greatest novels has been adapted by this English director into a powerful but extremely somber feminist allegory in which Ms. Anderson (somewhat miscast as Lily Bart but powerful nonetheless) is a precociously modern woman crushed by the cruel hypocrisies of New York society in 1905. More Dickensian than Whartonian in its telling, the story of Lily's downfall still has a crushing force. Laura Linney is exquisite as the treacherous, two-faced Berthe Dorset, who engineers her destruction (Holden).

* "O BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU?," starring George Clooney, John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson. Directed by Joel Coen; written by Ethan Coen and Joel Coen (PG-13, 143 minutes). The Coen brothers' latest picture is a whimsical, loose-limbed scramble through a Depression-era Mississippi that arises not from the pages of history but from a feverish imagination fed by old movies (chiefly Preston Sturges's "Sullivan's Travels"), folk music and Homer's "Odyssey." Mr. Clooney, in a witty, relaxed performance, plays Ulysses Everett McGill, who escapes from a chain gang with two goofy sidekicks (Mr. Turturro and Mr. Nelson). In the course of their ramblings, they encounter corrupt politicians, a blues-guitar prodigy and the Ku Klux Klan, as well as a cyclops and a trio of sirens. This whimsical tall tale has a warmth and conviction lacking in some of the brothers' other movies, thanks to a soundtrack full of blues, gospel and country tunes that prove immune to pastiche or cynicism (Scott).

* "THE PLEDGE," starring Jack Nicholson. Directed by Sean Penn (R, 123 minutes). Mr. Penn's grimly powerful third film, adapted from a book by Friedrich Durrenmatt, reunites him with Mr. Nicholson, who starred in his 1995 film, "The Crossing Guard," and who seems to be almost an alter ego. Here the actor plays a Nevada policeman on the eve of retirement who pledges to the parents of a young girl found raped and murdered that he will find her killer. His quest becomes an obsession. Mr. Penn and Mr. Nicholson (in a brilliant, understated performance) plumb the soul of this lonely, brooding protagonist whose mood is echoed by the ominously beautiful Western landscape. Benicio Del Toro, Helen Mirren, Robin Wright Penn, Vanessa Redgrave and Tom Noonan deliver incisive cameo performances (Holden).

"SAVE THE LAST DANCE," starring Julia Stiles and Sean Patrick Thomas. Directed by Thomas Carter (R, 112 minutes). A bland but poised melodrama for tweens not quite up to the sophistication of a Freddie Prinze Jr. movie. Ms. Stiles is a high schooler uprooted from the suburbs and transplanted to Chicago's inner city, where she meets a guy (Mr. Thomas) who shows her the ways of hip-hop, which are more than an attitude. (He does so without making the audience assume an attitude toward him.) The magnetic Mr. Stiles and an able young cast give their all to this stylish retread (Mitchell).

"SHADOW OF THE VAMPIRE," starring John Malkovich, Willem Dafoe and Eddie Izzard. Directed by E. Elias Merhige (R, 90 minutes). Mr. Merhige's ambitious and uneven film is based on an audacious premise: that Max Schreck, who gave a haunting performance in F. W. Murnau's silent classic "Nosferatu," was really a vampire. As played by Mr. Dafoe, Schreck is both sinister and oddly sympathetic, and his struggle with the megalomaniacal Murnau (Mr. Malkovich) gives the film a flavor of Gothic behind-the-scenes comedy. Mr. Dafoe's intriguing performance and Mr. Merhige's keen visual intelligence -- most evident in his uncanny re-creations of scenes from "Nosferatu" -- offset the picture's dubious central metaphor, which is that moviemaking is, at bottom, a form of vampirism (Scott).

* "SNATCH," starring Brad Pitt, Jason Flemyng and Benicio Del Toro. Written and directed by Guy Ritchie (R, 105 minutes). "Snatch" follows the path of a stolen diamond through the hands, pockets and minds of a group of criminals from all walks of the lower depths. This spicy comic strip without an ounce of fat is Mr. Ritchie's return to the milieu of his debut feature, "Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels": the London streets of guys, guns and ill-gotten gains. The director seizes the bespoke machismo of British gangster movies and gives it an action picture's ferocity. The effort is hyper-real, and he plays it for comic potential. Everything clicks into place by the end, though, in what is literally a shaggy dog story (Mitchell).

"13 DAYS," starring Kevin Costner, Bruce Greenwood and Steven Culp. Directed by Roger Donaldson (PG-13, 140 minutes). A competent and compact, though unsurprising, re-creation of the events surrounding the Cuban missile crisis, with Mr. Costner -- as President John F. Kennedy's right-hand man, Kenny O'Donnell -- graciously bowing out of the way to allow the president (Mr. Greenwood) and his brother Robert (Mr. Culp) center stage. Mr. Costner's move to the sidelines is as ostentatious as his Boston Brahmin accent -- he seems to be channeling Vaughn Meader. But Mr. Donaldson, despite having more confrontation scenes than all of the other Kennedy dramatization projects combined, brings an athletic rigor to the film. The movie is helped by Mr. Greenwood's crisp, intense President Kennedy: he's like a White House portrait come to life (Mitchell).

* "TRAFFIC," starring Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Dennis Quaid, Benicio Del Toro, Don Cheadle and Luis Guzman. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 140 minutes). Not since "Nashville" or maybe even "The Godfather" has Hollywood turned out an epic as resonant as Mr. Soderbergh's densely layered study of the Mexican drug trade and its devastating impact on the United States. In weaving together multiple stories, this intricate thriller, adapted from a British miniseries, jumps from Tijuana to Washington to San Diego to suburban Ohio. Mr. Douglas is the new American drug czar, Ms. Zeta-Jones the ruthless wife of a busted drug lord and Mr. Del Toro a Mexican policeman. Mr. Cheadle and Mr. Guzman are a team of government agents whose bust of a cynical midlevel dealer (Miguel Ferrer) precipitates much of the drama. Shot with hand-held cameras, "Traffic" builds into a profound and gloomy meditation on greed, violence and contemporary ennui. Perhaps last year's most remarkable acting debut belongs to Erika Christensen as Mr. Douglas's angry, drug-addicted 16-year-old daughter (Holden).

* "YOU CAN COUNT ON ME," starring Laura Linney, Mark Ruffalo, Matthew Broderick, Jon Tenney and Rory Culkin. Written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan (R, 111 minutes). This small, realistic gem, set in an upstate New York town, looks deeply and empathetically into the loving but strained relationship between Sammy (Ms. Linney), a single mother with an 8-year-old son, and Terry (Mr. Ruffalo), her wastrel brother who returns home after serving a jail sentence. The two share a special bond, having lost their parents in a car crash when they were children. Mr. Broderick is Sammy's stuffy new boss at the bank where she works as a loan officer. The tensions that erupt may not be the most melodramatic domestic problems ever filmed, but they're the stuff of life, and Ms. Linney's and Mr. Ruffalo's performances are achingly perfect (Holden).

Film Series

"A LIV ULLMANN RETROSPECTIVE." Liv Ullmann, the radiantly expressive actress who starred in such Ingmar Bergman films as "Persona" (1966), "Scenes From a Marriage" (1973) and "Autumn Sonata" (1978), is the subject of a retrospective that not only sheds light on her talents as a performer but also on her gifts as a director. This weekend, the series at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, concludes with four films, two of them featuring Ms. Ullmann as actress and two showcasing her as a director. At 2 p.m. tomorrow, Ms. Ullmann co-stars with Ingrid Thulin in Mr. Bergman's "Cries and Whispers" (1973), about two women caring for their dying sister. At 4 p.m. she will be seen with Max von Sydow in "The Emigrants" (1972), Jan Troell's depiction of a Swedish peasant family's journey to Minnesota. At 2 p.m. on Sunday, the attraction is Ms. Ullmann's "Private Confessions" (1996), based on a Bergman screenplay about his parents' marriage. And at 4:30 p.m. the museum will show the 200-minute version of Ms. Ullmann's "Kristin Lavransdatter" (1995), a story of a 14th-century woman who chooses the man she loves over the man her father has chosen for her. With cinematography by Sven Nykvist, the film is adapted from the first part of Sigrid Undset's Nobel Prize-winning novel of the same title. Admission to the series, continuing through Sunday at the museum, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, is $8.50 for adults, $5.50 for those over 65 and students with I.D., $4.50 for children 5 to 18 and free to children under 4. Information: (718) 784-0077 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue Chips Rise, but Nasdaq Falls After Greenspan Talks

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK

 BODY:
The stock market reacted cautiously yesterday to comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, in testimony before the Senate Budget Committee.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 82.55 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,729.52. But the rally was confined to blue-chip stocks, as technology issues declined. The Nasdaq composite index fell 104.87 points, or 3.7 percent, to 2,754.28, in part because of a sell-off in fiber optics stocks after Corning warned of weakness in the telecommunications market. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.79 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,357.51.
Mr. Greenspan backed a tax cut and acknowledged that the economy had slowed considerably. But he gave investors few clues about how much the Fed policy makers might reduce interest rates when they meet Tuesday and Wednesday.
On another day, "news of support for tax cuts and at least no discouragement of the notion of a" half-point cut in interest rates might have led to a sharp market rally, said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist for Deutsche Bank North America.
Though Mr. Greenspan artfully dodged most discussion of monetary policy, he "came across a little bit stronger in endorsing tax cuts than I might have expected," Mr. Hooper said.
After the Fed disappointed investors by not acting at its regular December policy-making meeting, it surprised Wall Street on Jan. 3 by aggressively reducing short-term interest rates by one-half of a percentage point. The move was a response to data showing that the economic slowdown was becoming more pronounced. Some economists and investors expect the Fed to cut rates one-quarter or even one-half point when it meets next week.
"Initially, the markets were a little nervous that his seeming support of tax cuts would obviate the necessity for rate reductions," said Jonathan Glaser, a hedge fund manager at JMG Capital Partners, a money management firm.
Mr. Greenspan dodged senators' questions about the form of a potential tax cut, calling those queries political, not economic.
"The market's disappointed he didn't say something explicit," said Gemma Wright, director of market strategy at Barclays Capital in New York.
Despite Mr. Greenspan's indication that the Fed recognizes the economic slowdown and may act to stimulate borrowing, investors could not overlook more obvious signs of slowing growth in technology companies.
Corning, a supplier of components to fiber optic networks, fell almost 20 percent yesterday after it warned Wednesday that its first-quarter profits could be weaker than expected because capital markets were tightening and telecommunications companies were cutting spending. Its shares fell $13.88, to $56.25.
The sell-off in Corning pulled down the shares of other fiber optics companies. JDS Uniphase fell $7.88, or 12.5 percent, to $55.19, while SDL lost $32.94, or 14.2 percent, to $199.19. After the stock market closed yesterday, JDS Uniphase warned that growth was slowing in the current quarter, even though it reported results for its second fiscal quarter that exceeded Wall Street's estimates.
Among the day's big movers, Cisco Systems fell $3.25, to $39.31; the company said it would invest $200 million in the Softbank Corporation of Japan.
Drug stocks rallied as pharmaceutical companies continued to deliver strong earnings. Merck, a Dow component, gave the index its strongest push, rising $2.94, to $81.88. Johnson & Johnson gained $1.19, to $91.75.
 --------------------

Treasuries Move Higher
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices gained yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the economy was near a standstill, raising hopes for a sharp Fed interest rate cut next week.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 16/32, to a price of 103 27/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.23 percent from 5.30 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32, to 109 13/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.59 percent from 5.66 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Wages Showed Strong Gain In 4th Quarter 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
The wages and benefits of United States workers rose solidly in the fourth quarter, wrapping up a year that posted the biggest annual gain in compensation costs since 1991, government figures showed today.
 The Labor Department reported that its employment cost index, a closely watched gauge of inflation, rose a seasonally adjusted 0.8 percent in the last three months of 2000, down from a 0.9 percent rise in the third quarter. 
That reflected a job market that cooled late in the year from a red-hot pace. 
 A second report showed that sales of existing homes slipped 7.4 percent in December, to an annual rate of 4.87 million units, one of a series of reports showing how the economy has weakened sharply over the last two months.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that "as far as we can judge, we have had a very dramatic slowing down."
"We are probably very close to zero at this particular moment" in the first quarter, he said in testimony before the Senate Budget Committee.
Mr. Greenspan's comments were viewed as a further signal that the Fed, which announced a surprise half-point cut in interest rates Jan. 3, was prepared to lower rates again when it meets next week.
Many economists expected fourth-quarter compensation costs to register a 1.1 percent gain.
The wages-and-salaries component of the index, viewed by economists as the best measure of changes in workers' compensation costs, advanced 0.7 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with a 0.8 percent rise in the third quarter.
The cost of benefits, like health insurance and vacations, also moderated in the fourth quarter, rising 0.8 percent, compared with a 1 percent increase in the third quarter.
