HEADLINE: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Testimony Before Senate Budget Committee 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, discussed the outlook for the federal budget and fiscal policy before the Senate Budget Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts from his testimony and exchanges between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico and the chairman of the committee, and Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland and a member of the committee, in a question-and-answer session after the testimony, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.
 The sequence of upward revisions to the budget surplus projections for several years now has reshaped the choices and opportunities before us. 
 Indeed, in almost any creditable baseline scenario, short of a major and prolonged economic contraction, the full benefits of debt reduction are now achieved before the end of this decade -- a prospect that did not seem likely only a year or even six months ago. 
The most recent data significantly raise the probability that sufficient resources will be available to undertake both debt reduction and surplus-lowering policy initiatives. Accordingly, the trade-off faced earlier appears no longer an issue.
The emerging key fiscal policy need is to address the implications of maintaining surpluses beyond the point at which publicly held debt is effectively eliminated. . . .
In general, as I have testified previously, if long-term fiscal stability is the criterion, it is far better, in my judgment, that the surpluses be lowered by tax reductions than by spending increases. The flurry of increases in outlays that occurred near the conclusion of last fall's budget deliberations is troubling because it makes the previous year's lack of discipline less likely to have been an aberration. 
To be sure, with the burgeoning federal surpluses, fiscal policy has not yet been unduly compromised by such actions. But history illustrates the difficulty of keeping spending in check, especially in programs that are open-ended commitments, which too often have led to much larger outlays than initially envisioned. It is important to recognize that government expenditures are claims against real resources and that, while those claims may be unlimited, our capacity to meet them is ultimately constrained by the growth in productivity. Moreover, the greater the drain of resources from the private sector, arguably, the lower the growth potential of the economy. In contrast to most spending programs, tax reductions have downside limits. They cannot be open-ended. 
Lately there has been much discussion of cutting taxes to confront the evident pronounced weakening in recent economic performance. Such tax initiatives, however, historically have proved difficult to implement in the time frame in which recessions have developed and ended. . . . In today's context, where tax reduction appears required in any event over the next several years to assist in forestalling the accumulation of private assets, starting that process sooner rather than later likely would help smooth the transition to longer-term fiscal balance. And should current economic weakness spread beyond what now appears likely, having a tax cut in place may, in fact, do noticeable good. . . .
In recognition of the uncertainties in the economic and budget outlook, it is important that any long-term tax plan, or spending initiative for that matter, be phased in. Conceivably, it could include provisions that, in some way, would limit surplus-reducing actions if specified targets for the budget surplus and federal debt were not satisfied. Only if the probability was very low that prospective tax cuts or new outlay initiatives would send the on-budget accounts into deficit, would unconditional initiatives appear prudent. 
The reason for caution, of course, rests on the tentativeness of our projections. What if, for example, the forces driving the surge in tax revenues in recent years begin to dissipate or reverse in ways that we do not now foresee? . . .
The risk of adverse movements in individual income tax receipts is still real, and the probability of dropping back into deficit as a consequence of imprudent fiscal policies is not negligible. . . .
Let me end on a cautionary note. With today's euphoria surrounding the surpluses, it is not difficult to imagine the hard-earned fiscal restraint developed in recent years rapidly dissipating. We need to resist those policies that could readily resurrect the deficits of the past and the fiscal imbalances that followed in their wake. 

SENATOR PETE V. DOMINICI. -- Is, in your way of thinking, considering the size of the surplus and the other claims that you are aware of on this surplus, would it be reasonable for us to seriously consider the president's proposals in terms of tax reduction here in the United States Congress?

MR. GREENSPAN. -- Mr. Chairman, I haven't actually done the calculations. And, actually, if I did, I don't think it would be appropriate for me to comment because these are fundamentally political decisions and -- I mean, as a citizen, I have my own views, but I don't think they're appropriate to be voiced in the context where we're talking about the economics of fiscal policy. . . .

SENATOR PAUL SARBANES. -- Well, we've had a slowdown in the economy, but we haven't had a recession. Is that correct at this point?

MR. GREENSPAN. -- We are -- as far as we can judge, we have had a very dramatic slowing down, and indeed we are probably very close to zero at this particular moment. You know, we're only into a third of the first quarter. We know that the fourth quarter was a very small positive, but there is an inventory liquidation process going on, in part the result of the same forces which the technology changes, which has created a super just-in-time inventory system, which is having a very dramatic effect on reducing production in the manufacturing sector.

Q. Yeah, but presumably, once that works its way through the system, it will no longer be a contractionary factor.

A. Yeah. The crucial issue, Senator, is whether that marked decline breaches consumer confidence, because there is something different about a recession from other times in the economy; it is not a continuum from slow growth into negative growth; something happens.

HEADLINE: Mayor Giuliani's Budget Choices 

 BODY:
The $39.3 billion financial plan for New York City offered by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani yesterday would reduce taxes moderately in the next fiscal year and increase spending for schools, housing and cultural institutions, all commendable objectives. But the education hike, while increasing money for buildings, does not go very far toward hiring more teachers or improving class size. The overall financial plan also contains traps that could ensnare the next mayor in wider deficits. 
 Mr. Giuliani contended yesterday that his budget would actually reduce spending slightly in the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. But that assertion was arrived at through bookkeeping gimmickry. According to the city's Independent Budget Office, spending would rise substantially, by 3.4 percent. It will rise even further if labor negotiations produce salary increases of more than 2.5 percent a year, which they are almost certain to do. The City Council has also vowed to restore the $700 million in spending for libraries, smaller cultural institutions and other programs that Mr. Giuliani wants cut. 
 The budget deficits, projected to be in the range of $2 billion for the next mayor, are certain to be driven higher by several other factors. Among them are a possible further economic slowdown, possible higher-than-estimated costs of welfare, and the costs of maintaining a large police force if there is a cutback in federal aid for police hiring. Indeed, the mayor's projections for more federal and state aid seem unrealistic, given that Congress and the State Legislature are under pressure to increase aid to schools rather than other aid to the city.
Compounding the problem for the future is that Mr. Giuliani once again is plugging the deficit next year by using more than $2 billion of the surplus racked up this year because of the flush economy. It is obvious that these surpluses will not last, or be available to the next mayor. 
Education will clearly be the focus of budget battles this year in Albany, at City Hall and in the mayoral race. The mayor's proposals to increase school spending are focused on supplemental programs rather than basic needs. The mayoral candidates will probably call for additional spending. We agree that more money has to be found for schools, as State Supreme Court Justice Leland DeGrasse directed last month in a landmark ruling that is now being appealed. Mr. Giuliani's plan starts the city down that road. But the next mayor will face serious problems on where to find the money to continue that journey. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Oil-Drilling Issue Could Set Bush Against Bush 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 

 BODY:
All week the White House has offered a partial solution to the California energy shortage and any future shortfalls around the country: more exploration for oil and gas, including drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.
 But one place in which the new Administration has not talked much about drilling is off Florida, where the Interior Department is in the final stages of seeking public comment about a proposal to auction off rights to a six-million-acre field in the Gulf of Mexico. The federal government -- that is, the administration of George W. Bush -- is facing opposition to its exploration plans from the governor of Florida, Jeb Bush. 
 "I am confident," Governor Bush wrote in a letter on Tuesday to the acting secretary of the interior, Thomas Slonaker, "that the new administration will recognize the need to protect sensitive natural resources located both offshore and along Florida's coastline for the benefit of the entire nation." 
The issue is important to Governor Bush, the president's younger brother, whose political future may hinge on his ability to stop this and other new drilling off the Florida coast. But President Bush will hear from others with a very different view.
Oil companies that helped finance his campaign and that have allies in the cabinet have already been pressing to ease drilling restrictions along the Florida and California coasts. They cite the recent surge in gas prices to bolster their arguments.
Mr. Slonaker is not likely to have much of a voice in the matter; it will fall to Gale A. Norton, President Bush's nominee for secretary of the interior, who appears on her way to relatively easy confirmation by the Senate. Ms. Norton is a strong advocate of new exploration and exploitation of natural resources, though she has hedged on the issue of what to do in Florida.
In her confirmation hearings in recent days, Ms. Norton said she and the president opposed any new leasing off Florida, though she did not comment specifically on the lease the Interior Department is proposing to sell in an area Governor Bush strongly objects to developing.
"It is an important issue and we will certainly review it," Scott McClellan, deputy White House press secretary, said today, noting that President Bush has pledged to work with states and local communities on the issue.
During the presidential campaign, George Bush supported a moratorium, long in place, blocking new leasing of fields in parts of the eastern Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Bush also said he was willing to work with local communities to determine what to do with leases already held by oil companies. 
But the area that his brother seeks to stop from being auctioned is not covered by the existing moratorium. It actually lies off the coast of Alabama, but close enough to Florida to worry state environmentalists.
"This puts everyone in a precarious position," said Mark Ferrulo, the director of the Florida Public Interest Research Group, which has long opposed any exploration or production along the Florida coast. He praised Governor Bush for opposing the lease, even though it is technically in waters off a neighboring state. "He has not gone this far before," Mr. Ferrulo said.
The governor has a large political stake in the issue. He faces re-election in two years, and is trying to recover from the political fallout from the disputed recount of the presidential election in his state. Drilling offshore is opposed by both Republicans and Democrats in Florida, and Governor Bush could be blamed if his brother's administration allows new drilling near the state's beaches.
"Florida's economy is based upon tourism and other activities that depend on a clean and healthy environment," Jeb Bush wrote in his letter to Washington. "As a result, we continue to have the nation's best beaches, abundant fisheries, and pristine marine waters. Protection of those resources is of paramount importance to the state of Florida."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is opposing offshore drilling in his state. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Nasdaq Registers 3-Week Winning Streak

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index rallied to finish its first three-week winning streak since September as investors bet that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates enough next week to lead to faster corporate profit growth.
 Qualcomm, a developer of cellular phone technology, led the gain after it reported earnings that topped expectations. Microsoft and Intel also rose as investors flocked to the biggest computer-related companies, which declined during the Nasdaq's record slide last year. 
 The Nasdaq rose 27.02 points yesterday, or 1 percent, to 2,781.30.
"Lower interest rates are almost always better for stocks," said James Floyd, who helps manage $180 million for Leuthold Weeden Capital Management L.L.C. "Investors are willing to forgive what's going on in the fourth quarter -- it's old news -- and they're taking a chance on things being better out on the horizon."
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 69.54 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,659.98. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.56 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,354.95.
The Nasdaq gained 0.4 percent this week. The last time it put together three consecutive weeks of advances was the period that ended Sept. 1. The S.& P. 500 rose 0.9 percent, while the Dow climbed 0.7 percent.
Qualcomm jumped $7.06, to $81, after reporting fiscal first-quarter profit from operations of 29 cents a share, beating estimates by a penny. The company also said it would meet profit forecasts for the second quarter and 2001.
JDS Uniphase rose $4.44, to $59.63. While the company, a maker of parts used in fiber optic equipment, said fiscal 2001 sales could be at the low end of forecasts because of slowing customer spending, it reported a fiscal second-quarter profit, excluding acquisition-related costs, that topped forecasts.
Microsoft rose $2.19, to $64, and Intel advanced $1.38, to $35.88.
PMC-Sierra plunged $21.88, or 23 percent, to $74 after it said sales would fall at least 25 percent from the fourth quarter to the first as customers bought fewer chips for telecommunications equipment.
Ericsson, the largest builder of cellular networks, dropped $1.75, to $11.25, after forecasting slower sales growth and cutting its estimates for profit margins this year. The company also said it would transfer the manufacture of its mobile-phone handsets to Flextronics International, which rose $2.81, to $39.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Reuters) -- Longer-term Treasury bond prices sagged for the fifth time in six days yesterday as investors made room in their portfolios for a fresh lump of new higher-yielding corporate debt.
Motorola sold $2.23 billion in 5- and 10-year obligations, the biggest deal yesterday in what has emerged as the largest month of corporate issuance on record. Companies have sold more than $25 billion in new supply this week.
Seeking to capitalize on lower borrowing costs since the Fed's half-point rate cut on Jan. 3, corporations have sold a record $83.05 billion in bonds this month, according to Thomson Financial Securities.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 7/32, to a price of 103 20/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.26 percent from 5.23 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 21/32, to 108 21/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.64 percent from 5.59 percent.

HEADLINE: Technology-Wary Investors, Once Scorned, Gain Respect 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
Michelle Brown was shocked when her investment club took her advice last summer. "Completely shocked," she said recently. Ms. Brown, a 31-year-old video producer, had suggested that the 19-member club buy shares in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, the style doyenne's fledgling publishing concern. 
 For two years, the club had been dominated by the roughly half of its members who work in the technology department of their employer, a Colorado charity group called Compassion International. By the beginning of last year, two technology stocks, Oracle and Cisco Systems, together accounted for about 72 percent of the club's $25,956.72 in assets. And club members like Ms. Brown who were not technologists had little voice in the group's investment decisions. 
 These days, though, more cautious investors are finding their voices, and those who for two years bought technology stocks at any price -- investors who bragged about their prowess, oblivious that they might simply have been rising with the market's tide -- have had to start listening. 
It is not that the meek now rule the earth. There is still no shortage of true believers in technology stocks. But after the market's retreat, diversification does not seem so fusty a concept, and its quiet advocates are no longer dismissed as losers who just don't get the new economy. 
For Ms. Brown's Colorado Springs investment club, her pitch of the Martha Stewart business "was a turning point," said Charles L. McGinty Jr., the club's 35-year-old president and Compassion International's communications director. 
"Back in '99 and early 2000, we had an attitude that virtually anything would go up as long as it was tech," he said. Those who suggested otherwise were politely ignored, as the technology advocates argued that "nontech companies were not going to grow nearly as fast." 
But then technology shares collapsed, with many Internet companies giving back 80 percent or 90 percent of their gains in the space of a few months. For all the frenzy over the technology boom, an investor could have made more money buying and holding onto shares of a diversified bond mutual fund at the end of 1998 than owning many of those hot-hot technology funds.
Now, the effects on investor behavior of a technology market turned sour are tangible. The flight from technology stocks has sent the Nasdaq composite index down more than 45 percent from its high last March, even after a rally this month. Flows of money into technology mutual funds remain weak. In the last three months of 2000, investors at Charles Schwab pulled more money out of technology funds than they put in. 
Even on Internet message boards, the wellspring of so much of the fervor for technology investing, the debate has been shifting. 
"More and more of our members are looking at the macro issues again, not for the next hot stock or the next hot trend," said Tara Burgess, manager of community development for Raging Bull, the popular financial message board site that is a unit of AltaVista. 
In this climate, there is vindication for both expert and novice who felt left out of the technology boom. 
"Last year, people were saying, 'Get me out of bonds, I don't care what they're selling for, I have to get into technology,' " said Lewis Altfest, a 60-year-old Manhattan financial planner who pushed his clients to stay diversified.
"There was a buying panic. People were saying 'I know it's irrational, but my friends at cocktail parties are making fortunes,' " he added. "I was considered to be someone who didn't get it. Well, thank God, I didn't get it."
Mr. Altfest said he lost about 5 or 6 of his 150 clients because he would not accommodate their technology stock lust. "We've gotten half of them back," he said, "with a mea culpa."
Ms. Brown's first attempt at getting her club to diversify came last June, when she pitched the group on Procter & Gamble. 
The stock, at about $62 a share, had been depressed early in the year and she thought it might be ready for a revival. There was also a personal attachment. Ms. Brown's grandfather spent more than three decades working for the Cincinnati company, and Procter & Gamble stock "paid for my college," as she puts it. 
But given the prevailing mood of the times and the club's dynamics, P.& G. was bound to be a hard sell. "When Michelle presented Procter & Gamble, it was pitched as a value stock, as a good buy at the time," Mr. McGinty said. 
That was not what the group was after. "I'm looking at long-term growth," said Jeffrey Wood, a club member who runs Compassion International's technology department. "I look at things like P.& G., and I just don't see it. I don't see the value of that stock doubling in five years." 
The membership passed on P.& G., which closed yesterday at $69.25. But as the year wore on, sentiment shifted. The club sold a quarter of its Oracle stock, whose shares have fallen by a third from their Sept. 1 peak, and all of its shares of Lucent Technologies, which dropped 81 percent last year. The members used the proceeds, and new contributions, to buy Calpine, a California-based power generator; Home Depot; T. Rowe Price; and Martha Stewart. 
Do not think these were easy decisions. 
"My feeling was that we should hold on to Oracle," said Michael Mikolaitis, a 49-year-old manager in Compassion International's technology department who feels comfortable with 70 percent of his personal holdings in the technology sector. 
"The concern was that the P.E. was too high, but Microsoft had a high P.E. for years," he said, referring to the stock's price-to-earnings ratio. During the bull market, such measurements were often rejected as too conventional for the technology sector. 
"You can't determine that a stock is going to go down because the P.E. is high," Mr. Mikolaitis added. "Looking 5, 10 years out, there will be market fluctuations, but that doesn't bother me."
But other group members who had been technology enthusiasts grew more cautious. 
"My concern about the club is that we've been pretty heavy in tech stocks, and as much as I like that industry personally, I'm not sure how smart it is to have so much invested in one industry," said Mark Hanlon, a 42-year-old club member.
This is not to say that the club will turn from meteor to mule overnight. By most measures, it is still on the meteoric side. Its kitty of $31,758.13 -- after a 22 percent decline in 2000 -- is now about half invested in Cisco and Oracle, an allocation that would cause even the most aggressive mutual fund manager to blush. 
But the baby steps toward a more balanced portfolio have begun. Debates are no longer about whether the club should diversify, but by how much, following its members' realization that nothing is a sure thing. 
"Today, there's no way we'd buy a stock with a high P.E. ratio," Mr. McGinty said. And that remains the case even after the recent, modest rally of technology stocks.
"I think from here on out we've seen we are vulnerable to having too much of our portfolio tipped in one sector," Mr. McGinty said yesterday. "That lesson is going to have a long-lasting impact on the club."
Recently, some of the most humble suggestions have come from the technology stalwarts. Warren Simmons, a 42-year-old network administrator, had pleaded with the club not to sell its Lucent shares early last year. By December, he had rethought his approach and pitched T. Rowe Price, the financial services company. 
"Even in bad markets," he said, "people need investment counseling."

HEADLINE: The Energy Calamity in California 

 BODY:
It is astonishing -- and alarming -- how little it took to cripple California, the incubator of high technology and a driving force in the nation's economic growth. Just a few years ago, the state's economy was booming and there was a modest surplus in electricity. Today California is scrambling to buy power at exorbitant rates, consumers have been hit with rolling blackouts, the utilities are nearly bankrupt and businesses are curbing production or threatening to move out of state. The only solace is that the crisis thus far is primarily financial. There appears to be enough power available physically if some way can be found to obtain it and pay for it.
 The causes of this debacle include a colossally wrongheaded deregulation plan, gross miscalculations of the likely demand for electricity, and a failure to build any new generating plants over the past decade. Virtually no one in the state foresaw the spectacular economic growth that occurred in the late 1990's, bringing with it an insatiable thirst for more power. Few sensed the urgency of building new power plants. Some generating companies were reluctant to invest in new plants until they saw how deregulation would unfold. Other plants may have been slowed by an onerous licensing process or by not-in-my-backyard opposition. Either way, the result was the same. Demand for electricity shot up. Supply stagnated. 
 Add to those factors sharply rising prices for natural gas and a shortfall in precipitation that feeds hydropower and you have the ingredients for escalating electricity costs. There are also hints that savvy (some would say rapacious) out-of-state generating companies have held power off the market so as to jack up the prices.
In deregulating its electric power system, California seems to have made almost every mistake possible. For starters, it deregulated only half the market. California's utilities have to buy power wholesale at market rates, but are limited in what they can charge their retail customers. That worked just fine when wholesale prices were low, but turned bad when wholesale prices soared, leaving utilities no way to cover their costs. The utilities are now billions of dollars in debt, and generating companies are reluctant to sell them any more electricity for fear they will not be paid.
The flawed deregulation plan also forced utilities to sell off many of their own power plants in the belief that the entry of other generating companies would lead to competition. But no real competition emerged, and when power supplies got tight, the utilities had less generating capacity of their own to buffer the shock. Worse yet, California would not let its utilities sign long-term contracts to buy electricity from other generators. That left them at the mercy of the spot market, where prices have soared to extraordinarily high levels.
Other states, notably Pennsylvania and Texas, have embarked on deregulation plans with initially favorable results, in part by avoiding many of California's mistakes. 
The burden of solving the crisis in California will largely fall on state officials, but there are national interests at stake as well. California's needs are already drawing down energy reserves and affecting some jobs and prices in neighboring states. And as the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified this week, it seems inevitable that the problems in California, which is roughly one-sixth of the American economy, will feed into the 49 other states. 
Thus it is discouraging that the Bush administration seems inclined mostly to look the other way. Administration officials have primarily suggested more drilling for oil and gas and a possible rollback of environmental standards to encourage power plant construction. That sounds more like using the crisis to promote other agendas than a genuine effort to help a struggling state.
California, for its part, is negotiating with generating companies to sign multi-year contracts that would stabilize prices, an approach that seems absolutely necessary but holds the danger of locking the state into prices that could look way too high when additional generating capacity comes online in future years. Hard bargaining over price and duration will be essential. 
Unfortunately, California's political leaders seem afraid to lift the caps on the retail price of electricity, lest angry consumers retaliate against them at the polls. But that deprives the state of a weapon that most economists deem essential to encourage conservation and to bring wholesale and retail prices into more rational alignment. Indeed, lifting the retail price cap would help restore the financial viability of the utilities and make generators more willing to sell them electricity.
California pioneered the move into the new era of electricity deregulation, and ended up teaching us a lot about how not to do it. Now it needs to muster the courage and intelligence to set matters right before its problems engulf the rest of us.

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
The collection plate may be half-full or half-empty, depending on who is weighing it and why.

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
How generous are Americans? More today than a hundred years ago? Ten years ago? Last year? Only a God able to plumb human hearts could know the answer, but several quite human organizations try to keep track of the admittedly narrower but still not insignificant question of how much money Americans give to charities. 
 Recently, however, a married couple who have been painstakingly tracking patterns of church giving for years are asking whether the standard sources of data are systematically skewed, giving Americans the impression of being more generous than they really are. 
 It is not only the news media who rely on these sources. In November, for example, when President Bill Clinton applauded the fact that charitable giving had increased by 41 percent from 1995 to 1999, he was relying on estimates from "Giving USA 2000," an annual report issued by a nonprofit affiliate of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, a consortium of for-profit fund-raising companies. 
Also frequently cited are figures from the Giving and Volunteering in America reports periodically issued by Independent Sector, based on surveys of households conducted by the Gallup Organization. 
The Chronicle of Philanthropy, a journal that travelers shuttling by air between New York and Washington can often pick up free on the way to the gate, publishes an annual Philanthropy 400 issue that ranks the top 400 nonprofit organizations by the support they receive. The NonProfit Times publishes a similar list, the NPT 100.
The couple, Sylvia and John Ronsvalle, have raised questions about these estimates before, but last month they released a study, "The State of Church Giving Through 1998," that devoted an entire chapter to their concerns. 
"Every time we push, the numbers disappear," Ms. Ronsvalle says. "We don't care what the truth is, but it should be the truth. We only want solid numbers."
Since 1972, the Ronsvalles have been running a mom-and-pop operation called Empty Tomb Inc., which Ms. Ronsvalle describes as a Christian research and service organization. Their first activities were directing and coordinating services to the poor for various denominations around Champaign, Ill., where the Ronsvalles lived in public housing for 19 years. This commitment to serving the poor led John Ronsvalle, who holds a doctorate in clinical psychology, to start looking at trends in the contributions made by members of a wide variety of Protestant denominations. Since the couple's first study came out in 1988, two trends have clearly distressed them. 
The first is that, even when church giving increased in inflation-adjusted dollar amounts or in contribution per member, it steadily decreased as a percentage of Americans' disposable income. 
The second is that more and more of these contributions go to cover the operations and upkeep of individual congregations and less to local, national or international programs of spiritual and material aid. 
The Ronsvalles say they feel that one barrier to greater giving by church members may be complacency encouraged by some of the most widely used estimates of charitable giving. 
They note an obvious misimpression that people might take from the year-by-year comparisons in lists like the Philanthropy 400 or the NPT 100. Instead of including the same set of organizations over time, each year's rankings will add the more successful and drop the less successful. It is as if the Dow Jones index, instead of examining a fixed set of industrial stocks (with periodic adjustments), listed whichever were the top 30.
The Ronsvalles also fault these rankings along with Giving USA for presenting gains in aggregate numbers without taking into account increases in population and after-tax income. While calling the Giving USA series "a useful tool," the Ronsvalles argue that an alternative method of calculating religious contributions might reduce its estimates of total giving in 1998 by $25 billion. 
They suggest that all these publications are overly influenced by the fund-raising industry, which is naturally more interested in reporting success than failure. 
"I can see the concern about having a built-in bias," responds Melissa S. Brown, the managing editor of Giving USA 2001, the next volume in that series. "But Giving USA relies ultimately on tax data, from the I.R.S." 
Ms. Brown works at the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University, which has agreed to research, write and edit the 2001 edition for the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's nonprofit AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy. 
Estimating charitable contributions is highly complex and sometimes subjective. If it employs the reports of charitable contributions itemized on tax forms, it must also employ formulas for figuring out the contributions of non-itemizers. If one wants to get more specific about exactly what sort of people give how much and to what causes, the holes in the data must be filled with clever deductions and sophisticated survey techniques. 
To underline the uncertainty in the data, the Ronsvalles make a calculation comparing the Independent Sector's findings about 1998 "household contributions" to the "individual contributions" (as distinguished from bequests or corporate or foundation grants) estimated for that year in Giving USA. The former comes out to $78.3 billion and the latter to $134.1 billion. 
But Murray Weitzman, senior consultant to Independent Sector, said this was a simple $56 billion misunderstanding. The "household contributions" tracked by the Independent Sector's survey method do not claim to encompass all "individual contributions," which are estimated differently, with results close to those of Giving USA. 
To complicate matters, other studies, including some at the Center on Philanthropy, suggest that the major sources of information on contributions may actually be underreporting what Americans give rather than, as the Ronsvalles fear, overreporting it. 
One reaction to all this complexity would be to thank the Ronsvalles for trying to get an affluent nation to live up to its own self-image of generosity -- but to ignore their insistence on developing a more accurate picture of American philanthropy. 
That was not the reaction of Ms. Brown, however, at the Center on Philanthropy, which itself has been bringing scholars together to explore these questions. "Their overall concern that we need a way to understand all these studies is very valid," Ms. Brown said.

HEADLINE: Jets, Citing Benefits to City, Detail a Stadium Plan 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In releasing their most detailed plans yet for a billion-dollar complex on the West Side of Manhattan, the New York Jets said the economic benefits to New York City would come not from the football games in a new stadium but from an expanded convention center on the site.
 L. Jay Cross, the president of Jets Development, described the team's plans as first and foremost an expansion of the city's undersized Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, rather than as a subsidized football arena. 
 At his office in Manhattan early this week, Mr. Cross acknowledged that a publicly subsidized stadium produces huge revenues for team owners and players but has relatively little impact on the city's economy. Conversely, he added, convention centers make very little money but have a huge economic effect as thousands of conventioneers spend their money in the city. 
"All the economic impact is driven by the convention center," Mr. Cross said. "By marrying the two, you get the advantage of investing in the convention center, which will have an enormous economic impact, and as a side benefit, we achieve the purpose of putting a sports team in a state-of-the art facility."
The price tag: more than $1 billion, with taxpayers picking up at least two-thirds of the cost.
His argument contradicts the positions routinely taken over the last two decades by the owners of professional sports teams who have sought to build a stadium or an arena with public money. The owners, and the politicians who support their plans, have long contended that new stadiums and arenas spawn restaurants, hotels and other businesses. Many economists, on the other hand, agree with Mr. Cross, saying that the only things that grow next to stadiums are parking lots.
City officials said yesterday that Mr. Cross's proposal was promising.
"It would fill a void in New York City -- the lack of a world-class convention center -- and it creates a stadium that would make us a front-runner for the Olympics in 2012," said Anthony P. Coles, a deputy mayor, yesterday.
Critics of the Jets proposal complain that the city's hotels are already full, and that while New York may need a larger convention hall, it does not need an expensive stadium in an already traffic-choked area.
But Mr. Cross noted that state officials, hotel owners and tourism promoters have long complained that the 814,000-square-foot Javits center is too small. The center is fully booked, with about 140 trade and consumer shows a year, and is turning away billions of dollars in business, he said.
His new plans show a 75,000-seat stadium with 300 luxury suites built on a platform over the rail yards east of 11th Avenue, between 30th and 34th Streets. The stadium could be converted to exhibition space or used for conventions and concerts. It would be linked by a broad, enclosed bridge over 34th Street to the existing convention center. Additional convention space would be built on the north side of Javits, up to West 41st Street, with a hotel at the northwest corner of 41st Street and 11th Avenue.
The new complex would have more than 1 million square feet of exhibition space on one level, 365,000 square feet of meeting rooms and an 85,800-square-foot ballroom, the world's largest. A public promenade would overlook the Hudson River and include a stairway to a waterfront park.
Mr. Cross contended that the new complex would draw more than 300 shows and 2.8 million people a year, up from 2.5 million today. And, he said, each conventioneer would be spending about $2,000, in contrast with residents from around the region who attend boat and auto shows.
But Mr. Cross could not say exactly how many of the 300 events would use the converted exhibition space.
Mark S. Rosentraub, a dean at Cleveland State University and an expert in urban tourism and the sports business, said that the Jets might be overstating their case. Stadiums do not often work well as exhibition halls, he said, and New York is too expensive for many conventions anyway.
Scheduling may prove difficult as well, he said. The National Football League sets the dates for a team's home games each year, but conventions are planned three or four years in advance. To avoid any potential conflicts, the Javits Center might not be able to use the stadium on weekends from August through January.
"The reality is you're not going to convince a lot of conventions to come to New York anyway," Mr. Rosentraub said. "Nor are you going to convince hotels to lower their rates to compete for convention business."
Bob Brown, vice president of Convention Management Group, agreed. "We produce some very large shows," he said, "but we have chosen not to go to New York because of the costs and the union issues."
According to PKF Consultants, a hotel consulting firm, the average hotel room in Manhattan costs $240 a night, $100 more than in Chicago and $145 more than in Orlando, two big convention cities. New York also has the highest occupancy rate in the country, at 84 percent, meaning the city's 60,000 hotel rooms are full 250 days a year.
"It doesn't make sense to expand the Javits, at least in the near term," said John Fox, of PKF Consulting. "We're already effectively sold out. Until we build some more hotels, we couldn't accommodate more conventions."
But Mr. Cross and Tim Zagat, chairman of New York City & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau, said that hotel chains would build convention hotels near the Javits if they were certain that the convention center was expanding. Mr. Zagat complained that the Javits was missing out on billions of dollars in conventions, trade shows and tax revenues because of its size.
Charles Greco, president of IDG World Expo, recently moved the Mac World computer show from Boston to New York, where it attracted 61,000 people. He said he would move more shows to New York if the Javits expanded.
"New York has a reputation for being pricey," he said, "but it has the venue sex appeal that show operators are looking for."
In any event, both the stadium and the convention center are tangled in the often barbed political relations between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
In December, Mr. Cross released a preliminary proposal that showed the Javits connected to a new stadium. The Giuliani administration promptly embraced it, while Robert E. Boyle, chairman of the convention center, which is controlled by the state, said the proposal did not constitute a convention hall expansion and, therefore, was "dead on arrival."
Mr. Cross went back to the drawing board, eventually designing an addition on the north side of the Javits.

Javits Convention Center; the center would be expanded to the north. (Jets Development) Map of Javits Convention Center highlighting site of proposed stadium: The Jets plan would expand the Javits Convention Center.

HEADLINE: Visions of Parting a Sea of Concrete With a Unifying River Greenbelt 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 

 BODY:
The Los Angeles River, a trickle or a torrent depending on the weather, flows in a massive concrete trough through poor neighborhoods, under viaducts, by rail yards and around warehouses, becoming many things to many people. 
 It is a storm drain, because it is designed to carry water as quickly as possible to the Pacific Ocean. By default, it is a sewer with everything picked up by the runoff flowing with it -- a melange of trash, pollutants, fertilizer and animal waste. 
 "But most people who grew up in Los Angeles don't realize it's a river," said Melanie Winter, a board member and former executive director of Friends of the Los Angeles River. "They think it's an ironic name for a built system." 
There are small reminders of its origin, like a stretch near downtown called the Glendale Narrows. There, trees and grasses flourish in the riverbed as ducks bob along in the current; because the water table is so high, the concrete bed would not stay in place. It provides a glimpse of what Ms. Winter and others would like to see happen all along the river. 
"You just have to imagine we've gotten rid of all the plastic bags," she said, referring to garbage hanging in trees and lining the riverbed. 
Getting rid of the trash is now on the agenda. On Thursday, the Los Angeles Regional Water Quality Control Board approved a measure to gradually decrease the trash entering the river, reaching zero in 12 to 14 years. The move is the first of many the board plans against pollutants.
But several cities, including Los Angeles, oppose the measure.
"We are definitely in favor of reducing and eliminating the trash in the Los Angeles River," said Judith Wilson, director of the Los Angeles Bureau of Sanitation. But the zero limit is "not achievable in our opinion." Ms. Wilson added, "and even if we get to 99 percent, it's still an opportunity for lawsuits by third parties."
Ms. Wilson said she would recommend appealing the decision to the state Water Resources Control Board, and lawsuits are expected.
But a variety of factors are helping the effort to reclaim the river. Engineering attitudes reflected in the paving of the riverbed, which began in the late 1930's, have changed. More natural solutions that allow water to spread over the land and percolate back into the earth are being emphasized. Attitudes have also changed about water resources. And Los Angeles has begun to reflect on its image as the most park-poor large city in the country. 
A master plan was drafted in 1996 and updated in 1999, and advocates and planners are reclaiming the river a little at a time. In most areas the river is enclosed by chain-link fence, but pocket parks have been created with river rock and native plantings in neighborhoods like the Elysian Valley near Dodger Stadium. 
A 4.5-mile lighted commuter bikeway runs from Burbank to the Elysian Valley. And in Atwater Village, across the river, small parks include a fitness trail featuring signs with yoga instruction rather than the typical chin-up bars and sit-up boards.
Similar efforts are going on downstream. The idea is to build parks along the river tied together with bike paths creating a parkway of green through the city.
Those efforts got a major lift last year as California voters passed a $2.1 billion park bond, part of which is being used to provide nearly $100 million for projects along the river. Included in that money is $45 million for a park at Taylor Yard, which would be the first new state park in Los Angeles in a generation.
"We don't have anything that unifies all the various communities, and a greenbelt park along the river would be a wonderful thing both symbolically and practically," said Buddy Roberts, a longtime resident of Atwater Village.
Still, obtaining land for a parkway will not be easy. Legal battles are being waged over the Taylor and Chinatown rail yards. Environmental groups have filed lawsuits to stop industrial development there. 
Joel Reynolds, a senior lawyer with the National Resources Defense Council, said the development, which is supported by the departing mayor, Richard J. Riordan, and the City Council, would not only deprive some of the poorest neighborhoods of parkland, but also draw diesel trucks, increasing pollution. 
"There's potential here to create something that's tremendous not just for the surrounding communities but for the city of Los Angeles as well," Mr. Reynolds said. "It's inexplicable to us why the mayor of Los Angeles would approve major industrial development on some the largest available vacant land in the heart of the city." 
Rocky Delgadillo, deputy mayor for economic development, countered that the development would provide desperately needed jobs.
"The per capita annual income is $7,000 a year," Mr. Delgadillo said, adding that development plans provide for open space as well as shops and cinemas that would provide needed community services. 
Behind the scenes, lawyers are working to find a compromise. Dozens of groups have formed an alliance to rescue the yards, and the fight is becoming an issue in the mayoral election this April.
The river presents a difficult set of reclamation problems. "The Los Angeles River is probably the most extreme example of a very damaged urban river," said Rebecca Wodder, president of American Rivers, a national organization dedicated to protecting and restoring rivers. "It has been just so completely remade by the corps of engineers in some places that it's just a sea of cement."
Floods in the 1930's killed nearly 130 people and destroyed hundreds of homes, leading the Army Corps of Engineers to create a gigantic waterslide that can bear, per second, up to 183,000 cubic feet, the equivalent of the water in two and a half Olympic-size swimming pools. The 51-mile river has a drop in elevation like that of the 2,250-mile Mississippi. 
"The striking difference is that a drop on the very top of the Mississippi takes weeks to get to its lowest point," said Vik Bapna, watershed manager with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Works. "For Los Angeles, that's 12 hours."
In many places, development goes right up to the river walls, leaving little room for natural solutions. Nowhere is the picture starker than at the point where the Los Angeles River and its Arroyo Seco tributary converge near downtown. 
So lush was the land in this area it provided the reason for settlement in Los Angeles. It is now the consummate picture of what the city has become: a maze of concrete viaducts arching over a concrete riverbed. 
"You may look at it and see a wasteland," Ms. Winter said. "I look at it and see a lot of mistakes that can be rectified."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about plans to clean up the Los Angeles River misstated the name of an environmental organization opposing industrial development projects on nearby vacant land that is sought for parks. It is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not National Resources.

HEADLINE: Court Upholds Rules Allowing Theaters' Sale of Air Rights 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A state appeals court, overturning a lower court decision, has upheld zoning rules that will enable more than 20 Times Square theaters to sell development rights to investors who want to build offices or apartments along Eighth Avenue or nearby.
 The rules, devised as an experiment in urban planning that would channel fresh resources into the theater business, provoked legal challenges soon after they were adopted in 1998. But in a unanimous ruling on Thursday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, the court rejected arguments by a group of residents in the Clinton neighborhood that the city was encouraging intrusive, unchecked development in their area. 
 "This is a triumph for the New York theater and for the future of Times Square," Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said at a City Hall news conference.
But opponents of the zoning rules said the court ruling had provided only a partial victory for the city, since their legal challenge had postponed any sales for more than two years, during what has been one of the city's most robust periods of real estate investment and development.
"We still ended with more than the city," said John Fisher, president of the Clinton Special District Coalition, which had been the principal plaintiff in the suit before the appeals court. He said the delay in enforcement meant developers had missed opportunities to take advantage of the new zoning.
The new zoning would mean large financial gains for some theater owners, but it also requires that the owners commit part of their profits to maintaining their buildings as legitimate theatrical houses.
It enables them to sell "air rights" -- the theoretical development space above their buildings -- to others who would use those rights to erect buildings elsewhere in a zoning district bounded by 40th and 57th Streets, and by Eighth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas.
Mr. Rose said yesterday that provisions of the zoning law require the theater owners to commit about 10 percent of their profits to improving their buildings or staging new productions, although he said the exact requirement was under study by his staff.
When they were adopted by the city, the zoning rules were intended to lure developers to the still tawdry blocks along Eighth Avenue that border the theater district, mainly to the east side of those blocks, where greater development incentives are offered. Taking advantage of the air rights they would purchase, developers could erect buildings on Eighth Avenue about 40 percent larger and bulkier than had been allowed.
Although the zoning rules upheld on Thursday would authorize the same increase in building size, the rules had been modified as part of the earlier ruling in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. That change, which Mr. Fisher called a victory for his group, was to permit developers to exceed the previous size limits by 20 percent without public review, but require environmental approvals for a greater increase in size.
Mr. Rose said yesterday that the appeals court ruling meant that the intention of city planners to "act in the public interest has been affirmed."

HEADLINE: Weakness Seen In Rise in Orders 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 

 BODY:
Strong demand for airplanes lifted orders to factories for big-ticket goods in December, but that masked weakness elsewhere.
 Orders for industrial machinery and metal products were down, as were shipments -- fresh evidence of a struggling manufacturing sector. 
 The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, "will peer straight through the fog and see a very troubled economy," said Ken Mayland, president of ClearView Economics. "A big increase in commercial aircraft orders, which will be built three years from now, will not rescue this economy."
The Commerce Department reported today that orders for all durable goods -- items expected to last at least three years -- rose 2.2 percent last month, up from a 1.8 percent rise in November. Analysts were a 1.5 percent fall.
But the increase came mostly from a 14.6 percent surge in orders for transportation products. A more telling figure about the health of manufacturing, economists said, is orders for costly manufactured goods, excluding transportation equipment. Those orders fell 1.4 percent in December.

HEADLINE: Gillette Operating Net Up On Strength of Razor Sales 

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
Despite a loss related to factory closings and employee layoffs, the Gillette Company posted a 3 percent increase in its operating net income for the fourth quarter yesterday, largely on the strength of its razor blade business.
 Questions remain, though, about the Duracell division, where sales declined 6 percent and profits fell 31 percent. 
 Profit from continuing operations was $345 million, or 33 cents a share in the quarter, up from $339 million, or 32 cents a share in the period a year earlier. The consensus estimate among analysts polled by First Call/ Thomson Financial was 32 cents a share. Still, the stock fell 94 cents yesterday, to $32.69. 
"This company has a lot of work to do," said Sally J. Dessloch, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Chase.
The company, which is based in Boston, took a previously announced one-time charge that reduced net income by $430 million, or 41 cents a share, to cover the expenses of laying off 2,700 workers and closing eight factories. Including the charge, Gillette posted a loss of $85 million, or 8 cents a share in the October-to-December period.
On Monday, Gillette announced that James M. Kilts would become the chairman and chief executive, only the second outsider to lead the 100-year-old company. In a conference call with analysts yesterday morning, Gillette's current management suggested that the worst was over and that the company had begun to right itself.
Over all, Gillette's revenue increased to $2.82 billion from $2.81 billion, driven by substantial increases in the profits from blades, razors and Oral-B toothbrushes. Gillette said yesterday that sales of blades and razors, about 32 percent of its business, increased 10 percent and profits increased 29 percent, in part because the company was able to increase the price of its blades faster than inflation.
Edward F. DeGraan, the president and chief operating officer, said Duracell, which represents 26 percent of Gillette's business, suffered from a comparison with record sales in 1999 related to Year 2000 concerns. 
Mr. DeGraan said Gillette stumbled by allowing the market share for Duracell's copper-and-black batteries to fall. But Mr. DeGraan expressed hope that the company was taking back market share and continuing to win converts to the higher-priced Ultra battery.
"We feel we had to get back on track; we had gotten off track," Mr. DeGraan said.

HEADLINE: Layoff of 10,000 Employees Said to Be in the Works at WorldCom 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
WorldCom Inc. is expected to announce plans soon to lay off more than 10,000 employees, or 13 percent of its worldwide work force of 77,000, in an effort to cut costs at some of its slow-growing businesses, people close to the company said yesterday.
 The company, the second-largest long-distance telephone carrier after AT&T, is facing slower growth in businesses like long-distance, wholesale and dial-up Internet service. Some job cuts would occur in those areas as well as in human resources, finance and sales, people close to the company said. 
 The layoffs, which are expected to be made public in the next few weeks, are part of a downsizing wave in the communications industry. Some small companies like ICG Communications and NorthPoint Communications have laid off employees as they entered bankruptcy proceedings, while larger companies like Lucent Technologies, AOL Time Warner and Motorola have announced plans for layoffs in recent weeks. 
Slower growth of some communications services and tight financing conditions in a slowing economy have hurt both large and small companies, but WorldCom's troubles appear to stem largely from fierce competition in the long-distance business. WorldCom uses the MCI brand to sell much of its consumer long-distance services.
WorldCom is seeking to bundle consumer long-distance and other slow-growing products like prepaid calling cards and Internet dial-up service into a division with a tracking stock that would trade under the name of MCI, the long-distance company that WorldCom acquired in 1998. The restructuring would let WorldCom focus on the faster-growing area of providing data communications services to business customers. 
"The world is still waiting to see how WorldCom's retooling plans will be played out," said Adrian Davies, an equity analyst for Federated Investors in Pittsburgh. "We were expecting job cuts to possibly be part of the package, but it's troubling to find out they are of this magnitude."
The layoffs come as something of a surprise to investors in WorldCom, which was founded in 1982. The company's chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers, a cigar-chomping former high school basketball coach, built WorldCom through voracious acquisitions and is known for seeking to keep the company lean by keeping costs low.
The layoffs were reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.
But as growth has been slower than expected in WorldCom's businesses, some deals, like the acquisition of UUNet, the huge Internet carrier, may have disclosed redundancy in the company's work force, some analysts say. Former UUNet employees are known within WorldCom for their efforts to maintain a separate identity, even four years after WorldCom acquired UUNet's parent, MFS Communications, in 1996.
Though some analysts speculated yesterday that some of the layoffs could result from the integration of UUNet with WorldCom's Business Markets division, the company did not comment on exactly where the job cuts would occur. It was also unclear yesterday which geographic areas would be hardest hit by the layoffs.
WorldCom is expected to announce the layoffs formally before the end of the first quarter, people close to the company said. The company, which warned investors in November that its earnings and revenue growth were slowing, plans to release its fourth-quarter results next week. 
Analysts polled by First Call/ Thomson Financial are expecting WorldCom, which is based in Clinton, Miss., to report fourth-quarter profit of 25 cents a share, down from 42 cents a share in the period a year earlier, in what would be the first such decline in more than three years. Sales growth of 7 percent to 9 percent is expected in the quarter, in line with guidance provided by the company late last year.
"The WorldCom of today is not the vibrant, growth-story WorldCom of yesterday," said John Waterman, managing director of Rittenhouse Financial Services, a Philadelphia firm that sold its holdings of WorldCom stock worth several hundred million dollars in October. "Big layoffs like these are at the beginning, not the end, of WorldCom's confusion."
WorldCom shares rose 94 cents yesterday, to $21.31. They are more than 60 percent off their 52-week high of $52.50 in February 2000, but a rally in the last few weeks has pushed their value up more than 50 percent.

HEADLINE: California Lawmakers Debate Bill to Compensate Utilities 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Amid skepticism about the success of an auction intended to purchase long-term energy supplies, California legislators debated a bill yesterday that would help the state's biggest utilities recover billions they have lost buying electricity at prices far higher than they can charge customers.
 Consumer advocates said it appeared increasingly likely that residents would have to pay a major part of the price of solving the state's electricity crisis, whether through higher taxes or higher rates. Gov. Gray Davis, who has opposed rate increases as part of any solution to the situation, appeared to be softening his position, analysts said. 
 The bill in the State Assembly would allow the state to sell bonds to buy power for resale to the utilities. The state would receive stock warrants or other financial instruments that would appreciate if the stocks of the utilities' parent companies recovered. 
Shares in those companies, the PG&E Corporation and Edison International, both on the brink of bankruptcy, rebounded this week on news that a power auction arranged by Governor Davis had resulted in bids that could begin stabilizing the state's power supplies. Yesterday, analysts said there were more questions than answers about the auction's results.
Governor Davis had hoped to secure supplies at $55 a megawatt hour, but on Wednesday said that he was happy to have had bids offering what his office called a weighted-average price of $69 a megawatt hour. That average, it turns out, did not include much higher prices that would have to be paid for electricity during periods of peak use, officials said yesterday.
Aides to Governor Davis said he had not tried to deceive anyone about the auction. In a news conference, Governor Davis said those peak-period costs would make only a "minuscule" difference -- but he did not specify how much they raised the weighted average of power companies' bids at the auction.
Despite calls from legislators, state officials did not release other details of the auction, like the amount of power that generators offered to sell and the length of the contract periods. 
If the contracts extend longer than a year or two, some industry analysts say the state may be in danger of accepting bids that save money and reduce volatility in the short term but result in spending far more than the market price for long-term supplies of electricity. 
An executive at one major power supplier, who insisted on not being identified, said a typical proposal to the state would have offered power for $95 to $100 a megawatt hour over five years, or for $75 to $80 over 10 years. Power during peak periods would probably cost another $200 to $300 a megawatt hour, the executive estimated.
As for the legislation being weighed in Sacramento, Steven Fleishman, a utility analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York, said it was too early to handicap its chances of passage. But Mr. Fleishman said it seemed clear that the bill was structured to allow for possible tax or rate increases. "I think the solution will be shared by a bunch of parties," including residents, he said.
A group of leading California economists issued a statement yesterday saying that rate increases were unavoidable.
"There is no other way out," the statement said. "Either retail prices must go up, or blackouts will continue with the consequent high costs to the California economy."
Governor Davis said that he still hoped to avoid a rate increase and that he was optimistic for a legislative solution. 
"We believe we will get there," he said. He also endorsed the concept of helping the utilities out in exchange for stock warrants or other securities that would appreciate if the utilities regained their financial footing. 
"Ratepayers should benefit from any infusion of capital," Governor Davis said. 
Consumer advocates blasted the legislative proposals as a bailout. "We haven't seen anything in the bill that holds out any promise that we're going to see anything but consumers assigned the entire bill for the fiasco," said Bob Finkelstein, a lawyer at the Utility Reform Network, in San Francisco. Should the eventual legislation give the state warrants or other securities tied to the performance of the utilities, that could create a huge conflict of interest, Mr. Finkelstein said, between the interests of serving ratepayers and bolstering the state's treasury. The state's Public Utilities Commission, he said, would be caught in between. 
"If the utilities come in and say, 'we need a higher rate of return,' what's the P.U.C. supposed to do?" he asked.

HEADLINE: Presidential Panel Recommends F.D.A. Regulation of Tobacco 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 

 BODY:
A presidential commission says that the Food and Drug Administration should be given the authority to regulate tobacco for health reasons and that the government should compensate farmers who agree to stop growing the crop.
 As president, Bill Clinton named tobacco farmers, antismoking advocates and economic development experts to the panel in September with a goal of giving tobacco farmers an economic lift while protecting the public from the hazards of smoking. 
 In a preliminary report, the 10-member commission said today that the government should regulate the manufacture, sale, distribution and labeling of tobacco products to protect public health. 
Andrew Shepherd, a commission member and Virginia tobacco grower, said farmers who once wore baseball caps saying "Keep the F.D.A. off the farm" now see the advantages of regulation.
"As a consumer, I certainly wouldn't mind a lot more information on that pack, where it's from, how it's manufactured and what else is in there," Mr. Shepherd said.
Philip Morris, which has fought regulation in the past, now says it will accept some oversight. "Having a set of defined rules will help bring greater stability and predictability to our business," said Brendan McCormick, a spokesman for the company, which is the leading maker of cigarettes.
Dr. David A. Kessler, a former commissioner of food and drugs, said he doubted the sincerity of Philip Morris's endorsement. 
"I think they're looking for the stamp of social acceptability," Dr. Kessler said.
The report was forwarded to President Bush. His spokesman, Ari Fleischer, declined to comment, saying the report had not yet been reviewed.
At a campaign stop in Kentucky last year, Mr. Bush said Congress should give the F.D.A. "the authority necessary to discourage teenage smoking."
Under Dr. Kessler, the agency in 1996 reversed a decades-old policy by asserting authority over tobacco products and issuing rules to crack down on cigarette sales to minors. But the Supreme Court ruled last March that the agency had exceeded its authority.
Legislation that would have given the agency regulatory oversight of tobacco failed in Congress last year.
"I think this report from this White House commission is going to give us a good shot in the arm to get this thing moving," said Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa.
The commission also sought to address economic concerns of tobacco farmers, whose numbers have dropped to 89,700 from 188,650 in 1978.
Increasing imports of cheaper foreign tobacco and declining cigarette sales have led to steep cuts in the amount of tobacco that American farmers can grow under the federal price-support program.
The report says that farmers should receive help shifting to other crops and should be paid for giving up their quotas, or allotments, that dictate how much tobacco they can grow annually.
The report said money to finance the buyout could come from cigarette taxes or the 1998 national tobacco settlement between states and cigarette companies.
Mr. Harkin signaled there would be Congressional support.
"Next year the farm bill is up," he said, "and we'll take another look at what we might be doing to encourage smaller farmers in the South to get out of growing tobacco and grow something else."

HEADLINE: Down Into the Fray 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 

 BODY:
In this relentlessly partisan city, Alan Greenspan has almost always floated above the fray, enjoying bipartisan support built on his successful stewardship of the economy.
 But he is also one of Washington's shrewdest and most enduring political operators, cultivating ties to Democrats and Republicans alike while fortifying his own independence as chairman of the Federal Reserve under administrations of both parties. And he is well aware of the influence he wields on matters far removed from monetary policy. 
 So Mr. Greenspan set off considerable speculation about his motives when he reversed his own long-held position on Thursday and said the federal budget surplus was big enough both to pay off the national debt and accommodate a substantial tax cut. 
Was he making a purely economic judgment? Or was he putting some of his considerable political capital to work on behalf of the Republican agenda -- an agenda very much in sync with his own ideology -- just five days after George W. Bush moved into the White House?
His explanation of his decision was consistent with his previous view of what was happening to the economy and his stated preference for tax cuts as opposed to increased government spending. 
More so than even a year ago, he said, the government faces the real possibility that a wave of surpluses will wipe out the $3.4 trillion national debt held by the public within a decade and then leave Washington with hundreds of billions of dollars a year in excess revenue on its hands. 
Mr. Greenspan said he particularly feared that if taxes were not cut, the government would end up using the surplus to buy stocks and bonds, a prospect at odds with his philosophy that the government should play a minimal role in private enterprise.
"I never expected to see the day where I would be talking about anything other than reducing the debt," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Budget Committee on Thursday. "I am running into the tyranny of zero, which is where you can't reduce it any more. And so, have my views changed? Yes, they've changed; they have to change."
Republicans and their supporters knew immediately that Mr. Greenspan had vastly improved the odds of passing a tax cut of the scale proposed by Mr. Bush, $1.6 trillion over 10 years. Mr. Bush's plan would reduce all income tax rates, double the child credit, give a break to two-income couples and repeal the federal estate tax. 
Republicans in Congress have lots of ideas of their own for expanding the tax package, including a reduction in the capital gains tax, the addition of provisions favoring businesses, and expansions of the individual retirement account and 401(k) retirement savings plans. And the administration is close to a decision to speed up the tax cut by reducing income tax withholding this year, a development reported today by The Wall Street Journal. 
"Greenspan probably has more impact on the fate of a tax cut than the president of the United States," said Mark A. Bloomfield, president of the American Council for Capital Formation, a business-financed group that lobbies for tax cuts.
For Mr. Bush, whose father's administration had strained and at times hostile relations with Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman's stance on taxes held the promise of a more productive partnership. Mr. Bush's Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, has already signaled that he shares Mr. Greenspan's views on economic policy.
Among Democrats, though, there was a sense of disappointment, and some suspicion that after eight years with a Democrat in the White House Mr. Greenspan was revealing his true colors as a conservative whose ties to Republican politics date to Richard M. Nixon's 1968 campaign. 
To them, Mr. Greenspan had been a bulwark against fiscal irresponsibility. By opening the door to a large tax cut, they said, Mr. Greenspan was inviting a bidding war that could lead to a tax reduction so big that it could threaten the government's newfound fiscal health just as it is confronting the rising costs of providing retirement and health benefits to the baby boom generation.
"He's taken the lid off the punch bowl," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland. "And once you take the lid off the punch bowl, you can't say you can only have half a cup."
So distressed were Democrats that some of them said Mr. Greenspan might have hurt his standing among them. While they acknowledged that it was fruitless for them to fight the Fed chairman publicly, some of them said privately that he would receive less deference on Capitol Hill in the future.
"We've put him on this high pedestal, and we've fooled ourselves," said one senior Democratic aide on Capitol Hill. "This is a man with a very conservative background. This is not some objective, nonpartisan oracle."
This was not the first time that Mr. Greenspan has injected himself into a political battle. In early 1993, he publicly backed the deficit reduction program developed by the Clinton administration, even though it was built on a tax increase. 
In fact, Mr. Greenspan had worked behind the scenes after the 1992 election to stiffen Mr. Clinton's resolve in attacking what was then a huge and growing deficit. And his support helped move the package through Congress even though not a single Republican in either the House or the Senate voted for it.
But while the deficit in 1993 demanded immediate action, it is not clear, at least not to Democrats, that the current fiscal outlook requires an immediate and large tax cut. Not only is there an argument in favor of using some of the surplus money to address needs like improving health care and education, but the surplus projections could prove overly optimistic.
"Clinton's budget policy in 1993 was the right budget policy from the standpoint of the Fed and Alan Greenspan," said Alice M. Rivlin, a former Clinton administration official and a former vice chairwoman of the Fed. "I find this current move a little harder to understand, in part because I don't agree with it. His concern about the surplus seems to me to be premature."
Still, Mr. Greenspan's position left Democrats with little choice but to acknowledge that a substantial tax cut is now all but certain this year, and to shift their sights to keeping it at least somewhat smaller than what Mr. Bush has proposed rather than letting it grow larger.
They sought to focus attention on the caveats that Mr. Greenspan attached to his endorsement of tax cuts, most notably his insistence that they not lead to a repeat of the 1980's, when the Reagan-era tax cuts contributed to a surge in the deficit and the national debt.
Senator Max S. Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, "remains concerned that Chairman Greenspan's testimony could be misinterpreted as a green light for an excessive and exploding tax cut," said Michael Siegel, Mr. Baucus's spokesman.
Mr. Sarbanes said he feared that Mr. Greenspan's caveats would be lost in a rush to pass politically popular tax cuts, and spending increases as well, that could lead to deficits and economic problems down the road.
"There's not just a danger but a pretty high probability that this thing will get out of hand," Mr. Sarbanes said. "He's going to have to live with the consequences of what he's set off."
