HEADLINE: Giving It The Old College Try; 
Local Universities Struggle to Raise Their Profile

BYLINE:  By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
WHEN advertisements for a certain small liberal arts college in Garden City described Harvard University as "the Adelphi of Massachusetts," they implied that the two schools shared high standards and goals common to elite liberal arts institutions.
 The 1989 ad campaign, which cost nearly $2 million, was a soaring act of hubris for Adelphi University, which would never be confused with Harvard if one compares laureates, curriculum, valedictorians, alumni or many of the other latinate catchwords of higher education. The ads stopped running in 1990. 
 But the campaign raised another question -- why was there no Harvard of Long Island? Why was there no premier university in Nassau or Suffolk County, a place where the best of the Island's graduating high school seniors, a group with a national reputation for high academic achievement and aspirations, could attend with enthusiasm, without ever having to drive through a borough of New York City? 
A dozen years later, the question is still valid, though there are signs that some of Long Island's schools, particularly those focusing on science and technology, are gaining. A 1997 study of research universities that ranks them according to research grants won per professor, among other criteria, ranked the State University of New York at Stony Brook third among the country's public research universities, behind only the University of California at Berkeley and University of California at Santa Barbara. In another burst of immodesty, a Stony Brook professor proclaimed his school "the Berkeley of the east."
But the Island's overall higher-education profile remains low, a fact local college presidents often ascribe to reputation lagging behind performance. That reputation has repercussions off-campus -- for years, Long Island has suffered a brain drain, with the top high school seniors heading to the mainland as fast as fingerling salmon swim to the big wide ocean.
Probably 60 percent leave for college, estimates Matthew Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, and once gone are more likely to launch their careers off-Island. Each Long Islander thus lost is "almost irreplaceable," Mr. Crosson said, in an economy where local corporate recruiters have been struggling for years to find enough college grads to fill all their job openings.
The local colleges the departing students shun are left competing for the students who stay: commuters, older students, those with lower SAT scores. Those schools are not particularly choosy. None of the larger four-year colleges on Long Island accepts fewer than 55 percent of its applicants, and SUNY-Stony Brook, Hofstra University and the New York Institute of Technology report that the average SAT scores of their incoming freshmen have risen to 1,158, 1,103 and 1,100, respectively, no great shakes when the national average is 1,019.
"The premier students traditionally leave it to go elsewhere," Vince Passaro, director of communications at Adelphi, said of Long Island. "There's a whole combination of factors. Some of them have to do with getting away from home, or the traditional elite institutions and where they are located." 
One explanation for that: the colleges on Long Island are virtual infants compared to those on the mainland. "Adelphi is the oldest college on Long Island and it's only 105 years old," Mr. Passaro said.
In fact, of the 18 four-year colleges in Nassau and Suffolk counties, 12 are less than 50 years old, scant time for lofty intellectual traditions to take root.
Matthew Goldstein served as president of Adelphi for barely a year before leaving Long Island in 1999 to become chancellor of the City University of New York.
"At Adelphi we all lamented that probably the most able students were leaving the Island because they had options," he said in a recent phone interview. "It's probably a good thing for them to experience a new environment. Long Island is sort of an insular place as well, and there are people who feel very comfortable in that environment."
But that does not account for the bright students who would rather stay close to home but feel they must go elsewhere for the best education they qualify for.
One college official who asked not to be identified said he sees a "very disturbing focus" on the 100 top-ranked universities and liberal arts colleges in the country.
"None of the schools on Long Island are in that group, so they're left to forage with the rest of this vast middle," he said. "And as a result each one has to forge its identity. At the same time there is a deep, long-bred tradition of students looking elsewhere instead of here." 
Edward Guiliano, president of the New York Institute of Technology, said, "I think all of the colleges on Long Island need to better define their niche." 
N.Y.I.T., which has an Old Westbury campus, seems to have succeeded in niche-finding. "No other college on Long Island has a school of architecture and design," Dr. Guiliano said. "We also have a world-class reputation in computer graphics. We offer a great deal that the other colleges do not and so students self-select our school and programs. What we don't have is a football team."
There are many historical reasons for colleges in Nassau and Suffolk counties to suffer in comparison to those on the mainland, said James Axtell, a humanities professor at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va.
"The place wasn't terribly well developed until fairly late in the 20th century," he said of Long Island. "It's off the beaten track. Colleges usually grow up where there's a center of commerce or banking or intellectual activities or population, and there are none of those. There's lots of population out there, but it's basically diffused in bedroom communities, and they all go to New York, which is where their kids go to college."
But the suburbs of Philadelphia, for example, have a handful of elite liberal arts colleges. Kenneth T. Jackson, author of "Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States" (1985, Oxford University Press), detected a difference between the two regions.
"Long Island is old in the sense that people were there in the 17th century, but as a suburban area, where people commuted, it's a little more recent," he said. "The North Shore was where the wealthy lived in summer estates and weekend houses, but it was not suburban the way the Main Line was. Maybe that makes a difference, too."
New York's state university system was slower to develop than some of the flagship state schools in the Midwest, leaving Long Island without a set of powerhouse public universities. SUNY-Stony Brook, the best of the three state universities on the Island (and by many measures the best overall), was founded only in 1957, making it a young pup by collegiate standards.
Historically in the East, colonial-era colleges "established a model of private higher education that was superb, and the Midwest, when people began moving in the 19th century, didn't have that, so states picked up responsibility for that earlier in the West than in the East," said Ellen Condliffe Lagemann, president of the Spencer Foundation in Chicago, which focuses on education research.
Other factors make Long Island a natural place for higher learning, said Jamie Ferrare, a senior consultant at the Academic Search Consultation Service in Washington, which has conducted searches for several Long Island university presidents recently.
"One of the attractions is its proximity to New York City, yet you don't have to be in the city," he said. 
The suburbs can be a draw for students trying to avoid the crime and dirt of city living, said Robert A. Scott, the president of Adelphi since July. "In addition to the beauty of the campus and the beauty and safety of Garden City, parents especially appreciate the pristine, safe town we're in," he said, noting it is only 45 minutes by train to Manhattan. 
And Shirley Strum Kenny, president of SUNY-Stony Brook, said that Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory are wonderful resources for her students.
"They form an intellectual nucleus that is very important, not just for graduate students but for undergraduates as well," she said. 
But it has not always been easy to sell students on her school, which is known for having all the architectural charm of a Soviet apartment block, as Dr. Kenny found out when she arrived on campus six years ago.
"When I first came here I thought this place is so ugly," she said. "There was no sense of center to the university, and all the doors seemed to lead to parking lots." Early in her tenure she helped create an academic mall, a cobblestoned area with a brook, fountain, and benches where students could sit, read and socialize. More improvements are afoot, with a new Asian cultural center under construction.
"I'm very convinced that the quality of space is very related to the quality of education," Dr. Kenny said. "It needs to be respectful of students, and it needs to say you're important, that learning is important." 
In the meantime, she has overseen the $81 million rehabilitation of all 26 dormitories on campus. The dorms needed the facelift because, as she puts it, "they were not respectful of students."
Of Stony Brook's 6,161 full-time undergraduate students, 52 percent live on-campus. Other local universities have been trying to boost their percentages of resident students, with Adelphi moving from 600 resident students two years ago to 869 this year, with 50 or 60 more rooms planned. Hofstra is adding an honors college to attract more qualified students, and has also made improvements to the campus to encourage commuters to spend more time in the academic environment.
Reflecting a national trend, applications for a number of Long Island colleges are rising, along with the caliber of applicants, many college officials say. And lots of the students who accept spots at the schools are pleased with their decision.
Jennifer Morley, 21, of Newington, Conn., said none of her high school classmates applied to schools on Long Island, while she turned down an acceptance at Smith College to attend Hofstra. She said she wanted a school with strong academic, dance and communications programs.
"My peers were all very liberal arts-oriented," she said as she lunched on some rice cakes recently with other members of the dance program. "They thought it was a step down for me. I know it was, to some degree, academically, but by the same token, I liked the breadth of what was offered here."
Maria Corso, 19, was likewise happy attending Adelphi. "I've been wanting to go here as long as I can remember," said Ms. Corso, who was registering recently as a transfer student from Nassau Community College. She finds it convenient to commute from home in East Rockaway.
"I can work and do all the things I need to do," she said. "I don't get the college experience of living on my own, being independent, but I'm not really interested in that." Most of her high school classmates went away to college, she said.
Anjuli Bova, 20, chose to go to Hofstra even though she was accepted at Boston University. "I don't know if I chickened out, I just decided to come here," said Ms. Bova, a dance student from Bellmore. "I regret sometimes not going away. I've missed the whole dorm atmosphere. But I love living here. It's close to the city, and the beach, and dance classes in the city."
Andrene Bennett, a 17-year-old Hofstra freshman from West Hempstead, said she was more attracted to the suburbs than to an urban school. "I already knew where all the shopping malls are, and the best places to eat, so I don't have to get to know an area all over again," she said. 
Dr. Goldstein of CUNY believes that Hofstra is probably the local college most likely to see more students applying from out of state.
"To attract students from all over, you need activities and programs to draw those students. Hofstra is probably the best on the Island to provide that environment, and serve as a magnet," he said. "I'm not sure if it really has a national reach and can be nationally competitive. If you really want to become a national draw, you have to do the kinds of things so people will say it is really worth the effort and expense and risk of going to a place they may not have thought of before."
But Professor Jackson said that with the right infusion of funds, other schools could gain national recognition. "Maybe one of the Long Island institutions will become such an elite institution in the 21st century -- Hofstra, Adelphi or Stony Brook," he said. "Sometimes one big gift can jump-start a place. A gift of $100 million could make a big difference."

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 5

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Replacing Windows to Save Heat

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
HERE is a simple, three-step test to determine whether it is possible to cut your home heating bills by replacing your existing windows:
 1. Stand in front of one of the windows. 
 2. Draw back the curtain.
3. Look at the window. 
If what you are looking at is an old-fashioned wood-framed window with a single sheet of glass, the answer is almost certainly "yes."
In fact, energy experts say, older windows are one of the most significant sources of heat loss in the home. And now, with home heating bills at near-record highs, replacing drafty old windows with new energy-efficient models is beginning to make more and more sense for many homeowners.
"There are basically two types of window replacement options," said Jennifer Grove, marketing manager for Pella Windows and Doors, a window manufacturer based in Pella, Iowa. "One would be a full-frame replacement," she said. This is needed when both the window and the existing frame must be replaced -- usually because the frame itself is rotted or otherwise damaged.
The other option -- replacement of just the window while leaving the existing frame in place -- is more common, less expensive and easier to accomplish.
"What we're talking about is a replacement window unit that is custom-sized to fit the existing opening," Ms. Grove said, explaining that the windows are individually manufactured to measurements provided by the homeowner. "You don't have to disturb any of the interior walls or woodwork to install them, and it's so simple to do that do-it-yourselfers can usually do it themselves."
Ms. Grove said that installing a Pella Precision Fit replacement window requires the removal of only the wood strips that hold the windows in place. Once those strips are removed, the original windows can be taken out of the frame and replaced with the new window assembly.
"You can get our wood replacement windows for about the same price you would pay for vinyl replacements," she said, adding that Pella's Precision Fit wood windows range in price from about $300 to $550, including installation. 
Brian Ciechanowski, the owner of Tri-Pane Installations, a replacement window contractor based in Farmingdale, N.Y., said homeowners who want vinyl replacement windows -- which are popular because they never have to be painted -- should be aware that not all vinyl windows are created equal. 
"Buying a window is a little like buying a car," Mr. Ciechanowski said. "You have economy, midpriced and luxury models."
The "economy" model vinyl window sash and frame assembly, he said, is generally held together with screws. Such windows are often advertised for as little as $169 installed. "It's not a very good window, though, because after a while, the parts start to separate," he said.
The midpriced model, which costs about $225 to $275, uses screws to hold together the frame, but employs a welding process to construct the sash -- the casing around the window glass itself. And the top-of-the-line vinyl replacement window, he said, uses welded seams for both the frame and sash, making the entire assembly more sturdy and resilient. 
Virtually all replacement windows sold today, he said, are at least double-glazed, meaning that there are two panes of glass encasing an insulating area of "dead air" between them. 
And the better windows contain energy-saving features like foam-filled frames, "low-emissivity" coatings -- which prevent heat loss from inside the house while protecting furniture and furnishings from the effects of ultraviolet light from the outside -- and argon gas instead of just "dead air" in the space between panes.
"Our fully welded windows run from $300 and up," Mr. Ciechanowski said, adding that the energy-saving features can add another $75 per window.
One way that homeowners can judge the quality of a particular replacement window is by using a rating system developed by the National Fenestration Rating Council, a not-for-profit testing organization based in Washington.
"When it comes to the energy performance of windows, the N.F.R.C. is basically the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval," said Leonard Greenberger, a spokesman for the organization. The council's ratings on hundreds of windows are available on its Web site at www.nfrc.org, and they are also on stickers that are placed on any windows that have been tested.
Mr. Greenberger said that while the council bases its ratings on various parameters of window performance, the most useful rating is the window's "U-value."
"The U-value measures how good a window is at keeping heat inside a home," he said, explaining that the lower the U-value, the better the window.
"The very best windows have a U-value as low as 0.15," he said, adding that the average U-value for a good replacement window is about 0.45 and the least efficient models have a U-value of 1 and higher.
Another important rating provided by the council is what is known as the "solar heat gain coefficient." 
"That tells you how much solar heat is coming into the house through the window," he said, adding that the coefficient ranges from 0.085 to 0.05. "The higher the number, the better the window is at keeping solar heat out."
Mr. Greenberger pointed out that since solar heat gain would be considered a benefit to homeowners in colder northern climates, windows with a lower solar heat gain coefficient would generally be considered preferable to those with a higher rating. The opposite would apply, however, in hot southern climates where heat from the sun is best kept outside.
For those who want the ultimate in energy efficiency when buying replacement windows, the so-called superwindow may be just the thing.
"The very best window out there is a triple-glazed double-soft-coat low-e window with two layers of krypton gas," said Gerald Damora, the owner of Morris Window and Siding, in Randolph, N.J.
Mr. Damora explained that with a triple-glazed window there are three separate pieces of glass that create two insulating dead-air pockets. Those spaces are then filled with krypton gas -- which is heavier than argon and thus better at insulating.
"That gives you a U-value of about 0.19," he said. "And that is fabulous."
Such superwindows also have soft-coat low-emissivity coatings on all the glass surfaces. "A hard-coat low-e coating is applied as the glass is being made," he said. "A soft-coat low-e coating is applied afterward and is much thicker and much better."
While such windows are more expensive than even the best double-glazed replacement units -- a triple-glazed superwindow will cost between $700 and $900 installed -- they are significantly better at saving energy. In fact, Mr. Damora said, while replacing a residence's single-glazed windows with high-efficiency double-glazed models will result in a savings of between 10 and 15 percent on heating bills, using a triple-glazed super-windows will result in a savings of as much as 47 percent.
"Not everybody can afford these windows," Mr. Damora said. "But think about it. If you put in a new kitchen for $40,000, you're not going to see a return on your investment until you sell your home. When you put in triple-glazed, high-performance windows, you begin saving money the minute the installer walks out the door."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 4, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Your Home column on Jan. 28, about replacing old windows, misstated the range of a measurement used to indicate how much solar heat a pane transmits. The "solar heat gain coefficient" ranges from 0 to 1, not 0.085 to 0.05. The column also misstated the way the coefficient expresses a window's properties. A window with a low coefficient is better at blocking heat than a window with a higher coefficient. A reader's letter questioning the figures was received on Feb. 24.

HEADLINE: Up Against The Drawing Board; 
For Lawmakers, Push May Come to Shove When 6 Congressional Districts Become 5

BYLINE:  By MAURA CASEY 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT, the Land of Steady Habits, may have been a bit too steady in the last 10 years.
 Because recent United States Census figures show that the state grew significantly more slowly than the rest of the country, Connecticut is poised to lose a congressional district for the first time since 1840. The state's delegation in the House of Representatives will go from six to five and the state's electoral votes in presidential elections will be reduced from eight to seven. 
 Since learning the news, state lawmakers have begun the delicate maneuvering that will eventually decide which of the state's six members of Congress will lose his seat and, perhaps, be forced to run against another incumbent. 
This political game of musical chairs will be in the hands of eight members of the General Assembly, four Republicans and four Democrats. The majority and minority leaders of Connecticut's House and Senate each have the power to appoint two members to a Reapportionment Committee; by tradition, they appoint themselves and one other legislator. The committee will then have until Sept. 15 to send a redistricting plan to the legislature for ratification by a two-thirds vote. 
Unlike many other states, where the process is more partisan, Connecticut's Constitution mandates an even-handed process that gives both major parties equal say. 
Still, tension is high. The eight state legislators will not only redraw the lines of congressional districts, but those of the General Assembly's Senate and House districts as well.
"There is no small amount of trepidation depending on where your district is," said Kevin Sullivan, the Democrat who is Senate President Pro Tempore. "There is no part of Connecticut that isn't going to change." (Mr. Sullivan said he expected to appoint himself and Senator Joseph J. Crisco Jr. to the redistricting committee).
Members have not been appointed to the Reapportionment Committee, which will do the bulk of its work after June 1, when the current legislative session ends. Still, activity has begun. Secretary of the State Susan Bysiewicz reports that her office has received telephone calls from first selectmen concerned about possible changes to legislative district boundaries and how alterations could change towns' representation in the General Assembly. The legislative leadership has begun to hire staff to assist the committee. The work of data collection has already begun, but it won't swing into high gear until the Census Bureau releases detailed, town-by-town population statistics, which are not expected until mid-March at the earliest. 
"This is likely to be a very contentious process," said Ms. Bysiewicz, whose office will produce a map outlining the districts after the Reapportionment Committee does its work. She said the Democrats would like to get rid of Representative Rob Simmons, a Republican who has just begun his first term representing the Second District, while the Republicans would like to get rid of Jim Maloney, who just won re-election to a third term, because his Fifth District is a swing district and several years ago was represented by a Republican.
In the end, it is the Fifth District that is likely to be merged with others, according to many politicians, including several who are likely to be on the redistricting committee. Mr. Maloney's district has the distinction of touching the boundaries of all the other congressional districts in the state; its longest border is shared with the Sixth District, now represented by Representative Nancy Johnson, an 18-year incumbent Republican. 
While some say that makes the Fifth a natural to be at least partially absorbed by the Sixth, Mr. Maloney argued otherwise, saying that his district contains Waterbury, which he says is too large a city to be included in another district. The idea that the Fifth would be merged into the Sixth District is "a Republican fantasy," he said. 
"Not necessarily," said a key Democrat, Senator Sullivan, who described the options as limited. "I don't know much else that we would likely be dealing with," other than the merger of the Fifth and Sixth Districts, he said.
The only other congressman whose district appears vulnerable is Mr. Simmons, the Republican who defeated Sam Gejdenson, a 20-year incumbent Democrat,last November. One option for the redistricting committee is to split the huge, 54-town Second District in half, creating a shoreline district that would stretch from New Haven to the Rhode Island border. This would change the Third District, represented for 10 years by a Democrat, Congresswoman Rosa DeLauro. The other half of the Second District would become part of the First District, dominated by Hartford and currently represented by another Democrat, John Larson. 
Mr. Simmons said such a split would be a big mistake. "Those who love Connecticut should think long and hard before screwing up the social, economic and political community that is Eastern Connecticut in the name of giving a hard time to a freshman congressman," he said. 
"If this process is to be fair, I need more Republicans in my district, not less," he said, noting that only 23 percent of the voters in his district are registered Republicans.
Congressman Larson said that the larger issue, beyond the fate of any one district, is one of clout. "Any time you lose a seat, you lose clout, but we are lucky that the delegation has so much experience and seniority," he said. 
State Representative Moira Lyons, who is Speaker of the House, agreed. "True clout is measured in the quality of people you have who represent you, not necessarily the number of people in a delegation," said Representative Lyons, a Democrat from Stamford. "We're fortunate in who we have in Congress. Certain delegations might have 20 people, but even if you have just one or two, if you have enough respect and clout you could bring that state the importance it needs. I don't see the issue in numbers, but in leadership and respect." 
Representative Lyons said she would probably appoint herself to the Reapportionment Committee, although she had not originally planned to do so, saying she had been unaware until recently that it was a common practice for leadership to do so.
With regard to the need to reduce congressional seats, she said: "What will probably happen is that a Republican and a Democrat will end up facing off. If you think of the rationale of one side against another, are the Republicans going to agree that two Republicans will run against one another? I don't think so. Are we Democrats going to make two Democrats run against each other? I don't think so." 
Representative Robert M. Ward, the North Branford Republican who is minority leader of the state House of Representatives, said he expected to appoint himself to the Reapportionment Committee. He said that the five new congressional districts in the state would each have about 100,000 more people than the existing districts and that the Fifth District is "the most likely to get amended" because it touches on all the other districts. 
The Senate Minority Leader, Louis C. DeLuca, agreed, saying it wasn't logical to cut the Second District in half. Senator DeLuca, who said he intended to appoint himself, so far is the only member of the committee who is a veteran of the last Reapportionment Committee in 1990. "We'll try to keep politics out of this as much as possible," he said.
He said that his experience on the 1990 committee doesn't necessarily give him the edge. "Experience doesn't drive this process," he said. "It is the art of compromise. Nobody has the advantage."
Senator DeLuca noted that, in the event the committee can't come to a decision by Sept. 15, the committee would become a Reapportionment Commission and would choose a ninth member. That ninth member would cast the deciding vote on the new districts, and the decision would be legally binding without a ratifying vote of the legislature. In both 1980 and 1990, the committee deadlocked and had to elect a ninth member. 
Unlike many states, Connecticut's redistricting process has virtually no role for the governor; the vote of the legislature is considered a resolution and therefore is not subject to a gubernatorial veto. The only influence that Gov. John G. Rowland could have -- outside of his powers of persuasion -- would occur in the unlikely event that the legislators couldn't decide on new district boundaries by Nov. 30 even with a ninth member. Then it would be turned over to the state Supreme Court, and the governor's judicial appointees would have until Feb. 15 of next year to choose new districts. 
"Letting the courts decide this is the worst-case scenario," Senator DeLuca said. "Not that the courts aren't smart, but they might chop up the state as if they are wielding a cookie-cutter. It's incumbent upon us to work things out."
Because the committee will have to eliminate a congressional district, something the 1990 committee didn't have to contend with, the job "would be a little tougher this time around," Senator DeLuca said. Has he received any anxious telephone calls from Washington?
"Congressmen haven't called me, but let's just say that they've all been a lot more friendly lately," Senator DeLuca said with a laugh.

HEADLINE: For the Director, It's Lights Out 

BYLINE:  By ANNE M. AMATO 

 BODY:
LAST October, Louis Burke, the artistic director for Stratford Festival Theater Inc., predicted that January would be the "do or die" date for securing money needed to complete renovations to the theater that was once home to star-studded Shakespeare productions. If the money didn't come through, he said, it would mean curtains for the project.
 Mr. Burke was right about the date, but not about what the curtains would fall on. 
 On Jan. 9, Mr. Burke himself was fired in what the theater's Board of Directors called "sweeping management changes in order to at long last bring the theater to life again after decades of darkness." Two directors resigned in protest of the board's action.
In another change, the board -- whose number has fluctuated considerably over the years -- added two new members who are Broadway producers, Leonard Soloway and Steven Levy. 
At issue is the future of the 14-acre Elm Street property where the 1,502-seat former American Festival Theater is located. The theater, which opened in 1955, went bankrupt in 1982 and was taken over by the state. Since then the theater has been open for only one season -- 1989.
In 1995 the state chose Mr. Burke's company, Brickhill-Burke Productions Ltd., to redevelop the theater site; that contract has also been terminated by the board. In 1998, the group Stratford Festival Theater Inc. was set up as a nonprofit fundraising organization to work on Mr. Burke's elaborate $180 million plan for the site, which would include two more theaters, hotels, restaurants and shops.
A major reason cited for Mr. Burke's removal was his inability to bring in the funding he had promised so the theater could reopen, according to Bill Martin, spokesman for Stratford Festival Theater.
In fact, Mr. Burke had admitted last October that backers of the project had pulled out because of a clause in the contract that said the property would revert to the state if the theater project failed.
Mr. Martin said "lots of other funding sources" were interested in the project, but they felt that if Mr. Burke "wasn't able to revive the theater after 10 years, then why back him?"
State Senator George Gunther, a Republican of Stratford who is a longtime supporter of Mr. Burke and his project, agreed. "Lots of money people we have met with over the past few months seemed to have a problem with him," said Mr. Gunther, who added, "Louie just made a lot of promises, but never seemed to follow through."
But Mr. Burke said this week that it was the board, and not him, that failed to come up with money, for the project and for productions as well.
"The board had asked me to prepare a summer season and said they would provide funding for it, but they didn't deliver," he said. "Now they are finger-pointing at me."
Mr. Burke also claims he was underpaid for his services. "I was paid $100,000 over the past three years,' he said. "They owe me $1.25 million."
Mr. Burke said he was considering suing the board. 
His attorney, Ira Grudberg, said: "We want to take our time and look at our options. There's no hurry. This isn't a rear-end collision."
Alan Capper, the chairman of the board's public relations committee, said that the board was now "working on specific goals, like getting a fund-raising package together and making an appeal to the state and to foundations and corporations in the immediate area." 
The board, over the past two years, has already obtained a $500,000 grant from the state Department of Economic and Community Development; a $500,000 matching grant from Stratford to complete infrastructure improvements; and a $1.5 million working capital bank loan, guaranteed by the Department of Economic and Cultural Development. 
Also, in July the state conveyed the title to the theater property to Stratford Festival Theater and forgave the purchase price of $1.5 million -- actions for which the board gives credit to Mr. Gunther. 
However, more than $1 million is still needed to complete the theater renovations, Mr. Capper said. 
The board also needs money for operating costs, said Mr. Martin, adding many employees of Stratford Festival Theater, including himself, haven't been paid in months. Otherbills, like those for utilities, are also piling up, he said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Burke still lives at a house next to the theater property, which he has been renting. However, locks to the theater and to the administrative building, where Mr. Burke had an office, have been changed.
"It's pretty normal procedure to change the locks immediately after any type of personnel change," said Mr. Martin. "It's more an insurance issue than anything."
The theater has also been boarded up, due to the high cost of heating the building this winter, said Mr. Martin. 
"It's the same thing that used to be done when the theater was used for summer stock," he said. "We drained all the pipes and put anti-freeze in the toilets and it will stay that way until we can pay for the heat, or until the spring."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
College Plans to Develop Business Park in Lakewood

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: LAKEWOOD 

 BODY:
FOR more than 20 years a 240-acre swath of scrub pine along Cedar Bridge Avenue in the northern Ocean County township of Lakewood has sat fallow. Now a development company owned by a Jewish college is pursuing plans to turn the site into a two million square foot business park.
 The $300 million Cedarbridge Corporate Campus at Lakewood will have up to 15 low-rise and midrise buildings with office and research and development space as well as stores and restaurants. Some 120 residences for the elderly are also planned as part of the project. 
 It is to rise over the next 15 years on the site, which is in the southeastern section of the 25-square mile community and has long defied development because such public services as roads, sewers, electricity and telephone have not yet been brought in. The township, which owns most of the 240 acres, declared the site a redevelopment area in 1990. 
For Lakewood the aim of the project is not only to generate tax revenue and jobs, but to shift the township's image from an industrial to a corporate address, said State Senator Robert W. Singer, a Republican from Jackson and a member of the Township Committee, Lakewood's governing body.
"We could have put in another industrial park," he said, referring to three such nearby parks. "But we wanted something that would bring in higher-paying jobs, have a ripple effect and offer residents who work outside the area a reason to stay." 
Lakewood designated the Cedarbridge Development Corporation as developer of the site in June. The company was formed by Beth Medrash Govoha, which has 3,000 students and has been a presence in Lakewood since 1943. The college's main nine-acre campus is between Sixth and Seventh Streets across from Georgian Court College, a Roman Catholic institution.
For Beth Medrash Govoha the project "represents a prudent risk and an opportunity to create a serious long-term endowment for the college, as well as jobs for students and the township," said George Kline, chairman of its committee for development and endowment. And "who knows the neighborhood better than the college?" said Mr. Kline, who is also president of Park Tower Group, a Manhattan-based development company, and who sits on the board of Cedarbridge Development.
Principals of other development companies in New York and New Jersey are also on the board, including Charles Kushner of the Kushner Companies of Florham Park and Samuel Halpern of Atlantic Realty of Woodbridge. 
Cedarbridge has hired Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate service firm, to market the project and the Hillier Group of Princeton to design it. The manager is Picus Associates of Princeton, which works with Princeton University to develop Princeton Forrestal Center, a 2,200-acre office and research park in Plainsboro and East Brunswick, where six million square feet of space has been built out of an eventual nine million feet.
FINANCING for the Lakewood project will come from the school and conventional lending sources, said Philip Ludeke of Picus Associates. So far Cedarbridge has invested $500,000 in developing the site. 
Mr. Ludeke said construction would start once it secures state and local approval, which is expected in 12 months. The site improvement cost is expected to be at least $10 million.
After the improvements are made, the redevelopment agreement calls for the township to release the land, valued at $4 million, in pieces to Cedarbridge. It also calls for Cedarbridge to develop 40 acres in the first seven years and 40 more acres five years later.
Such safeguards will protect the interest of the township, according to Senator Singer and Lakewood's mayor, Marta D. Harrison. If the agreement is not met, the land with improvements reverts to the township, and "we will be no worse off than when we started," Mayor Harrison said.
If the project is fully realized, it will produce 12,000 jobs, according to the developer, and it will generate between $8 million and $10 million in new tax revenue a year, Mayor Harrison said. In addition, she said, the project is not expected to overburden the town's roads, because it will be close to a new interchange planned along the Garden State Parkway, where construction is to get under way this summer. 
With its benefits and safeguards, the project "is a good deal," Mayor Harrison said, noting that Cedarbridge was selected over one other developer, who wanted to develop the site for industrial use. 
Months after Cedarbridge was designated, however, some residents accused the five-member Township Committee of making the deal to gain votes from the town's large Orthodox Jewish population. The Ocean County Prosecutor's Office said it made inquiries about the deal but concluded there was no basis for an investigation.
THE township owns almost all of the 240 acres of the proposed office park's site. That property, along with the 1,800 acres of the three existing industrial parks -- which decades earlier had been made up of tiny lots -- was acquired by the township through foreclosure or condemnation from numerous private owners. Senator Singer said the business park was part of efforts begun several years ago to promote Lakewood as a place for corporations. It follows the construction of a $20 million minor league baseball stadium that he said will make Lakewood a destination. The stadium, to open this spring, is on 55 acres adjacent to the planned business park.
For its part, the township has agreed to reduce taxes on the park's site for 35 years, Mr. Ludeke said. He added that each building would rise only after commitments were received for at least half of its space to safeguard the college from undue risk. 
By proceeding with the park, the developer and township are betting New Jersey's office market will continue its southward march to Ocean County in general and Lakewood in particular. They said that though the county is known for its shore areas, the project should draw pharmaceutical, service and technology tenants for several reasons, including location. 
Along with being near the ballpark and the planned Garden State Parkway interchange, the project is in both an urban enterprise zone and a foreign trade zone. Such zones provide tax breaks and other business incentives to companies locating there. 
Another factor is the project's accessibility to a growing labor pool. Through the 1990's Ocean County grew by 64,000 people, to 497,533; and neighboring Monmouth County increased by 58,000 residents, to 611,444. Both were among the five fastest-growing counties in the state and are expected to remain such through this decade, state planners said.
Both are also targets for jobs. About 28,000 jobs were created in the counties from 1995 to 1999, and the total is expected to rise to 50,600 by 2006, according to state estimates. 
For the Lakewood project Mr. Ludeke said that graduates of Beth Medrash Govoha along with other residents "have moved rapidly into high technology fields, helping to create a solid employment base for technology-savvy companies hoping to locate in the region." 
With its labor base, Ocean County will mature, albeit slowly, into an office market said Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization/TNC Worldwide, a real estate services firm in Woodbridge. While there is little existing office space to lease in Monmouth County, this could change, he added, if projects planned there, totaling more than one million square feet, move ahead or the economy cools. 
The Lakewood project will be competitive because of its expected price, said Joseph J. Sarno, senior director at Cushman & Wakefield. In addition to the tax and business incentives, rents will be $3 to $5 a square foot lower than the $15 to $20 a square foot rents in Monmouth County, he said, adding that negotiations are under way with a telecommunications company for 100,000 square feet.
The economy, Senator Singer said, "goes in waves, and while things may be slowing, they are not stopping; so with this project Lakewood will be poised and ready."

HEADLINE: Ready for a Black Governor? If Not Now, When? 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

 BODY:
WHEN Secretary of State DeForest B. Soaries Jr. dipped his toe into the murky pool of gubernatorial politics last month -- suggesting that the next governor of the state should be a member of a minority group, or maybe even himself -- he unleashed a riptide.
 Although Mr. Soaries, or Buster, as he is invariably known around the State House, quickly and inexplicably withdrew his name from consideration, the issues he raised remain on the table. 
 In a state as culturally diverse as New Jersey, where 32 percent of the people are members of a minority group; where the number of minority candidates elected to local and county seats increased by three percent in the last year, outpacing national trends; and where voters are becoming increasingly aware of such sensitive issues as racial profiling, the question must be asked: Is New Jersey ready to elect a black governor?
By most measures, entering this year's gubernatorial race now is almost academic. But if Mayor Jim McGreevey of Woodbridge -- who has been campaigning relentlessly for the Democratic nomination for governor since his narrow loss four years ago -- is any example, it is not too late to begin building support for 2005. 
"You almost have to do two times around the track to get known here," said Tom Giblin, the state Democratic chairman. "If you have serious plans to run for governor in 2005, right now is not a minute too early to begin."
Although blacks represent just 13.6 percent of the state's voting age population, they have played an enormous role in shaping the outcomes of the last several statewide races, from Al Gore's trouncing of George Bush last fall to Mr. McGreevey's near victory four years ago to Jon S. Corzine's narrower-than-expected victory over Representative Bob Franks.
And with Governor Whitman having broken the glass ceiling as the first woman to be elected governor in the state, there is growing sentiment among many blacks that it is time for one of their own to step up to the plate. So far, none have come forward, though some are testing the water. 
"I would be disappointed if in four years time there is not someone in the African-American community who is considered not just by the African-American community but by the state at large to be a viable candidate for governor or U.S. senator," said the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, executive director of the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey. But being a viable candidate and taking the plunge are two very different things.
While blacks hold 15 seats in the State Legislature and are mayors of some New Jersey's largest cities, they have not managed to leverage that strength and catapult a candidate into statewide office, said Walter Fields, a former political director of the New Jersey chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
"Black elected officials have grown comfortable with their fiefdoms, and they are not willing to grow further or work collectively toward that goal. Historically, we've not aspired to greater heights, we've lowered the bar, accepting the floor when we should be going for the ceiling," said Mr. Fields, noting that in an area like Essex County, where there are four black mayors, a collective front could "wield a tremendous influence on the rest of the state."
Beyond the complacency described by Mr. Fields, several other obstacles stand in the way of a run for governor -- from exposure to substantial financing to an ingrained system of bossism to a suburban bias that runs throughout much of the state. The barriers have apparently been large enough that only one black has run for statewide office, former Mayor Ken Gibson of Newark, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for governor in 1981 and 1985.
One of the biggest obstacles is simply gaining access to the voters, since New Jersey's political structure offers few opportunities for statewide exposure. While most states have several elective state offices, New Jersey is one of four states where the governor is the only elected state official. Elsewhere, positions like lieutenant governor, attorney general and state comptroller are usually seen as good places for minority candidates to showcase their abilities and build voter confidence on the state level.
"Having a minority as a lieutenant governor gives the ticket a balance and people become used to you," said State Senator Shirley Turner, a Democrat from Mercer County. "So when the governor leaves office, they're comfortable voting for you and don't feel they're taking as much of a risk as with an unknown."
But New Jersey has no lieutenant governor. Moreover, all of the cabinet posts, board commissions and judgeships are appointed by the governor. So while Governor Whitman, for instance, may get points for naming the first black Supreme Court justice and the first black secretary of state, the appointees often find themselves in the politically awkward position of being beholden to the governor.
Most political observers agree that this contributed to Mr. Soaries' quick decision not to enter this year's race, and it was what kept Len Coleman, state commissioner of consumer affairs at the time and more recently commissioner of baseball's National League, from running for United States Senate in 1985 after being discouraged by Governor Tom Kean.
Richard W. Roper, a public policy consultant, suggested that the only real way to get statewide visibility is through an issue, like Mr. Jackson has done with racial profiling.
"If you are able to speak to an issue, and that issue demands coverage, then you're going to be the person attached to that issue and you're going to get the exposure," said Mr. Roper, who, like many others, noted that buying advertising in the two major television markets that serve New Jersey is prohibitively expensive.
Running a statewide campaign can easily cost $5 million; Mr. Corzine just spent $62 million of his own money to become a household name and get elected to the United States Senate. That kind of money is not readily available to most candidates, let alone minority candidates who have historically had far weaker ties to corporate Amnerica.
"For emerging minority candidates, 9 out of 10 will pick up their wealth from outside of the state, drawing money from all over the country," said State Senator Wayne Bryant, a Democrat from Camden County, citing former Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia. "They have to go to a bigger drawing room."
Then, of course, there is the boss system, which is well entrenched in New Jersey. To be a viable candidate, having party backing is essential, and that means receiving the nod from the state's 42 county party chairmen. In the Democratic Party, there is just one black county chairman, John Currie of Passaic County. Among the Republicans, there are two female county chairwoman, but no black men or women.
And while Mr. Currie has been working hard to get more blacks and Hispanics to run for county and local seats, pushing for diversity at the state level is a bit more difficult.
"If a person has worked hard and paid their dues, they shouldn't be kept back because of the color of their skin or ethnicity," said Mr. Currie. "We have a number of qualified African-Americans who could run for governor, but we have a way to go to get to that point."
The state's strongest black leaders come from urban areas, like Mayors Sharpe James of Newark or Douglas Palmer of Trenton, a factor that can actually hurt them in a statewide race, said Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a liberal research organization in Trenton, who believes "New Jersey is not just a suburban state, it's an anti-urban state."
Councilman Cory Booker of Newark, whose name comes up on several lists of black politicians with potential statewide appeal, says he believes that the future of the state is in its urban regions and that the candidate who embraces a more regional attitude will go far.
"We need to stop the tyranny of the 'or' and start the vision of the 'and' to look at how we can have both cities and suburbs and build on that regionalism," said Mr. Booker.
While he says he has no political aspirations beyond Newark at this time, Mr. Booker is quick to add, 'It would be great to see a governor come from Newark."
Despite the challenges of party bosses, New Jersey's voters have proven to be moderate and open-minded, willing to back newcomers whose positions reflect their own concerns. The right candidate with the right message could win public support, forcing party bosses and financial power brokers to line up behind that person.
If the state is not ready for a black governor -- or a black is not ready to run -- there is one minority candidate who many political observers say is well-positioned to make history: Robert Menendez, the Hispanic congressman from Hudson County. But as the fourth-ranking congressional Democrat, Mr. Menendez might well have his sights set elsewhere.
"Generally speaking, being governor of the state would be more desirable than being one of 435 voices in Congress," said Mr. Shure. "But as someone who is moving high up in the ranks, the success of Menendez's career in Congress might make him see things differently.'
One thing New Jersey politics has proven to be is unpredictable.
"Things can happen overnight," said Assemblyman Joseph Charles Jr., a Democrat from Hudson County who is chairman of the New Jersey Legislative Black and Latino Caucus. "Four, almost five years is a long time for something to happen that makes someone irresistible and compelling."
When asked who that compelling or irresistible force might be, the same names kept coming up.

Douglas Palmer
As head of the state's capital city for the last 10 years, Mayor Palmer knows not only the ins and outs of running an executive office but also how state government works. In addition, he gets high marks for helping improve the city's economic base.
Despite the tough decisions he has had to make about raising taxes, he has managed to recast his urban message to a more tempered, regional vision. At 49, the Democratic mayor still has time to widen his base, which he has begun to through a leadership role in the United States Conference of Mayors.
The only thing stopping Mayor Palmer from being a leading contender for governor is what he acknowledges as a "warm but not burning desire in my belly to do it yet."
Still, he says he has been talking about his future with close friends and advisers and asking himself, "Am I going to be mayor my whole life?"
"I look at the candidates who are running for higher office and think, "They don't have anything more on the ball than I do,' " he said.

DeForest Soaries Jr.
Although Mr. Soaries now insists his bid for governor had more to do with delivering a can-do message to a gathering of 600 young black men, the one thing his brief foray into gubernatorial politics did do for Mr. Soaries was convince him of his potential.
"It left me thinking I could put together enough money and support in three years to do it," he said.
As the top-ranking black in the current administration, Mr. Soaries has had the opportunity to gain statewide exposure, but frequently -- like during last year's Martin Luther King Jr. commemoration and the announcement of an initiative for curbing violence in schools -- he has had to step aside to let the governor bask in the limelight.
Although the 49-year-old Mr. Soaries is a Republican and has not enjoyed the natural base of support a Democrat would, he says confidently that for now he is keeping an eye on two other nationally prominent black Republicans, Colin Powell, the new secretary of state, and Condoleeza Rice, named by President Bush to be his national security adviser.
Mr. Soaries said he planned to spend the coming weeks putting together a proposal that would set up an organization to help guide members of minority groups who hoped to seek elective office. And he said he would "watch the political climate this year, see what happens, and see if I have any appetite for 2005."

Reginald T. Jackson
By virtue of his outspoken stand against the practice of racial profiling by the state police, Mr. Jackson has probably had more exposure on television in the past year than any other black leader. While he balked at the notion of seeking office -- "I'm more effective with the role I play now than if I were an elected official" -- Mr. Jackson dismissed those who said he would have to expand his one-issue platform to be considered a serious contender.
"If they're saying that, then they haven't been listening to me," he said. "I've spoken out on school funding, on health care, and education. There's no other organization in the state that has been a more important spokesperson group than the Black Ministers Council."

Wayne Bryant
One of the more powerful black legislators, Senator Bryant has both the advantage and disadvantage of coming out of Camden County. He has solid financial support from corporations and groups based in South Jersey, but being from the politically weaker end of the state, and from the state's poorest city, erodes his base of support. In addition, his strong ties to former Gov. Jim Florio -- who fared poorly in his primary bid against Mr. Corzine -- does not work in his favor.
Nevertheless, by sitting on key committees in his six years in the State Senate and 13 years in the Assembly, Mr. Bryant, 53, has established a good record as a lawmaker and a defender of civil rights.

Sharpe James
By most accounts, Mayor James is the most powerful black politician in the state. It was his endorsement of Mr. McGreevey that helped trigger Senator Robert Torricelli's withdrawal from this year's race for governor. That does not mean everyone likes him, particularly those who have run against him over the last 30 years in the rough-and-tumble environment of Newark politics.
While Newark provides the 64-year-old mayor with vast corporate contacts and fund-raising resources, Mr. James could run squarely into the bias of the suburban voter. 
In addition, high-ranking members of his administration have been investigated by the federal government, including his former chief of staff, Jackie Mattison, who was convicted in 1997 of bribing an insurance broker in exchange for city contracts, and the former police director, William Celester, who in 1996 was convicted of using $30,000 in police funds for vacations and personal gifts. While Mayor James was never charged, the baggage from these scandals may well be too heavy to carry into a statewide race.

Cory Booker
Nipping at Mayor James's heels is the 31-year-old Central Ward councilman who has everyone guessing what his next move might be. For his part, Mr. Booker says his primary interest is in Newark at this time.
"It's time for a change in the top position," he said, addingthat if he could play a role in bringing the city back, "that would be a career. I could walk away from politics after that."
As a Rhodes scholar who grew up in Bergen County's affluent Harrington Park and graduated from Stanford and Yale universities, political observers say Mr. Booker has great cross-over potential -- so much so that the first-term councilman says he has been approached by Republican leaders asking him to consider switching parties.
His own party named him one of the country's "100 Young Democrats" to watch during last summer's Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles. Yet others are suspicious of what they call his "Mr. Clean" image.
"I've never felt such a sense of efficacy in my life," Mr. Booker said in response to his detractors. "If I continue to feel that sense, I'm going to stay in it."

Donald Payne
The 66-year-old senior black statesman, Donald Payne, may be too old to consider a run for governor in 2005 or 2009, although he says he is in excellent health and has a lot of energy. For now, he is content to play a watchdog role in Congress, which he has been doing since he served as chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus in 1994 and fought conservative initiatives to reduce social service programs.
"With the new wave in Washington, there's going to be a lot of rolling up of the sleeves to prevent roll backs of the gains we've made," said Mr. Payne, whose brother and nephew both serve in the State Assembly.
As for the governorship, he says: "It's like a continuum. If you're engaged and involved and still committed to public service, you should not rule out any possibility of seeking higher office."

Shirley Turner
The one woman whose name came up on several lists, Senator Turner, has also demonstrated her cross-over appeal, having been elected in a district that includes both urban Trenton and wealthy Princeton and West Windsor. In addition to her four years in the Senate, she has served two terms in the Assembly and as a Mercer County freeholder.
Flattered by the suggestion of seeking the governorship, Senator Turner said she had not really given any thought to running for higher office. But she added: "When I was a freeholder, I never thought about running for Assembly, in the Assembly, I never thought about running for Senate. So based upon my track record, I couldn't rule anything out."

Joseph Charles
As head of the Legislative Black and Latino Caucus, State Assemblyman Joe Charles, 57, is well regarded by his colleagues and minority leaders throughout the state.
Mr. Charles, who is also a lawyer, predicted conservatively that it would take two more cycles before a black could be a viable candidate for governor -- one term for the Democrats to regain control, and another to build a base of support.
By that point, the Essex County assemblyman said he thought "it will be time for me to move over for someone else."

HEADLINE: Houses Are to Replace A Pittsburgh Slag Heap 

BYLINE:  By CHRISS SWANEY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH 

 BODY:
A ONETIME riverside slag dump where refuse from Pittsburgh's blast furnaces formed towers as high as 20-story buildings is being turned into the city's largest residential development since World War II. 
 Site clearance is under way for Summerset, a residential community intended to rejuvenate a former industrial dump along the Monongahela River into a community designed according to the tenets of the New Urbanism movement, with front porches, patches of green lawn and other touches of an old-fashioned neighborhood shared by people of many economic levels. 
 The $243 million project is to produce 713 homes and apartments on 240 acres in a section of the city's affluent East End and the infrastructure to support them. 
As in most Rust Belt cities, Pittsburgh's riverfront was once home to mills and warehouses. Now, more than $300 million in public and private money has been pumped into a half dozen projects to restore the old industrial riverfront. 
Stadiums for baseball and football are under construction near the city's downtown waterfront. They join other river-based entertainment venues including Sandcastle, a water-based amusement park that opened in 1989, and several new boat clubs featuring river sailing.
Summerset is one of the city's first major residential waterfront developments, and its backers say it has attracted extensive interest. Sally A. Pfaff, Summerset's project manager, said the developers plan to conduct a lottery to pick bidders for the lots.
"People are fascinated by the New Urbanism," Ms. Pfaff said. "The chance to have porches, garages off an alley and a real pedestrian community has given us a waiting list of 500." 
THE development, which is near Beechwood Boulevard, a major street, and which provides direct access to Frick Park, one of the city's oldest attractions, is designed to have the look and feel of an old-fashioned city neighborhood.
Vince Sacca, a metals broker who is on the waiting list for a house in the project, said that for him Summerset's attractions include the project's design and the views of the water and the adjacent park, as well as its proximity to upscale restaurants and recreation.
"I want to live in a home that has all the modern amenities but has a traditional feel to it," he said.
Mark Jones, the architect in charge of the Summerset project for the Memphis firm of Looney Ricks Kiss, said the ideas summed up in the phrase New Urbanism were "spreading like wildfire." Mr. Jones said that homebuyers are looking for communities where they can walk to the grocery store or the neighborhood playground. "We have purposely put the garage behind the homes and created the old neighborhood alley, so people have room to interact from their porches and front yards," he said.
The riverfront site has played several roles. At the turn of the century, the property was used as a golf course. Frederick Law Olmsted Jr., whose father helped plan Central Park in New York City as well as Golden Gate Park in San Francisco, wanted the site to be set aside as a park. But the golf course was eventually razed. 
Between 1922 and 1972, more than 20 million tons of slag were dumped at the site by local steel producers. Looking like a desolate moonscape, the old industrial slag heap had been home to a flock of migratory birds and a few stray dogs until the city's Urban Redevelopment Authority purchased the 243 acres in December 1995 from the Duquesne Slag Company, which had used it to dispose of the residue of steel manufacturing, for $3.8 million in the hope of developing the property. 
A combination of public and private financing is helping to clean up a polluted stream running through the development. The watershed cleanup will also add 130 acres to the 455-acre Frick Park, named for Henry Clay Frick, whose stockpiles of coke helped the industrialist Andrew Carnegie turn Pittsburgh into a major steel producer.
The new community will include single-family homes, attached town houses and apartments, with prices ranging from $180,000 for two and a half story cottage-style homes with two or three bedrooms to $375,000 and up for 4,500-square-foot houses with four or five bedrooms, according to Mark Schneider, president of the Rubinoff Company, the lead developer. 
More than 122,000 tons of soil have been dumped on the site so far as part of the process of making it suitable for housing, and by the end of the decade a total of 203,000 tons of topsoil will be needed to cover all the slag. 
Several community groups had voiced concern about the amount of dust created from grading the old slag site, so air-monitoring equipment was mounted on a hill overlooking the project. 
Summerset is less than 15 minutes from the medical complexes and cultural district in the city's Oakland section, 10 minutes from the upscale Squirrel Hill shopping district and a 15-minute drive by expressway to downtown.
IT is expected to add $3.4 million annually in property and wage taxes to the city. The National City Bank of Pennsylvania will provide the construction loans.
This is the second major riverfront property developed by Rubinoff, which is based in Pittsburgh. In 1987, the company started construction on the long-neglected, 42-acre Herr's Island, which had been the site of slaughterhouses, a scrap yard and a company that refurbished old railroad cars. The island is now home to several commercial buildings, residential housing and a handful of technology incubator firms.
Construction at Summerset is scheduled to begin in February with the building of six model homes. It is to be completed in three phases over the next 10 years. The first segment, estimated to cost $42 million, includes construction of 72 single-family homes; 41 town houses; a two-story 48-apartment rental building; and 40 two-story rental town houses.
The second phase, estimated to cost about $73 million, is to include 139 single-family homes, 49 town houses and a two-story, 104-apartment rental building, while the final phase, at a cost of $63 million, includes 125 single-family homes, 28 town houses and 64 apartment units in a two-story building. 
Each of the homes will have a two-car garage, fireplace, landscaped yard and wiring for Internet connections. 
The city's Urban Redevelopment Authority received $7.5 million from the state, $7.1 million from the city and $360,000 from the Environmental Protection Agency for sewer and road work and the planting of grass. The restoration of the polluted stream running through the project is being supported by $5 million from the Army Corps of Engineers and $2.7 million from the city.
Summerset's development partners include Rubinoff, Montgomery Rust of Pittsburgh and JR Glunt of Pittsburgh, which are building the village homes, town houses and estate houses; Pennrose Properties of Philadelphia, and Pittsburgh-based Ralph Falbo, producing the multifamily units; and EQA Landmark Communities and Kacin Builders, constructing the cottage houses. 
The city still owns the land and will receive a portion of the sales price when each home is sold. For the first phase the city expects to receive $1.6 million, and for the whole development it expects to receive more than $21 million in the next 10 years or so.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Drilling has begun, below, for a retaining wall for the main entry road for the first phase of Summerset, which is to be built on 243 acres along the Monongahela River. (Photographs by Kristin Petersen for The New York Times) Map of Pennsylvania highlights Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
Seeking a Common Rule Book for International Mergers

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
IMAGINE two giant corporations merging their businesses, from corporate headquarters in New York and London to far-flung divisions across the globe. The deal is done. The headlines sound their clarions. The chief executives announce the winner's prize (the executive suite) for one and the loser's (stock options) for the other.
 What comes next is the part most dreaded by the partners in some megamergers: scrutiny by antitrust regulators, supposedly to guarantee that newly created behemoths -- like AOL Time Warner, which faced regulatory objections in Europe and the United States -- do not threaten consumers by dominating markets. 
 That scrutiny, according to an increasing number of corporate officials, lawyers and regulators, means growing thickets of obstacles to the current surge of mergers and acquisitions.
In the decade since capitalism's triumph over the Soviet empire, the corporate rush to ever greater economies of scale has been accompanied -- though with much less fanfare -- by a proliferation in the number of jurisdictions with competition laws, supposedly to ensure that mergers do not create corporate monsters accountable to no one. So corporate lawyers now confront a litany of regulatory requirements.
J. William Rowley, chairman of the International Bar Association's Global Forum for Competition Policy, says the number of regulatory agencies worldwide that must sanctify mergers has mushroomed. "This is the antitrust explosion," he said. "We have probably got over 80 antitrust regimes in the world and another two dozen in the making. Ten years ago, we would have had six or seven."
In one deal alone in 1999, Mr. Rowley said, lawyers from the Coca-Cola Company and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. sought antitrust approval in more than 40 jurisdictions around the world. In another -- the ultimately failed effort to merge Alcan Aluminum of Canada, Pechiney of France and Algroup of Switzerland into an aluminum giant -- lawyers from 35 firms filed for regulatory approval in 16 jurisdictions and 8 languages, he said. And in each jurisdiction, corporations faced costs that included wildly varying filing fees paid to regulators and lawyers.
In Austria, the filing fee for regulatory approval of a merger can be as little as $77. In the United States it is $45,000. In Croatia, it is $140,000.
Next weekend, though, regulators, legal experts, business representatives and government officials will try to take a first step in what is expected to be a difficult route toward a standardized global antitrust review process.
Meeting under the auspices of the International Bar Association, based in London, the participants will include important officials like Mario Monti, the European Commission's competition commissioner. The conference will be held in an 18th-century manor house with 42 bedrooms at Ditchley Park, near Oxford.
It is unclear who will represent the United States, where the new Bush administration has yet to clarify its antitrust policy or indicate how it might differ from that of the Clinton administration. For that reason, the timing of the conference has already provoked something of a trans-Atlantic spat.
But Mr. Rowley said, "the reason you ought not to wait is that this is an initiative that has been a long time coming." The organizers, he added, thought that any delay would have been a setback to a process that had been gathering steam since last September, when Joel I. Klein, the former United States Justice Department official in charge of antitrust enforcement, announced a shift in American policy.
Previously, the United States had rejected the idea of trying to reach an international consensus on competition law. But Mr. Klein promised broad backing for an approach to draft international standards. That shift surprised and encouraged European regulators, who had been pressing for a similar approach for years. How the Bush administration views the issue remains to be seen.
"There have been a lot of people asking questions about the direction of antitrust under the new administration," said Eric London, a spokesman for the Federal Trade Commission in Washington. But until the decision-making officials are appointed in the Justice Department and the commission itself, he said, "there's not a lot to go on."
For Europe, of course, a common competition law is a necessity, in part because the 15-nation European Union plans to expand to as many as 25 nations, creating a huge market that is supposed to encourage competition. Mr. Monti, who has a reputation as a tough enforcer of antitrust regulations, has made clear that he will not allow big companies to hamper new competitors as the European Union expands.
In the United States too, corporations and regulators have been pushing for some standardization of the confusing patchwork of merger regulations across the globe. In several countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Turkey and Russia, the notification rules are based on the global revenue of the companies in the merger. The thresholds can vary from a paltry $300,000 in Russia to $2.5 billion in Argentina, according to the International Bar Association.
The Ditchley Park conference has set only modest aims. No one on either side of the Atlantic is talking about a new international bureaucracy to oversee mergers -- an idea that the United States has rejected. In the past, the United States has also opposed a European proposal to give the World Trade Organization a central role in policing mergers.
Rather, according to Clinton administration thinking, the idea is to simplify competition laws and, in the words of one official last year, create a consensus among regulators to make "antitrust enforcement coherent and predictable."
Mr. Rowley said that at the conference next week, "we should make progress in defining objectives."

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS; 
Far-Flung Inspirations For Itinerant Gardeners

BYLINE:  By ANNE RAVER 

 BODY:
JANUARY is almost over, and those seed catalogs are piling up. Have you pruned the grapevines yet? Ordered those fruit trees and asparagus roots? Built the new fence for the vegetable garden?
 Whoa. Take a deep breath. Before the avalanche starts, why not map out a little vacation for yourself, to get you away from your own garden for a while this year and to nurture your gardener's soul? Here are some good destinations. 
 Desert in Bloom: The Arizona-Sonoran Desert Museum in Tucson, reports that wildflowers are blooming early this year, thanks to October rains and a warm fall that helped seeds germinate. Poppies have been sighted at Picacho Peak, 40 miles north of Tucson; lupines along the hillsides; penstemons in the washes. Peak bloom, if there is one, is expected from mid- or late February to early March. Wildflower updates are at (520) 883-1380.
Cool Gardening: Northwest Flower and Garden Show, Feb. 7 to 11, Seattle. Gardens and plants that thrive in the cool rain. Lectures by the English garden designer David Stevens; Kathleen Brenzel of Sunset Magazine; Christopher Woods, the executive director of Chanticleer, a public garden in Wayne, Pa.; Daniel Hinkley of Heronswood Nursery in Kingston, Wash.; and Ann Lovejoy, on sustainable natural gardens. Information: info@gardenshow.com or (800) 229-6311.
