HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS; 
Slowing Business Travel Means Savings for Tourists

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
JANE ISTVAN will soon make her annual winter journey to Miami Beach to visit her grandmother. But this year's trip will come with a bonus: significant savings on hotel expenses. 
 Ms. Istvan, 34, a lawyer from Philadelphia, along with her husband, Jeffrey, 33, also a lawyer, and their 2-year-old son, Sam, will spend six nights in March in a two-room suite at a Hilton Grand Vacations beachfront resort in South Beach. Their room rate is $150 a night, a bargain for Florida's peak travel season. Last year, she and her family paid $20 less a night, but for a much smaller room at a hotel with fewer amenities and blocks away from the beach. 
 To get the suite, Ms. Istvan turned to Quikbook.com, a hotel consolidator. Consolidators obtain blocks of rooms that hotels are unable to fill and sell them at discounts, usually 25 to 60 percent off published room rates, to individuals or travel agents. 
Had she booked directly with the Hilton resort, she would have paid $350 a night.
Other leisure travelers may find similar bargains this winter and spring as a softening in business travel adds to the inventory of vacant hotel rooms for consolidators and discount travel companies to sell. A slowing economy and continued increases in business air fares are causing many large companies to curtail travel plans this year. 
Sean Hennessey, director of the hospitality and leisure practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers, predicted that 4.3 million rooms that hotels previously would have reserved this year for business travelers would go instead to convention visitors or leisure travelers; that figure represents 3 percent of total hotel room inventory in the United States. Among the cities where he expects to find weakness are New Orleans, Dallas, Denver, St. Louis, Phoenix, Atlanta, Seattle, Philadelphia and Orlando, Fla.
Survey results released last week by the National Business Travel Association appear to bear out some of Mr. Hennessey's forecasts. It found that 61 percent of Fortune 1000 companies planned to eliminate all but the most essential travel, while 57 percent said they would reduce the number of employees per trip, and 46 percent reported cutting back on business meetings that required travel.
"There's no question companies are asking people to think twice before they take trips," said Henry Harteveldt, who oversees the travel practice of Forrester Research, an Internet consulting firm.
Although Mr. Harteveldt said he thought the trade group's survey painted an overly bleak picture, he predicted that business travel could fall significantly if the economy continued to weaken. If economic growth slowed to a rate of 2 to 3 percent, down from about 4.5 percent last year, he said, business travel would decline 5 to 10 percent. But in the event of a recession -- a decline in the economy for two consecutive quarters -- the falloff in business travel would be 10 percent to 20 percent, he added.
There are already signs of softening -- as Ms. Istvan has discovered. Several hotel consolidators, like Quikbook of New York, and Hotel Reservations Network of Dallas, and travel discounters like Priceline.com, say they are receiving a higher-than-usual number of rooms in major cities, which could mean more bargains for vacationers. "Corporate travelers have a short booking horizon, so any rooms they cancel must go to channels of distribution that are fast," Mr. Hennessey explained.
Bob Diener, the president of Hotel Reservations Network, said he had seen "a huge number of hotels lower rates and increase blocks of rooms in the last four weeks." At his network, which offers rooms at 2,500 hotels in 105 cities, the deals are showing up most often in New York, San Francisco, Chicago, Orlando, New Orleans and Washington, with rates dropping $5 to $40 a night, he said.
Quikbook, which represents about 400 hotels in over 30 cities, has seen an increase in available rooms in New York, San Francisco, Chicago, Los Angeles, Boston, Miami and Seattle, according to Raymond Vastola, the company's president. At the hotels' request, he said, the rooms are being offered at rates $10 to $35 less than usual for this time of year. And the discounts are for longer periods -- 60 to 90 days in the future, rather than the usual 30- to 60-day advance booking period, he added.
FOR Priceline.com customers, who list the price they will pay for rooms, then learn if their bids are accepted, the bidding success rate for rooms in New York "is double what it was a couple of months ago," said Christopher Soder, Priceline's president for hotels. Customers bidding for rooms in Orlando, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Atlanta are also finding "a very high success rate," he added. Priceline offers rooms at more than 6,000 hotels in 1,300 cities in North America.
Mr. Diener of Hotel Reservations Network said he thought 2001 would be "a soft year for hotels -- not terrible but not as good as it's been the last couple of years."
"This will translate into great bargains for consumers," he added. "If you're flexible, you'll probably find a bigger selection of deals this year than last."
Most online hotel consolidator and discount travel sites require customers to list their destination cities, travel dates and the range of rates they are willing to pay. The Web sites then search for lists of appropriate hotels. But some sites, like Priceline.com and Hotwire.com, do not reveal the names of hotels before they are booked. Priceline also requires travelers to pay whatever rate they propose, though Hotwire lets customers reject rates they consider undesirable.
Other rules may apply. Hotel Reservations Network requires full payment in advance for its rooms and charges a $50 fee to change or cancel a reservation; similar fees for changes or cancellations are sometimes imposed by other consolidators or by the hotels they represent. 
And, sometimes, the best rates are still available directly from a hotel, not from a discounter site. The lesson, of course, is to shop around.
David Goldstone, 32, a business executive from Orlando, did some shopping before settling on Travelocity, an online travel agent that obtains its discounted hotel rooms from Hotel Reservations Network. Over the last three years, he has booked 50 business and pleasure trips through Travelocity, including several vacations with his wife, Juli, 37, and 2-year-old son, Max. 
His next trip will be a three-night visit to Las Vegas in mid-March to attend a convention and to visit with several college friends. He found a $100-a-night rate at the Las Vegas Hilton through Travelocity. If he had made reservations directly through the hotel, the total rate would have been $477 for the three nights.
Jaci Maher, 37, who owns a print shop in Pittsburgh, recently used Quikbook to reserve a six-night stay early next month at the Doubletree Guest Suites at Walt Disney World. She and her husband, Larry, 36, an engineer, and their three young children will stay in a one-bedroom suite at $135 a night for the first three nights and $165 for the last three. The room normally goes for $179 a night. "I'm probably staying at a nicer hotel than I would have -- right in Disney World," Mrs. Maher said.
How long such deals will last will depend primarily on the health of the overall economy, industry experts say. Mr. Hennessey, for one, expects that hotel bargains will be offered online at least "through the start of the summer." 
"What happens in the first quarter of the year will establish whether these favorable opportunities continue," he said.
That is good news for Ms. Istvan, who is also thinking about an overnight excursion to New York. As for the Miami Beach trip, she said, the savings on accommodations will let the family splurge on other things, like an extra stone-crab dinner. And the larger room will provide more privacy.
"My husband and I will be happy not to have to whisper to each other for two hours when we put the baby to sleep at night."

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 

BYLINE:  By ANDREA DELBANCO

 BODY:
LOWER MANHATTAN
The Mighty Hudson, In Words and Images
 Douglas Lazarus traveled the length of the Hudson River by boat and painted 68 watercolors of the scenes he saw, towns and villages of the Hudson Valley, and vignettes of New York City and its harbor. Mr. Lazarus compiled his images into a book, "Hudson River Journey: An Artist's Perspective," with text by Alan McKibben. The book was inspired by "Panorama of the Hudson," which the artist and writer William Wade had originally published in 1846 as a 12-foot scroll that documented the length of the river. 
 A copy of William Wade's book and Mr. Lazarus's paintings are on display in an exhibit also titled "Hudson River Journey: An Artist's Perspective" at the Port Life Gallery of the South Street Seaport Museum.
"Hudson River Journey" through June 30, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., closed Tuesdays; Port Life Gallery, 209 Water Street, between Fulton and Beekman Streets; $5; (212) 748-8600.

WASHINGTON SQUARE
The Enduring Legacy Of Louis Armstrong
Each Monday in February the Gallatin School at New York University is presenting an event focusing on Louis Armstrong; sometimes two events, as is the case tomorrow. 
"Show Me the Money: Race, Political Economics and the Music Biz" is a round-table discussion about the economic impact of black music. The discussion moves from the 1920's to today's hip-hop, and panelists include Yvonne Bynoe, an entertainment lawyer and co-founder and president of Urban Think Tank, and Norman Kelly, author of the novel "Black Heat."
The moderator will be David Earl Jackson, a journalist and founder of the International Institute for Black Music Studies. The discussion will be followed by a concert titled "West End Blues: Louis Armstrong," performed by Andre De Shields, who is pictured at left as Louis Armstrong. 
"Ambassador Satch: A Centennial Tribute to Louis Armstrong" tomorrow 4 to 6 p.m. panel event, 7:30 p.m. performance; both in Vanderbilt Hall, 40 Washington Square South; free; (212) 998-9163.

Twenty-three members of the New York Film Critics Circle will introduce movies that have changed their lives personally and professionally in a series titled "Critical Passions," which begins Saturday at the American Museum of the Moving Image.
The 23 screenings will be shown over a month. This is the second series of this kind. Last year's focused on films from the 1990's.
Participants include Amy Taubin of The Village Voice and Leah Rozen of People. 
The eclectic group of films includes works by directors like Robert Altman, Michael Mann, Orson Welles and Jean Renoir.
"Critical Passions: Movies Selected by the New York Film Critics Circle" Saturday, screenings at 2 and 4:30 p.m.; weekends through March 4; American Museum of the Moving Image, 36-01 35th Avenue, Astoria; screening included with museum admission: adults $8.50, $5.50 for students and people over 65, $4.50 for children 5 to 18, under 4 free; (718) 784-0077.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Eroding Paper Gains May Undo a Remarkable Resiliency

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
STOCK market investors endured considerable pain last year, and for the most part, they took it with aplomb. As stock prices sank, nobody seemed to panic -- or to riot in the streets. Even when they saw their losses in black and white in year-end statements from brokerage firms and mutual funds, investors kept their cool.
 An impressive performance, given that from the stock market's peak last March to its trough in December, an estimated $3 trillion in market value vanished from sight. 
 Had investors panicked in the face of such losses, the broad market indexes would be in far worse shape in 2001 than they are. At the close of last week, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 2.6 percent for the year, while the Nasdaq composite had a gain of 12.6 percent. Only the Dow Jones industrials showed a loss, of 1.2 percent. 
Fathoming how investors will react to falling share prices has become an important study among economists and strategists. After all, the rising stock market and the wealth it brought to consumers did a lot to fuel the economy in recent years. Flush with their stock gains, at least on paper, Americans bought second homes and luxury cars and vacationed with a vengeance. If those gains disappear, some economists fear that sobered consumers will push an already slowing economy into recession. 
So it was a great relief to many people that the market stabilized in January. One of the biggest reasons it did, of course, was Alan Greenspan's surprise move to cut interest rates by one-half of a percentage point on Jan. 3. And most economists believe that rates will be slashed again when the Federal Reserve Board meets on Tuesday and Wednesday. 
Jim Bianco, president of Bianco Research in Barrington, Ill., contends that the early-January decision was made in part to forestall an investor panic in the stock market, especially in Nasdaq stocks. But Mr. Bianco, in a report written for the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis, argues that investors are not likely to abandon the stock market en masse until most of their unrealized profits disappear. Only then will they jump ship, causing the reverse wealth effect to harm the economy.
To try to measure where individual investors stand with their portfolios, Mr. Bianco has compiled an index of the stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average and the Russell 2000, all weighted equally. This combination, which he has tracked since 1990, best reflects the holdings in equity mutual funds, he said. Then he estimates the average cost of investors' domestic mutual fund purchases by analyzing equity fund inflows.
"Since 1990, the public has put about $1.4 trillion into the stock market, and they have about $1.88 trillion of market value," Mr. Bianco said. The difference between those numbers -- approximately $470 billion as of the end of November -- is their unrealized gain.
Investors view their unrealized profits as gamblers do their casino winnings: it is the house's money at stake.
"You don't treat it with the care and love that you do with your hard-earned paycheck," Mr. Bianco said. 
But the minute that those winnings disappear, all bets are off.
Mr. Bianco saw such a shift in investor psychology some years ago, in bond funds. Investors in those funds reached the break-even point in April 1994 and they promptly began exiting the arena. For the next year, bond funds saw nothing but outflows, on a monthly basis.
Although investors' unrealized profits have fallen by $285 billion, or 38 percent, since they peaked in December 1999 -- Mr. Bianco said that because investors still had $470 billion in house money to play with, they would remain bullish on stocks. 
"My argument is the reverse wealth effect will hit with a vengeance when we get to the break-even point in stock market gains," he said. "Only then will people become disillusioned with the stock market and not jump back in."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Wealth Effect"Graph tracks the average mutual fund gain and average investor costs from 1995 to 2000.(Source: The Leuthold Group)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Tale Of2 Totals In the Jobs Report

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
IT is the case of the missing four million jobs.
 When the Labor Department releases its monthly employment report on Friday, it will show that private employers in the United States have added about 21 million jobs to their payrolls over the last decade. The same report will also show that the employers have added fewer than 17 million jobs to their payrolls over the last decade. 
 Confused? You should be.
The Labor Department's jobs report, which can move markets and dominate business news once every month, is in fact two reports. One comes from a survey of 350,000 businesses that provides data on hours worked and employment by sector. The other comes from a survey of 50,000 households that produces the unemployment rate. Each survey gives the government an estimate of the total number of jobs in the American economy. 
All of this would seem like technical detail best left for doctoral students in economics -- if it were not for the discomforting fact that the two surveys have been telling quite different stories for the last decade. The business survey has offered a far more optimistic picture, suggesting that the private work force has grown by an impressive 22.8 percent. The household survey says employers have increased their payrolls 18.5 percent -- the worst such gain since the 1950's. The difference is those four million jobs that exist only in the business survey.
To be fair, there has always been some gap between the studies. People who work two jobs, for example, show up twice in the business survey and only once in the household survey. But the current difference between the studies is unprecedented.
Until the early 1990's, the gap remained between one million and four million. Add that to the mysterious growth of the gap in the 1990's, and the total difference today rises to just a hair under eight million. This growth, Chinhui Juhn and Simon Potter wrote in a report published in late 1999 by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, "has puzzled many analysts."
It might never have been as troublesome, however, as it is now. From Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, to individual home buyers and investors, Americans are closely watching the economy these days to see whether a recession, or simply a slowdown, is arriving. Yet one of the most-watched reports issued by the government has a basic flaw. 
The deeper one digs, the more inconsistencies arise. The business survey says contingent work, like temporary staffing, has taken off in recent years. The household survey says it has barely budged.
Which survey is more credible? 
Labor Department officials tried to answer the question by looking at the most likely suspects for the gap's cause. The officials studied whether more people held two jobs today than in the past or whether more teenagers under 16, who are not counted in the household survey, now work. They asked whether the surveyed households were concentrated in slow-growing regions.
"There was no smoking gun," said Thomas L. Nardone, who oversees the household survey.
The most popular theory, offered in the paper written by Ms. Juhn and Mr. Potter, is that the Census Bureau's estimate of the nation's population is too low. That would mean that even if the household survey accurately estimated the portion of Americans who were working, the Labor Department was not multiplying that percentage by a large-enough number. When the government finishes work on the 2000 Census, the answer should be clearer.
Of course, this theory supports the business survey and its more optimistic view. Because the business poll covers so many more jobs -- tens of millions versus 100,000 -- most analysts consider it more reliable, Mr. Nardone said, even if they cannot explain the gap.
But the matter should not be dismissed simply by throwing out the household survey. (And if it could be, people should reject the unemployment rate as inaccurate, too.) The business survey has its weaknesses. 
To account for start-ups, the Labor Department now adds 165,000 jobs each month that do not actually turn up in its survey. Based on historical data, researchers figure that this is the number of jobs they are missing. But the economy has been slowing sharply, and the number -- twice what it was in 1993 -- could now be exaggerated.
Executives are also more likely than household heads to err by counting some workers twice. That happened once in the early 1990's, forcing the government to make an embarrassing revision.
It is enough to make most people throw up their hands. The better solution is to look at both reports with a skeptical eye -- until somebody can solve the mystery.

GRAPHIC: Chart: The Labor Department surveys businesses and households separately. Here is the gap in their estimates to total jobs. Chart tracks the total jobs in millions from 1950 to 2000.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
California Still Stands, Despite One More Punch

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
BASED on all the hoo-ha, one may think that the shocks from California's power crisis will soon loose the state from the North American land mass. The stock market is telling a different story.
 Since Dec. 21, when it hit a six-month low, the Bloomberg California Index, comprising 594 companies based in the Golden State, is up nearly 14 percent. 
 Power failures are clearly annoying. But the state, which is the world's sixth-largest economy, has faced much bigger challenges. It is not nice to have the lights go out in the office, but most public California companies are not parochial operations. 
Conrad Herrmann, manager of the $2.8 billion Franklin Templeton California Growth fund, took time last week to talk about the power crisis and California stocks. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Lots of people are wringing their hands over the California power situation. How serious is it?

A. There is reason to be concerned, and there have been disruptions. But most of the disruptive effects will be felt by smaller companies, and we are not invested in those.
The power crisis is the latest punch the state has had to take. Last year, we had to deal with the dot-com implosion. 
By comparison, when we launched the fund in 1991, California was suffering its worst recession in years: the defense sector was downsizing; the savings-and-loan crisis was at its peak. California had lost its luster. But the state continually reinvents itself.

Q. As a portfolio manager, isn't one of your goals to find companies that are not heavily dependent on continued good times in the local economy?

A. We try to avoid companies that are vulnerable to a downturn in the California economy.
There are 850,000 incorporated businesses in California, of which about 1,400 are publicly traded. But we winnow that down to some 800-odd names. 
Right now, we have about 150 companies in the portfolio. Of that, only about six or seven are located outside the borders of California.
Some of the companies we invest in, like Intel, Cisco and Flextronics International, are very globally oriented. Others are big domestic players, like Safeway or Tenet Healthcare. 
And we make investments in companies that might benefit from the power crisis, like Calpine, an independent power producer, and Capstone Turbine, a smaller-capitalization company which is focused on utilizing a cleaner way to produce energy.

Q. Your fund's share price hit a six-month low on Jan. 8. Since then it is up about 12 percent. What has been going on?

A. Well, we have seen a nice bounce in the Nasdaq recently. And I think the market is looking ahead and realizes that these companies are not just California-focused. They march to their own drummer.

Q. Equity mutual funds that focus on one state are rare. What was the thinking behind creating this fund?

A. We wanted to take advantage of our resources as a large, West Coast-based money manager. And it is an asset to be close to your investments.
In addition, the California economy has traditionally grown at a faster pace than the country as a whole. 
And there are some underpinnings in California that make for good investments. One is the state's higher education system, which generates a great deal of brain power.
The second is Silicon Valley. Twenty-one percent of the nation's research-and-development dollars are spent in California. 
The third is the venture capital industry. About 40 percent of the venture capital money raised in the country is flowing into California-based companies. 

Q. You said that not all of your investments are in California-based companies. What are some of your out-of-state holdings?

A. We own Expeditors International, a freight-hauling and logistics company based in Washington State that benefits from a lot of traffic to and from California. Another example is Costco.

Q. Applied Micro Circuits and Veritas Software, two technology companies, are the biggest and fourth-biggest holdings in the fund, respectively. Both stocks are well down from their 52-week highs. Have you been adding to your positions?

A. We have not been adding to either position.
We have added to our holdings outside of technology. We have bought some Univision and added to some biotechnology holdings like Genentech and Amgen. We are quite optimistic about biotechnology. 
And we have been adding to positions in down-and-out firms like Mattel.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
A Fight for Survival in the Broadband Wreckage

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SANTIAGO 

 BODY:
UP to its knees in uncollected bills from customers that resell its high-speed Internet connections, suffering from a battered stock price, relying on competitors to deliver its product and caught in a severe market downturn, Covad Communications may be facing a technology-sector version of the perfect storm.
 The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has become a case study in the tumultuous history of the market for broadband Internet access, a market spawned by the 1996 Telecommunications Act. 
 The law was intended to promote competition, and Covad and other start-ups raced in on its heels to offer faster and higher-capacity access as an alternative to the dribble of data allowed by standard modems. Covad and its rivals began aggressively selling digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., connections to Internet service providers, which in turn resell them to businesses and residential consumers.
But in October, 19 of its 250 customers defaulted on payments to the company. Some, like Flashcom Communications, Zyan Communications and Relay Point, filed for bankruptcy. Of the 274,000 D.S.L. lines that Covad installed that quarter, 92,000 were not paid for, and the shortfall spun Covad into crisis. 
Consumer demand for broadband is huge, of course, and will remain so for the industry's survivors. Analysts, investors and entrepreneurs agree on that. The question is whether Covad will be among those survivors. It clearly hopes so.
"I think the market overreacted," Chuck McMinn, Covad's chairman, said of the trouncing that Covad, a leader in the wholesale broadband market, took on Wall Street.
When the company missed third-quarter revenue projections last year by $21.8 million, or nearly 30 percent, its stock plummeted to just over $1 a share, from a high of $66 in March. On Friday, it closed at $3.72. 
And investors did not see it as an isolated case, giving a cold shoulder to its rivals as well. "I think they threw the baby out with the bath water, putting all the companies in the same bucket," Mr. McMinn said.
His company, he said, was and is on more solid ground than its precarious competitors or its insolvent customers.
Still, Covad, which has yet to make a profit, responded swiftly. It laid off 800 employees, one-quarter of its work force, and scrubbed plans to open an operations center in Alpharetta, Ga. Robert Knowling, its chief executive and former chairman, resigned, and the chief executive's post went to Frank Marshall, previously a general manager at Cisco Systems.
Mr. McMinn, one of three Covad founders and its first chief executive, left a year ago to found Certive, a company offering management services over broadband connections, but returned to Covad in November. "The layoffs and other steps were taken in reaction to the market's change in focus," he said. "At the end of 2000, the market decided it cared only about profitability. Any company that was not already profitable, they got very worried about."
By slashing operating costs and slowing capital spending, Mr. McMinn expects Covad to see profits by the end of next year. Analysts, while uncertain about Covad's future, say its greatest advantage is a cash reserve of more than $800 million.
"With a company in bad times, if you have enough cash to weather it out, and your competition doesn't, at the end of the day there are fewer people competing for a slice of the pie," said Clay Ryder, chief analyst at Zona Research in Redwood City, Calif. "And therefore there's more left for you. The question is: Can they survive on the resources they have to ultimately thrive at a later date?"
On Jan. 16, NorthPoint Communications, another D.S.L. wholesaler, gave up its piece of the pie and filed for bankruptcy after a merger with Verizon Communications fell through. The same day, Rhythms NetConnections, an Englewood, Colo., D.S.L. company, said it was cutting 450 jobs, 23 percent of its work force.
At the beginning, the future of D.S.L. looked not just rosy, but irresistible. D.S.L. connections promised speeds up to 50 times as fast as conventional modems. And because the service was always on, there were no more busy signals or waits for a connection.
Still, only 5 percent of Internet users now have broadband, by some estimates. Jupiter Media Metrix, a research firm, predicts that there will be 11.5 million D.S.L. users by 2005, up from 1.2 million last year.
"The economics of our business were so compelling," Mr. McMinn recalled, "that for a time the financial markets were willing to fund a parallel rollout of our services in 112 different metropolitan areas."
Building a D.S.L. network from scratch was considered unrealistic because it required an astronomical investment before ever selling a single subscription. But the Telecommunications Act required local phone companies to lease their existing infrastructure -- copper wire networks and switching control centers -- to competitors. In exchange, local companies that played by the new rules would be permitted by the Federal Communications Commission to enter the long-distance market.
ALTHOUGH it set off a gold rush, the convoluted arrangement had built-in problems, creating immediate nightmares for customers and, eventually, havoc for wholesalers.
For example, a customer who wants D.S.L. may call an Internet service provider, or I.S.P. The provider may then call Covad, which in turn passes the order along to the phone company leasing the wires.
"At every point there's the possibility that the information will lose a critical detail," explained Justin Beech, an analyst at DSL Reports in New York. "A misspelling of a street will cause the phone company to reject the order, and it has to go all the way back to the customer for a correction. Now you call up the phone company and say, 'What's the problem here?' And they say, 'You're not our customer; you have to talk with Covad.' And Covad says you have to talk to the I.S.P., and then the I.S.P. isn't picking up because they're concentrating on selling."
As a result, customers ordering D.S.L. through that chain of middlemen can sometimes wait months for a connection. The very phone companies leasing the wires, meanwhile, also sell D.S.L. service directly.
"Part of the problem is that the incumbent phone companies, like Pac Bell, didn't really want to sell that circuit to Covad and then Covad sells it to you. They'd rather just sell it right to you," said Mr. Ryder, the analyst. So D.S.L. companies are often at the mercy of competitors for delivering their service. This, some D.S.L. wholesalers have contended, leads phone companies to give their own customers priority for installation over leased connections.
Despite the incentive of gaining entry into long distance, many local companies are understandably reluctant to make things too easy for D.S.L. wholesalers vying for the same customers, experts say.
Even if there is no such prioritizing of installations by phone companies, "the most difficult part of this business is getting them to be a quality supplier that delivers on time," Mr. McMinn conceded.
On the other hand, he points to a recent deal with SBC Communications, which chose to regard Covad as a partner rather than as a competitor. "They have committed to buying $600 million worth of D.S.L. from Covad for their customers, and to make a $150 million equity investment in Covad," he said.
That big players like SBC have been sought as saviors by bruised D.S.L. contenders is a sign, some experts say, that the local phone companies will eventually own the D.S.L. market. In addition to deeper pockets, they enjoy the advantage of established brands.
"You've never heard of Covad, right?" said Jerry Grasso, spokesman for Epoch Internet, a service provider based in Costa Mesa, Calif. "You hear of companies like Pac Bell. Pac Bell is on the radio, on TV, in the paper. The amount of marketing money you have to spend on getting each new customer, it's almost more expensive than what the customers can bring in by signing up."
Add the competition posed by cable and wireless broadband, and many experts say suppliers will be forced into a major consolidation. "I think what you are going to see is a lot of companies ripe for acquisition," Mr. Grasso said.

LENGTH: 3797 words

HEADLINE: Think Nasdaq. Now Double the Pain. 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: MILAN 

 BODY:
EVEN amid the intoxication that surrounded Internet start-ups early last year, Silvio Scaglia's experience was an eye-opener.
 As co-founder and chief executive of E.biscom, Mr. Scaglia had little more than a good reputation and a bold plan. Working in offices about a block away from the Teatro alla Scala, he proposed building fiber optic networks in Italy's biggest cities that would reach directly into homes and businesses. 
 E.biscom had no network, no sales and no expectation of turning a profit for at least three years. Yet in March, the company raised $1.5 billion in fresh cash. 
It did so by going public here on the Nuovo Mercato, a fledgling stock exchange for new companies that was less than a year old at the time. Most Italians had never invested in stocks, let alone in little-known start-ups. But mesmerized by the rise of American companies like Yahoo and Cisco Systems, they oversubscribed E.biscom's huge offering by 26-fold.
Today, investors are far less euphoric. Mirroring the panicky crash of American technology stocks traded on the Nasdaq market, shares of E.biscom now trade 25 percent below their offering price.
"In March 2000, we were swimming with the tide, and everything seemed extremely easy," Mr. Scaglia said. "Today we are swimming against the tide."
In truth, it is a bit more like a riptide. After decades of paying little heed to entrepreneurs and new companies, European investors and financial institutions embraced American-style start-up capitalism in the last three years as zealously as converts to a new religion.
Now they are trying to decide if they got to the temple too late or whether it was all a false credo. The Nuovo Mercato and the Frankfurt Neuer Markt have plunged about 70 percent from their peaks last spring, and the Nouveau Marche in Paris is down 60 percent. In Madrid, Amsterdam and Brussels, smaller "new markets" have also withered.
American investors have been there, too, of course. The Nasdaq has lost almost 50 percent in the last year, though it has rebounded a bit recently. But European investors -- individuals and institutions -- had never before put money into companies that often had little more than promising technologies. Now the question is whether their nascent enthusiasm for investing in start-ups will recover or die on the vine.
Europe's traditional stock exchanges started creating these markets about four years ago, hoping to replicate the Nasdaq and to stem the flow of entrepreneurial talent to the United States, where finding capital was easy. There was also hope of providing money for job-creating companies that might become Europe's answers to Amazon.com or Cisco.
Though these European companies faced little scrutiny from regulators, compared with new offerings in the United States and Britain, the reaction was thunderous. Inexperienced individual investors -- discouraged by the meager interest rates they were receiving on government bonds -- clawed for a piece of every new offering. 
Banks fell over themselves to underwrite new stock offerings from dozens of dot-com start-ups and software companies and from older, family-owned companies whose owners simply wanted to cash in. Among those in the parade: EM.TV and Merchandising, which bought the Jim Henson Company last year, but is now struggling to survive; J. P. Tod's, the Italian shoe company; Lycos Europe, the Internet search engine company; and Jazztel, an upstart Spanish telecommunications carrier.
More than a few entrepreneurs became overnight billionaires, at least on paper. At one point, the market value of a two-year-old Italian Internet company called Tiscali S.p.A. was almost as high as that of Fiat, Italy's automobile and industrial conglomerate.
By far the biggest new exchange is the three-year-old Neuer Markt in Frankfurt, which trades 338 companies with a combined market capitalization of $111 billion. The four-year old Nouveau Marche in Paris has more than 150 companies with a combined market value of more than $20 billion. The Nuovo Mercato here has only 40 companies, but with a market about equal to that of the Paris market.
London actually led the way in 1995, when it created the Alternative Investments Market, or AIM, for small companies. AIM now has more than 500 listings, but it is dominated by companies with tiny valuations, from restaurants to courier services. As a result, AIM's total market capitalization is about on par only with that of Paris and Milan. 
Other European exchanges have been slower to catch on. The Nuevo Mercado in Madrid has only 12 stocks, most of which had already listed on other exchanges. And Easdaq, an electronic trading network modeled after Nasdaq, based in Brussels and billed as a pan-European exchange, has been a disappointment. After a strong start in 1996, Easdaq has steadily lost ground to the national exchanges.
Now, 10 months into the downturn, all the fledgling exchanges are scrambling, both to survive and to establish themselves as pan-European markets. Deutsche Borse A.G., the parent of the Frankfurt Neuer Markt, failed last year to merge with the London Stock Exchange, for example. Despite gloom surrounding financial institutions, Deutsche Borse is trying to raise nearly $1 billion by going public next month.
Euronext, which was formed last year through the merger of the Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam exchanges, is trying to fold its three "new markets" into a new entity called NextEconomy. Exchange officials also hope to put all three on a common trading system later this year, though the markets will remain legally separate and have slightly different rules. Madrid and Milan are weighing whether to cast their lot with Frankfurt or Paris.
NONE of Europe's other new markets grew as explosively as Frankfurt's Neuer Markt, and none are now more shellshocked. From the start in October 1997 through last year, companies on the Neuer Markt accounted for 56 percent of the market value and 72 percent of the trading volume on Europe's new-company exchanges.
At its peak last spring, the German frenzy for new stocks seemed insatiable. Previously obscure entrepreneurs had become celebrities, routinely appearing on television. Banks were bringing a constant stream of new companies to the market: Internet bookshops like Bucher.de and Buch.de, Web-based travel agencies, advertising agencies, dating agencies. A few start-ups were even American companies that went to Germany because investors there were willing to pay higher prices than those in the United States.
"It was like a baker that was always sold out," said Lothar Mark, chairman of Gontard & Metallbank, a small but busy underwriter in Frankfurt. "As soon as you baked the next batch of rolls, people were lining up to buy them. There weren't any rolls left."
Mr. Mark should know. Gontard & Metallbank, formed from the merger of two tiny banks that had fallen on hard times, managed 13 offerings last year. Of those, eight are now below their offering price and five are still above. Mr. Mark took his bank public last year, but its shares are since down about 36 percent.
"The Neuer Markt was a new toy," said Holger Tim, chief executive of Berliner Effektengesellschaft, parent of a company that acts as a market maker for many German stocks. "Investors saw it as 100 percent safe, a money-making machine."
Statistics provide a glimpse of the transformation. In 1997, only 8.9 percent of German adults owned stocks or equity-based mutual funds, according to the Deutschen Aktieninstitut, a research group in Frankfurt. By the end of 2000, that share had more than doubled, to 19.3 percent. (In the United States, about 30 percent of the population owns stock, directly or indirectly.)
Comparable statistics for other countries are hard to obtain, but they probably lag behind those for Germany. Though the Paris Nouveau Marche opened a year before the Neuer Markt, it never gathered as much steam or soared as high, no doubt because the French have never liked imitating American capitalism. In Spain, disagreement and uncertainty among financial institutions delayed the start of the Nuevo Mercado until last April, when technology stocks were heading down sharply. In Amsterdam, investors were shocked and embittered by the flop of World Online, whose founder quietly sold part of her stake to private investors shortly before the company went public.
BUT in Germany, the fever spread to millions in all walks of life. More than 50 banks jumped into the business of underwriting new stock offerings. Television shows about new stocks became so popular that statements made by their hosts and guests routinely moved markets. At least a half-dozen glossy new business magazines were started, from Teleborse to Bizz.
Volker Meier, an unemployed economist who grew up in the formerly Communist east, devoted himself nearly full time to investing in stocks and bonds to stretch out his life savings. Thinking he was cautious, he invested a small percentage of his money in a mutual fund for Neuer Markt companies. To his delight, the investment nearly doubled in value last year. When it began to sink, he stayed in after the fund manager declared his continued optimism.
"Things seemed very exaggerated and overblown at the time, but I figured this man was much cleverer than I was," recalled Mr. Meier, who is 54.
Today, his fund investment is worth one-fifth its value a year ago.
Almost incredibly, stock valuations in Germany, measured by price-to-earnings ratios, were sharply higher than on the Nasdaq. Thomas Effler, an analyst at Commerzbank, estimated the average P/E ratio in the market's index was nearly 50 percent higher for the Neuer Markt as recently as December. It was little wonder that the exaggerated euphoria set the stage for an exaggerated decline.
Stefan Powels has a perfect view of the new shopping and office towers at Berlin's Potsdamer Platz, where the Berlin Wall once severed the city -- and a perfect view of the trading decline.
Mr. Powels runs a two-month-old Internet trading center for Wallstreet:Online, one of 30 Internet-based brokerage firms that have sprouted in Germany in the last three years. His center has all the latest technology for day-traders -- workstations with sleek double screens; software that lets amateurs see not only current prices but also the volumes of shares being offered; instant access to reams of analytical data and news.
But on a recent morning, the trading center was nearly empty. "Customers just say they don't want to trade anymore," Mr. Powels said. "I expect the next two months will be very difficult. We won't hire any more people, and we will open up fewer accounts than perhaps we had expected."
Mr. Meier, the economist, was among those who showed up recently at one of Wallstreet:Online's regular investment seminars. "We are victims of the media, the fund managers and the analysts," he complained. "There were never any analysts who said we ought to get out, but the fundamentals were clear. For me, it's a fraud."
Ruby Ma, who stages her own investment seminars in Berlin, recalled how all the major banks continued to publish bullish forecasts for EM.TV until the company suddenly revised its results and said it was seriously overburdened by debt. "Dresdner Bank, Commerzbank, all of them said EM.TV was going to keep going up," Ms. Ma said. "Then, when it suddenly went into crisis, they said 'sell.' But before that, there were no sell recommendations."
MAKING matters even worse for investors was misleading behavior at several companies. EM.TV, whose stock price shot up more than 11,000 percent, made worldwide headlines last year buying Henson, renowned for the Muppets, and a 50 percent stake in the Formula One racing organization. Today, the shares are down more than 90 percent and the company is in a desperate struggle to survive.
How did it happen? EM.TV's hyperkinetic founder, Thomas Haffa, dazzled investors by announcing a seemingly endless stream of deals to acquire rights to children's television programming.
But the pace of acquisitions left EM.TV swooning in debt. It also employed dubious accounting, which inflated its revenues and profits. In October, the company said it would have to restate its first-half earnings. In December, Mr. Haffa acknowledged that operating profits for the year would be one-tenth of what the company had predicted just a few weeks earlier. Mr. Haffa's brother, Florian, resigned as chief financial officer, acknowledging that he had lost the trust of shareholders.
Last week, Thomas Haffa's lawyer said in an interview that his client secretly sold 200,000 shares of EM.TV stock last February, violating rules that prohibit executives from selling shares within six months after a public stock offering.
EM.TV now faces an avalanche of shareholder suits, which are also almost unprecedented in Germany. But even if the shareholders win, they may not receive much compensation. German law also makes it difficult for shareholders to claim damages, even if executives made demonstrably misleading or false statements. And class action suits do not exist, which means that lawyers have to file individual suits on behalf of each client.
"Totally inadequate," summed up Daniela Bergdolt, a lawyer in Munich who is suing EM.TV on behalf of hundreds of shareholders. "The amount of work involved is enormous, and the merits of each case have to be scrutinized individually."
German investors have suffered through other shocks as well. The founders of Infomatec, a software company in Augsburg, are now in jail as German prosecutors investigate accusations of insider trading and fraud. Gigabell, an Internet company whose founder touted deals that did not exist, has collapsed. Adpepper, an Internet advertising firm, warned that its results would be lower than expected less than one month after its public offering in September.
NOT surprisingly, the barrage of bad news has raised a storm of criticism about lax oversight and shoddy practices. Until this month, company founders did not have to tell investors if they bought or sold their company's shares. German law also makes it difficult to sue companies for damages stemming from false statements.
Under pressure to clean up its image, the Deutsche Borse is tightening up its rules. It now requires top executives at Neuer Markt companies to disclose any transactions in their company's stock. It also tightened requirements for the way companies report their results, tailoring demands to individual industries. Unlike some of Europe's other markets -- including Germany's main exchange for big companies -- the Neuer Markt already requires companies to use either American-style Generally Accepted Accounting Principles or the fairly similar International Accounting Standards. 
"Four years ago, only about 10 companies, if that many, used I.A.S. accounting," said Rainer Riess, head of primary markets at Deutsche Borse. "It was a big issue whether it would be possible at all."
Mr. Riess conceded that the rules governing Neuer Markt companies were still less stringent than those in the United States. But, he said, "we are tightening up, screw by screw." 
Tougher regulations are only part of the story. In the heat of the craze for new stocks, German banks and even some Wall Street firms pumped out new issues with ever less regard for quality. 
DG Bank, which serves as an umbrella bank for about one-third of Germany's community-owned savings banks, was lead manager on 52 offerings. Of the 20 initial stock issues it managed last year, only three are above water.
Rolf Michael Betz, head of investment banking at DG Bank, said his institution had done its best to scrutinize new offerings. "We perform extensive due diligence, not only hiring accountants and lawyers to make sure that the prospectus is in order," he said. "We also have a team of analysts that scrutinizes the business plan. The problem is that these industries are so new that it is very hard to know what will happen."
Shareholder advocates sharply disagree. "Let's speak clearly: some of the worst offerings did not come from obscure little stock brokerage houses," said Ms. Bergdolt, the Munich lawyer who represents one of Germany's biggest shareholder advocacy organizations. "All the banks were involved, and they were all motivated by the fact that the higher the offering price was, the higher their profit would be." 
Ms. Bergdolt said it could be years before the banks and the markets regained their credibility with investors. "The damage that has been done here goes beyond just the Neuer Markt to the economy as a whole," she said. "The wave of new companies provided an important new source of jobs, and that wave has now been stopped dead in its tracks. It is a terrible loss."
ITALY has had only slightly better luck with its new market, as the tale of E.biscom shows.
Francesco Micheli, the company's chairman and other co-founder, is a walking synthesis of old and new Italy. Now 62, he built his career as an investment banker and played a central role in Olivetti's hostile takeover of Telecom Italia. A passionate art collector and pianist, he works in an office at E.biscom that includes oil paintings from his private collection and a magnificent electronic piano. "This was a way of bringing a part of my home with me," he said.
When he and Mr. Scaglia created E.biscom in 1998, Mr. Scaglia, once chief executive of Omnitel, an Italian mobile telephone operator, was convinced that Italy was ripe for a leap into advanced telecommunications. 
E.biscom would build fiber optic networks in major Italian cities that would be independent of the telephone network and run directly into individual buildings. They would have so much capacity that even ordinary customers would be able to get movies on demand and many new video Internet services. 
"Four years ago, it would have been impossible to take the company public in Italy," Mr. Scaglia said. "Even two years ago, we had very different plans."
E.biscom's principal draw was Mr. Scaglia's record at Omnitel and his willingness to risk his own money: he and Mr. Michaeli invested $10 million each and pledged not to sell their shares for six years.
Their timing -- last March -- was perfect. Milan's Nuovo Mercato had been a late arrival, having started in June 1999, and many Italians feared that they were about to miss out.
They had also been electrified by the public offering of Tiscali, the brash Internet service provider whose shares had soared from 46 euros to 1,300. Yet the public offering of E.biscom was even more remarkable. The founders and other early investors held on to 80 percent of the shares, while raising 1.7 billion euros (about $1.5 billion) in new cash. Today, E.biscom has built fiber optic links to several thousand corporate customers, and its sales reached 46 million euros by the end of 2000.
Mr. Scaglia hopes to generate positive cash flow, not counting interest and depreciation, by 2003. But profits are a long way off.
Italian exchange officials are convinced that Italian attitudes toward new companies and entrepreneurs have changed permanently. The watershed, they said, was the rise of Tiscali, a start-up from Sardinia that is now one of Europe's biggest Internet service providers. 
"Tiscali changed everything," said Maria Pierdicchi, director of the Nuovo Mercato. When the Borsa Italiana, Milan's main exchange, first tried to start a new market in early 1999, she said, banks and financial institutions were overwhelmingly dubious. "People were avoiding us," Ms. Pierdicchi said. "They said it's a risky project, that Italy doesn't have entrepreneurs or venture capitalists. Tiscali showed that there were entrepreneurs in Italy, and a lot of people saw that if he could make it, then maybe they could make it, too."
Oliver Novick and Elserino Piol experienced the shift in thinking from the vantage point of venture capitalists. Mr. Novick, an American, and Mr. Piol, who had been in charge of Olivetti's venture capital activities, started a venture fund called Pino Ventures in October 1998. In their first attempt to raise money from investors, the two were barely able to get $22 million. But they had the good fortune to back Tiscali, which was able to capitalize on Internet mania and surge to success. 
When they started a second fund in May 1999, they raised $500 million. Investors included scores of big European banks as well as American companies from Microsoft to Cisco.
Now the outlook has changed entirely. Venture capital firms earn their profits by being able to exit their investments, and Pino was able to pay back all its first-round investors with the profits from Tiscali's public offering. But with the Nuovo Mercato down about 70 percent from its peak, prospects for new public offerings range from difficult to impossible. "The next year will be difficult," Mr. Novick said.
BUBBLES are bursting in most European markets. In Madrid, the Nuevo Mercado has been unable to generate any initial public offerings. In Germany, at least 25 companies have postponed or delayed plans to go public. And because so many newly listed companies are a long way from making a profit, the inability to raise more money has led some to the edge of bankruptcy.
"It is sensationally awful," said Florian Homm, founder of Value Management and Research, a small company that invests in new stock offerings around Europe. "It makes the Crash of 1929 look like a joke. We're going to get slammed."
Yet for all the unhappiness, few investors seem ready to abandon stocks and return to their old ways. Even in Germany. For one thing, government bonds pay low interest rates today. Beyond that, investors generally say they knew there were risks in investing and that the huge price rises would not last forever.
"People really didn't pay attention," said Jurgen Kramer, 31, a publishing executive in Augsburg who started an investment club just as the Neuer Markt was peaking. "They just wanted to subscribe in public offerings, regardless of what the company did or its management. We didn't want to hear anything to the contrary."
Rudiger von Rosen, director of the Deutschen Aktieninstitut in Frankfurt, a research institute financed by the investment industry, said it was significant that Germans continued to invest in equity-based mutual funds even as the market headed south. "German investors have demonstrated a remarkable maturity in the past year," he wrote this month, after publishing a survey of investor attitudes. "Private households have not allowed themselves to be disconcerted by the temporary decline in the market."
That remains to be seen. But Mr. Kramer is ready to vouch for the theory. "We are absolutely buying right now," he said. "We see this correction as a good chance to get back in."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Andrew J. Knuth and Edmund H. Nicklin Jr.; 
Westport Small Cap Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
ANDREW J. KNUTH and Edmund H. Nicklin Jr. work closely together as co-managers of the $574 million Westport Small Cap fund. Very closely.
 "He sits about eight feet away from me, so I couldn't avoid him if I wanted to," Mr. Knuth said of Mr. Nicklin. "There's a glass partition between our offices, and we have to look at each other all day long." 
 But they don't always have to listen to each other. Mr. Nicklin noted that his office had a door. 
Whatever the logistics, shareholders appear to have benefited. The fund returned 24.9 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Jan. 25, compared with 9.1 percent for its peer group of small blend funds, according to Morningstar Inc.
Mr. Knuth, 62, and Mr. Nicklin, 54, are long-term contrarian investors who look for bargains among United States companies with market capitalizations of less than $1.75 billion. "We try to buy good businesses when other people don't want them," Mr. Knuth said. "That means a lot of risk has been taken out of the price."
They divide their purchases between the fund, which is open to new investors, and $2.8 billion in institutional accounts, which are not.
The managers work in their Westport, Conn., office with two analysts to choose the 60 or so stocks in the fund. Unlike many other money managers, they do not use computer screens to pick investments. Instead, they rely on a combined 55 years of experience to find solid small companies that they believe will improve their profitability and stock prices.
Such companies abound today, Mr. Knuth said. "Because of the relatively poor performance of small-cap value stocks over the last few years," he said, "we're seeing many opportunities."
First, the managers seek out niche businesses. These may be regional or local banks, semiconductor companies with proprietary designs or radio broadcasters with government licenses for specific areas. "If you don't buy a niche business," Mr. Nicklin said, "the bigger companies that have economies of scale are likely to erode your profitability and your returns over time."
That focus often means that portfolio companies become takeover targets. Seven holdings were acquired in 2000, and another, the Fritz Companies, agreed this month to be acquired by United Parcel Service. "Virtually every company in the portfolio is a legitimate acquisition opportunity for bigger companies," Mr. Nicklin said. "Acquisitions give us the opportunity for value-added returns that we don't pay for."
They compare a company's current stock price with what they believe it will be in two years, given their forecast of earnings or cash flow. Typically, the managers buy when a company's difficulties -- real or perceived -- have driven down its stock price. Their goal is a 50 percent increase in price over two years.
Mr. Knuth said they evaluate management's plans to improve profitability, by selling unprofitable divisions, for example, or via mergers. 
The fund sells shares when a company's stock price exceeds the managers' two-year price target or when the company's fundamentals deteriorate. Because of the fund's long-term focus, turnover averages a measly 10 percent a year. 
The fund has owned shares of Universal Health Services of King of Prussia, Pa., a big operator of acute-care and psychiatric hospitals, for more than 10 years. The managers bought more of the stock in March, at an average price of $42.27, after the company announced disappointing third-quarter earnings. "At that point, it sold for four times cash flow," Mr. Knuth said, adding that he believed it was worth 8 to 10 times cash flow. The earnings shortfall was created by health maintenance organizations' payment problems, compounded by staffing costs, he said; those issues have been resolved. 
He expects Universal's earnings to grow 20 percent a year over two years. The stock is now at $83.69.
Another holding is Precision Castparts, a Portland, Ore., company that makes castings and forgings, primarily for aircraft engines. Mr. Knuth expects cost savings from Precision's 1999 acquisition of Wyman-Gordon, which produced parts for the aerospace industry. Precision also supplies component parts to the utility industry, for gas turbines that generate electricity.
Mr. Knuth expects the company to have annual earnings growth of 15 percent for the next two years. The fund began buying shares last April at an average price of $21.03; they now trade at $37.06. 
THE managers also like IMS Health of Westport, Conn., a health care database company that supplies prescription information to drug companies. "No other company has the scale and capacity to deliver this information to drug companies at a better price," Mr. Nicklin said.
Early last year, to create an Internet presence, IMS proposed a complex transaction with a smaller company, the TriZetto Group, involving a reverse acquisition. The stock fell from the mid-$20's, and the managers began buying shares in March, at an average price of $16.20. "IMS was a very attractive business, and we felt this transaction would not be approved by the shareholders," Mr. Nicklin said.
The merger was abandoned in favor of a simpler transaction with the same company, and a new chief executive, David M. Thomas, took over last November. The stock closed on Friday at $24.94.

HEADLINE: Montana Republicans Seek to Ease Environmental Laws 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HELENA, Mont. 

 BODY:
Citing steadily declining jobs in traditional industries like mining, logging and energy development, Montana is preparing to change its environmental regulations to make them more favorable to business.
 The current efforts are the most ambitious by any state to speed the process of obtaining construction and operating permits, and they have set off an old-fashioned fight between environmentalists and business interests. But both sides agree on one thing: the state's actions have taken on added force and importance in light of President Bush's promise to review the Clinton administration's environmental policies and the willingness of the nominee for interior secretary, Gale A. Norton, to let the states assume more power to regulate themselves. 
 "The concept is not new, but I haven't seen other states do something as comprehensively as Montana," said Paula Carrell, state program director for the Sierra Club. 
The changes proposed for Montana, in at least eight bills being drafted, have the support of the new governor, Judy Martz, a Republican, and Republican leaders of the Legislature, who say the Republican majority in both chambers almost assures passage of the bills. 
In particular, two state laws are under review, the Montana Environmental Policy Act and the Montana Major Facility Siting Act, which regulates the construction and operation of power plants. Both laws are nearly 30 years old. 
"The laws are so vague," said Don Allen, executive director of the Western Environmental Trade Association, a coalition of industry groups. The Montana Environmental Policy Act "and other things are used so widely that they play a role in keeping our economy from what it needs to be." 
Governor Martz agrees. "The process needs to be changed," she said, adding that only the regulations for gaining permits would be changed, not laws that protect the air and water.
For example, some permits could be granted after 90 days of review rather than a year. Another change under consideration before the Legislature would allow the state to issue a permit after the 90-day deadline even if all environmental reviews had not been completed.
Environmentalists who have fought long and expensive battles over mine cleanups and timber harvesting are not optimistic that they can stop the initiatives. "State agencies will be forced to act prior to having all the information they need to make an adequate decision," said Anne Hedges, program director for the Montana Environmental Information Center, a watchdog group. 
Supporters of the legislation contend that the state's current environmental regulations make it too expensive for companies to operate profitably, driving away high-paying jobs and discouraging out-of-state businesses from expanding into Montana. They also contend that the regulations have helped drive up Montana's electricity costs by discouraging the construction of power plants. Utility rates for consumers have doubled in the last year.
The environmental groups are challenging the new measures as unnecessary, saying they could endanger not only the quality of the state's air and water but also its economy. They say that Montana ranks eighth in the country in per capita job creation, and that the state's 5 percent unemployment rate, though slightly higher than the national average, is relatively low and has been falling. 
Yet the Republican lawmakers want Montanans to believe that the state is in dire trouble, said Thomas Power, chairman of the economics department at the University of Montana. "Their whole premise is wrong," Mr. Power said. "All they know is they are losing jobs in mining, milling and smelting; therefore they must be hurting. But the industrial base of the country is evaporating. These people are staring into the rearview mirror, lost in fantasies tied to the past." 
Tourism and recreation, the environmentalists note, are fueling job growth; service industry jobs jumped to 119,571 in 1999 from 82,684 in 1990. At the same time, the number of jobs in farming, forestry and mining fell. Mining jobs alone dropped to 7,081 in 1999 from 8,977 in 1990. While state income from natural resource industries has fallen or remained even, income from the recreation and health industries has risen substantially. 
The environmentalists say economic declines have less to do with environmental regulations than with the state's tax policy, the quality of schools, Montana's 1997 deregulation of electrical power -- and the enormous financial burden of cleaning up defunct mining sites. 
"To get out of the bottom of the barrel, they want to strip the protections away," said John Wilson, conservation director of Montana Trout Unlimited. "But that just puts out a welcome mat, particularly to the natural resource industry of coal, oil and gas." 
"It sends the same message to George Bush, as well," he added. 
That is fine with the Republicans, who note that Montana has consistently ranked low in wages. In 1988, Montana ranked 44th in per capita income; by 1998, the state had fallen to 47th, with an average per capita personal income of $21,229. 
"We're always at the bottom of the barrel," said State Senator Lorents Grosfield of Big Timber, Mont.
Democratic lawmakers say they share the concerns of the environmental groups, while bowing to what appears to be the inevitable.
"We may need to look at the process to see if it needs to be modernized," Kim Gillan of Billings, the House minority leader, said, "but only as long as it keeps to the substance of the state environmental laws." Nonetheless, she added, the Republican majorities in both chambers might make it too difficult for Democrats to contain their efforts. Republicans control the House, 58 to 42, and the Senate, 31 to 19. 
Environmentalists fear that other states will follow Montana's lead, emboldened by a new administration in Washington that is more sympathetic to natural resource industries than the Clinton administration was. 
So far, though, there is no sign of that. Officials in Idaho and Wyoming -- states that have traditionally relied on mining and logging -- have said that they are not replicating Montana's model. 
Ms. Carrell of the Sierra Club also said she knew of no other state as active as Montana in trying to loosen environmental regulations. Still, she added, "it could be that Montana just stuck its head out of the hole first."
"We're expecting a lot more of this stuff to surface," she said, "especially now with new sympathies in Washington."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
The New South: Old Times There Are Not Forgotten

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA 

 BODY:
IN 1956, with little debate or public notice, a handful of men at the helm of Georgia's government decided to change the state flag, altering Southern history in a way that once seemed permanent. They added the Confederate battle cross to the flag, turning a state symbol into an officially sanctioned tool of protest that could be waved at the Democratic National Convention in defiance of federal desegregation orders.
 On Wednesday, again with little debate or public notice, a handful of men at the helm of Georgia's government decided it was time to undo what their predecessors had done. With only a few hours of advance warning, they persuaded the state House of Representatives to approve a new flag designed behind closed doors, one in which the Confederate symbol is reduced to a tiny historical artifact at the bottom edge, amid a ribbon of other flags that have flown over Georgia. 
 If the manner in which statehouse business gets done in the South hasn't changed much over the years, the differences between the two flags themselves very much reflect changes in southern society that have taken place between 1956 and now. Just as the symbolism of a flag is usually more important than its aesthetic values, this new flag -- assuming it is adopted by the state Senate this week, as expected -- is very much a mental map of the contemporary South. And the long, winding path taken by Georgia's leaders to reach agreement on what this symbol should look like is woven into its composition.
The flag designers in 2001, unlike those 45 years ago, are both white and black, and to reach agreement they consented to compromises they would have found unthinkable even a few years ago. The two sides found common ground by recognizing the emotional heart of their opponent's argument: Blacks acknowledged the profound attachment to the Confederacy held by many native Southern whites, while whites acknowledged that flaunting that attachment from every flagpole was deeply offensive to those with a different view of Southern heritage. 
By successfully seeing the same history through other people's eyes, the House leaders moved the largest state in the old South a giant step farther away from the Civil War that has obsessed it for a century and a half.
"If I had been in the legislature in 1956, the truth is I probably would have voted for that flag they passed back then," said Larry Walker, the House majority leader. "Even now I still have deep, deep feelings for my Southern heritage and for the Confederacy, which for a lot of us was the defining moment of the South. But now I think it is time we started to move away from that moment."
Mr. Walker is a white Democrat from Perry, former Senator Sam Nunn's hometown in central Georgia, who until recently was unalterably opposed to removing the Confederate symbol from the flag. For years, his opposition to a change, and that of his fellow rural Democrats, was the reason the flag remained, even as black colleagues tried to persuade him that, to them, it was a degrading reminder of white supremacy.
But over the years, he said, those arguments gained weight in his mind, aided by the growing threats of economic boycotts of the state and the behind-the-scenes persuasion of Gov. Roy E. Barnes. On Tuesday, Mr. Walker told the House that his decision to support a new flag was the hardest he had made in 28 years as a legislator but that he believed it was past time to consider "the Georgians who were forced here, and who are just now beginning to share in the wonderful bounty of this country; Georgians who at least until recently have received little respect and much ridicule and deriding."
But Mr. Walker's change of heart was not an unconditional surrender. He told his fellow negotiators that he would not accept a flag completely shorn of Confederate symbolism. And that posed a problem for Tyrone Brooks, a prominent black state representative from Atlanta, who has worked relentlessly for 23 years to rid the Georgia flag of its dominating Confederate emblem. He has led marches against it, called it the "Georgia swastika" and helped keep it off the sites of the 1996 Olympics.
THIS time, however, sensing that his goal was nearly in reach, Mr. Brooks and another leading black legislator, Calvin Smyre of Columbus, agreed that the object of their vilification could remain on the flag, in reduced form and in historical context.
"What I finally had to acknowledge was that Confederate history is a part of our history," Mr. Brooks said. "We cannot erase it, and it needs to be preserved for history's sake. Just like I have no intention of removing the statues of Robert E. Lee or Stonewall Jackson, because as long as they're there, they will help us remember not to repeat our history."
Initially, some of Mr. Brooks's black colleagues in the House were angrily against any trace of the Confederacy remaining on the flag, but they ceased their opposition when it became clear that it would cause the compromise plan for revision to fail outright. 
In that sense, they traveled the same path as legislators in South Carolina last year, who agreed to lower the Confederate battle flag from the statehouse dome, but only after a smaller version was placed on a less prominent flagpole on the Capitol grounds.
In Mississippi, where race relations are a bit more raw, legislators have been unable to make that journey on their own, and recently decided to let voters choose a new flag in an April referendum. Many Georgia leaders believe that was a terrible mistake, and hope that Mississippi voters at least can learn from Georgia's example.
"There comes a time in your life when you realize you can't duck the real issues anymore," said Mr. Smyre. "You have to look across the table and realize that just because someone has a different view of history doesn't mean they hate you."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Overcoming the Dark Side

BYLINE:  By Rick Gladstone 

 BODY:
The blackouts in California may be chilling its economy and giving people second thoughts about moving there. But the power crisis was not a big deterrent to Integra Realty Resources, the nation's leading real estate appraisal firm, which has just ranked San Diego, Sacramento and Orange County among the best places for property investments. 
 In its Viewpoint 2001 annual ranking, Integra said San Diego was the best place to invest in suburban office space, Sacramento was No. 3 and Orange County was No. 10. Orange County and Sacramento were also among the best 10 places to invest in downtown office space, and San Diego was among the top 10 for industrial real estate investments. By contrast, some cities with plenty of power, like Pittsburgh, Memphis and Cleveland, fared badly in Integra's ranking. 
 Sean Hutchinson, president of Integra, said the appraisal was done in late 2000, and "we went to print past the time the whole energy thing blew up." 
Obviously, he said, "in the case of California, it's impossible to run a real estate building if you can't get energy."
"You know, dark buildings don't sell," he added. "But I have to trust that in some way there will be an adequate response to this crisis." Rick Gladstone

HEADLINE: DATABANK: JANUARY 22-26; 
Watching for Signs of a Rebound

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
It was another tepid week for the markets as investors appeared to be in a holding pattern awaiting this week's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. 
 There were signs that the economy was rebounding from a sharp slowdown in the fourth quarter. 
Preliminary retail sales figures surged for January, and General Motors and DaimlerChrysler reported unexpectedly strong consumer demand for the month. 
 Warnings about first-quarter earnings continued to pile up, coming this time from blue-chip companies like Dell Computer, American Express, McDonald's, DuPont and Corning. But those gloomy forecasts seemed to have already been factored into Wall Street's calculations as the markets finished up modestly for the week. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500 led the way, ending at 1,354.95, up 12.40 points or 0.9 percent. The Dow industrials also rose, finishing at 10,659.98, up 72.39 points or 0.7 percent. The Nasdaq climbed to 2,781.30, up 10.92 points or 0.4 percent.
 The modest rally in the equity markets took some of the steam out of the Treasury markets. Falling prices meant that the bellwether 10-year Treasury note ended the week with a yield of 5.26 percent, up from 5.16 percent the previous week. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
