HEADLINE: Princeton to Replace Loans With Student Scholarships 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
As American students take on ever-larger mountains of debt to help pay for college, Princeton University said yesterday that it would replace student loans with scholarships so that its undergraduates eligible for financial aid would not have to worry about paying back thousands of dollars for their education. 
 Next year, Princeton students will be charged $26,160 for tuition, and undergraduates will pay $33,613 a year for tuition, room and board, a 3 percent increase. 
 Princeton said it would use the bounty from gifts and from its growing endowment -- now about $8 billion -- to expand scholarships for all students eligible for financial aid beginning this fall. It also plans to increase aid for graduate students. 
The university said the no-loan program and other financial aid improvements for undergraduates would cost it more than $5 million next year, while improving graduate support would cost more than $6 million.
Princeton's decision to reduce student indebtedness is likely to put pressure on other elite colleges and universities competing not just in academic programs but also in real-life economics for the best students. 
"This is an extraordinary gesture," said Arthur Levine, president of Columbia Teachers College. In the last two decades, he said, "there has been good support for poorer students, and wealthy students could afford to pay. But the only way middle-class students could afford to attend these colleges was by taking out huge loans."
"Every Ivy League university is going to have to try to match this if they want to compete for the best of the middle-class students," he added.
This is the second time in three years that Princeton, one of the wealthiest universities in the United States, has moved to improve financial aid for undergraduates. In 1998, it substituted grants for loans for its lowest-income students, from families earning less than $46,500. It also altered the formula it used to calculate a family's ability to pay for college so that middle-income students would be eligible for more aid.
Harvard and Yale were among the universities that followed with similar programs, although many other colleges and universities decided they could not afford to match Princeton's plan. 
Princeton, like other colleges, has traditionally provided students deemed eligible for financial aid (based on family income and assets) with a mix of loans and grants to supplement their own payments. 
Across the United States, more and more aid has been provided in the form of loans, especially for middle-income families. Twenty years ago, loans were used to pay for about 40 percent of a college education; today, that figure has jumped to about 60 percent. 
Don Betterton, Princeton's director of undergraduate financial aid, said that graduates of four-year colleges would leave campus this year with average debt of $15,000 to $20,000. Such debt affects student decisions about whether to go to graduate school and what careers to pursue, he added. 
Randall Smith, a freshman from Anchorage, said, "I am planning to go on to graduate school, so it will be nice not having a large debt from my undergraduate years starting out." He said, "I'll have some from the loans that I took out from this year, but besides that, I will be saving about $12,000." 
Princeton said that about 40 percent of its freshmen receive financial aid, and nearly two-thirds of the aid recipients -- or about a quarter of the freshmen class -- borrow to help cover their Princeton bills. 
Princeton freshmen borrowed an average of $2,615 this year. That is significantly lower than the $4,000 average loan taken out by this year's seniors, who were not covered when Princeton said that it would expand its financial aid three years ago, beginning with incoming students.
Mr. Betterton said that Princeton's new policy should make it possible for students to graduate without any debt, although most students would still be expected to contribute something. Princeton sets the amount it expects families and students to pay at a level it believes they can afford, based on the family income and assets and on what a student can earn working part time and during the summers. Families will still have the option of borrowing to pay their share of the bill. 
Princeton also said yesterday that it would reduce the amount students would be expected to contribute from their savings, and would increase grants to pay the $370 annual cost of the health care plan for students from families earning less than $66,500.
The university also said it would pay more attention to the rent a family paid in determining its ability to pay for college. Three years ago it said it would not count a family's home equity when it assessed its financial assets.
Graduate students will also receive more generous financial aid. Princeton said it would double the number of doctoral students in the humanities and social science that it supports during the summer, to 650 from 325. Stipends for graduate students and their health care coverage will also be improved.
The university also said it would provide all first-year doctoral students with full tuition and a stipend to help cover living expenses.
The university said it would increase the rate of spending from its endowment to help pay for these programs and others, including providing more money for faculty salaries and a larger budget for teaching foreign languages, and sabbatical leaves for senior lecturers.

HEADLINE: January 21-27; 
Power Struggles

BYLINE:  By Todd S. Purdum

 BODY:
 California continues to struggle with a crisis that seems surreal at its core: the state that is the epicenter of the nation's high tech economy has been repeatedly struck by the failure of a vital piece of its electrical service. State leaders edged toward a first-step solution, negotiating to buy power on long-term contracts at reasonable prices, then pass it on to the state's near-bankrupt utilities. 
The state would float bonds to finance the deal, perhaps in exchange for receiving utility stock that could be sold to repay the cost once the market rebounded. Consumers would also pay through an extension of recent rate increases. But officials warned that a crash program to conserve energy and finish construction of new power plants would still be needed to avoid blackouts at times of peak demand this summer. Todd S. Purdum

HEADLINE: Connecticut Protests Over Cross-Sound Power Line 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE 

 BODY:
THE most lucrative oyster beds in Connecticut are in New Haven Harbor. That is the exact place where the Long Island Power Authority hopes an electrical cable can be buried next year to carry up to 600 megawatts of power 26 miles underneath Long Island Sound to the Island, where the demand for electricity appears to be creeping close to the limits of supply.
 The Connecticut attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, and two environmental groups, Save the Sound and the Connecticut Maritime Coalition, say the cable could damage an area of the harbor roughly 3 miles long and 5 feet wide and have formally intervened in the application now before the Connecticut Siting Council. It is the first in a string of applications for necessary permits. 
 TransEnergie US Ltd. of Westborough, Mass., an affiliate of Quebec-based TransEnergie, applied last fall to the Connecticut Siting Council for a "certificate of environmental compatibility and public need" to bury the cable six feet deep in the harbor. Later they negotiated with the State Department of Agriculture to bury it four and a half feet deep. 
The nine-member council opened the public hearing last September in New Haven, and continued it over six other days in November, December and January, said Joel Rinebold, executive director of the siting council. Mr. Rinebold said the next hearing was on Monday at the council's headquarters in New Britain.
"They have to prove that the benefits from the facility would outweigh the environmental effects," Mr. Rinebold said.
For LIPA, the cost-benefit calculation is a slam-dunk for the cable, especially since there are no sensitive shellfish beds at the Shoreham end of the cable route.
"We're seeking to get more power to Long Island so we won't have a situation like California," said Bert Cunningham, vice president for communications at LIPA, referring to electric shortages in the deregulated California power industry that led to selective blackouts in that state.
Mr. Cunningham said LIPA predicted in 1998 that consumption would increase by 2 percent a year but that the growth rate has been 3.5 percent.
"The economy really picked up steam over the past couple of years," Mr. Cunningham said. "More people have home computers, fax machines; companies are putting in more computers. We have seen an incredible increase in the consumption of energy."
The LIPA chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said that Long Island came "extremely close to blackouts" during a four-day heat spell in early July.
The proposed cable would add the kind of insurance against brownouts Long Island seeks. Four major tie lines from New York to Long Island, and one underwater cable from Norwalk to Port Jefferson, join with six oil-fired steam plants on Long Island to provide about 5,100 megawatts of electricity to the public. On July 6, 1999, between 3 and 4 p.m., customers gobbled up 4,590 megawatts of electricity.
Mr. Cunningham said the authority had sought the cable because it was responsible for producing power, even though it was pushing a conservation program, and even though deregulation of the industry had produced a slew of proposals for independently owned power plants on the Island. The cable, he said, seems more sure than those other power sources, all of which are subject to Nimby attacks.
The cable is actually a bundle of three: two high-voltage cables and one fiber-optic connection. It would be encased in a protective steel jacket and would not have insulating fluid, which can leak on buried cables. A cable owned by Northeast Utilities, between Norwalk, Conn., and Port Jefferson has leaked its insulating fluid, drawing criticism from environmental groups. TransEnergie plans to install the cable next fall and winter, said James Nash, project director for the cable plan.
The cable would leave the land in New Haven at the East Shore Station of United Illuminating Company, which is now owned by Wisvest Connecticut. (NRG Energy Inc. is negotiating to buy that station.) It would meander south across the Sound and tie in to the power substation built on the grounds of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which was decommissioned in 1992 before it ever produced electricity.
Mr. Nash said New Haven was an ideal place to install the cable because the company would not have to gain rights of way from landowners. He said the company believed that the sea floor in New Haven Harbor could recover after the cable trench was dug.
TransEnergie has agreed to contribute $1 million toward establishing an oyster seed hatchery elsewhere in Connecticut, and to pay $1 million to restore the shellfish beds in New Haven Harbor.
"We're committed to performing a bed refurbishment of the very narrow passage," Mr. Nash said. He referred to the damage when a hydraulic "jet plow" would stir up the bottom to make a four-foot-wide trench for the cable.
TransEnergie also has negotiated a private agreement with Tallmadge Brothers, Briarpatch and Fairhaven Clam and Lobster, three commercial oyster growers that lease beds in New Haven Harbor. The terms of the agreement have remained secret.
Bruce Gresczyk, deputy commissioner of the Connecticut Agriculture Department, said the state's oyster industry was worth at least $60 million each year and the clam industry several million dollars. The state leases beds in New Haven Harbor to commercial growers. Half of the state's oyster crop begins life there before growers move them to other beds to mature. The clams grow buried in the soft mud and sand of the harbor bottom. New Haven Harbor holds the most intensely cultivated oyster beds on the Connecticut coast, said John Volk, director of the state's Bureau of Aquaculture in Milford, which has spent the last decade and a half trying to boost the state's shellfishing industry.
The Connecticut Department of Agriculture, which oversees the shellfishing industry, negotiated an agreement with TransEnergie that said the department did not want the cable built but that it would not object if other state officials believe it was necessary.
"Our position from day one is that we preferred an overland route but we also recognized that we are neither the permitting authority or the siting authority," Mr. Gresczyk said.
"No. 1, we want to protect the integrity of the resource," Mr. Gresczyk said. "If this thing was going to get sited there we wanted to protect it to the best of our abilities." 
But the state attorney general, Mr. Blumenthal, said the cable would do too much damage to be worth what it accomplished. While Mr. Gresczyk said he was guessing the shellfish beds could be restored in a few years, Mr. Blumental said experts didn't know what such a cable will do to the beds over time.
"The potential environmental impact is huge, profound and lasting, and the unknowns are even more alarming than the known pitfalls," Mr. Blumenthal said. "There has been no real exploration of alternatives. There is no ascertainable benefit to Connecticut since the power at least for the foreseeable future will be flowing from Connecticut to New York."
Mr. Volk of the state aquaculture bureau said that New Haven Harbor was the heart of Connecticut's oyster production. Here, private oyster growers lease beds from the state to nurture the shellfish, which only a few years ago recovered from a disease, MSX.
The state made its concerns clear, Mr. Volk said, because it is not known what effect the dredging operation and cable would have on the environment. For example, Mr. Rinebold said the temperature of the water was expected to go up a 0.5 degrees Fahrenheit on the sea floor directly over the buried cable, and Mr. Volk said MSX had been linked to warmer temperatures.
Save the Sound, an environmental group based in Stamford, became an intervenor in the Siting Council application. The group's president, John Atkin, said the group's board was worried that the cable could continue to do damage after it's installed.
"We're concerned about what happens after it's built," he said. "And we're also concerned about what kind of precedent it might set. If the Siting Council were to allow this cable -- and with electric deregulation we see what's happening in California now -- maybe private companies will be asking for cables all up and down the Sound."

HEADLINE: AOL Time Warner Base Lifts Silicon Alley 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
AOL Time Warner's decision to locate its corporate headquarters in New York seemed to have had little more impact than a few new signs going up in Rockefeller Center. After all, the heart of America Online is still based in Dulles, Va., many executives remain in other parts of the country and few new jobs came to the city.
 But nearly three weeks after Time Warner and America Online completed their merger, making it the world's largest Internet media company, the presence of its headquarters in Time Warner's skyscraper at 75 Rockefeller Plaza has already begun to have at least a psychological impact on Silicon Alley. 
 Around water coolers and at technology industry events and meetings, business leaders say that the symbolic act of choosing New York for the merged entities' headquarters has buoyed a battered Silicon Alley, which has faced thousands of layoffs and the closings of many dot-coms since April. 
"If nothing else, it is a beacon in the climate of the last year," Anna Copeland Wheatley, the editor in chief of AlleyCat News, said of AOL Time Warner's decision to base itself in New York. "A lot of New York accounting firms, law firms and insurance firms target the new-media industry, and to have an 8,000-pound gorilla sitting at the table, it makes it a lot easier."
The creation of Silicon Alley, a cluster of Internet media startups mostly in Lower Manhattan, in the early 1990's "demonstrated that New York was a viable place to create an early stage technology company, and I think there was a lot of doubt about that," said Brian T. Horey, the venture capitalist who founded the New York New Media Association. But when the dot-com boom went bust last year, Silicon Alley seemed to take a harder hit than many other technology regions. Since April, thousands of employees have been laid off, entrepreneurs increasingly complain they cannot find capital and at least 15 Silicon Alley companies are performing so poorly that their stocks are in danger of being removed from the Nasdaq composite listing. 
Randy Schoenfeld, a managing partner at Redwood Partners, Silicon Alley's oldest executive-recruiting and venture capital consulting firm, said that AOL Time Warner provided a needed psychological shot in the arm.
Mr. Schoenfeld said market conditions suggested that layoffs at Silicon Alley companies would continue, but said that at the very least "AOL Time Warner gives us validation that New York is going to be the Internet media capital of the world."
In the January edition of the Silicon Alley Reporter, a trade magazine that featured a photograph on its cover of the Hindenburg crashing, the noticeable bright spot was AOL Time Warner. "Silicon Alley's upper border is now Rockefeller Center," the magazine said in an article on the Silicon Alley top 100. The merger was Silicon Alley's "first significant step toward fulfilling its potential as the center of the new New Economy," the article continued.
Since the merger was completed on Jan. 11, AOL Time Warner has announced 2,000 layoffs, and company officials continue to stress that they are only bringing a relative handful of workers to New York.
Jeff Dachis, the president of Razorfish, an Internet consulting company based on Grand Street, said "the company's presence is being welcomed."
"It's like Seattle," he said. "Everybody knows about Microsoft, and they think you are probably near their campus, and that you probably have some ex-Microsoft executives running your company."
Charles Millard, a former Giuliani administration economic development chief, remembers having to convince people in the mid-1990's that Silicon Alley was not a typographical error. "To the extent that there has ever been doubt about New York's standing as an anchor in the digital world, I think that this is going to put it to rest," he said. "It has been a tough year. Something like this is helpful."
But whether or not AOL Time Warner proves good for the city, or Silicon Alley, not everyone was enthusiastic about its presence. Avner Ronen, president of Odigo, a Lower Manhattan company that has battled AOL over whether all instant-messaging program users should be able to communicate with one another, said: "Maybe now there is a chance of me running into one of AOL's people in the streets. But I find it hard to believe that being closer will make them any nicer. I don't expect them to change the way they act."

HEADLINE: Reagan Was a Reaganite 

BYLINE:  By David Brooks; David Brooks is a senior editor at The Weekly Standard.

 BODY:
 REAGAN, IN HIS
OWN HAND
The Writings of Ronald Reagan
That Reveal His Revolutionary Vision for America.
Edited by Kiron K. Skinner,
Annelise Anderson and Martin Anderson.
Foreword by George P. Shultz.
549 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $30.
 The Russian philosopher Nikolai Berdyaev once wrote, "It would be possible to determine two patterns, two types among men's souls, the one inclined toward the spirit of Tolstoy, the other toward that of Dostoyevsky." And isn't it amazing how that quotation reminds you of today's Republican Party? For among Republicans, too, there are two patterns, two types, the one inclined toward the spirit of Reagan, the other toward that of Bush.
The Reaganites had their formative experiences in secluded corners of college libraries, where they discovered Friedrich Hayek and Milton Friedman, Russell Kirk and Leo Strauss. For them politics is a battle of ideas. Liberal ideas -- like affirmative action and legal abortion -- are in error and must be disproved and replaced. Reaganites tend to work in think tanks, or wish they did. They care about long-ago disputes, like the guilt of Alger Hiss, because they want you to know not only that liberals are wrong now but also that they were always wrong. 
The Bushies, on the other hand, are more normal and more boring. They have neat desks and thin briefcases because their reading comes in the form of memos. They tend to work -- very hard, in fact -- in corporations, law firms and other large organizations, and regard themselves as master managers. They see politics as a competition of interests. They are good at striking deals. 
Reaganites and Bushies are both skeptical of government. The differences are in how they think, not what they think. The Bushies look at the Reaganites and see hapless geeks -- useful if you're in need of a speech, but certainly not the sort to be trusted with real responsibility. The Reaganites see the Bushies as hapless anal retentives. They may be good at playing the bureaucracy, but they don't know where they're going because they have no principles. They don't even know what an idea is. They say things like, "Our foreign policy should be in our national interest," and think they have expressed one. 
Since the Republican Party is a conservative, orderly party, the two camps take turns screwing up. Bushian pragmatists dominated the first Bush administration. They got so caught up in the 1990 budget process that they compromised on what were supposed to be their core principles and lost touch with the American people. So after Bush's defeat, the ideologues, led by Newt Gingrich and Dick Armey, took control of the party. But they were harsh, radical and uncompromising, so now Republicans are once again dominated by Bushianism. In selecting his cabinet, George W. Bush generally passed over provocative thinkers and people who give good interviews in favor of sober executives. This is an administration so corporate that the lone academic at the top level -- the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice -- sat on the board of Chevron and has an oil tanker named after her.
In the midst of this Bushian risorgimento comes a book to remind us of the differences between the two mental types. The book is called "Reagan, in His Own Hand," and it is mostly a collection of radio commentaries Ronald Reagan delivered between 1976 and 1980, between his failed primary challenge to Gerald Ford and his successful campaign against Jimmy Carter. During those years, Reagan returned to the rubber-chicken circuit, wrote a column and delivered these daily radio messages. Ghostwriters wrote the column, but Reagan actually worked on the radio commentaries himself. He'd sit on airplanes and in the back of cars, drafting piece after piece on legal pads, and would come back from a trip with three weeks of commentaries ready for typing. The dominant impression these drafts leave is that Reagan really was a Reaganite. He'd already been governor of California, but he still saw politics primarily as a battle of ideas. 
These are earnest policy sermons. Reagan covered everything from bilingual education to the Panama Canal to the political situation in Equatorial Guinea, engrossing himself in a level of detail that frankly surpasses that of almost all op-ed columnists today. In 1978, for example, he came across a speech the Yale law professor Eugene Rostow gave on the proposed SALT II arms control agreement. Reagan couldn't do just one radio commentary summarizing and commenting on Rostow's views. He did six, going through the arcana about mobile launchers, MIRV's, Minutemen versus MX missiles and so on.
Reagan was a middlebrow (and I mean that as a compliment). He believed in the serious explication of ideas. He'd troll through clippings from The Public Interest or National Review, or a policy document someone had sent him, and he'd want to bring it to his listeners' attention. Sometimes, caught up in didactic fervor, he'd get carried away. During a commentary on how tax indexing works, he declared: "A family of four earning $9,600 last year will have to get a $595 raise to keep even with the 6.2 percent inflation rate. So this year their income is $10,195. But that raise put them in a higher state tax bracket reducing their purchasing power by $70." Reagan must have understood that cramming all those numbers into three sentences makes for terrible radio. But he was eager to get the concept across. 
Unlike radio commentators or newspaper pundits today, he never responded to the news blip of the moment. He generally ignored political scandals; anyone looking for personal attacks on Jimmy Carter will come up empty. During a commentary on the capital gains tax rate, Reagan declared, "Frankly speaking the president was a little off base." That was as rough as he got.
The editors of this volume, Kiron K. Skinner, Annelise Anderson and Martin Anderson, have toted up the commentaries by subject matter. Twenty-seven percent of them were on foreign and defense policy, 25 percent were on economic policy, 15 percent were on regulation and individual liberty, 10 percent were on energy and the environment, and the like. As the editors note with some surprise, only 3 percent were on social issues, and only one commentary was on abortion. Judging from these pieces, Reagan was more of a policy wonk than a culture warrior. His abortion commentary is entirely secular. He says that until he was governor he'd never given the subject much thought. He declared that neither medicine nor law nor theology rendered a clear verdict. So he asked his lawyers if fetuses had property rights. If a pregnant woman became a widow and found that her husband had split his estate between her and the unborn child, Reagan wondered, could she abort the child and inherit all of the estate? On the basis of such questioning, Reagan decided that since fetuses had property rights, they must have rights to life. 
One of the things these commentaries do is blow apart the notion that Reagan was a flighty actor who floated through the presidency on the basis of charm and communication skills. Reagan spent the years leading up to his presidency -- the decades, really -- involved in day-to-day policy disputes. Another thought one can't escape is that George W. Bush could never have written these commentaries. It is impossible to imagine George W. sitting down and composing little essays on the inefficiency of Amtrak subsidies or the foolishness of the Law of the Sea treaty, as Reagan did. 
But that doesn't mean that Bush is stupider than Reagan, just that the Bush mind is of a different cast. Reagan must have been happiest reading National Review essays on cold war disputes. Bush is clearly happiest reading people. If anything, the Bush mentality is the more conservative, if by conservative you mean prudent, managerial and incremental.
IN fact, the great promise of the Bush administration -- and the early days of any administration are the season to dream -- is that he will finally reconcile the two mentalities. He is staffing his administration with people like Tommy Thompson and Donald Rumsfeld. Thompson is a legislative tactician, but he also pursued the long-range vision of welfare reform. Rumsfeld, an administrator and businessman, has latched on to missile defense. And in one respect Bush already does resemble a Reaganite. Once he gets a policy notion in his head, he sticks with it. Unlike most pragmatists, he doesn't overreact to the daily flow of events. If anything, he underreacts.
So maybe the two sides of the Republican brain can finally be brought into harmony. If that happens, the epic novel to describe the second Bush administration won't be "War and Peace" or "Crime and Punishment." It will be a love story called "Geeks and Golfers." But if it's longer than 200 pages, the Bushies won't read it.

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE; 
Changing TheWorld, From Top To Bottom

BYLINE:  By FRED ANDREWS 

 BODY:
IN their economic thinking, President Bush and Jeffrey E. Garten have much in common, an overlap that makes Mr. Garten's new book all the more timely.
 Both the president and Mr. Garten are firm believers in the private sector and free trade. But in "The Mind of the C.E.O." (Basic Books, $26) Mr. Garten has sketched a role for business leadership that goes far beyond what Republicans and business itself have traditionally accepted. 
 In this provocative but ultimately frustrating book, Mr. Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, asserts that big business must aggressively help to overhaul the world marketplace and apply its mind to global poverty and other plights. 
For some readers, Mr. Garten's vision will seem impractical and overreaching. For others, it will be a fair test of willingness by the Bush administration and its business allies to exercise creative leadership on the global scene.
Mr. Garten served President Clinton as undersecretary of commerce for international trade. Once an investment banker, he has high esteem for the chieftains of global business -- in his estimation, the elite of the corporate elite. 
"These are people who best understand the effects of change, technology, globalization," the dean writes. "They are the ones who know what it means to set concrete goals and meet them." 
He asks for a new way of thinking about business and society that recognizes the multinational corporation as a pivotal participant in society and politics.
His book was inspired by watching Jack Welch of General Electric, a spellbinder without equal, enchant an audience of Yale management students. A big conglomerate is like a big house, Mr. Welch counseled, each floor a layer of management, each wall separating one division from another. Toss in a grenade, the grandmaster urged, and obliterate all those barriers. 
Charmed by that wisdom, Mr. Garten took to the road to pick the brains of the most farsighted chief executives he could find. 
He compiled a list of 40, mostly but not exclusively chief executives. Almost all run (or advise or finance) huge multinational enterprises. Three lost their jobs before the book was published.
The impressive selection sparkles with innovative figures from the new global economy, pathfinders like Stephen M. Case of AOL Time Warner, Frederick W. Smith of FedEx, Jorma Ollila of Nokia, Richard Branson of Virgin and Stan Shih of Acer in Taiwan. 
Not that the old establishment was treated with disrespect. The Fab 40 also include Sir John Browne of BP Amoco, Dr. Rolf-Ernst Breuer of Deutsche Bank, Benson Ford of Ford Motor, Kenneth I. Chenault of American Express and Hiroshi Okuda of Toyota, plus James D. Wolfensohn of the World Bank and Susan V. Berresford of the Ford Foundation.
More precisely, the book is "The Mind of the C.E.O. Inside the Mind of Jeffrey E. Garten." He sets out to discover not only what chief executives think, but also what he thinks of what they think. 
Mr. Garten has a keen mind and a confident sense of global economic reality, and his detached assessments save the book from simply serving up the lofty words that eminent people often offer when placed on a pedestal and invited to opine. 
HE championed free trade in the first Clinton administration and now promotes a far more robust role for big business than either the Bush administration or big business itself shows any eagerness to embrace. He urges multinational leadership to take the lead in laying new foundations for the global marketplace, adding what he considers a much-needed layer of regulation and enforcement. Even more ambitiously, he wants big business to provide the leadership in global problem-solving on poverty, income extremes, dismal health services, epidemics, education inequality and other issues. 
A monthly columnist at Business Week, Mr. Garten writes cleanly and clearly. He sees the global economy as vastly promising but dangerously underregulated, lacking rules that mature national economies take for granted. And more broadly, he asks, how can global companies expect to prosper amid appalling poverty and angry nationalism?
He describes capitalism today as "less regulated and more ruthless" than it was four or five decades ago. The financier George Soros tells him that "the market" is wrongly seen as a pendulum, righting itself when swung to an extreme. In fact, Mr. Soros says, the financial markets have become a wrecking ball, knocking over one economy after another.
On reflection, Mr. Garten has concluded that trade policy in the Clinton era amounted to America throwing its weight around, eager not to level the playing field but to give it a good tilt in our direction. "I was definitely one of the culprits," he allows. Though trading partners are still sore from American bullying, all eyes remain on the United States as the great hope. 
Not a harsh word enters this book. Business school deans do not prosper by giving affront to corporate patrons. An admiring interviewer but hardly one with hat in hand, the dean found his hosts "uniformly thoughtful -- even philosophical," but also pragmatic and nonideological, not to mention down to earth and approachable. 
"They can be a progressive force in building capitalism around the world, or they can constitute a rear-guard action," he said. "However they behave, their influence will be at least as important as that of national governments and international organizations -- probably more so." 
For starters, Mr. Garten argues, elite multinational corporations must be less shy in backing the president when he fights their battles (as President Clinton did, unsuccessfully, on legislation to expedite Congressional approval of trade agreements). 
Mr. Garten sees opportunities as specific as helping to establish more business schools abroad and dispatching teams of accountants and regulatory experts to help design economies for tomorrow. 
And he marvels at the burdens carried by chief executives. Deluged by data, swimming in uncertainty, his immortals routinely place bold, multibillion-dollar bets with a fragment of the information they need. They survive by finding "simplicities that work -- following basic instincts, identifying first principles clearly and remaining true to them in good times and bad." Orit Gadiesh of Bain & Company calls that "finding true north" -- the character, consistency and principle that hold an organization together.
THIS is not to say that Mr. Garten is a patsy. Two-thirds of the way through the book, it becomes clear that he is gravely doubtful that the corporate elite will rise to his challenge. As coolly as a scholar discoursing over a favorite merlot, he lays out exactly why he expects to be disappointed. Ultimately, the dean is profoundly critical of the chief executives, but his book does not so much hold their feet to the fire as it warms their tootsies. 
His chief executives would rather fly coach to Australia than pick up the gauntlet. Though they have to maintain a certain stance, the last thing they want is still another responsibility on an alien playing field. They dread being caught in the trench warfare of politics. 
In tough times, statesmanship becomes an indulgence. "Unless you are competitive, then all other issues are moot," says C. Michael Armstrong of AT&T.
So a gulf persists between talking the talk and walking the walk. Mr. Garten is fully aware that many critics speak in much harsher terms than he does. "The upshot," he says, "is that C.E.O.'s need to get in front of movements they see coming, rather than always fighting a rear-guard action."
He concedes that many people already believe that big business has bought and paid for too much sway in Washington. Much of the world has experienced big business mainly as an oppressor. Under enlightened leadership, multinational corporations have nevertheless committed high crimes and misdemeanors. Acknowledging all that, Mr. Garten warns them that active or passive, they are targets of the growing backlash against corporate globalism. 
In a chapter called "Reflections," he concludes that history will judge today's renowned chief executives lukewarmly, as competent but overwhelmed, smothered by pressures "much greater than anything these individuals could handle well." It is disappointing that the dean's self-rebuttal is more persuasive than his visionary agenda.

LENGTH: 1083 words

HEADLINE: The World; 
The General Picks Up Where He Left Off

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
SECRETARY OF STATE COLIN L. POWELL is beginning his days in office with the same problem he left behind eight years ago: Saddam Hussein. But now, instead of reeling from the general's war during the first Bush administration, Mr. Hussein seems more and more in the driver's seat. He's been cockily inviting all and sundry to fly into his newly refurbished Baghdad airport, sending emissaries abroad, emboldening Palestinians by moving troops around, and soaking up hard currency from smuggled oil as sanctions lose nearly all international support.
 For the new Bush team, Mr. Hussein's burst out of isolation is a serious -- and embarrassing -- crisis in the making. Increasingly, the situation looks less like a standoff with Mr. Hussein and more as if Mr. Hussein has attained the upper hand. Already Iraq is forcing the Bush administration to step back from campaign statements about getting tougher with Mr. Hussein, and even of taking him on. Instead, General Powell is proposing what amounts to a realist's narrowing of American goals and a recognition that maintaining full sanctions and restoring United Nations arms inspections are lost causes. 
 The new strategy General Powell is devising would focus on enforcing narrower sanctions rather than on seeking a military overthrow. (There is a historical parallel in this: In the months leading up to the fighting in the gulf in 1991, the general was the most eager of the national security team to keep sanctions as the main pressure on Mr. Hussein, and one of the most reluctant to go to war to push Iraq's troops out of Kuwait.) 
The new administration has little choice but to revise Iraqi policy, which remained virtually dormant in the last two years of the Clinton administration, once United Nations inspectors were forced to withdraw in 1998. Even Britain, Washington's closest ally on Iraq, is now conducting a review of its policy. In part, British officials have grown weary of the burden on its military of the bombing flights it shares with the United States to enforce the no-fly zone in southern Iraq. Also, the British can see the stampede at the United Nations, where three of the five permanent Security Council members -- France, Russia and China -- as well as many Arab and Asian countries are pressing to eliminate sanctions so they can resume full business ties with Iraq. 
Judging by his Senate confirmation hearing, General Powell has the contours of his approach worked out: Go to the old coalition partners in the Gulf and persuade them that they -- not the United States -- are most threatened by Mr. Hussein's efforts to develop weapons of mass destruction. So they should agree, the general argues, to enforce sanctions -- but in a narrower but tighter form, this time focusing on military equipment and dual use items that Mr. Hussein can use for weapons production. That new formula would allow General Powell to loosen up the flow of consumer goods so that the Iraqi people emerge from being the chief victims of the West's sanctions. But General Powell still wants the United Nations to keep tight control of the money, now in an escrow account, that Mr. Hussein receives from his oil exports. 
Stressing the strong personal ties that he has among leaders in the gulf countries, General Powell offered the senators a preview of the argument he will carry to the gulf's leaders: "You'd better see it as you that is at the other end of these missiles."
IMPLICIT, though not yet firmly stated, in General Powell's arguments is that he will visit the major Arab countries, most likely Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, and cash in some of the personal chits he earned during the gulf war. The 10th anniversary of victory in the gulf is next month and the Kuwaitis have asked everyone, especially General Powell, to come. But his task may not be as easy as he might want. These leaders remain frightened by the anti-American sentiments their people are expressing based on the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza. 
Also implicit in General Powell's strategy is giving up on the hope that United Nations inspectors will get back into Iraq. How the administration would finesse this loss of face remains to be seen. And how the embargo on military and dual use items would be enforced is not quite clear either.
"United Nations inspectors should not be the focus of American policy because it is unlikely to happen and because by focusing on that we would lose the chance to modernize the sanctions regime," said Meghan O'Sullivan, a fellow at the Brookings Institution who specializes in sanctions policy. One obvious way to check imports of military material is to mandate inspections of the increasing number of flights that are going into Baghdad, Ms. O'Sullivan said. Another possibility under study is to post inspectors at key border points.
A hard-line wing of the Bush administration has been pushing to get more money and weapons to the Iraqi opposition in exile. For now, at least, this does not seem the preferred option. Paul D. Wolfowitz, who is slated to become deputy secretary of defense, and others say the Clinton administration was half-hearted in its support of the Iraqi opposition and favor beefing it up now. But General Powell, during his hearings, said with a skeptical tone that a requirement for such a plan is a "sound basis for believing that people could be successful once they go onto Iraqi territory."
Some experts see the Powell approach as minimalist but achievable. "All Bush can do at this point is to maintain consensus on blocking the sale of war materiel to Iraq," Graham E. Fuller, a former vice chairman of the National Intelligence Council at the Central Intelligence Agency, said recently. "The bad news is that it is probably too late for the new administration to effect genuine change in Iraq at a price the United States is willing to pay." 
Despite facing Mr. Hussein again, the general is still anxious to justify the decision he helped make at the end of the gulf war to leave the Iraqi leader in place. "Mr. Saddam Hussein can put a hat on his head and shoot a rifle in the air at an Army Day parade," General Powell told the senators, "but it is fundamentally a broken, weak country -- one-third the military force it had some 10 years ago. We really did what we said we were going to do with Desert Storm -- bring them down to size."
But that was then. The question for today is whether even a shrunken Iraqi threat is too much to tolerate with any degree of comfort.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Et Tu, Alan?

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Despite his legendary obscurity, what Alan Greenspan has to say is usually quite clear and intellectually coherent once translated into English. But his testimony last Thursday before the Senate Budget Committee was evasive and often inconsistent. It was hard to avoid the impression that Mr. Greenspan's intent was to give aid and comfort to the new administration, while retaining plausible deniability.
 True, Mr. Greenspan explicitly rejected the administration's argument that we must immediately cut taxes to prevent a recession. While conceding that the economy may grow little if at all this quarter, he suggested that a recovery would probably be under way before tax cuts could have any impact. By the way, new evidence suggests that manufacturing, which suffered a nasty downturn in the last few months, has already started to rebound. 
 Nonetheless, the headlines were all about Mr. Greenspan's endorsement of tax cuts -- something the Fed chairman must have known would happen. And when you look at the tortured logic by which Mr. Greenspan arrived at that endorsement, you have to wonder whether those headlines weren't exactly what he wanted. 
His argument went as follows: given its projected surpluses over the next decade, the federal government may not only pay off its debt, but actually find itself using surplus cash to buy private assets. This could cause problems, he suggested, because it would be "difficult to insulate the government's investment decisions from political pressures." So we should engage in "pre-emptive smoothing of the glide path," which turns out to mean cutting taxes enough so that the federal government never does pay off its debt, after all.
Now I would quarrel with those surplus projections. I would also point out that in declaring "it is far better . . . that the surpluses be lowered by tax reductions than by spending increases," Mr. Greenspan was out of bounds. Since when is it the Fed's business to say that we should have a tax cut rather than, say, a new prescription drug benefit -- or for that matter a missile defense system? (Neither program is factored into those surplus projections.) Mr. Greenspan himself seemed aware that he was on shaky ground, offering the very inadequate excuse that "I speak for myself and not necessarily for the Federal Reserve." 
But the really strange thing about his argument was that he seemed to ignore the fact that the main reason the federal government will one day become an investor is the buildup of assets in the hands of the Social Security and Medicare systems -- and those funds must accumulate assets to prepare for the future demands of the baby-boom generation. Indeed, by all estimates even the huge projected surpluses of those trust funds will be inadequate to the task. "Certainly," Mr. Greenspan declared, "we should make sure that Social Security surpluses are large enough to meet our long-term needs." Well, I'm sorry, but you can't do that without allowing the federal government to become an investor.
So if that prospect was what was really worrying Mr. Greenspan, he should have focused on the problem of how to prevent the government's position as an investor from being abused. And there are many ways to do that -- including, by the way, realistic plans for partial privatization of Social Security, which (unlike the fantasy promises of the Bush campaign) would require the federal government to ante up trillions of dollars to pay off existing obligations, solving the "problem" of excessive surpluses quite easily.
But Mr. Greenspan seemed determined to arrive at tax cuts as an answer. After dismissing the argument that we need a tax cut to fend off a recession now, and conceding that tax cuts have historically "proved difficult to implement in the time frame in which recessions have developed and ended," he waffled: "Should current economic weakness spread beyond what now seems likely, having a tax cut in place may, in fact, do noticeable good." But by the same token, if the economy is strong again by the time a tax cut goes into effect, won't that tax cut do noticeable harm? Mr. Greenspan declined to answer questions along those lines.
When a man who is usually a clear thinker ties himself in intellectual knots in order to find a way to say exactly what the new president wants to hear, it's not hard to guess what's going on. But it's not a pretty sight.

HEADLINE: Nation Awash in Ideas For Changing Voting 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 

 BODY:
Next week, an art design course will be offered at the University of Massachusetts in which students will study the infamous "butterfly ballot" that confused voters in Palm Beach, Fla. In California, a hastily organized trade show of voting-machine manufacturers proved so popular that the state is planning a second. And here in Washington, state elections officials will gather next week to recommend changes in voting.
 "There's an enormous amount of activity out there," said Kimball Brace, an elections expert with Election Data Services, a Washington company that specializes in election administration and redistricting. 
 "Nobody wants to be the next Palm Beach," Mr. Brace said.
As a result of the disputed presidential election and its messy aftermath in Florida, the nation -- Congress, local governments, industry and academia -- seems awash in proposals to change election laws. Even President Bush gave change a nod last week, albeit privately to leaders of Congress, which will consider the first serious overhaul of federal voting procedures in decades.
Ideas include changing Election Day to a weekend or making it a federal holiday, closing polls at the same time across the country, allowing voter registration on Election Day and requiring that machines give voters receipts.
Constitutional amendments have been proposed to apportion electoral votes based on the popular vote in Congressional districts and to abolish the Electoral College. 
Bills would provide millions of dollars to local governments to upgrade their voting equipment. Companies are suddenly in fierce competition to produce modern voting systems, not normally a lucrative field but now potentially a multibillion-dollar market. The projected cost of installing new equipment -- four electronic machines, each costing $5,000, in each of the nation's 191,000 voting precincts -- is nearly $4 billion.
With interest in changes so high, the money potentially available is ballooning. One of the leading Senate bills, co-sponsored by Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, started by proposing $250 million in matching grants to local governments for one year. The proposal has evolved to at least $250 million in matching grants every year for five years -- to $1.25 billion -- and could spiral even higher.
The potential market leaves manufacturers wide-eyed. In California, the secretary of state's office, which oversees elections, recently co-sponsored a trade show, "Election Technology Expo 2001," in Sacramento. Organized in just two weeks, the show drew 40 voting equipment companies and 400 election officials from 14 states.
Microsoft, Unisys and the Dell Computer Corporation are uniting to produce and market new election systems that cover the gamut of election processes, from voter registration to reporting results.
Although the voting machine business in the United States has been slack, several companies made advances as they upgraded equipment for other countries. Unisys, for example, installed electronic systems in Brazil, Italy and Costa Rica that featured touch-pad voting and instant reporting of results.
Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting, which helped organize the 1999 elections in South Africa, with computers and satellites, will demonstrate its wares on Capitol Hill on Tuesday.
Other major corporations, including I.B.M., Compaq, Cisco Systems and Diebold Inc., are considering entering the field.
"We've pushed a lot of countries around the world to have democracy and open elections, and when we can't conduct an election efficiently and accurately ourselves, it chides us, it's humbling," Senator Brownback said.
Only 9 percent of Americans vote with electronic equipment. New voting systems must be certified because of concern about glitches as they move from the laboratory to the real world.
"The equipment is out there, and it works great -- if there are no voters and no candidates," said Thomas Palfrey, a professor of political science and economics at the California Institute of Technology. Caltech is teaming up with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to evaluate technology and propose solutions.
Surely the butterfly ballot is headed for the dustbin, as graphic designers study it as a model of how not to impart information.
"This was design run amok," said Copper Giloth, an associate art professor at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, who, with Ana-Maria Campos, is using the confusing ballot to help teach Art 297h.
Last week, even President Bush indicated his assent to looking at the system.
"He's open to ideas," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's press secretary. 
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, announced that the House would appoint a special committee to examine voting proposals. He said he expected the committee to make recommendations in six to eight months.
Even as many focus on high-technology solutions, elections experts caution that these are not necessarily the best way to avoid the problems that became evident last year. They say that less glamorous responses, such as training election workers and refining election law, are essential.
"Everyone who is focused on this -- everyone except elections administrators -- is looking for simple solutions," said Doug Lewis, executive director of The Elections Center, a nonpartisan group in Houston that seeks to improve elections.
"While technology is important, it really is tangential to what happened last year," he said. "In Florida, you had a lack of definition as to what constitutes a vote and no appropriate recount procedure. If you fix those two problems in law or administrative rulings, you solve 90 percent of the issues."
Overhauling the system will take time, and it is not clear whether a new system can be in place by the 2002 elections for Congress.
"It is very complex," Mr. Brace, of Election Data Services, said. "We have to train poll workers, and we have to train the voters. If they were confused with the punch card, wait till they get into this new stuff."

HEADLINE: Forum in Switzerland Focuses on U.S. Economic Slowdown 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 27 

 BODY:
The slowdown in the American economy will cut the global growth rate but will probably not drag the world into recession, a top International Monetary Fund official told world business and political leaders at an annual economic forum here today. 
 The I.M.F.'s deputy director, Stanley Fischer, said the slowdown was causing the fund to predict that growth in the global economy would be considerably lower, "possibly in the range of 3.5 percent." That was scaled back from its prediction of 4.2 percent in September. 
 But, he said, "we are a long way from a global recession."
Mr. Fischer praised the decision by the American Federal Reserve to cut interest rates and said the prospects of further cuts would help speed the United States through its decline. The Bush administration's plans for a tax cut, he added, could help as well if Congress passes it quickly; otherwise the impact will be more over the long term. 
He warned that the slowdown in the United States could have a particularly bad effect on Japan's efforts to pull itself out of a decade of economic trouble, as it might slice into demand for Japanese electronic products. 
But the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, took a strong stand against such pessimism and assured the gathering that his country's economic rebound was nearly complete.
"A path has already been solidly laid," he said, adding that it "will lead the Japanese economy to a full recovery."
As the discussions took place, the protests that have been a constant at world finance meetings in recent years returned. Police officers turned water cannons on about 150 chanting and singing demonstrators when they refused to disperse about half a mile away. "Money, power, profit destroys our world," read one protest banner. 
The demonstrations here were smaller than expected, in part because about 600 protesters were prevented from reaching Davos, and instead clashed with the police in Landquart, 25 miles away. The police there said they had fired tear gas and rubber pellets after some of the demonstrators attacked security personnel with sticks. 
Also at the forum today, Bill Gates, Microsoft's founder, pledged $100 million to a private foundation seeking vaccines against H.I.V. The donation to the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative was made via his Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

HEADLINE: BUSH'S TRANSITION LARGELY A SUCCESS, ALL SIDES SUGGEST 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 

 BODY:
As President Bush completes his first week in office, prominent Republicans and even many Democrats agree that he has presided over one of the most orderly and politically nimble White House transitions in at least 20 years.
 If the first days offer any clue, they say, Mr. Bush may avoid the kind of stumbles that disrupted the early days of past presidents and hobbled them as they tried to turn their campaign promises into action. 
 Independent academics and analysts as well as politicians in both parties said Mr. Bush had carefully calibrated his legislative offering this week by introducing his education package in a way that made it palatable to many Democrats, even as he reassured conservatives by moving to prohibit federal aid to groups that counsel on abortion overseas. 
They said that Mr. Bush displayed a deft touch in stroking lawmakers, and that his aides have been surprisingly responsive to members of Congress at a time when previous administrations would still be skirmishing over office space.
And next week, Mr. Bush will lay out a carefully planned agenda to help the neediest Americans through religious organizations. He also plans to unveil part of his prescription drug program.
"We were all raised by mothers who told us we had one chance to make a first impression," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, echoing many of his colleagues. "The first few days are certainly encouraging. And a first impression can last you awhile." 
In an unexpected turn that was not of Mr. Bush's making, the new president was helped immensely on Thursday when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, validated the thrust of his economic program in Congressional testimony.
"Talk about a windfall, he got a gigantic break with Greenspan's testimony," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat. "Why God is so good to Republicans is beyond me."
Mr. Bush's success is partly the result of his aides' intensely examining previous transitions, scouring the historical record for gestures and timetables -- and even interviewing important players from past administrations.
For all the respectful reviews, the new administration is barely in its infancy and its political execution has not been flawless. Mr. Bush's selection of former Senator John Ashcroft as attorney general enraged Democrats and many interest groups, who criticized Mr. Ashcroft as too conservative. Though Mr. Ashcroft is expected to be confirmed, even many Republicans questioned why Mr. Bush picked a fight with Democrats still smarting from his excruciatingly close victory.
"There are missteps that will haunt him," said Richard B. Shenkman, a presidential historian. "He campaigned as a uniter, not a divider, then he goes ahead with the Ashcroft nomination."
And while Mr. Bush's move on his first full day in office to deny aid to overseas groups that provide abortion counseling was celebrated by conservatives, it distracted from his theme of the week, education. (One White House official said the move was deliberate, because if Mr. Bush had not acted "there would have been a rising chorus from the right.")
Another reality, if no surprise, is that Mr. Bush has not tackled many of the most nettlesome issues. And with one ill-considered remark or misstep, the successful efforts by the president thus far could unravel.
But when Mr. Bush did run into trouble by selecting Linda Chavez as labor secretary, he moved quickly to accept her withdrawal and selected Elaine L. Chao, who is likely to be confirmed by the Senate next week.
Despite his misgivings, Mr. Shenkman said that over all this transition has been the smoothest since Ronald Reagan arrived here two decades ago. "Hats off to George W.," he said.
White House officials said they began painstaking preparations for the first two weeks of the new presidency immediately after New Year's and had a day-by-day plan in place by Jan. 8.
In a demonstration of the importance Mr. Bush's aides placed on his debut, Karl Rove, the president's senior adviser, said that in December, the staff drafted detailed briefing books on the beginning of every administration since John F. Kennedy's. The books included such facts as how many members of Congress each president met with his first week in office, what time the president and his staff reported to work, when he took his first domestic and foreign trips and when he announced legislative initiatives.
"It's important to strike the right starting note," Mr. Rove said. "Time is precious."
White House officials said they were most impressed by Mr. Reagan's transition, and they met with several officials from that White House, including Edwin Meese III, who was the attorney general; Michael K. Deaver, Mr. Reagan's image adviser; and Richard Wirthlin, a pollster and strategist.
While some experts said Mr. Bush had faced an even more difficult challenge than his predecessors because the five-week post-election stalemate limited the time he had to prepare -- a point the new administration has made time and again -- many others asserted that Mr. Bush actually benefited from the truncated timetable.
That is because with the focus in the press on the electoral dispute, Mr. Bush and his advisers could work quietly behind the scenes assembling a staff. They were spared the fate of Bill Clinton and other incoming presidents who for months found that their deliberations were subjected to speculative, and often damaging, coverage.
"In a weird way, the transition following one of the most turbulent and contested elections in history just didn't draw the same level of media glare as either the Bush transition or the Reagan transition," said Ralph Reed, a Republican strategist who is close to the White House, referring to two of the president's predecessors. "And that worked to the Bush team's benefit."
White House officials said they were determined to move swiftly and boasted that they tied the record of President Franklin D. Roosevelt of having six cabinet appointees confirmed and sworn in on the first day.
Officials also said that Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff, directed the staff to focus on the smaller touches, like the importance of senior staff members' returning one another's telephone calls as well as calls from members of Congress. They said he also set an example by incessantly writing thank-you cards to people with whom he met with the first week.
This attention to detail impressed some lawmakers in this city of egos, who said they were pleased to get their calls returned by Mr. Card and other top officials who barely knew their new telephone numbers. "A quick response on calls may not seem like a lot," Senator Dodd said, "but it is."
Mr. Bush also placed significant emphasis on meeting with members of Congress.
"I guess the biggest, most pleasant surprise, if you'd call it that, was how receptive members of Congress are to come here to the White House to talk about how we can work together," Mr. Bush said on Friday. "I think we've met with 90 members of Congress here in the first week." About a third of them were Democrats.
White House officials and advisers said Mr. Bush would lay out proposals next week for helping the needy. On Monday, they said, he will announce the opening of an administration office to promote the further integration of faith-based organizations into federally financed social services.
Officials are also likely to announce a national advisory board on the subject. Stephen Goldsmith, the former mayor of Indianapolis who was the Bush campaign's chief domestic policy adviser, will have a leading role in this broad effort, they said.
As the week progresses, the officials said, Mr. Bush will meet at the White House with a variety of religious leaders and heads of not-for-profit charities. He is also expected to unveil proposals including changes in tax deductions that encourage people to give more money to religious and not-for-profit organizations.
Aides said that Mr. Bush would also propose a part of his prescription drug program that deals with an immediate mechanism to get prescription drugs to poor Americans in the interim before there are changes in Medicare to make them available to everyone.
By contrast, Mr. Clinton's transition eight years ago was especially sloppy. In his first days, he found himself mired in a firestorm over gays in the military, an issue that plagued his first term. He was also distracted by severe difficulties in settling on appointees, like an attorney general.
A top aide to Mr. Clinton said of the new president: "It's hard walking into the place on Day 1 and pulling it off. They did a lot better than we did. It's pretty impressive."
Four years before Mr. Clinton took office, President George Bush acknowledged at the end of his first week that there had been "ripples" of trouble. He was less aggressive than his son has been in pressing forward on an agenda. And there were flare-ups over how his administration planned to handle the savings and loan debacle, and over the abortion views of Mr. Bush's choice to run the department of health and human services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan.
John H. Sununu, who was then the White House chief of staff, said at the time, "Probably the most important thing we did not do well was that we could have had more discipline in the packaging of the message."
In 1980, Ronald Reagan won plaudits for a relatively peaceful transition, but even he found himself under attack in the first week from conservatives who objected to his selection of appointees whom they did not deem sufficiently conservative, like Donald T. Regan as secretary of the treasury and Samuel R. Pierce Jr. as housing secretary.
But in Mr. Reagan's first days, there was nothing like the turmoil of Jimmy Carter's debut, when there were huge public fights between the campaign staff and a separate operation designed to run the transition.
"Most White Houses are lucky if they get the furniture in," said Patrick H. Caddell, who was Mr. Carter's pollster. Referring to the Carter transition, he said: "There was disarray. We were still learning. And Clinton blew it all in the first week. He drove his numbers to the ground in the immediate transition. George Bush and his people seem to know everybody. They all look like they've been in the same club before. So he's got momentum going for him."
Most of all, politicians gave credit to Mr. Bush for surrounding himself with advisers and aides who have vast Washington experience, beginning with the vice president, Dick Cheney, who was chief of staff for former President Gerald R. Ford, a member of the House and, later, a secretary of defense. Mr. Card was a deputy chief of staff for Mr. Bush's father.
"President Bush has put together a pretty seasoned team around him -- if you add their years in Washington, you get a century's worth of experience," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat. "So his first few days in office have been largely free from controversy."
Although Mr. Bush has benefited from seasoned Washington hands, White House aides said that the officials who had the largest role in stage-managing the agenda for his first days were two of the president's confidants from Texas: Mr. Rove, who developed the central strategy, and Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's counselor, who was responsible for message development.
Robert M. Teeter, who ran the elder President Bush's transition, also praised the new president for skillfully playing on low expectations for his debut.
"If you go out and make a lot of overblown assertions about what you're going to do," Mr. Teeter said, "you're just setting yourself up."

HEADLINE: Experts Try to Make Missile Shield Plan Palatable to China 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 27 

 BODY:
With President Bush dead set on building a national missile defense, American and Chinese military experts have begun exploring ways to make such a shield more palatable to China and say a compromise, though extremely difficult, might be possible. 
 American plans for a missile shield have stirred opposition in capitals across the globe, but China's resistance may be the most intractable. If the Bush administration does push ahead with its plans -- and it has given every sign that it will -- China's objections loom as a stiff foreign policy challenge. 
 A way out of the impasse might be found, military experts say, but it will require near-heretical political steps by leaders in Washington and Beijing. Without some accommodation, experts and Chinese officials warn, the American shield could poison relations, set off a dangerous arms race across Asia and even raise the chances of a war. 
Up to now, American officials have said the proposed defenses are intended to counter only smaller powers like Iran and North Korea while offering little more than assurances that a missile shield is not aimed at stifling China. 
But Chinese leaders are acutely aware that any working system may effectively neutralize their bantam nuclear forces and fear it will subject them to potential American bullying, particularly regarding Taiwan. They have uttered shrill denunciations of the American plan and refused to discuss their own plans to expand their nuclear arsenal. 
Now, experts from both countries say, as it has become clear that a new American administration is determined to press ahead with a missile shield, new thinking is required. 
"If the American intention is to use this system to defend against China, then I can't see any room for compromise," said Li Bin, a nuclear physicist and arms control expert at Qinghua University who advises the government. "But if they really are just worried about the so-called rogue states, and they aren't trying to undermine China's deterrent," he said, "then it may be possible in principle to reach agreement." 
An unofficial group of private American military experts visited Beijing recently to discuss the issue with Chinese officials and scholars. 
The Chinese officials listened to proposals for compromise, according to some who attended, but did not endorse them and mainly restated Beijing's opposition to the American plan, while the interest of scholars outside the government was more obviously piqued. But the fact that Chinese authorities attended and allowed such meetings to take place at all indicated their strong desire to find a way for their concerns to be taken into account. 
"We wanted to help the Chinese understand more clearly that the missile-defense train has already left the station," said Bates Gill, an arms expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington who was part of the visiting American group. "They can try to engage in a serious dialogue with the United States, or they can keep their heads in the sand as important decisions get made."
Military experts on both sides of the Pacific say the ideas they discussed would require the American president to place clear limits on the size of the shield and -- risking sharp divisions in the Republican Party and Congress -- to acknowledge China's stature as a nuclear power. The Americans would have to agree, implicitly at least, that China could preserve a capacity to hit back at the United States with at least a few nuclear bombs, even after suffering a surprise American attack. That would require that the United States accept a Chinese arsenal just large enough to outnumber any proposed defense. 
The Chinese, these experts say, would have to move beyond their reflexive condemnations and relax the hypersecrecy that has surrounded their weapons program, allowing the United States a clearer idea of the size and capability of their arsenal. They would have to convince American planners that any nuclear buildup would go only so far and would be keyed to the size of the American shield, allowing China to keep something resembling the minimal capacity for a counterattack that it has had in the past but not fundamentally altering the balance. 
The immediate goal would not necessarily be a treaty, like those the United States negotiated with the much more powerful Soviet Union to stabilize the arms race, which openly endorsed a balance of terror. 
Rather, the two countries could begin by seeking a more private and informal "strategic understanding" about the expected size of the shield, as well as the number and kinds of offensive weapons China planned to develop, Mr. Gill said. 
A serious concern, he said, is that if the American shield develops without a dialogue, then hard-liners on each side who describe "worst case" threats will be strengthened, promoting tensions and a race between offensive and defensive weapons. 
James Mulvenon, an expert on the Chinese military at the Rand Corporation who was also part of the discussions, said, "Even if China doubled or tripled its strategic nuclear forces, it would not affect the strategic balance between China and the United States, as Washington would still possess an overwhelming advantage." 
The real worry, he said, is that an arms race would seriously erode relations, and that China might supply missiles or countermeasures to the very countries a missile shield was intended to defend against. 
Even American allies are nervous about the antimissile plan because it raises the specter of the United States' shrinking from their defense. But in the end, proponents say, they will have little choice but to join in the defense plan or live with it. In any case, a shield may not be in place for a few years, until the technology is better tested and the Bush administration decides on exactly what kind of system to build.
The Russians have been hotly opposed because it may put them at a military disadvantage and upend the bilateral Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. They may never be pleased about this symbol of American technological superiority, experts say. But Russia, like the United States, retains thousands of long-range nuclear weapons -- enough to overwhelm any foreseeable defense. 
China's opposition, however, is probably the most stringent of all, and the hardest to argue away. In the 1960's, when it first developed nuclear weapons, China knew that it could not hope to compete with the United States and Russia and adopted a strategy of "minimal deterrence." Instead of matching missile forces in a costly arms race, China developed a small force under the assumption it could ride out a nuclear attack, then still hit an enemy city with a few bombs -- enough to make any opponent think twice. 
Today, China is believed to harbor fewer than two dozen long-range nuclear missiles, based in silos. As these are increasingly outdated and vulnerable, China is developing new, movable and more accurate missiles, but has never said how many it plans to build. 
Even the limited missile defense discussed by President Clinton involved 100 interceptors, enough to knock down at least 25 incoming weapons -- theoretically at least since no workable defense has ever been built. President Bush's advisers have spoken of larger scale defenses. 
In any case, "what China worries about is losing its deterrent capability," said Yan Xuetong, director of the Institute of International Affairs at Qinghua University. 
Mr. Yan said that given the political climate in Washington, he doubted whether the American president would be able to forgo the drive, urged by some hawks, to gain advantage over China. He gave some broader reasons for China's fear of the antimissile plan. 
"The United States says this is a defensive system, but everyone knows it will be used to strengthen your offensive capability," he said. "It protects your troops so you can attack any time without fear of retribution." 
"If the United States feels 100 percent secure, it may believe it doesn't need to worry about a third world war," Mr. Yan said. "This will make the American military too brave, and that will be very, very dangerous for everyone."
The more the United States is emboldened militarily, he added, the more pro-independence forces in Taiwan, too, may be encouraged to act. This could force Beijing to take drastic measures and lead to war. 
Mr. Li, the arms expert, also wondered about Washington's motives and how they would be reflected in the design of a missile shield. 
"If the United States is just worried about rogue states, it doesn't need a big defense system," Mr. Li said. "But in practice, the promoters of the missile defense want a large one, and they don't like the idea of constraining it." And while the United States says a national defense is intended for maverick states, in reality it could be used against anyone, and its size increased at any time. 
If the United States wants to reassure China, Mr. Li said, then it should limit the number of interceptors and the scale and quality of the radars and other missile-detection systems, ensuring that the system can be used only against a few missiles from a smaller power. 
"An arms race would be very bad for China," Mr. Li said. "Our priority is economic development." While China is already developing new, improved missiles, he said, "American missile defenses may force China to take a very different path."
China, he said, would definitely have to consider simple countermeasures like decoys, a large increase in the number of missiles or, perhaps most destabilizing of all, putting multiple warheads on each missile. 
Multiple-warhead missiles would add special new dangers, American and Chinese strategic experts agree. Because China would still have comparatively few missiles, the multiple warheads would make each a more tempting target for an enemy. This, in turn, could make China quicker to launch them if it feared they might be destroyed first. 
While there is no guarantee that China will not eventually deploy such missiles anyway, many experts here say that they hope to avoid it and that it does not fit well with China's overall strategy. 
Mr. Gill, the American expert, said he could give the Chinese no guarantee that President Bush would have the desire and political strength to openly legitimize China's nuclear deterrent. "But this will be much more likely," he said, trying to nudge the Chinese, "if a serious strategic dialogue gets under way."

HEADLINE: Our Fragile Ecosystems 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 An oil spill in the Galapagos; an energy crisis in California; and global warming accelerating (news articles, Jan. 22, 23 and 25). Common to all is our dependence on fossil fuels: their extraction, mining, refining, transport and combustion. 
 From fragile ecosystems to choking cities, oil and coal play profoundly destructive roles. Today, the ocean is warming, ice is melting and water vapor is rising. How many disasters will it take before we adopt energy conservation policies that use clean energy sources? The proper incentives could make the energy conversion a boon to the global economy.

PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D.
Boston, Jan. 25, 2001

The writer is associate director, Center for Health and the Global Environment, Harvard Medical School.
