HEADLINE: Dartmouth and Town Reel In Wake of Double Killing 

BYLINE:  By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 29 

 BODY:
Dartmouth College grappled today with grief and fear and uncertainty in the wake of the murder of two widely beloved professors, Half and Susanne Zantop, a German emigre couple found dead in their home on Saturday night.
 Normally, Dartmouth, an Ivy League college with about 5,500 students set in rural New Hampshire, is "a place where people have a sense of confidence, of optimism, of security," James Wright, the college's president, said today. "An event such as this shatters for many that sense of confidence, of optimism, and of security." 
 And it is hard to grieve, Mr. Wright said, with so many questions unanswered. 
The Zantops were killed not on campus but in their contemporary style house about four miles away in the town of Etna, a wooded hilly spot of old barns and stone walls. 
But it was on the campus where the murders' aftermath was most visible, in widespread mourning and speculation and added security.
"I'm from a big city where tons of people get killed every week and no one really cares," said Jourdan Abel, a sophomore from Miami. "But there's this feeling that this is the perfect school, the perfect town, no one locks their door. It's like something has disturbed our perfectness."
"Yesterday my roommates and I locked the door while we were in our room," Ms. Abel said. "That's definitely a new thing." 
The authorities said today that they had advised Dartmouth that there was no specific reason to believe students were in danger and that it did not need to increase its security. They would not say how the Zantops had been killed but said the crime had been ruled a double homicide. 
The college has taken several reassuring measures, however, including offering rides to students 24 hours a day instead of just at night and increasing the visibility of its safety and security staff. 
Asked today why a killer on the loose was not considered a threat to the public, Kelly Ayotte, the chief of the homicide unit of the New Hampshire attorney general's office, repeated to reporters that there was no "specific information at this point to believe there is a current threat to public safety."
"There is no reason for there to be panic in the public right now," Ms. Ayotte said.
She declined to comment on the investigation, saying only that it was making progress, as 30 investigators worked on it full time.
Such silence is frustrating to some: "I think they're doing all they can," said Amanda Behm, a freshman. "But it feels like they don't have very much information and I know they don't have much, but I want to know -- is it over? Are we still in danger?"
Ms. Behm's mother sent her an e-mail message, she said, asking, "What is going on? I thought you were safe in this town." 
Colleagues and friends described the Zantops, who had two adult daughters living in other states, as an exceptionally active and generous couple, both socially and academically. Susanne Zantop, 55, was the chairwoman of the German department; she had also taught comparative literature and was the parents' distinguished research professor in the humanities. Half Zantop, 62, was a specialist in economic geology, and had been a professor in the earth sciences department since 1976. 
Both Zantops were known for helping colleagues and students and for keeping the doors of their house open to friends and acquaintances.
The Zantops "were really both remarkable people," said Bruce Duncan, a professor of German studies. "They were generous and open and very international in focus. They tended to reach out to a wide variety of people."
Susannah Heschel, head of Jewish studies at Dartmouth, said that she and many others were too shocked to speculate about who had killed the Zantops. "People are crying and people are in shock and people are in denial. I have a feeling that they are on a trip and they are going to come back and tell us about their adventure," Ms. Heschel said.
For those trying to understand the crime, however, one area of speculation has revolved around the question of whether the Zantops might have been repaid for a kindness with violence.
Audrey McCullom, the Zantops' next-door neighbor and a retired therapist, recalled that Half Zantop had tried to help a mentally ill young man in the past and said, "If a student, a faculty member, a community member turned to Half in distress, Half could underestimate the degree to which a troubled person was truly ill."
Ms. McCullom's husband, a doctor, and her daughter were the first people to see the bodies after they were discovered by a guest who arrived for dinner at the Zantop home on Saturday. 
The guest ran next door to the McCulloms, and Ms. McCullom's husband and daughter went to the scene, she said, where they found Mrs. Zantop's body in the study in a pool of blood and Mr. Zantop's nearby. They had apparently been dead for several hours.
Although he has seen much as a doctor, Ms. McCollum said, her husband said, " 'This was the most awful thing I had ever seen.' "
Hanover, a town of nearly 10,000, is considered one of Dartmouth's drawing points, a bucolic haven that looks safe and quiet compared with the settings of most other Ivy League colleges and universities. It last had a murder -- the slaying of two graduate students -- in 1991, and the one before that, the police say, was at least 50 years ago.
Today, Eric Winn, a freshman, said he did not feel scared, that Dartmouth still had one of the safest campuses in the country. 
But Laura Smalligan, another freshman, admitted to feeling a bit scared since she saw several detectives this afternoon investigating something -- it was not clear what -- in the basement of her dormitory. Asked if she would still walk alone at night, she said, "I'll probably be more scared doing it, but I still will."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Half Zantop, above, and Susanne Zantop, both Dartmouth College professors, were killed at their home in Etna, N.H. (Photographs by Associated Press); State Police investigators gathered evidence yesterday from the house where two Dartmouth professors were found slain on Saturday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Earthquake Survivors Cite Confusion in Rescue Effort 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: BHUJ, India, Jan. 29 

 BODY:
Two babies an 8-month-old boy and a 7-month-old girl -- were rescued today after three days in the rubble here, symbols of the heartbreak and the singular miracles of India's killer earthquake.
 The boy, Murtza Ali, was found in the lap of his dead mother. The girl, Sweta Kumar, was rescued from the rubble of her home in a town east of Bhuj. Hours later, she was returned to her joyous mother, Bhawna. 
 The rescues offered a rare cause for hope after Friday's quake, whose damage is now estimated at up to $5.5 billion. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, who visited Bhuj today, acknowledged that India was ill-prepared for such disasters.
Survivors say confusion and a lack of equipment is hampering rescue efforts. Rescuers lack cranes and bulldozers, and many units do not have generators for lights, making night work impossible. 
The hope of finding many more survivors "is dwindling hour by hour, but as long as there is hope, we won't give up," said Joachim Ahrens, who represents a Swiss rescue team in Bhuj.
In the newest estimates of damage, the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and the industry secretary, Gen. Amit Mitra, said losses might be as high as $5.5 billion, and added that production losses were running $110 million a day. Officials in Gujarat state put forward a much lower figure, $2.17 billion.
A grim Mr. Vajpayee, who toured Bhuj, Ahmedabad and other cities in Gujarat today, said he was forming a national disaster agency to ensure immediate response to emergencies.
"The country is not ready to face such disasters," Mr. Vajpayee told reporters in Ahmedabad, Gujarat's economic hub. He also announced federal grants totaling almost $110 million for the state.
In New Delhi today, the agriculture minister, Bhaskar Barua, appealed to private aid groups for field hospitals, clothing and cranes and other equipment, as well as volunteers to put up tents and prepare and distribute food.
As recently as Sunday, Mr. Barua said it was the policy of his government not to ask for foreign aid, but today he expressed thanks for the foreign help that had been offered. Such offers so far include $14.6 million from Britain, $8 million from Unicef, $6.1 million from Germany and $5 million from the United States. More than two dozen other nations have pledged to help, and six -- France, Israel, Poland, Russia, Switzerland and Turkey -- are sending substantial medical teams. 
Here at the scene, however, the routine of death must also be observed, over and over. 
At the Lohna Samshran crematorium today, every effort was made to follow Hindu tradition in sending the dead into the next life with respect.
Normally each body is placed on its own funeral pyre, but that has not been the case since Friday. More than 6,200 dead have been registered across western India, but officials in Bhuj believe that between 15,000 and 20,000 people may have died here alone.
As many as 16 bodies were being placed on a single pyre, and they were not being segregated by caste.
By today Mr. Thakkar and his workers had cremated 387 bodies, and more were being brought in by truck and stretcher. Despite the enormity of the task, most Hindu traditions were followed.
Tears running down their faces, relatives shared their grief along with the funeral pyres.
"We were very proud of our brother and his job," Damor Balawat Nuvajubhai said. The body of his brother, Damor Rajendrakumar Nuvajubhai, 24, was wrapped in a sheet and placed on a pyre; he died while working as a nurse at the civilian hospital in Bhuj, one of 36 nurses killed when the building collapsed.
Damor Balawat took a large can of clarified butter and poured some onto the logs. He and his three other brothers then sat on the stack of wood, quietly weeping for an hour until three other bodies were placed on it.
Crematorium workers, wearing baseball caps and scarves over their mouths, placed more logs on top of the bodies and helped relatives of the victims start the fire and stoke it into a roaring blaze.
The only sound came from the crackle of the fire and the engines of heavy trucks jamming the streets with relief supplies. 
Bhuj is in a semi-desert with few trees, so officials have called for donations of wood. Outside Lohna Shamshran, trucks unloaded tons of lumber donated from all over India for the 12 pyres. --------------------

World Bank Offers $300 Million
NEW DELHI, Jan. 29 (Agence France-Presse) -- The World Bank offered India $300 million today to help recover from the earthquake that struck Gujarat and killed at least 6,300 and possibly as many as 20,000.
The World Bank said in a statement that within six months it would also put together a longer-term assistance plan in consultation with the Gujarat state government.
The national finance minister, Yashwant Sinha, asked on Sunday for a $1.5-billion loan from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank to aid the recovery, a billion from the World Bank and half a billion from the development bank. 
The Asian Development Bank said today in a statement that "the A.D.B. is ready to extend all technical and financial assistance within its capability to help the state of Gujarat and Government of India restore the affected areas," initially by deploying disaster management experts to assess the damage. 
Mr. Sinha also said the two state-run insurance firms, the Life Insurance Corporation and the General Insurance Corporation, would be instructed to settle quake claims immediately. Gujarat is one of India's most prosperous and industrialized states.

About 50 miles to the west in Bhuj, at right, residents waited in line for food. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: As Law Firms Scramble for New Talent, The New Talent Reaps the Rewards 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
AS a 1998 graduate of Rutgers, with a degree in criminal justice and sociology and a willingness to share an apartment, David Dugan went to work for the American Arbitration Association. It was a "decent job," he said, paying about $24,000 a year.
 But that was before law school. Last summer, after his first year at Rutgers School of Law in Newark, he discovered his new market value. The law firms descended in search of this year's summer associates, who are practically assured of permanent offers later. And among Manhattan firms looking for starting associates with credentials like Mr. Dugan's, the going rate is $125,000. That doesn't include the guaranteed bonus of $25,000. 
 "I hadn't really thought about it," Mr. Dugan said. "It was just a nice surprise." 
At Rutgers, as at most law schools, a basic rule of supply and demand is at work: in a nation that would probably find it hard to believe and harder to appreciate, there is a shortage of legal talent.
It is no longer news that elite law firms, having matched the eye-popping increases in salaries started by a Silicon Valley firm a year ago, are elbowing one another for the opportunity to pay people just out of school more than federal judges earn. But what began as an arms race among major powers has nudged up demand for law school graduates everywhere. 
The demand has not faltered even in an academic year that began with ominous news about the dot-coms that set off the salary escalation by luring some young and well-credentialed lawyers away from conventional practices.
THE law business, like the real estate business, generally expands with the overall economy. 
"The market for corporate legal services depends on the number of business transactions," said Prof. John P. Heinz of the Northwestern University Law School, a former executive director of the American Bar Foundation, a research organization. 
But while the economy has grown by about two-thirds since 1980, law school enrollment has barely budged. Since a surge of new schools during the 1970's, bringing the total to 169 from 144, very few have entered the market. 
Moreover, Professor Heinz said, "New schools have a brand-name problem, and they end up supplying more at the bottom of the market."
Since 1980, the schools have kept the number of new places between 40,000 and 44,000 a year. Applications, meanwhile, have zigzagged between a low point of 60,000 (in 1985) and a high point of 99,000 (in 1991). 
"Among the 25 schools that think they're in the top 10, you have relatively modest growth, where you have had any growth," said J. William Elwin Jr., the director of professional development and training at Shearman & Sterling, a Manhattan-based law firm. 
The demand is by no means even. Professor Heinz said there was a persistent surplus of lawyers who handle slip-and-fall cases, divorces and criminal defense. In a profession that gauges status finely and obsessively, he said, "some law schools supply one market and some supply others." 
Nonetheless, he said, as firms that once hired everyone they needed from Harvard, Yale and Columbia claim an ever larger share of law graduates each year, students at the middle-to-top-tier schools are benefiting. That group includes Rutgers law school. This fall, employers went "deeper into the class" to fill their interview schedules, Dawne M. Smith, the placement director, said. She noted that many interviewers arrived with greeters, whose job was cordially pitching their firms.
Debra King, the placement director at Seton Hall University Law School, also in Newark, said, "Firms are turning to their so-called alternative schools, like us, not just the Ivies." 
This fall, Ms. King said, at least three national law firms that "generally don't come over the river" came for on-campus interviewing. The school also had recruiters from firms in San Francisco and Palo Alto, Calif.
At Brooklyn Law School, the number of jobs listed with the career services office in 2000 increased 41 percent from 1998, said Joan A. King, the director of placement. 
Ms. King said salaries at the smaller firms and government agencies that employ most Brooklyn graduates were also rising. 
"Finally the D.A.'s offices are paying decently," she said. "That's a good side effect."
Still, at $38,000 to $47,500, the pay for those new graduates is about what the average city transit worker receives. Ms. Smith said one recent graduate, now working in a prosecutor's office, had sent an e-mail message that said, as Ms. Smith recalled: "I'm working for $33,000 a year and I have $76,000 in student loans. I can't do it."
Public-interest employers, the nonprofit organizations that for years have relied on the socially committed and self-sacrificing, drew 1 percent of 1999 graduates, down from 5.9 percent in 1986.
"You do see people taking firm jobs who wouldn't have a couple of years ago," Ms. Smith said. "And this used to be known as the People's Electric Law School." 
More surprising to placement officials is the number of students forgoing judicial clerkships, despite their resume-enhancing value. Ms. Smith said that while 77 students in the class of 1998 took clerkships, in the class of 2000 she has counted a little over 40. 
"I have judges coming out of the woodwork," she said.
While this market should foster happiness among law students -- Ms. King at Brooklyn spoke of "an overall sense of well-being" -- it has also created expectations that are easily disappointed. 
"Some of them are very cocky," Ms. Smith said. "Then the student who comes out of law school and gets $60,000 feels it isn't acceptable when a colleague is making $125,000."
News of salaries and much more is never farther away than the Web, where message boards like Greedy Associates (www.infirmation.com) report salary and bonus schedules and exchange advice ("take all the money you've hoarded and run") and commentary ("much of what I do is chimp work"). 
Derek Craig, a second-year student and member of law review at Rutgers, said that salaries were definitely a factor in drawing classmates to large New York law firms, instead of to government or the nonprofit sector. "I need to pay off my loans," said Mr. Craig, 29, adding, "What's really scary is the debt." 
He explained that he had spent the three years before law school teaching English in Taiwan for "$1,000 U.S. a month, tops."
Mr. Dugan, who is 24, agreed that six-figure salaries helped attract people to Manhattan. 
"As much as this is an academic experience, I don't know one person who would say money isn't a factor," he said, though he is applying for clerkships and is not ruling out a job in government later. 
Having been selected for the law review and the moot court board, Mr. Dugan is among those who will have a choice. He received his first summer job offer in early September and ended up with five offers.
Kelso Anderson, 26 and another second-year student on the law review, said, almost apologetically, "I did have many offers" after interviewing with New York and New Jersey firms. 
MR. ANDERSON, 26, who came to the United States from Jamaica 10 years ago, said the market "was certainly not what I expected," even though his sister practices law in Manhattan. 
"I never knew I would be this fortunate," he explained. 
Like many students, though, he said he worried that the good times might expire soon, perhaps before he finishes his one-year clerkship with a New Jersey Supreme Court justice. (As he enters this risk-averse profession, Mr. Anderson is taking a bankruptcy course.) 
The market has heated up and then frozen before. When Ms. Smith graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1986, big firms could not raise salaries fast enough: Less than an hour after she reported for her first day at a top-paying New York firm, all the new associates were told that they were being given a $10,000 raise.
A few years later, many firms were shedding associates. Ms. Smith's firm had fallen apart.
So now, she said, even in the hiring wave last fall, employers were restrained. "Many of the firms learned a valuable lesson in the 80's: that they shouldn't hire more people than they can sustain," she said.
Law schools are apparently following the same general rule. Applications are climbing modestly after a big downturn in the mid-1990's, but they remain below the level of a decade ago. 
Professor Heinz at Northwestern said that in the meantime, some law schools have quietly chosen to shrink their classes rather than "dip down farther in the applicant pool." 
And the hierarchy of the legal profession, while loosening, is not crumbling. Many students do not have jobs lined up for the summer or fall, and most who go into private practice will join firms of fewer than 50 lawyers. For the firms, to be elite is to be large. 
In the most recent survey of starting salaries by the National Association for Law Placement, the median was $40,000 in firms of 2 to 10 lawyers and $97,000 in firms of more than 500. 
The biggest firms, meanwhile, are hewing to certain status lines in law school recruiting. 
"As desperate as we've been, we're just now talking about putting our toe into the second tier," said a manager at a Manhattan firm. 
Like most partners and recruiting managers, this one would speak only on condition of anonymity. As Ms. Smith said, "Who's going to want to go to a firm that can't find anybody?"

HEADLINE: Some Brands To Be Sold By Unilever 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 29 

 BODY:
Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods giant that bought Bestfoods in the United States last year, said today that it had agreed to sell some of its European sauces and packet-soup businesses to Campbell Soup for about $920 million to satisfy conditions imposed by regulators when they approved the Bestfoods deal.
 Today's sale means that some stalwart European brands, like Batchelor's dry soup mix and Oxo bouillon cubes in Britain and Leiseur Mayonnaise in France, will change hands, as Unilever, based in London and Rotterdam, purges its stable of overlaps with Bestfoods products like Knorr soups and Hellman's mayonnaise. The price was generally in line with analysts' expectations. 
 Unilever executives also said that the group was close to a long-expected sale of Bestfoods Baking, which could fetch as much as $1.4 billion. Unilever is talking to the Sara Lee Corporation about the baking unit, which includes Entenmann's, Freihofer's and other brands in the United States, but it has declined to give details of the negotiations.
In a television interview from Davos, Switzerland, where he is attending the World Economic Forum, Antony Burgmans, the Unilever co-chairman, said today that news of a deal would emerge "pretty soon," but he did not elaborate.
Unilever's divestitures have fueled speculation among analysts that it might be planning to bid for the Clairol cosmetics business in America, which is being sold by Bristol-Myers Squibb. But Nicolas Sochovsky, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said Unilever was far more likely to use the proceeds to pay off debt, which stood at 1.8 billion euros ($1.7 billion) last September, because the company "has got a lot to prove to the market" after the Bestfoods acquisition.
For Campbell, which has struggled to generate earnings growth on its own, the deal will bring significant expansion in Europe, including factories in Britain, the Netherlands, Ireland, France and Sweden that employ about 1,300 workers. The brands Campbell is acquiring have annual sales of about 435 million euros ($402 million), Unilever said. While they have grown only slowly in recent years, they command steady profit margins of around 18 percent.
The deal is still subject to approval by the European regulators whose conditions on the $24.3 billion Bestfoods acquisition led to the sale.
Patrick Cescau, Unilever's foods director, said Campbell had bought all the brands Unilever had to sell, and that by concluding the deal swiftly it had spared its employees some uncertainty. Mr. Sochovsky at Lehman Brothers said a "clean sale" to a single buyer "would be viewed by the market as reasonably positive." Unilever shares rose 2.5 pence, to 509 pence, in London.
Unilever announced a $5 billion program almost a year ago to trim its work force and focus on 400 top-selling brands. But while culling lines, it has also been buying aggressively in the United States, snapping up Slim-Fast Foods and Ben & Jerry's ice cream as well as Bestfoods.

HEADLINE: Cap Gemini Has Contract For Services to4 Hospitals 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The consulting firm Cap Gemini Ernst & Young plans to announce today that it has reached a seven-year $350 million contract to provide technology services to four New York City hospitals, people who helped negotiate the agreement said yesterday.
 The contract, which covers Beth Israel Medical Center, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital and New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, all in Manhattan, and Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, reflects Cap Gemini's strategy to expand its operations into what is known as outsourcing, especially in light of the uncertain economy. 
 Under the contract, Cap Gemini will provide computer support and data management services, including accounting, patient billing and communications, to the hospitals. The contract is Cap Gemini's largest in the health care sector.
Outsourcing, which accounts for about 20 percent of Cap Gemini's annual revenue, offers some protection to consulting firms in the event of an economic downturn, said Robert Pryor, head of the company's outsourcing business in the Americas.
"A slowing economy that you see now offers much more significant opportunities for us in the outsourcing space," Mr. Pryor said. That is because when times toughen, he said, companies look to reduce costs by delegating those activities that might be more cheaply performed elsewhere to an outside supplier.
"It forces them to make those general 'make or buy' decisions that they might otherwise put off," he said.
For the four New York hospitals, which belong to Continuum Health Partners Inc., a holding company and client of the consulting arm of Ernst & Young, now part of Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, the outsourcing agreement should lower costs, said Gail F. Donovan, who as chief operating officer at Beth Israel Medical Center was involved in negotiating the agreement.
"It's our largest outsourcing experience," Ms. Donovan said. The agreement should allow the hospitals to standardize their computer systems to make it easier to share information, she said. 
Using Cap Gemini will also eliminate the need for the hospitals to try to retain technology-savvy professionals, who are prone to leave for more profitable jobs outside the health care industry, she added.
"It was very difficult for us to maintain any consistency in our staff," she said.
As part of the agreement, the hospitals have sold their computer hardware to Cap Gemini for $5 million and laid off 275 employees who worked with that equipment, Ms. Donovan said. Cap Gemini will hire those employees, she said.

HEADLINE: Transition Time, and Washington Is Waist-Deep in Resumes 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
GEORGE W. BUSH won not only the presidency and the chance to set national policy, but also the spoils that come with victory -- the chance to appoint thousands of people to jobs in his administration, from confidential secretaries to cabinet secretaries. And the White House is far from the only place where the desks are now piled high with resumes. 
 From K Street to Capitol Hill, Washington is in a state of flux remarkable even for a capital that has come to expect a good deal of turnover in the months after a national election. Not only did the presidency itself change hands, but the protracted way in which the election was decided added more uncertainty and delay to the job-hunting process. 
 When the election logjam finally broke, it unleashed a torrent of activity. 
"I wouldn't be surprised if there are 100,000 resumes that the Bush team has probably already received," said John H. Trattner, the vice president of the Council for Excellence in Government, a nonprofit organization here that aims to improve government performance. "Some people are just ringing the doorbell and asking for a job. Others are angling with influence. Some have given money to a campaign, others were already in the Bush campaign. A lot of people think they have a leg up in getting a job."
Job hunting in Washington falls into three concentric rings, the first starting at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. From the cabinet down, there are 7,500 presidential appointees at nearly every level in the executive branch. These people come and go with the administration and are hired because of their agreement with the president's political objectives and solid partisan ties. 
Many of these jobs are considered plums, and all are listed, along with salaries and the names of the current occupants, in a 334-page government publication called the Plum Book -- which actually gets its name from the color of its binding. (It is available on the Web, at www.gpo.gov/plumbook/ 2000/.) A companion volume, distributed free to office seekers by the Council for Excellence in Government, is called the Prune Book. (A prune, the council explains, is "a plum seasoned with experience and wisdom.") Also available on the Web, at www.excelgov.org, it provides far more specific information about many administration jobs, including the necessary qualifications and the issues the job entails.
"To get one of these top jobs, you need to be able to put up with delay, confusion and a fair amount of uncertainty," said Paul Light, an expert on government employment at the Brookings Institution, the Washington policy study group.
The next ring is Capitol Hill, where even the garage attendants and elevator operators are political hires. Each member of Congress has a staff of 10 to 15, and powerful members have control over thousands of appointments to the professional staffs that do the legwork on the committees that oversee the budget, appropriations and all the issues that come before Congress.
The majority party typically gets two-thirds of all committee jobs. But with the Senate now divided 50-50 between Democrats and Republicans, the two parties have agreed on a power-sharing arrangement that will give each equal staffing on all committees. This means that on the Senate side, at least, things will be tighter for Republicans.
In the final ring, there is everyone else: career civil servants who may find themselves suddenly sent to a far-flung spot or who do not share the views of their incoming bosses; news media bureaus that typically use a change in the White House as a time to move employees around; and lobbying firms that are trying to beef up their staffs with people with fresh contacts and a knowledge of Washington's inner workings.
For six years, David R. Runkel was the chief spokesman for the House Banking Committee. Now he is looking for a job. With term limits removing his boss, Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, as chairman of that committee, the new committee head will name his own communications director. 
"I knew this would happen, and last summer I started making inquiries," said Mr. Runkel, himself a Republican. "Right now, I'm exploring options on the Hill. I like working for government because there are so many interesting policy issues, and I know dozens of other people who are also in the middle of change, too."
On the Democratic side, the retirement of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey meant that his entire staff had to look for jobs. Many have found them, including Daniel E. Katz, Mr. Lautenberg's former legislative director, who became a lobbyist for the nonprofit group Americans United for the Separation of Church and State.
Mr. Katz said he would have sought an administration job had Al Gore won the election. "Once Gore was defeated," he said, "it means there are something like 5,000 more Democrats on the street and a couple thousand more in agencies that don't want to work for Bush -- or expect to be transferred to the mailroom." 
While Mr. Katz is happy to have landed where he did, he said the last two months were bumpy. "Lots of people were committed Democrats who worked for Lautenberg until the end," he said. "Then they found their chance for an administration job was gone. There was chaos in town and no one knew what was happening on the Hill."
Retha Sherrod, Mr. Lautenberg's communications director, said that while her boss had announced his retirement plans months ago, a combination of the flow of daily work and the uncertainty about the election kept her from looking full time for a new job -- until now. "The job market in Washington right now is flooded with unemployed Democrats," said Ms. Sherrod, who had worked as a television producer in New York before joining Mr. Lautenberg's staff two years ago. 
A colleague, Tralonne Shorter, has become a lobbyist at Peyser Associates and will track the course of legislation, just as she did for Senator Lautenberg. "As a Democrat, I knew I could get work with Gore in office," she said. "But with Bush, I had to restrategize."
The troubles of Linda Chavez and, before her, Zoe Baird and Kimba M. Wood, whose nominations were derailed over allegations about people who had worked in their homes years earlier, may make many people wonder whether a political appointment is worth the highly public, highly partisan scrutiny that goes with the territory. The Brookings Institution's Web site (www.brookings.org) has a "frequently asked questions" section for job seekers that includes questions like: When I was in college, I smoked marijuana from time to time. Will this disqualify me? And, I've been using a nanny to care for my kids. Will I be asked to report that?
Despite such drawbacks, thousands are drawn to Washington's political power grid and, once there, often stay on in the private-sector jobs that feed off politics.
"People are moving constantly, and that's the nature of this town," said Mr. Light of Brookings. "This town is really sized to accommodate a certain number of people who leave Capitol Hill and go to trade associations or people in lobbying firms who go to the administration. There is a political class and, ultimately, they all seem to find work."

Better Drag Those Skeletons Out of the Closet
The phone rings, and a familiar Texas twang comes on the line with an offer to come to Washington and be part of the new administration. You're flattered. You're terrified. You accept the offer. What do you do now? 
What follow are excerpts from a "A Survivor's Guide for Presidential Nominees," a new manual by two Washington nonprofit organizations, the Council for Excellence in Government and the Brookings Institution's Presidential Appointee Initiative. The book is available online, at www.appointee.brookings.org.

The Opportunity
For a great many, a presidential appointment marks the capstone of their careers. It opens opportunities that they never had before -- positions with even greater responsibilities in government or in the business or academic world they came from. Thinking of public service as a steppingstone, however, is a serious mistake. If the job you really have your eye on is the one that awaits you after your stint in government, you run a serious risk of fumbling your work on the public's behalf.

The Money
Your government salary may stay flat or grow very slowly during your time in office. Top law firms, for example, are hiring law school graduates today at salaries approaching what a deputy cabinet secretary makes. There are no stock options or bonuses for political appointees. And senior-level political appointees cannot moonlight. . . . The prohibition includes speaking fees.

The Paperwork
You'll need to tackle a pile of paperwork at the outset of the appointments process. . . . These forms are, as the 1992 National Academy of Sciences report put it, "separate, complicated and incompatible." Some nominees face more than one committee, and must fill out separate forms for each. . . . 
You will also be investigated by the F.B.I. (and, in some cases, questioned by Senate committee investigators as well). Embarrassing details of your life could become public. . . . Even if you never broke the law, you could find yourself facing public criticism for engaging in activities many years ago that seemed entirely harmless.

The Wait
Many officials remember this vetting process as a trying time, even though their names were moving forward. . . . "You're in limbo," says Louis Caldera, a graduate of West Point and Harvard Law School who served in the California Assembly before becoming Secretary of the Army in 1998. "You can't go ask people for business. You can't develop new business in good conscience when in fact you're thinking about leaving. So your whole life is in limbo; your kids' life is in limbo; your wife's life is in limbo. After a while, you say to yourself: 'I'm setting a deadline, and if they cannot tell me by this date that I am either the nominee or not the nominee. . . . I'm going to have to tell them I can't take the job anymore.' "

HEADLINE: The Wave Of Layoffs: Is It Bound To Get Bigger? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
ECONOMIC growth has ground nearly to a halt, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said last week. The 2000 holiday shopping season was the weakest in a decade. Announcements of layoffs reached their highest level last month in at least seven years, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a job placement firm in Chicago.
 Amid all the grimness, the December unemployment rate sat at 4 percent, only a tenth of a percentage point above its lowest level in 30 years. 
 The contrast is enough to befuddle anyone trying to figure out the current condition of the nation's labor market. The United States seems to be dangerously close to its first recession in 10 years, one that could again lead to hundreds of thousands of pink slips for blue- and white-collar workers. In the meantime, however, executives are still complaining that they cannot find enough qualified employees.
In part, the apparent contradiction reflects nothing more than timing. The low unemployment rate gives a picture of where the economy has been, not where it is going, and the number can distort reality during turning points in the economic cycle. As those announced layoffs take effect, the unemployment rate will start rising -- perhaps as soon as Friday, when the government releases the next jobs report.
"The economy slips first, and then the jobless rate goes up later," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist for Wells Fargo in Minneapolis.
That is not the entire story, though. The early evidence suggests that during this slowdown companies are relying heavily on cutbacks other than permanent layoffs. The question for workers -- many of whom have suddenly grown concerned about their jobs in the last two months, according to regular consumer surveys by the University of Michigan -- is whether this trend can withstand a prolonged downturn.
For now, while the jobless rate holds steady, the workweek is shrinking more quickly than it did at the start of the 1990-91 recession. In December, production employees -- about four-fifths of the work force -- logged almost 30 fewer minutes per week on average than they had in June. In the months leading up to the last recession, by contrast, weekly hours fell by half that amount, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Similarly, the number of people who want full-time work but can find only part-time jobs has risen in recent months, and the number of temporary workers has dropped.
Economists point to these developments as evidence that companies, chastened by becoming bloated in the 1980's and then laying off thousands of employees in the early 90's, are looking for another solution this time. Perhaps they now view some job cuts as too costly to employee morale. Or maybe they have read the demographic charts and decided that the upcoming mass retirement of baby boomers will cause a worker shortage in the decades ahead.
"There's a general sense still out there that the weak period is going to be short-lived," said Ethan Harris, a senior economist at Lehman Brothers in New York. "If you fire people, you're going to have to hire them back six months later."
In such a situation, the surge in layoff announcements in December could be a blip. Job growth would continue to slow, and people outside the work force -- like mothers who stay at home with their children -- would stop joining at the rate they have in recent years. But the large majority of people looking for work would find it, keeping the unemployment rate fairly low, even through a downturn.
Judging from the strong recent gains in productivity -- the amount that a worker can produce in an hour -- companies have remained leaner through this expansion than they did in previous ones. Even when looking for places to cut, they may decide there are relatively few employees whom they can lay off.
But there is another side to the productivity increases, and economists say it could set the stage for another heavy round of downsizing.
If the downturn worsens and companies find that cutting overtime hours does not reduce costs as much as revenue growth is slowing, they will turn to job cuts, as they always have.
This time, though, they may do it before their sales actually start to fall. If productivity keeps rising, companies can keep growing even as they shrink their work forces, as long as the remaining employees continue to become more efficient and make up for the loss of their former colleagues.
The raft of recent layoff announcements -- from DaimlerChrysler, Xerox, Office Depot, Lucent Technologies and AOL Time Warner, among others -- could be just the beginning.
A mild version of the productivity-related cuts may already be happening. In the first quarter, Lehman Brothers predicts that the United States economy will grow 1 percent even as the number of hours worked falls 1 percent. Productivity gains will make up the difference.
The reduced hours are translating into less income. For the time being, however, the slowdown is coexisting with nearly full employment.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:
 EUROPE

BRITAIN: MANDELSON VOWS TO FIGHT
Peter Mandelson, who resigned from the government after admitting issuing a misleading statement about helping an Indian get a passport, has set off an argument with former cabinet colleagues by saying he was forced to quit under pressure on the basis of incomplete evidence. "I am not a liar," he said, vowing to clear his name. "This trivial error was turned into a huge misjudgment." Clare Short, secretary for international development, said: "He wasn't accurate, didn't speak the truth, let himself down and the government. Peter Mandelson is over." Warren Hoge (NYT)

MONTENEGRO: YUGOSLAV PRESENCE
The Yugoslav government opened an office in Podgorica, the Montenegrin capital, setting up a federal presence for the first time in years in the small independence-minded republic that along with Serbia makes up Yugoslavia. Montenegro, which has scheduled general elections for April and then a referendum on independence, described the move as "political aggression." Carlotta Gall (NYT)

KOSOVO: ETHNIC FLARE-UP
Violence flared in the divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo as Serbs and Albanians attacked each other with grenades in a mixed area of the town that is heavily patrolled by international peacekeepers. One Albanian was killed and two were wounded and an Albanian house was set on fire in one of the worst incidents in months in the troubled town. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

GERMANY: ARMY BASES CLOSED
Defense Minister Rudolf Scharping announced that 39 of 598 bases and 20 other smaller military installations would be closed by 2006 under plans to reduce Germany's military personnel from 310,000 to 282,000. The number of civilians working with the armed forces is to be reduced by about a third, to 85,000. Victor Homola (NYT)

FRANCE, ITALY: TRAIN TUNNEL
Italy and France agreed to start work on a multibillion-dollar high-speed rail link between Turin and Lyon, incorporating an environmentally contentious 32.5-mile tunnel through the scenic Alpine region of Valle di Susa. The two countries also settled a rift over the Mont Blanc tunnel by agreeing that it would reopen in September. It closed in March 1999 after a blaze in which 39 people died. (Reuters)

THE AMERICAS

CANADA: OFFICIAL VISIT BY BLAIR
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain will make his first official visit to Canada from Feb. 21 to 23 before flying to Washington to see President Bush. Mr. Blair is expected to discuss Canada's views on a proposed American missile defense system, which Ottawa fears could set off a nuclear arms race with Russia and China. James Brooke (NYT)

CUBA: TOP CZECH INVITED
A senior Czech official flew to Cuba at Fidel Castro's invitation in a bid to free two Czechs jailed for contacts with dissidents on behalf of the United States, the Foreign Ministry said. The visit of Petr Pithart, the Czech upper house chairman, is the first high-level contact between the two countries since the arrests of a former finance minister, Ivan Pilip, and a student leader, Jan Bubenik. (Reuters)

ASIA

MYANMAR: EUROPEANS VISIT
A European Union delegation began talks with military officials in a visit aimed at pressing the ruling junta to move toward democracy. Today it is expected to visit the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who is under de facto house arrest. (Reuters)

KOREAS: NEW ROUND OF REUNIONS
Red Cross officials from the two Koreas agreed to a third round of reunions and exchange of letters for families divided for 50 years. The reunions of about 100 familes from each side will be held over three days from Feb. 26 and the letter exchange will be on March 15, a South Korean Red Cross spokesman said. (Reuters)

AFGHANISTAN: U.N. ENVOY VISITS
The United Nations special envoy for Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, arrived in Kabul to discuss with the ruling Taliban their harboring of the fugitive Saudi Osama bin Laden, among other matters. The Taliban's refusal to expel him and shut down guerrilla training camps led the Security Council on Jan. 18 to impose new sanctions on Afghanistan. Christopher S. Wren (NYT)

AFRICA

TANZANIA: REGAINING CONTROL
Security forces said they had regained control of Pemba and Zanzibar islands after three days of street battles with opposition protesters that left at least 40 people dead. As international condemnation of the authorities grew, some diplomats said Western aid to Tanzania could be affected. The fighting began after the opposition called demonstrations to demand a rerun of last October's discredited elections on Zanzibar, which has a semiautonomous status within Tanzania. (Reuters)

MIDDLE EAST

KUWAIT: GOVERNMENT QUITS
Kuwait's head of state accepted the resignation of his government after the prime minister asked to step down, saying the cabinet's work was being disrupted by unidentified obstacles. Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, the emir, said in a decree: "The resignation of Saad al-Abdulla al-Sabah, the prime minister, and the ministers is accepted. Each of them carries out urgent matters in his post until the new government is formed." (Reuters)

IRAQ: ALLIED ATTACKS REPORTED
Iraq said seven people were hurt when Western planes attacked civilian targets in the south. There was no immediate comment from the United States or Britain, whose planes patrol no-flight zones set up after the 1991 Persian Gulf war. (Reuters)
